algorithms.sectionHeader: WALLACE'S BIRD OF PARADISE 0 SEMIOPTERA JVALLACE1)
algorithms.bodyText: By Walter Goodfellow, F.Z.S. |For many years I had had a great desire to see this bird alive, and intended when an opportunity came, to make an expedition to its island j lome and be the first to introduce it to Europe, but the war and other f hin S s intervened, and my hopes were not fulfilled until 1926. It is I ertainly not one of the most beautiful members of this gorgeous family, >ut there was always something about its eccentric appearance which ippealed to me irresistibly, and now that I have succeeded in capturing aid safely landing over here five examples, I confess that far from being disappointed, I am more in love with it than ever. In fact, I may as |^ ell say at once, that of all the Paradise Birds I know so far, this is my j avou rite. Therefore, if I seem to some who have now seen it to be too mthusiastic, they must excuse me. At the same time I am sure that nybody who has kept one as long as I have will understand my lfatuation for it. Their tameness, inquisitiveness, and merry ways, ould not fail to appeal to everyone. They seem entirely without fear, na this applies to them equally in their native jungle. They take an itelligent interest in all one does, and at the same time keep up a lerry chatter ; in fact, their repertoire of notes is extraordinary,

Walter Goodfellow-- Wallace's Bird of Paradise sometimes reminding one of our English Starling on the chimney stacks, bubbling, gurgling, and producing occasional explosive sound which shake their whole body. Other notes are reminiscent of th- King, and still others of the Rifle Bird. Wallace first discovered the bird in the fifties of last century on th island of Batchian, or, to write it more correctly, Batjan, one of th Moluccan islands \ perhaps the most beautiful of them all. Havni been almost all over the globe, I think I can say that these islands ar the most exquisite in all this world of ours. Later, it was found to occu also on the much larger neighbouring island of Halmaheira, or as w write it on our maps, Gilolo ; although Gilolo (or, rather, Djailolo) i only a small town on the western side, nearly opposite to the bette known island of Ternate. My birds came from Halmaheira and belon to the sub-species hahnaherce, which has longer shoulder plumes tha those from Batjan, and a more metallic violet shade on the top ( the head. Perhaps, apart from the wonderful emerald green, resembling ric silk, of the elongated breast shield, the first thing to strike one about tt bird, is its long flat head, which gives it a rather reptilian appearance In spite of this flatness, the bird is by no means stupid, quite tl contrary. The two long feathers which spring from each shoulder, ari; from two horny sheaths and are elongated spatula, whitisb towards tl ends. These when at rest hang straight down towards the feet, but win the bird is excited, and even at other times, stand out at right angl to the body with a wild-Indian-like effect. I had always understood the Malay name for the bird was Buroi poelet ", the Epaulet Bird, but on Batjan I failed to find anyone wl knew it. The island has only a very small population, including fr whites, and is everywhere covered with dense virgin jungle, right the top of the mountains ; the most conspicuous peak being Goenoi Zibella. Failing to find anyone there to give me information about tl bird, I continued on up to Ternate, where reside many merchants the Paradise plume trade. Still among them I found only one who kne the " Burong poelet " by name only. He said he must have had sor of the skins, although he could not recall what they were like, and believed they came from Patani, South-East Halmaheira. So to Pata
algorithms.author: Walter Goodfellow-- Wallace's Bird of Paradise
algorithms.bodyText: booked by the first monthly boat, and so elusive did the bird seem, it v r as like chasing a will-o'-the-wisp. Everywhere I inquired, all told the ame tale, " No Birds of Paradise were found on the island." At length o > rhen calling at Tobello on the north coast, where the Dutch have a nilitary post, I came across a man who had been a plume hunter in \ew Guinea. He knew the bird and correctly described it. From him learnt that the local name was u Vecca-vecca " (nearly all birds' tames are doubled out there), that he had seen a few occasionally in the ungle, knew nothing whatever of their habits, and thought it would be er > difficult to catch them alive. As this information did not seem very iromising, I thought it best to continue the journey to Patani, several lays further on. We arrived at Patani early one morning, and I was quickly on shore, aving left all my baggage and stores on board until I had made further nquiries. I went to the house of the " Kampong Kapala ", or head nan, who seemed very surprised when I told him what I was searching or. Oh yes," he said in Malay, " you mean the Whicca-wacca, there re many here. Naturally I took this to be the local pronunciation of ^ acca-\ ecca up north, so hurried back to the boat and landed all ay gear. About an hour later the boat having already left, and as I .as arranging myself in a native house, I received a visit from several f the head men of the village to know exactly what it ivas I wanted, explained that I had come from my country on the other side of the rorld to get " Wacca-waccas ". One replied : " There they are," and 'ii looking through the open door, I saw many large black crows among he coco-nut palms outside ! My ship was barely out of sight, but had k ^ een still in port I am sure I should have gone back with her instead of >eing obliged to waste a whole month with no better prospects than rows. Vainly I tried many times later to make them understand the >ird I wanted, minutely describing it. At length I made a fairly good ketch of one, when one old man present exclaimed " the Burong 'let" (but sometimes they pronounced it " Pleti "). Hunters from idore had been there years before and shot some. Still I.could not ear how far away I should have to go to find them ; therefore I ngaged several men to go in different directions to try and locate them, hese men were most uninterested in the whole affair. I doubt if some

of them went at all, but others did report the results of their searcl I learnt that at one place five birds had been seen, and in anothe three or four, but what I wanted them most to find were the feedin trees, or dancing places, otherwise I did not see how I could calc them. In this I had no success. One morning at daybreak I started o with the men, when after a four hours' scramble and climb over shar! coral trails, tumbling repeatedly, cutting hands and feet, we at lend came to rather high jungle where at last I did see three or four hire very high up in the trees, looking very small in the distance , but thei was no doubt about their really being Wallace's. They all had gree breasts, and seemed to be just moving along, and were soon out of sigh The following dav I visited another locality in the opposite directioi with still worse luck, for we did not see even one bird, but finding small palm leaf shelter there I got my Indian boy to stop the nigl there with one man to see if they could come across any in the vei early morning, the distance from Patani being too great to get the] early enough when the birds might be about. When he returned tl next day he informed me he had seen one or two birds, but could nt find any feeding trees. Things remained in this unsatisfactory state f( a long time. The people lost all interest, and evidently had no knowledi how to catch birds, and in vain I tried to enlist their help. These peop are not jungle folks, but purely coast dwellers, cultivating little beyor coco-nuts, and feeding chiefly on sago and fish. The whole of the interim of the island seems to be uninhabited by any tribes. During this time I was not idle myself, and as far as I could, withoi a guide or trails to follow up, I made many short journeys to the jungl clad hills at the back, till all mv shoe leather was worn through on tl sharp outcrop of coral which one encounters everywhere. My body at ached with rheumatism all over, through being constantly wet, ai sometimes sleeping out all night in the rain. By the beginning of the third week I think I had abandoned i hope of ever getting Wallace's Standard Wing ; then one night a nu came to me mysteriously, and said he knew a place where tin abounded. How man}? - did I want, and what would I pay for them ? et( etc. All this sounded too good to be true, especially as he was n willing to take me along with him. Then another week, and still i
algorithms.author: Walter Goodfelloio -- Wallace's Bird of Paradise
algorithms.bodyText: jrther news. The weather too was very wet and stormy. Real south- ast monsoon. I had just one w T eek left before the boat was due to call )r me, and the only Birds I had managed to capture so far were a pair f Insular Lories ( Eos insularis) and their young one, caught on the est; four Sun Birds, and a good number of Three-coloured Parrot 'inches ( Erythrura trichroa). This was the sum total of my collection, ut nice as these were, I had not come all that long journey just to get hem. I had other islands still to visit, and it was now the end of June, nd I naturally wanted to get home before the cold weather set in over ere. Then the man I have mentioned turned up again. He said the irds were still there, but he could not catch them, so came to enlist ly help. I arranged to go with him early the next morning, and he isisted that we must start before daylight, so that the villagers should ot see the way we went. Before daybreak we were off ; the party insisting of the man and his young son, myself and my Indian servant, fter the same hard climbing up and down, perhaps three hours of , we came to a stunted kind of jungle. A few enormous trees grew here
algorithms.listItem: ad there, but the majority were saplings of 30 or 40 feet high, * ;raight, and with few branches, and these quite short; very little ndergrowth, in some places none at all. Perhaps after being dis- f ppointed so many times, my surprise may be imagined when I saw in unparatively low trees at the very least thirty Wallace's Birds. I 'ally could hardly believe my eyes, and out of all this number possibly 3t more than two females, or birds in brown plumage. The others
algorithms.bodyText: pemed to be all fully adult males. My guide had certainly done his \0x25A0 3st to catch them. He must have put up scores of limed twigs, some sing long tapering bamboos 20 or more feet long, with lime on le extreme ends. This bird-lime is made out of the sap of the bread- |> uit-tree, and in the Aru Islands I have myself caught apodas with it. i the present case I think it had been badly prepared, as he said rds had repeatedly settled on it and were not held. The birds were all \0x25A0nstantly on the move, flying backwards and forwards from tree to ! ee with a great fluttering of their wings, and at times hanging in all rts of positions from the slender branches, some turning round and und like a cartwheel, and all the time making a variety of squawks id calls. Wallace, in his Malay Archipelago, speaks of their restless

Walter Goodfelloiv--Wallace s Bird of Paradise movements, and emphasizes a habit they had of clinging to tree trunks after the manner of Woodpeckers. I think from his description I had always imagined this was a common habit of theirs, therefore I was looking for it, but never once saw them do it. I can quite believe, however, that they may do so, for even in a cage they are constantly hanging upside-down, turning round and round the perch, and assuming all manner of queer attitudes. Wallace also says : " The females and young males far outnumbered the fully plumaged birds, which renders it probable that the extraordinary accessory plumes are not fully developed until the third or fourth year." This was the opposite to my experience, for I did not see one half-plumaged bird among any I cann across. It may be that the females were away nesting during June anc July, and that the one or two entirely brown birds which I took to be females were really young males. Although we were plainly visible, the birds were not in the leas i alarmed at our presence ; in fact, some came lower down to look ail us, and one or two came within 15 feet. Neither then nor on subsequen visits could I find any fruit-trees in the neighbourhood, and I neve did find out what they live on. Of course, it would have been eas^ enough to have shot one to see what it had in its stomach, but thi would have frightened them away, the very last thing I wanted to dc Wallace, again, says " They seem to feed principally on fruit, bu probably take insects occasionally My experience now is that the;; are very insectivorous, and certainly prefer green-coloured insects, wit a pronounced partiality for the large soft-bodied grasshoppers, near]; 5 or 6 inches long, which live on the branches of the coco-nut palim i It was a lesson in anatomy to watch the expert way they dissecte< I these insects, and also the large tropical cockroaches. These preference were, of course, noted in the early days of their captivity. The naturally change later. Looking at the birds from below, in the jungle, they appeared to b so very light in colour, almost white. The under sides of the wings ai whitish, but I don't think that accounted for it all. After we had caugh the first bird, the man remarked : " There must be two kinds, for th others are white." I saw some of the birds with their green breasl shields elevated, not horizontally, but perpendicularly, so that the hea j

Walter Goodfellow -- Wallace's Bird of Paradise G3 nly is seen looking through at the deep V-shaped base of green feathers, t this time the long shoulder plumes stand out at right angles below he shield. These whitish plumes are constantly raised and depressed, 'he short scalelike feathers on the top of the head, which are silvery nrple, also seem to undulate with a curious effect. Of course, this I nly noticed in captivity, as it requires a certain position of the head to how it off, otherwise this colour effect is not even suspected. As I have before said, I was always looking for their dancing places i the jungle, but I now feel certain that these low trees formed a dancing lace, and what I saw there, the display, otherwise why did they frequent ,!; more than any other spot, for it certainly was not their feeding round ? I spent the remainder of the first day at this place and noticed hat at midday all the birds disappeared. A few, I believe, remained n the dense top of one of the great trees near by, and came out again <or a short time later in the afternoon. It did not take me long to note hat certain trees were more frequented than others, so the next day ve started to put up the nets. The trees were far too slender to allow I anyone but a very light person climbing them, so I sent my Indian "oy up. As he was arranging the first net one bird came within > yards of him to watch the proceedings and as soon as the boy came lown it went and shook the net with its bill. I was standing at the base >f the tree and at once gave it a shake, when the bird flew right into the 'let, so I got my first Wallace, and this is the bird now in the Zoo. t was so inextricably entangled, the whole net had to be taken down v ith the bird in it. As the boy was coming down with it its screams nought all the other birds around, and I am sure if I had then had all he other nets up my scoop would have been a large one. This habit of oming to a companion in distress is not, of course, peculiar o Paradise Birds, but I have many times seen plume hunters in the Vu Islands and in New Guinea take advantage of this and deliberately round a bird and keep it tied up out of sight under a dancing tree \0x25A0 or its cries to attract the other birds, so that they could more easily hoot them. After catching the first bird there was great excitement in the yillage. Men, women, and children crowded around my house en masse, oossibly thinking it would be on public view. Needless to say, they were

Walter Good fellow--Wallace s Bird of Paradise sadly disappointed. Advice was freely given as to what I should, and should not, feed it on, and this from people who had not only nevei seen the bird before, but did not even know such a bird inhabited theii I island. Many were now anxious to try their hands at bird catching, tempted by the reward I had given to the man who showed me the place, and all sorts of ruses had to be adopted to avoid giving the locality away. Others were curious to know how I, a foreigner, knew these birds lived there. As one man said : "We don't know the birds in your country." This last week of my stay was unfortunately very wet, and during rain or dull weather no birds came out at all. This further convinces me that I had found a real dancing place ; but with one ray of sunshine, i birds suddenly appeared from somewhere, and at such times during the remainder of the week, we managed to secure four more birds, three! males and one female. I was at first very doubtful if such restless birds would take kindly to cage life, especially in comparatively small travelling cages. All fears, however, were soon set at rest by the birds feeding at once, and showing no signs of fear whatever. They greedily \0x25A0 snatched green grasshoppers from my fingers the first day. When the boat came to fetch me away the weather was so bad that it was quite impossible for the ship's launch to get through the raging surf, although several attempts were made to do so. A native in his catamaran managed to reach the ship, and by him the captain sent me! a note to say that if I could manage to get over the mountains to the j other side of the peninsular, he would pick me up there. In spite of the pouring rain, I had instantly to hunt up men to carry all my kit over ; no light task, and after endless trouble I got some forty carriers, j the bulk of them being anything but volunteers. Cases had to he hurriedly broken open and the contents distributed almost anyhow among them, for so steep are the mountains that not even moderately bulky packages can be carried over. The journey took about four hours! in almost continuous rain, and water poured down the steep trail like a waterfall. Two of my birds had been caged less than twenty-four hours, and yet they came through it all in perfect condition. That is j the great charm about Wallace's Birds, their tameness and good sense makes them ideal birds to move about. When crossing the range

Duchess of Bedford -- Bed-Breasted Geese Breeding in Captivity 65 several times heard others calling in the jungle, and at these places noticed an abundance of wild nutmeg trees growing, which inclines ! ae to think that they may feed on this fruit. In New Guinea I have ound the Eaggianas and Kifle Birds very fond of it. They swallow he nut whole with the lacelike mace encircling it. After the latter is digested the nut is ejected. Without counting any Bower Birds, this makes twenty-two species >f Paradise Birds that have been in captivity over here ; while no other ountry has yet had even half that number. I have brought twenty pecies, and seventeen of them for the first time. I have counted in this lumber only two species of Manucodes, although I am sure we have had more.

By the Duchess of Bedford Nine of these birds were obtained, some from Mr. Carl Hagenbeck i nd some from Mr. Falzfield, between 1911 and 1913. They showed no igns of nesting until July of 1926. One of the birds was then missed, md on search being made was found sitting on six eggs. The eggs were hfted and put under a hen. Four goslings were hatched, one of which died after three days. Another nest of six eggs was found, all of which pad been destroyed. This probably accounted for a single egg which E as found a week later and proved fertile. The eggs were removed \0x25A0om the hen and put in an incubator to hatch out to avoid the danger of le hen killing the young birds by trampling upon them. The period >f incubation was twenty-five days. The young birds were put in a foster- nother on a grass lawn. They were a dull grey brown all over when in lown x except the face, which was dark brown. They did well, feeding pn grass only. In six weeks' time they showed a good deal of colour i >n their feathers, and by the end of September were in full plumage j is regards colour and markings. At this day, 17th January, all survive.
algorithms.figure: Woburn Abbey. [The Red-breasted Goose, Branta ruficollis (Pallas), is an inhabitant 1 )f Siberia, breeding on the banks of the Yenesei, where nests were found
algorithms.bodyText: 66 John D. Brunton--Notes from Inveresk Lodge Aviaries by Mr. H. L. Popham at the foot of cliffs, the clutches consisting of from seven to nine creamy white eggs. It migrates south in winter to the southern shores of the Caspian and even as far as the northern portions of Africa. It occasionally wanders to the British Isles, to Sweden, Denmark, Northern Germany, Holland, and France. That it was known to the ancient Egyptians is proved by the picture known as " The Geese of Medum ", for a photograph of which I am indebted to my friend, Mr. F. L. Berney, who when sending it wrote as follows : " The photo is of what is said to be the oldest picture in the world. The age is early fourth dynasty, say, 3,000 years b.c. Found in a chamber tomb at Medum on the Nile, where it formed part of the wall decoration. The birds depicted are, first and last, Anser cinereus, first pair Anser albifrons, second pair Branta ruficollis. It is pleasant to think that in those far-off times there must have been ornithologists and painters of birds, Thorburns and Keulemans. Wealthy Egyptians of those days had the walls of their tombs decorated with scenes such as had interested them during life, their work, their hobbies, pastimes, and so on ; and the owner of the tomb was evidently one who took pleasure in watching the rare and interesting birds he kept in captivity. When one realizes that the painting is nearly 5,000 years old it has to be acknowledged that it is a wonderful piece of work." The Bed-breasted Goose is very rare in living collections at the present day, and a female received by the Zoological Society in 1858 appears to have been the only example that that institution has possessed. The breeding of the species at Woburn is an event of very great interest.-- Ed.]

Still some interesting results were obtained; and the following notes may be of some interest to members of the Avicultural Society. First may be mentioned White Peafowl. These do quite well here : and each season since their arrival has seen some young hatched, the

algorithms.bodyText: John D. Brunton--Notes from Inveresk Lodge Aviaries 67 otal this year being seven. Some of these have been disposed of. A ufficient breeding stock has been retained, but an infusion of new blood vould be an advantage. These birds roost out summer and winter on arge trees in the park. It is an interesting fact that, about a year ago he birds abandoned their favourite perch, and took to an adjoining ree. About a fortnight later the original tree, which had shown signs )f decay about the roots, broke off short and fell to the ground. It ooks as though the birds had some feeling that all was not well with it. Red Junglefowl, of which I received a trio from Rangoon a few years igo, do very well here, and a considerable number of young has been liatched. They are " as hard as nails ", and give no trouble. The hens batch their own eggs and are excellent mothers. This year they got little encouragement and only eight were reared, though a large number of eggs was laid. Pheasants have been rather disappointing, only five Golden, ten Silver, and six Amherst having been reared. Reeves were a blank, one adverse factor having been an inveterate egg-eating hen ! By accident two Amherst-Golden hybrids have also been obtained. I am still hoping to get, at some future time, eggs from a nice pair of Monaul Pheasants, though these, I understand, are likely to be few and far between. The only other species represented here at present is the Crestless Fireback, of which two odd hens are in residence. Ducks, which comprise Japanese Teal, Pintail, White-faced Whistling Tree Ducks, an odd Widgeon, Mandarin, Carolina, and Yellow Bills, have not done much, there being only four young each from the two last named. The Yellow Bills have had a few young in previous seasons. A very interesting acquisition to the collection arrived from I Wellington, New Zealand, recently, in the shape of a pair of " Pukekos ' or " Swamp Hens ". These are Blue Rails native to that country and with their glossy black-green backs and indigo blue breasts they are very attractive looking birds. It should be possible, given more natural surroundings, to breed these birds, but as they are confined meantime in an ordinary Pheasant run there is little prospect of doing so. I am rather loth to turn them into the Waders' aviary, where they would find water and a considerable amount of rough cover, as I fear they would

68 John D. Brunton--Notes from Inver ash Lodge Aviaries make short work of the contents of any small Finch nests that might be built in the bushes. These birds appear quite healthy, but do not relish frosty weather much. As might be expected, there are no results to report from Waders though some excitement was occasioned in the spring when a Knot was seen squatting in a hollow beneath a grass tuft. It may have beer broody, but no further developments took place. Each year some ot these birds assume the full breeding plumage. The small Finch fry flying in the Waders' aviary never seem to have much luck with their numerous nests. Two or three broods of Zebra Finches were, however, hatched in boxes, and two or three young Waxbills also appeared. Most, if not all, of these seem to have died out While the above results may seem meagre, some very interesting hybrids have been hatched in addition to the Pheasants already mentioned. From a Vulturine Guinea Fowl cock and a Common Guinea Fowl hen fifteen eggs were obtained and hatched by various foster- mothers. The hen, it may be mentioned, is itself a curiosity, it being a pale lavender-coloured " freak " bred here from ordinary coloured stock The young " favour " the male in their first plumage. The Vulturine in common with his progeny, seemed hardly hardy enough for this climate, and he unfortunately succumbed after a frosty night. Another interesting cross was obtained from cock Red Junglefow' and a common hen Pheasant, which for want of other accommodatior was turned down with them. There was a considerable overplus oi young cocks in the pen at the time, which fact no doubt favoured tin fertilization of the Pheasant's eggs. A last year's bird of this crosf (unfortunately a hen) is now a very robust bird. It is even larger thar its mother, which it generally resembles, though the brown body coloiu is considerablv richer or redder. The head and neck are black. Thert J are two young this year from this mating, one of which I am in hopee may turn out to be a cock. Has anyone heard of this cross before ? A most interesting hybrid, which I believe is undoubtedly the first of its kind, was obtained in the Waders' aviary. Amongst the miscellaneous Finch oddments was a large Yellow and Black Grosbeak, said to be from South America. It was described as a " Giant Yellow- bellied Grosbeak ". There was also an odd green Cardinal hen which
algorithms.reference: G. H. Gurney--The Black Bail
algorithms.bodyText: ad lost its mate. This bird was seen to be carrying food, but for a ime it was only observed to be assisting a hen Blackbird, attending to :s Grey-winged Ousel hybrid progeny. One day, however, the Cardinal ras seen, after visiting the Blackbird's nest, to pop into an adjoining ompartment. From its actions it appeared to be feeding there also, nd when the Grosbeak was seen to lend a helping hand from time to ime it was surmised that something out of the common was happening. It may be explained that the nests were situated right on top of the fall in the shelter, much too high up for any inspection.) In due course "ne young hybrid Blackbird flew from the first nest, and some days after young bird from the second nest was found on the floor in the shelter, t had apparently made rather a premature departure from its home, as t was little more than half-fledged and quite unable to fly. It was well ooked after by its parents, however, the cock bird particularly, which :ept continually packing it with food. It soon acquired sufficient *strength to clamber about the bushes and finally to fly strongly about he aviary, where it quickly developed into a strong, bold bird. It considerably resembled a Cardinal in dull plumage, but had a larger leak, intermediate in size between those of its parents. It eventually lecame pretty much the " boss " in the aviary, from which it appears ikely that it was a cock. It is very much to be regretted that one has low to speak of this interesting bird in the past tense. It was picked lip dead early in January. It may have fallen foul of its male parent, which bird was showing signs of coming into breeding condition, and had been standing up to its precocious offspring more boldly ! Most unfortunately the body of the young bird was too much damaged by mice to make the skin worth preserving.

By G. H. Gurney, F.E.S. Amongst the very interesting consignment of African birds recently imported by Messrs. Gamage, Ltd., were several examples of the little Rail (Limnocorax niger). In their printed list, which was sent to many members of the Avicultural Society, these birds were classed as new to Aviculture. But I brought one back alive from East Africa in 1908, and Monsieur Delacour had two in his aviaries at Cleres six years ago ;

Viscountess Grey of Falloclon -- The Booh this pair he gave to me and I still have one of them in the best of health the other escaped soon after it came here, and was never seen again. The bird I have at present is a hen, and has laid single egg on two occasions, making a nest of broken pieces of rush, clos to the pool of water in its aviary ; needless to say that they dii not hatch, though the old bird sat assiduously. But now that severa have come over, there should be no difficulty in breeding this charmin; little species. With me it is quite hardy, which one would expect, a certainly in some parts of Africa it lives at a considerable elevation where the nights are very cold. I have seen it at various places in Eas Africa; on Lake Naivasha it was abundant, and much less secretive ii its habits than the Rails generally are, differing much in this respec from its big cousin, the Green-headed Porphyrio, which was equally common on Naivasha, but seldom observed owing to its skulking habits The Black Rails ran freely about on the leaves of the blue water-lilie in company with Jacanas. I sometimes caught them in traps baitec with cheese, set for small mammals, and once I dislodged one from ; large Weaver Bird's nest, built in tall reeds hanging over the watei In the streams and rivers they did not appear to be so common, althoug] Crakes of other species were obtained ; probably the Black Rail prefer a wider expanse of water. I find mine are great vegetable feeders, and probably require considerable amount of green food.

A high chalk ridge of downland, once primeval turf, but now muc of its surface cultivated, transected by farm tracks set between th wide fields; the margins thick with sandfoin, rest harrow, brooi rape, and other furrow weeds. The centaury and yellow agrimon grow with the talk grasses ; here and there high bushes of sloe tak

algorithms.bodyText: e line of a hedge. Then a large wood of beech trees, laid across ie ridge, like a great mantle thrown over one shoulder of the landscape, id a chalk-pit set at its foot; which, facing west, at sundown becomes led with rose colour. This is the Rooky wood, which gives shelter > a large community ; and it was from this wood Rookster came to us. One of my children who, when very young, had the pretty idea lat it was customary on one's own birthday to give presents to others, rought him to me as a gift. With the candour of childhood that *nders it unable to keep a secret, he had spoken daily of this surprise >r some time before the right date fell. " It isn't out of a shop, you now," he would say, a silken head nodding wisely : It is nothing lat you can buy." Then, with a sudden largesse of confidence, with oth hands tightly squeezed the better to keep back a part, at least, f the previous news : It is something that God is making nicer nd nicer for you, every day ! " This meant that Reuben, the garden oy, had said that the rook was as yet too young to be taken ; and so nother week would have to be passed in this struggle for silence. Then one morning the day arrived. I saw them coming from ar off across the open valley, threading their way by the narrow plank widges set over the runlets and glittering streams that feed the water tieadows, brilliant with marsh marigold. There was the tall figure of he nursery maid, the small figure in a blue overall, Reuben, stout in orduroy, with a ladder, and--when they were nearer--the young Rook. He was easy enough to rear. He would take large pieces of milk- op, thin shreds of meat, soaked biscuit, anything ; and soon he was itting comfortably enough on the edge of his wastepaper basket, hat was weighted against overturning by containing a large flint. He was crafty from the first. He would be intrigued by the clefts )etween the closed fingers of my hand, and he would prise them apart vith an investigating bill, and an air of great secrecy. Anything slightly lidden or an outline suggesting concealment would hold his attention it once. As he grew older this led to trouble, for he was more destructive han a Jackdaw, and, if not cleverer, more alert than a Raven. "To loard," this was his motto ; and he remained as thin as a bone, because mything that he liked eating, he immediately hid. He would take the 'Smallest portion, and then in a series of long elastic leaps or a sidling

walk, he would be off with the remainder. So his whole life was o long-drawn-out starvation, enhanced by delicious concealments, a crafty storings in garden cupboards. If no further food had be forthcoming, would he, I wonder, have remembered where he had hidd those bones ? The pleasantest part of his character was his sense companionship. This led him not only to occupy himself ceaseless with our feet, shoe leather presenting pleasant beak-work, but a] to accompany us on a walk. He was never shut into a cage. His ca was what all cages should be, a place of rest and security wherein could sleep, or find food, or drink if he wanted. So he would sudden appear in the air beside us, as we started on a walk ; he would J about eight feet above the ground, alighting ahead of us. There would sit till we reached him, then he would take another flight, ai so on, about twenty or thirty feet away. He always flew on our le But after a certain distance the territory instinct arrested him-- did not care to go far from the house. This is curious when one conside how far afield are the flights of the wild Rooks. He was mischievous, and more inquisitive than Fatima. He nev outgrew the interest that carpets aroused. What was underneatl This is what intrigued him. The edge of a rug which could be easi lifted was a matter for peering investigation. He took great trout to undo one's shoelaces, he would even unlace a shoe. Thus he passi his life in ceaseless investigation, and when he died it was from eatii what even his powerful gizzard found indigestible. He had stolen pin-cushion from one of the bedrooms, and, taking it to pieces, had mai too light of the pins. I would never have another Rook ; not from sentiment, except so far as sentiment means right feeling, but because Rooks are mo beautiful in their setting of wild life, in their own environment. Her on Salisbury Plain, they are seen to great advantage ; large numbe out on the open Down, gleaming in the winter sun ; or some few, nei at hand and looking unexpectedly large and noble, alighting on tl lichen-grown railings that surround a lonely dew pond, the surma sunlight waking bronze or purple lights in their sombre plumes. ( again in November, printing the sunset sky with their dark forms, j they cross the valley, passing overhead in steady battalions ; one (

algorithms.listItem: o leaders, then the full company, and a straggling few bringing * the rear. On summer nights, about ten o'clock, "in the warm twilight, ey make their sonorous tumult in the trees ; a sound that has some,
algorithms.bodyText: ing in it of the volume of the sea. In March the Rooks make their joy-flights. It is as much a sign of ring as the scent of moss in the copses, or the sight of snowdrops earing through last year's leaves ; and it accords well with the song the Missel-thrush that has so much weather in it ; for the Rooks g themselves be blown about the sky. Every year one should save the young of the Missel-thrushes from e Jackdaws, in recognition of their song in February and March, v. H. Hudson is right when he tells us that our attitude towards eatures should be expressed in the injunction : " Pet none, persecute me." Yet how far easier it is not to persecute than not to pet ! very spring, as it comes round, I am tempted afresh to bring birds p by hand. I get such pleasure from this. I love their dependence
algorithms.equation: i me ; I love, through this, to learn their ways. I had a hand-reared
algorithms.bodyText: T ren this spring, a rare achievement. It would play about the rose ushes gathering aphis, and return to one's hand as to a chosen abode, he delicacy of its ways cannot be described, nor the beauty of its ce. Shakespeare says somewhere, as a term of endearment : " Here lines the youngest of nine Wrens " ! He knew what it looked like. If I ore a silken dress it bathed on its surface ; it appeared to be enchanted 'y the soft touch of the material. It would go into a perfect folly of lovement, making all the gestures of throwing water-drops over its ack, just as a bird does when it bathes among wet leaves. I should ever have known wild birds have this custom had I not once brought p a Blue Tit by hand. This Tit would take its bath in the watercress n the breakfast table. One day I was sitting in the aviary. That pest f quiet summer hours arrived, a face fly ; the fly that will occupy self pertinaciously with one's face, and goes from eye to eye, as if ndecided into which to plunge. The Wren was playing around me, so stooped and took it in my hand ; then I held my Wren up to my face, ! nd caught the fly with it. It was most neatly done ; and--as one is ! sually the helpless victim of such a fly--extraordinarily satisfactory. I brought up a Wood-pigeon last year ; this year my care is a young

Birds in North-Western Australia Rock Peplar. It is of the species called the Black-tailed Parrakeet two others with it were hatched in the aviary here. I took it from th nest when it was still in down, which was like eiderdown in quality with just a hint of lovely fruit-coloured feathers showing from th quills. I feed it from my lips, with bitten-up brown bread and rasp berries; with banana, and gooseberry pulp; sometimes biscui moistened by a bite of a peach, varying this with lettuce. It connect the sight of my face now with nourishment, though it is still uncertaii wdiat exactly is the point of happy contact, for it sometimes makes ; hopeful dive into my ear. It holds its head high, swaying on a rope neck, making the while a rasping noise with its brilliant persimmon tinted beak held open. It shall fly free in the garden when it is fully grown. None of ou birds have their wings cut. Those small African Finches, called Cordoi Bleus, fly free among the trees, returning to eat and bathe in thei cage on the window sill. Their blue feathers look exquisite agains the green of an ilex tree.

A very interesting account of an interview with a bird and anima dealer, Mr. Foglia, of Adelaide, appeared in the Adelaide Registe of 20th November last. Mr. Foglia had just returned from a collecting trip to the Kimberle} district, in the far north of Western Australia, -where bird life appear, to be exceedingly abundant, but where occasional seasons of drough result in great mortality :-- " As far as bird life is concerned in those parts, he said, an abundanct of feed and water had resulted in remarkable increases in the bircj population, including the larger types, such as Ibis, Native Companions Turkeys, Geese, and Ducks ; and the area could only be described as ' Nature's sanctuary '. Untouched by the ravages of the white man foi the greater part of the year, the Kimberleys especially had become theii natural feeding ground. Mr. Foglia said he had been in other parts oi Australia, but he had never had any idea of the extent of bird life existent there. It was amazing, and he could not understand, after a $

sit to those parts, why people agitated for the protection of Australian itural animal and bird life. A sojourn in the far north of Australia >nvinced one that there was little need for a policy of protection along lose lines. Of course, those people engaged in the pursuit of birds ere protectionists in themselves. To take 100,000 birds away was a ere drop in the ocean ; but there was now the danger of an epidemic \0x25A0iping the birds out over the coming wet season and during the icceeding months. The birds multiplied to such an extent during a accession of good seasons that when subsequently feed became short, iture in her own way counter-acted this influence through disease, aving the fittest to act as the rejuvenators of the species. There was ms always sufficient feed to satisfy the wants of the bird community, isease was manifesting itself at the moment, for all the birds caught iere thin and miserable looking ; but, when fed well during three weeks captivity had recovered. He felt sure that a trip next year would be omparatively futile. His investigations showed him that these diseases about every six or seven years."

By the Marquess of Tavistock and J. Delacour ( Continued from p. 51) II. The PLATYCERCINiE Besides certain anatomical distinctions the Platycercinse are ^cognizable by their short beaks which may be light or dark grey, at never red, their longish legs and long broad tails. The genus is eculiar to Australia and Tasmania. The Rosella Parrakeet (Platycercus eximius), from South-East tid South-West Australia is the best known member of its genus, and ne of the most beautiful. Its cheeks are white, its head, neck, and reast and the feathers under the tail are red ; its belly is yellow, and ie mantle greenish yellow, every feather having a black centre ; ings blue and black ; rump and back green ; tail blue and green ; , eak whitish ; feet grey ; eyes brown. It is the same size as the Ring- ecked Parrakeet. The sexes are very much alike, but the male is a rifle bigger and brighter coloured, with a thicker head and larger beak ;

Aviculture the most reliable distinction lies in the colouring of the little feather at the back of the eye ; they are brownish green in the normal adul female, while in the adult male they are invariably red. Most female have their flights spotted with white, and there is a green bar from th back of the neck to the centre of the head ; these two latter feature are rarely found among adult males, though immature specimens ma; display them. The young on leaving the nest resemble their parents, but the re< covers a smaller area, and all the colours are paler and the black mark less distinct. The full colouring appears gradually, and is complete after the first moult. If kept in a large aviary and well cared for Rosella! may breed when a year old, but more often do not nest until th following season. This applies also to the whole family of Platycen and Barnardii. Rosellas, like all the family, are quarrelsome when paire and in good condition, single and weakly birds are less spiteful. The specially dislike their own and closely allied kinds, but are dangerou with all weaker Parrakeets; they will not usually molest small Passerin birds as long as these keep out of the way, unless the aviary is over crowded. Rosellas should be fed on a mixture of two parts of Canar to one of hemp, one of millet, one of sunflower seed, and one of oat: together with monkey nuts ; they require green food and fruit preferring apples, cherries, and gooseberries. They do not care fc grapes or oranges, which are liked by the Palseornis. Groundsel, chick weed, sprouting oats, flowering grass, and lettuce are all acceptable and they love a fresh branch of some non-poisonous tree, of which the will eat the buds and nibble the bark. Rosellas are fond of bathing and should never be without watei They are perfectly hardy once they have moulted, and can be wintere out of doors if they have protection from rain and wind. Mos Platycerci are stupid about using their shelter and often will 11 c enter it, and prefer to freeze outside: they must therefore b accustomed to their shelter by being shut into it for some days at tli start by being fed there. It is also wise to shut them up every nighl Young birds of the year need more protection than adults. Platycerci do well in a movable aviary such as I have described i my general notes on Parrots. Failing this, they should if possible b

aced in a fixed aviary, with a cement floor. They are long-lived if ven room to use their wings even in a small aviary, but it is cruel to mt them up in a cage, and under these conditions few survive longer lan two or three years. A large aviary is needed if they are to breed itisfactorily, for if confined in a small space they often rear only sickly r crippled young ones. Hollow logs or boxes make good nests for lem, but there should be at least two for each pair, as the hen often ,ys a second time before the first family is fledged, the male parent iking entire charge of the latter. If the hen bird has to wait until the rst brood have flown she may pluck them in the nest, or she may herself :art moulting, in which case all hope of a second brood is lost. There is o fear that the father will neglect his youngsters. The young must be sparated from the old birds as soon as the male begins to grow npatient with them and drives them off. The usual clutch is from four Jo six eggs. Rosellas cross freely with allied species, and the hybrids are generally srtile. The Yellow-Mantled Parrakeet (P. splendidus), described by Jould as a distinct species, is really only a local variety of Rosella, and s even prettier and more brilliantly coloured. The edges of the feathers I its mantle are golden yellow, with little or no green tinge. It is rarely mported, and I have only seen four cocks and one hen alive. A cock Platycercus whose hen is shut up can be safely given his reedom and will not go farther than half a mile from her aviary, le may bite off some fruit buds in spring and nibble apples m the iutumn, but he will not do much mischief, and it is easy to shut him up or a few weeks when necessary. The Platycerci will breed at liberty, but pairs are sometimes inclined o wander and nothing smaller than a cock Rosella is safe from the I ittacks of the Tawny Owl, who is the worst enemy of exotic birds which \0x25A0lave been set at liberty, and is the cause of many mishaps. If it is |lesired to set a pair at liberty it is wise to wait until they have bred mce in an aviary. The cock should then be let out on a calm evening, somewhere where he can see and hear the hen and where he will not be ifraid to come down and visit her ; his food should be placed on the \0x25A0 3op of the aviary. Some days later the hen can be released, also in the

Aviculture evening, taking particular care that she sees her mate as soon as she i; let out. Nesting places must be put up and Starlings, which tak< possession of these, must be shot, for, strange to say, these birds cai overcome Parrakeets, even as large as Pennants. All Platycerci have a great fondness for exploring chimneys and mus be prevented, as far as possible, from amusing themselves in this way The worst danger is that a bird may come out in an uninhabited room where it may die of hunger before it is discovered. A movable win netting top to the chimneys will not interfere with the sweeping, an( prevents Parrakeets from entering, which they will do at all times o year. Young birds reared at liberty must be caught up as soon as the 1 ' can feed themselves, or they become too independent, take long distant flights and annoy the neighbours by robbing their orchards. It must not be forgotten that a pair of Platycerci are far mor* spiteful at liberty than a cock whose hen is shut up, and more disposec to drive away all their fellows. If a Parrakeet at liberty happens to die if its mate is not replaced, it must be caught up at once, or it will stra^ and be lost. Pennant's Parrakeet (P. elegans ) is decidedly larger than th- Rosella ; it is a native of East and South Australia. Its colour is ; fine carmine red, with pale blue cheeks, wings, and tail; the flight and rectrices are in part blackish green. The feathers in the mantle bav black centres. The sexes are alike, but the hen is smaller and her heat and beak are slighter. This species ranges over a wide territory, ant there are local varieties which vary in size and the amount of black h their plumage. The beak is grey and white, iris brown and feet greyisl black. When the young leave the nest they are deep green, with blm cheeks, have a few red feathers on the throat, and some blue ones 01 the wings and tail.. The red feathers appear gradually through th' green ones during autumn and winter, and the adult plumage is com pleted after the first moult. Young birds have been known to leave th nest wearing the adult red plumage, but this is exceptional. Pennants are the least quarrelsome of the large Platycerci, but thi does not mean that they are amiable with other birds ; they ar< merely the mildest of a very quarrelsome family. They should bi treated in the same way as Rosellas. A cock bird whose hen is shut u|

the aviary does well loose, has nothing to fear from Owls, and jduces a very fine effect in a garden. A pair at liberty very often sappoint their owner by staying several months and disappearing len they appear on the point of nesting. In order to succeed with a ir it is necessary to have a very steady cock, for among the Platycerci is the cock bird who decides the movements of the pair. The Adelaide Parrakeet (P. adelaidce), from South and Central istralia, is classed by certain authorities as a variety of Pennant. In :y opinion it may very well be a hybrid between P. elegans and !. flaveolus , which has become fixed and now comes true. The Adelaide differs from the Pennant by the paler red of its umage, which has a yellowish tinge, and the mantle has pale orange d edges. Individuals vary much in colour; some are very like Pennants, [ L t the majority look very different and wear a mixture of colours which akes them appear at once beautiful and remarkable. The sexes are ike, the head and beak offering the only distinction, \oung birds *e like Pennants, but their green is more golden in shade. They \0x25A0quire the same treatment as the preceding species. The Yellow-rumped Parrakeet (P. flaveolus) comes from the me locality, but is very rare in confinement. It may be described as small Pennant, whose red has everywhere been replaced by pale ;llow tinged with olive. The sexes are much alike in colour, but the )ung seem to be much greener than the adults. A male which I ; Assessed was exceedingly quarrelsome. The same treatment as le above. The Yellow-bellied Parrakeet (P. flaviventris), from Tasmania, aly differs from the last named by having the back, wings, and rump ark green. Both sexes are alike in colour, but the hen may readily be nown by her weaker beak and small head. The young are distinguish- ble by their green breasts and more uniformly green backs. This species is the most delicate of the Platycerci. Although easy ) feed and not much affected by cold, it is very subject to septicaemia, iberculosis, and other diseases. It does best in a movable aviary |ith plenty of grass, and the site must be changed annually. It must ot be too much exposed to the sun in summer, but enjoys it at other imes of the year ; besides seed and fruit, it should have some meal- worms. It resembles the Rosella in disposition.

Aviculture The Mealy Rosella (P . pallidiceps) inhabits the east and the interic of Australia ; it has the top of the head and back of the neck pal yellow, the cheeks white, mantle greenish yellow mixed with blacl the under tail feathers red, the lower back, rump, and all the und( parts are pale blue. The hen is smaller and not as brightly coloured a her mate. The young are less distinctly marked, and there is a shad of green in their plumage. This species should be treated like the others. Once acclimatizec it is as hardy as any other of the family, but when newly importe they are subject to chills and need watching. With ordinary precaution they are not difficult to breed at liberty or in an aviary. A variet (P. amathusia ) living in North Australia has blue cheeks and a greene mantle. It is very rarely imported, although very beautiful. Brown's Parrakeet (P. venustus ) from North Australia is smalle than the above-named species. Many people consider this the mos beautiful of its genus ; its head is black with white cheeks 5 under parts lower back, and rump straw coloured, each feather narrowly edged wit' black ; sub-caudals red ; the feathers of the mantle are black edge* with straw colour ; the wings and tail violet blue. The female is smalle and not as brightly coloured as the male. They require the same treat ment as the rest of the genus. But, like Palliceps, they must be protecteii from cold on first arrival; afterwards they may be looked upon a quite hardy. They do not breed as freely as the other Platycerc: being slow to accustom themselves to our seasons, persistently moultin, in May and laying in September. Toung birds hatched during autum: and reared in a heated aviary rarely makegood specimens ; it is bette to exercise patience and only to provide nesting boxes in April and t" remove them at the end of August. If this plan be rigorously persevered with the birds will moult earlier every year and finally go to nest h July. Needless to say, it is quite useless to allow Brown's to nest outsid* in cold w r eather ; if the hen does not die of egg binding the young wil certainly perish soon after they are hatched. For no apparent reason many more hens than cocks are imported. There is a blue-cheeket variety which also has a yellow breast. The Stanley Parrakeet (P. icterotis) is a native of South-Wes' Australia ; it is the smallest of its genus, and the only one in which th<

k and hen have very different colouring. In the cock the cheeks are it yellow, the rest of the head, the neck, and all the under parts of " body are bright red ; the back and rump are green ; the tail and igs green and blue. The hen is distinguishable by her dull red head I breast, speckled with green and yellow. Young birds resemble dr mother and gradually change their colouring like the other itycerci. By the middle of January their sex can easily be determined, is species should have the same treatment as the Kosella ; it breeds ely in an aviary, but is as spiteful as its larger relatives. Parrakeets of the genus Barnardius may be distinguished from the le Platycerci by certain structural details ; but to the ordinary lateur they belong to the same class. They are, however, larger and ve thicker and shorter beaks ; they are usually green. Barnard's Parrakeet (B . barnardi) from South and South-East istralia is a beautiful bluish green, with a red forehead, head and intle tinged with dark grey ; a half-collar round the nape of the neck d lower breast is yellow ; the wings and tail are variegated blue and een. A variety exists which has no yellow on the breast. The sexes e alike, though the hen is sometimes duller ; the only sure distinction :s in the size of the head and beak. When the young leave the nest ey are less brightly coloured, and are greener and duller than the lults. Barnard's bear a bad reputation in Australia for dying in lantities on being captured, but those which reach us are usually strong id hardy. They go to nest readily, either in an aviary or at liberty. !iey should be treated like Rosellas. Bauer's and Yellow-naped Parrakeets (B. zonarius and B. mitorquatus), held by Gould to be two species, are only local races the same bird. It is true that there is a great difference in the size, *louring, and even the voice of the large Yellow-nape, all green ith a red forehead, and the little Bauer with a yellow belly and black rehead ; but between the two extremes is every possible gradation, * much so that it is impossible to say where one begins or the other ids. Yellow-napes inhabit the south-west and Bauer's the south and iterior of Australia. Bauer's are green, with blue on tail and wings ; the belly yellow, half-collar of the same colour and a black head, shading into blue on

Aviculture the cheeks. Yellow-napes are larger and have the under parts whol green and the forehead red. The sexes are alike, but the hens ha narrower beaks and smaller heads. Both Bauer's and Yellow-nap are perfectly hardy. They should be treated like Bosellas. They a terribly quarrelsome, and have a habit of biting off their adversary beaks. Therefore, they must not be allowed their liberty where the are other Parrakeets bold enough to join battle with them. These Parrakeets can learn to whistle a tune, and even to speak few words in a hoarse voice, but none of the Platycerci nor Barnarc talk really well, nor can they be made real pets, for as soon as they lo, their fear of man they usually grow vicious and aggressive and she no real affection for their owner. The natural voice of Yellow-nape though too powerful for indoors, is agreeable in the open, and the wi whistling calls of a male bird when flying are charming. None of tl Platycerci actually scream unless wounded or frightened, and as have already said, their voices are usually musical. A blue and whi colour variety of Bauer's Parrakeet has been met with. The Bed-capped Parrakeet (Porphyriocephalus spurius) occupi an isolated position and differs from the genuine Platycerci in its shap its colour, and its manner of life. It is the same size as a Pennan with a long and pointed tail and a long, narrow, peculiarly shaped bea Its plumage is unique ; the top of its head is red, as are also the bel and sub-caudals ; cheeks green, changing to yellow on the sides of tl neck ; the back is green ; wings and tail green and blue ; the brea is a pretty shade of slaty purple. This species is to be found in West Australia. Its range is restrict and its numbers are rapidly decreasing, owing to cultivation and tl war waged on it by the owners of orchards. If it be not bred in co: finement it will probably soon cease to exist. The sexes are easi. recognized, for the hen always has more or less green mixed with the re on her head and her cheeks are much duller. Young birds have entire: green heads, but attain adult plumage after their first moult. The Bed-capped Parrakeet is rare and is troublesome to manage i confinement in this country ; if caught when adult, it is very wild an never becomes really tame even after years of aviary life. Young birc taken from the nest are, however, easily tamed. The species needs

it deal of exercise ; if shut up in a cage it quickly becomes too fat l dies of fits ; tame birds, which seem more greedy than timid ones, uld, when not breeding or moulting, be given only a teaspoonful of in seed a day with unlimited fruit and green food. This bird must be efully protected from chills, and although it may, once acclimatized, iter out of doors, it should be shut up for the night. When newly )orted it requires a very high temperature and plenty of exercise. \ first it must not be placed in an unheated aviary, even in summer, [ the first cool night will kill it. The shelter of its aviary must always I heated whenever the weather is chilly or damp and also at night, is a quarrelsome species, and as it is no more amiable towards its n kind than towards other Parrakeets, it is imprudent to put several lples together, even when travelling. In spite of its shyness, it is !"; difficult to persuade it to nest; it has been bred in England. One my specimens lived for a long time at liberty. A Red-capped Parrakeet's aviary must be very strongly built, although some individuals do not bite through ordinary wire netting, lers quickly make themselves a way of escape, \oung birds are very icate, for which reason the nest-box must be hung in a very sheltered r sition and the shelter well warmed. The Blue Bonnet is the name given to two varieties at least ;
algorithms.equation: i one has a red belly ( Northiella hcematogaster) and the other a yellow e ( N . xanthorous). They are peculiar little Parrakeets, which were
algorithms.bodyText: ' merly included among the Psejpholi, but have now rightly been placed j a separate genus, for they are no more Psephoti than Platycerci or 1 rnardii. The yellow-vented Blue Bonnet which is the more frequently ported, inhabits South Australia. It is mainly mouse-coloured, with I eeks and part of the wings and tail sky blue and the wing-coverts ! ve yellow ; the middle of the belly is red ; sides straw-coloured ; j e lower belly and sub-caudals are yellow. It is about the size of a j ckatiel, and has a long tail. The red-bellied variety, which is to be found in the south-east of the i ntinent, wears a chestnut red spot on the wings, and its sub-caudals e red ; it is the more brightly coloured of the two. A new sub-species s recently been discovered ( N. narethae) further north, which has no i d at all on the under parts. Many intermediate specimens are met L-

Foreign Birds at the Crystal Palace Bird Shoiv with ; the sexes are alike, but the hens are smaller and duller. T1 young are very much the same as the adults, only slightly less bright coloured. Blue Bonnets are very active and playful, they are not suitable f a cage, but would make admirable aviary birds but for the susceptibility to infectious diseases, especially two kinds septicaemia. They are very spiteful and can kill birds a good deal biggj than themselves. Some aviary keepers have found them amiable wi, small birds, but not all. Blue Bonnets should be fed like Rosella | they can stand cold well, even when first imported if they are in goq plumage, and they seldom require heat. In consideration of their liability to disease, it is best to keep the! in movable aviaries. A cock whose hen is shut up stays well, an notwithstanding his small size, escapes the attacks of his enemi, through his agility, caution, and his power of biting savagely. Paii however, rarely succeed well at liberty, and are disposed wander away.
algorithms.sectionHeader: FOREIGN BIRDS AT THE CRYSTAL PALAC BIRD SHOW
algorithms.bodyText: The annual cage-bird show at the Crystal Palace was held fro 3rd to 5th February, and was said to beat all previous records far as numbers and value were concerned. The foreign bird section w quite up to the average, and contained a most interesting collection birds. The Dulwich and Peckham Cage Bird Society and their energet Show Manager, Mr. A. W. Smith, are to be heartily congratulated ( the success of their enterprise. Amongst the Lories was a splendid pair of Musky Lorikeets whi< won a 1st prize for Mr. Maxwell, Mr. Frostick taking second with a go( pair of Yellow-backed Lories and Mr. Whitley third with a Black-cap. The class for Lovebirds, Brotogerys , etc., contained no less tin twenty-two entries, and almost all were in show condition, and i there were only four prizes many excellent birds had to go witlio a card. In the class for Conures (excepting Golden and Whitleye Mr. Whitley showed a fine Patagonian, a rare bird nowadays (fir
Foreign Birds at the Crystal Palace Bird Show

j e ), as well as a pair of Red-masked, while Mr. Frostick sent a good en and a pair of Golden-headed Conures and Mr. Holdstock a pair lendayas. Two fine pairs of King Parrots were shown by Mr. Whitley l Mr. Jackson (first and third), while Mr. Adams' Pennant came third l a fine pair of Bauer's (Mr. Frostick) fourth. The " All Other Species" class contained Whitley's Conure, of which recently had a coloured plate in our Magazine. It received the first 1 a special prize. Mr. Whitley's beautiful Alexandra Parrakeet, ich took second prize, was a superb bird, while Lord Tavistock's rfolk Island Parrakeet, which obtained third prize, was a great Sty. Mr. Frostick sent a fine pair of the Tasmanian Yellow-bellied Aakeets and Lord Tavistock a fine Yellow-rumped. The class for Hybrids and abnormally coloured birds was, as usual, , ery interesting one. Lord Tavistock sent his exquisite Lutino Blue- nted Amazon. It is a wonderful bird, of a bright canary-yellow h crimson markings. His hybrid Alexandra Crimson-wing is also a tutiful and most interesting bird. Mr. Whitley's hybrid Glossy trling is a great curiosity, the male parent being a BurchelFs Starling I the female a Chestnut-winged Starling. There were two Black Cockatoos, one sent by Mr. Whitley (first) d the other by Lord Tavistock (second). Mr. Hawkins sent a Spix, icaw (third), in a cage that was too small for it. In the class for " All other species of Parrots ", Mr. Whitley took it prize with a pair of the very rare Yellow-headed Poeocejphalus . citreicajpillus ) from Abyssinia. Mr. Maxwell's Yellow-billed onus, which took second prize, is also a rare species. Third came a ry good Hawk-head, and fourth a Brown-headed Parrot, of which \0x25A0 3 cies there was a second example in the class. The class for Quails, >ves, etc., contained but two entries, both belonging to Mr. Whitley, )air of Black-headed Caccabis and a Ground Dove, of which I do not low the species. The class for rare Grassfinclies, Waxbills, etc., contained two pairs of ters' Spotted Firefinches, the first shown for many years, the st prize going to those shown by Mr. and Mrs. T. R. Berry, and third those belonging to Mr. C. T. Maxwell. Mr. Timberlake took second ize with a good Violet-eared Waxbill, of which species two others

Avicultural Notes were shown. There were also some good Rainbow Buntings, a Versicoi Bunting, Gouldian, and others, but the rarest thing in the class, thou perhaps the least conspicuous, was a small Waxbill sent by Mr. Width It belonged to a species described as recently as October last and nam Estrilda xanthophrys by Mr. W. L. Sclater in the Bulletin of the Brit, Ornithologists Club. It was therefore the rarest bird in the show, thou the judge may well be excused for not spotting it. A very fine Mariqua Sunbird belonging to Mr. Maxwell very right took first and special prize in the class for these birds, and the small Tanagers and Sugar-birds. In the Glossy Starling class there were t\ pairs of Royals, some Superbs, and a very good Purple-head. The class for Crows, Jays, and Toucans was interesting. Mr. Frostij was lucky in securing first for a Red-bellied Toucan agaiu Mr. Maxwell's very rare and beautiful Green Toucanette, which w awarded second prize. Mr. Whitley's pair of Pileated Jays we beauties, and his very small Aracari was a rarity. The " Any other small species " class contained some very got birds. Mr. C. T. Maxwell sent a lovely Minivet which obtained fir prize, a rare Indian Shrike, shown by Mr. Whitley, coming second ai a beautiful Rufous-bellied Niltava (Mr. C. S. Dunstan) third. In the " Any other larger species " class Mr. Whitley took fir with a very beautiful pair of White-breasted Touracous, a speci that is a bad liver as a rule, though Mr. Whitley seems to have solvt the difficulty of keeping it in excellent condition. Why the secoi prize should have gone to a Donaldson's, a common species nowada; and easily kept, instead of to the very rare Green-necked Touraco which was also in the class and probably the first ever exhibited, not clear. D. S-S.

The popularity of the blue variety of the Budgerigar in Japan h resulted in the most remarkable rise in value of these birds in Europ Their value is now about twelve times as much as it was two years a# or less, and several breeders of these verv attractive birds have mac small fortunes during the past year. And this rise in value is nc entirely confined to the blue and other coloured varieties of tl
algorithms.title: Avicultural Notes
algorithms.bodyText: dgerigar, the normally coloured birds being also affected, though to ssser decree. Their value may fluctuate, but at 'the time of writing ;se are about four times their normal value. There is a danger that the high prices offered for these birds may ult- in valuable stock birds being sent out of the country, and this, ear, has taken place to a considerable extent, especially in the case the Cobalt birds. if The Turquoisine was comparatively common as a cage-bird in rope many years ago, and it might with care have been conserved 1 multiplied instead of being allowed to die out as it did, while fortunately no trouble was taken to protect it in its limited habitat South-Eastern Australia. The youths of Sydney were in the habit proceeding to the country on Saturday afternoons in order to shoot rrakeets for " Parrot-pie ", much of the " bag " consisting of rquoisines ! Sheep farming was also a very potent factor in the diminution of this icies, for the grass seed which formed the food of these Parrakeets s not allowed to form when the sheep came and ate the grass. But the Turquoisine is not extinct, as was at one time feared, and s satisfactory to hear that our member, Mr. Simon Harvey, jun.,of elaide, has reared a brood of Turquoisines in his aviary. Mr. Blaauw has for many years kept a wonderful collection of terfowl at Gooilust, in Holland, and he has bred most of the rare ;cies of Geese and Ducks. One of his latest successes has been with ,} Blue-winged Goose of Abyssinia (Cyanochen cyanoptera), a rare xdes of which he published an account in our journal in July, 1925. Mr. Blaauw has also bred the rare Slight-billed Parrakeet lenicognathus leptorhynchus), from Chili, from a pair he brought home 1911 . That the Californian Quail is not perfectly hardy may have been covered by some of our members. While dry cold does not seem to ( ?ct it much, it cannot stand damp cold. Mr. Maurice Portal writes me : "I had three pairs which laid some eighty-five eggs in 1925.

Correspondence I hatched sixty, and brought up the chicks in the Pheasant field. Th vanished in October. In 1926 I hatched thirty-seven. Ten were ke in a movable pen in the field. The balance I let go as they liked. Sevi roosted by the keeper's house in a yew-tree, and about ten in some bill scrub in the wood, and a few in an old Scotch fir. All were dead aflj a thick white fog which froze about 1 a.m., and ended in 9 degrees hoar-frost. All were fat with full crop and gizzards full of grit. Tlj accounts for my friends telling me they migrated ! " D. S-S.

Sir, --I purchased a pair of Egyptian (presumably Common) Quo the other day. Though I have kept Californian Quails for years | ordinary seed and corn, I would be much obliged if you could let .j know something about the common species, which I have never It before, though I have tried to get them for ages. (1) What is the sexi difference ? (2) Correct feeding ? (3) Are they likely to breed in outdoor " Parrakeet " Aviary, with only a sandy ground, and abd 12 feet by 8 feet ? (4) Anything further you can tell me. Thos. L. S. Dooly i
algorithms.listItem: [(1) When adult the sexes of the Common Quail may be distinguish by the two dark brown bands which descend from the ear-coverts a terminate in a blackish patch on the throat of the male. The femab slightly the larger bird. (2) Canary and millet seed or almost any small grain and gn food. They also readily devour insects. (3) To breed Quails successfully a fairly large outdoor aviary j
algorithms.bodyText: which grass is allowed to grow long is essential. Although they may j eggs, they will never incubate them unless the nest is in a very seclu( spot, such as beneath a tuft of long grass, approached by a tuu through the grass. (4) The young are not difficult to rear providing plenty of live ai cocoons can be obtained, but they are not likely to thrive on pui artificial food. The Common Quail is the wildest and least attractive of any of genus Coturnix. --Ed.]

By Karl Plath (Chicago) The Thick-billed Parrot is the monotype of the genus Rhynchopsitta d is placed between the genera Ara and Conuropsis in Ridgeway's tssification of American Psittacidse. It is a medium-sized parrot out the size of the Yellow-headed Amazon and is slightly reminiscent the Military Macaw in appearance. It's bill is large and heavy d black in colour. The habitat of this fine Parrot is in the pine belt the mountains of northern and middle Mexico and it occasionally mders northward into Southern Arizona. Mr. Lee S. Crandall, curator of birds in the New York Zoological irk, says he knows of no record of its ever having been kept in captivity d diligent search on my part fails to reveal this fact. In colour it is a deep green with none of the dusky colour edging , the feathers. The cheeks are brighter green and the under parts hter green and slightly duller. The forehead and a broad stripe er each eye is deep carmine and the bend of the wing and lower part i thigh is bright geranium red. The under surface of wing and tail slate colour and the under primary coverts are clear yellow. The *dy feathers have a highly polished effect.

G. H. Gurney--The Chestnut-headed Buarremon Our bird, which we call " Mickey ", is very tame and affectionat especially with our young son, but it does not seem to take to the ladie It delights in snuggling around one's neck and rubbing its cheek again one's ear. It has a decidedly unpleasant voice which, if my memo] serves me right, is similar to that of the Rose-breasted Cockatoo.

By G. H. Gurney I have lately received a pair of these birds, which I believe are ne to Aviculture. The genus Buarremon is composed of a group of Tan grine Finches, closely allied to the Saltators and to the Magpie Tanage ( Cissopsis ). They range over the whole of Central America, froi Mexico to Peru, and are especially common in the Andean area. M birds, which arrived in fairly good condition, have now settled dow well, they are at present in a large flight cage, but no doubt later ( they will be put into an aviary. They are rather larger than a Scarl Tanager, but much more sturdily built, the wings are short, and vei square looking in flight, and the bill is considerably longer and mo elongated than in the majority of the Tanagridae. There is a slig] difference in colour between the two birds, one being somewhat light than the other, and the black spots on the front of the head are n so pronounced, this is presumably the hen. Above and on the low^ parts of the breast they are a dull yellowish green colour, wings ar tail brown, the crown of the head is a rich chestnut red, sides of tl head and forehead jet black, with three white longish spots, the thro, down to the pectoral collar is snowy white, the collar black, upp parts of the breast grey ; this description of their colouring will sho that they are very showy birds, the black and white of the thro; and head and the rich red brown top making them very conspicuou My pair are very tame, and extremely active and inquisitive, alwaj on the move, jerking their heads continually and flicking their rath short tails in quite a Shrike-like way ; they are so square lookir and thickset, that they remind one almost of a Dipper, and as the

Capt. H. S. Stokes--The Clarino or Clarinet Bird 91 pear to be somewhat terrestrial, this adds to the similarity. So far tave not heard them utter any note. They are doing well on ordinary ;ectivorous mixture, are very fond of mealworms, and eat a good al of fruit.
algorithms.sectionHeader: THE CLARINO OR CLARINET BIRD (MTIEDESTES UNICOLOR )
algorithms.bodyText: By Captain H. S. Stokes Mr. Chapman has lately received a fair quantity of these from exico. It is also known as the Grey Solitaire, and has been exhibited fore at the Zoo, while an allied species, Townsend's Solitaire l. toivnsendi), was described by the late Mr. Astley, and well illustrated this journal in 1919 (New Series, Vol. VII, p. 319). According Dr. Hopkinson's book, it was bred in Moscow in 1912. It is about the size of a Scarlet Tanager, of dark slaty blue, with a ag of white feathers round the eye. It sings very attractively and continuously. Two or three in a room mind me of a chime of little silver bells, or of those Japanese glass limes which clash and tinkle in the breeze. (I am also bound to admit iat one of my birdy friends described the song as like the scraping of wheelbarrow wheel in need of oiling !) The Clarino seems to be largely frugivorous, mine preferring soaked irrants and chopped apple to anything else. The hens sing also, and have a " feminine look " and a narrower sad than the cocks, and care should be taken to see they get their ir share of food when the sexes are put together as the cocks are very hteful towards them.

By W. Shore-Baily I am venturing to send you these few notes on the happenings 1 1 my aviaries during the last season, as they may be of interest to ur readers. In a Society with a membership of something like 00, it is astonishing how few write anything about their birds.

92 W. Shore-Baily--1926 in the Boyers House Aviaries Occasionally if there is a medal in view we get an account of som< success, but how often do we hear about the failures. I venture t( think that in many cases the failures or partial successes are quit* as interesting as complete successes, and beginners are certainly mon likely to learn something from them. With this apology I will comment
