By the Marquess of Tavistock and J. Delacour (Concluded Jrom p. 84) The genus Psephotus is a well-defined group of small Parrakeet whose chief characteristic is the striking difference in plumage betweei the sexes ; the hens are nearly as plainly clad as hen Pheasants ar when compared with cocks. Their wings and tails are long but thei beaks and feet are small. The Psephoti have very weak and musical voices which couli not annoy the most sensitive ear, and are besides graceful and pretty They are, however, very quarrelsome. They succeed very well ii| aviaries but should never be confined in cages for any length of time! To keep any Psephotus permanently in a parrot cage is exceedingly! cruel. The Red-rumped Parrakeet (Psephotus hcematonotus) is th commonest of the group ; it is very hardy and easy to breed whd acclimatized. The male bird is a fine green tinged with blue on th head and wings, with a greyish mantle ; his belly is yellow passing into white on the sub-caudals and the rump is red, the outer retrice are blue and white. The female is greyish green. Young males car be told by their greener hue and by a little red on the back. Th length of this species is about 15 inches. Red-rumps should hav the same treatment as Rosellas ; they do not care for fruit but ea green food freely. They are charming at liberty and stay well, breed rjeadily, do n< harm to fruit and never go down chimneys ; they look particularly fascinating running about on a closely-cut lawn. Unfortunately they can only be kept safely where there are no Tawny Owls. I

Red-rump loses his mate he will disappear after a few days if another 3 not provided at once. On letting out a pair the same precautions hould be taken as advised for the Platycerci. Red-rumps are natives f South and South-East Australia. The Manycoloured Parrakeet (P . multicolor) inhabits the iouth and interior of Australia ; it is the same size as the Red-rump nd the male is really magnificent. His colour is satiny green shading ato blue, with a yellow forehead. The nape is sometimes brick ed, the wings are blue and green with a yellow mark on the shoulders, he belly is red, w T ings blue and green bearing a yellow spot on the houlders ; the tail is blue and white, green at the base ; there is a ed spot on the rump and the belly is red, the sub-caudals yellow. The female is grey green with nape, rump and shoulders spotted i.ith brick red ; wungs and tail tinged with blue. They fly very racefully. They should be fed like the previously mentioned species, omitting uemp and sunflower. They are nearly as ready to go to nest in confine- aent but not so easily kept in good health. They can be kept out >f doors when acclimatized, but w r hen first imported must be kept warm, lanycolours must be shut up at night when kept in an aviary. Their hief trouble is their habit of contracting contagious diseases, especially epticsemia. But as the germs of this illness are local, one amateur nay succeed very w t ell with this species while another cannot save them, lovable aviaries are very desirable for them, indeed almost essential, lanycolours may be let fly like Red-rumps, but are more inclined o stray and it is necessary to take more precautions. The Hooded Parrakeet (P . dissimilis) is one of the prettiest ^rrakeets in the world, and w r hen flying, looks like a huge butterfly, die male has a black top to his head, his cheeks, throat, breast, belly, nd rump are turquoise blue ; his back and mantle are greyish brown, \ ail and wings deep blue green ; the small wing-coverts are golden ellow and the sub-caudal feathers orange-red. The female has greenish grey head ; back, wings and breast pale green ; the belly s blue, sub-caudals orange-red, tail green and blue. The female a a light brownish olive, washed with pale blue on the cheeks, breast, nd under parts. This species is a native of North Australia.

Aviculture The Hooded Parrakeet should have the same food as the precedi species. As it comes from the tropics, it needs to be very cafefu? acclimatized, and on first arrival it requires a high temperatui; later it should be shut up for the night and in bad weather healtj' specimens may be kept outside throughout the year. Unfortunate the Hooded Parrakeet often retains the habit of moulting and breedi according to Australian seasons and to cure this it should be treat! like Brown's Parrakeet. In its native land it breeds in the neJ of the termite and consequently some hens are difficult to please ai will not make use of the ordinary nesting logs, and must be tempt with other shapes. Where there are no Owls these Parrakeets can be given their liber and a pair of them will charm their owner more under those conditio than a whole aviary full of other birds. When they have settled dov they never stray, but a good deal of care must be exercised in liberatii them. Young cocks are like the hens except that their cheeks a a little bluer ; the black and yellow colouring appears after the fir moult. A dealer will occasionally offer a young bird, apparently in god health, but minus flight and tail feathers. On no account should be bought, for not only do the missing feathers never grow, but in tin the bird loses even the feathers which it has. The Hooded Parrake has always been a rare species in Europe. Golden-shouldered Parrakeet (P. chrysopterygius) is four farther south in the interior of Australia ; it is much like the abov but can be distinguished by its smaller hood and by a yellow bar on the forehead. The hen also shows traces of this band. It is eve more rarely imported than the Hooded. The Paradise Parrakeet (P . pulcherrima) from East Australia | a delightful bird which was believed to be extinct but which has recentl been rediscovered in small numbers. The male has a red forehea: and a black crown ; his back and wings are deep grey-brown wit red shoulders ; the sides of his head and neck, the throat and breaf are green; his eyes are encircled with yellow ; his flanks, rump, an tail-coverts are turquoise blue tinged wfith green ; his belly and silt caudals are rosy red ; tail deep green and light blue. The female i

stinguished by the sides of her head and neck, and her breast being wn or beige ; her belly is pale blue with red spots. There is now very little chance of this species being imported, though it is said that one or two have reached America. Former nateurs who had them found them not particularly susceptible
algorithms.listItem: * cold and quite easy to breed, but that they seem to have been liable
algorithms.bodyText: ) contagious diseases like Manycolours and would appear to require le same treatment. Bourke's Parrakeet (Neopsephotus bourkei) from South Australia iperficially resembles the genus Neophema but in reality it is very istinct and has no very close affinities. It has none of those faults hich make some people dislike Parrakeets. Its plumage is not gaudy ut softly shaded, rosy grey on the head, neck, and breast, grey edged ith green on the mantle and wungs, the folds of which are light blue ; ae belly is pink, the under tail-coverts sky blue, the tail blue and dark rey. It has a melodious voice, does not bite when handled and does ot destroy shrubs. The sexes are alike in colour but the difference l the size of the head is sufficiently pronounced to enable them to e distinguished. Bourke's Parrakeets inhabit desert country and never bathe in onfinement nor eat green stuff ; they feed exclusively on millet and anary seed. There is no harm in offering them groundsel or flowering rass but they seldom touch it. Sometimes they like a turf of grass, specially when it begins to wither. Once acclimatized they stand old fairly well if protected from wind and damp. They go to nest eadily but must only be allowed to breed during the w r arm months, breeding pairs should be kept by themselves as the cocks may kill ach other or if they do not go as far as that, the weaker will be >adly plucked. The bottom of their log must be quite near the sntrance hole, for this species, unlike most other Parrakeets, is not a limber. Bourke's Parrakeets are susceptible to disease, particularly tuber- miosis, and need a clean sunny aviary. Their worst fault is their nveterate habit of banging themselves against the roof and sides of keir aviary in flight if they are frightened, or, in the case of the young oirds, when they leave the nest. It is absolutely necessary to have

Aviculture an inner lining of string netting and to see that it is always perfect taut. I have found this species inoffensive 'with other birds. The Grass Parrakeets ( Neojphema ) include some of the mo interesting small Australian Parrakeets. They are, generally speakin harmless to other birds, do not bite, and their voices are not disagre able ; they are extremely pretty and breed quite readily in an aviar Unfortunately they are excessively rare and competent observe:: assert that they are on the way to complete extinction ; but for a that it has for years been believed that certain species had entire^ disappeared, and yet they have come to light again either in littl scattered flocks or isolated pairs. The Blue-winged Grass Parrakeet (N. venusta) is found i Tasmania and specimens still occasionally arrive in Europe and America Its colouring is olive green, yellower on the cheeks and belly, whic last is sometimes tinged with orange ; a narrow band across the fore head ; the wings and part of the tail are very bright blue. The fee and beak are small and delicate. Its length is about 10 inches. Th blue band across the forehead is duller and less marked on the hen and she has also greenish feathers in the blue patch on her wings Young birds have less blue than adults, but assume their full plumagi long before they are a year old. Adults are quarrelsome ; the hen, being more pugnacious and stronger than the cocks and a watch mus' be kept lest a hen take a dislike to a new mate, for she may injure hin severely. Bluewings require heat wdien they first come over, but once acclimatized they will live out of doors if they are shut up at nighl and during cold weather. These Parrakeets are liable to septicaemia and it is advisable to house them in movable aviaries. Like Bourke's they have the annoying habit of hitting themselves against the wire and require an inner lining of string netting to keep them from biting the roof mesh. A smooth plank on which they cannot hang should be fixed just underneath ; they do not gnaw hanging head downwards as they are not good at climbing. Bluewings are rather liable to sunstroke in great heat for they are apt to expose themselves most rashly. A few leafy branches should be laid on the roof of their aviary so as to intercept the direct rays, but in winter they need all the sun they can get. Like other

embers of the group they are subject, when first imported, to the me disease of the eyes which causes losses among Barrabands; ith Grass Parrakeets it is always fatal. Grass Parrakeets eat millet and canary seed with a little hemp and enty of groundsel and flowering grass. They usually lay four eggs it unless they are kept in a spacious movable aviary, male birds :e d in captivity are mostly infertile. As already mentioned when waling with Bourke's Parrakeet, the entrance hole should be near ie bottom of their nesting log. The Elegant Parrakeet (N . elegans) from South-West ustralia is much like the foregoing but the blue strip on its wings is mch narrower and of two shades, and the green more golden. It is iow very rare but in former times it was well known and has been Ted in aviaries. Old males may have an orange patch on the b do men like Bluewings and Orange Bellies. The Orange-bellied Parrakeet (N . chrysogaster) is a native of asmania and South and South-East Australia. It is like the luewing but is greener and the blue area on the forehead is wider, more idefinite, and less brilliant in colour. The species is almost unknown i aviaries, and is probably on the verge of extinction. The Rock Grass Parrakeet (N . petrophila ) is much like Venusta ut is duller and more olive and has less blue in its wing. It is the ullest-coloured member of the group. This species inhabits certain oastal districts in South-West Australia and nests in holes under large xmes. It is being exterminated by cats and rats, and is now very ^arce. I had two males in my possession for several years ; they were msitive to the cold and could not be wintered out of doors. One f them paired with a hen Venusta, but the eggs were clear. It has een bred in Germany. The Turquoisine (N . pulchella ) is a native of South and South- last Australia. It is a tragedy that this lovely little bird was not reserved in Europe, for it bred freely and might have been domesticated ke the Budgerigar. For years it was believed to be extinct but latterly few specimens have been discovered and two or three have reached lurope and the United States. The male bird is olive green above dth blue forehead, cheeks, and wings, a red patch on the shoulders,

Aviculture and all the under parts and the tail yellow. The female has no r on the shoulders and only a trace of blue on the cheeks. Young bii have even less blue than their mother but attain their full pluma when a few months old. These Parrakeets should be fed on millet and canary seed wi flowering grass and groundsel. They have the same habits and diseas as Bluewings. Turquoisines in former days were commonly in t market. The Splendid Parrakeet (N . splendida) is more beautifj even than the Turquoisine Parrakeet; it was a native of Sout West Australia and has always been very rare. It is, however, report' to have bred in the Zoological Gardens of London. Its back, manh and tail are green, the latter being yellow underneath and at the side Its head is brilliant cobalt blue ; its breast bright red \ its wings mixture of light and dark blue; its abdomen golden yellow. The h< has no red breast. This species which was thought to be extin has lately reappeared. It is said that two specimens were caugi and eaten by a farmer whose granary they had entered during drought ! Owing to the destruction of its refuges in times of droug] and the increasing colonization of the country, there is no hope th; the bird will maintain itself permanently even in the deserts of tl interior. The Cyanoramphus Parrakeets come from New Zealand ar Oceania and are about the size of a Rosella. They are usually gree but their heads are adorned with red or yellow and their wings tingf with blue. The Lew Zealand Red-fronted Parrakeet (C. novce-zelandic was formerly very frequently met with in aviaries, but owing to ii scarcity in its native country and to the strict protection afforde it, it is now hardly ever seen here. It is a fine grass green, has if flights marked with blue and all the crown of the head bright red a well as the lores and a small patch on the flanks. The sexes are alike but the hen's beak and head are smaller and weaker. This species has often been bred and used to be considered hard and prolific. I once had two males and one female but one cock injure* the hen and the other killed her, so the species is not always as gentl
algorithms.author: Australian Parrakeet s
algorithms.bodyText: some writers declare. It does as well in a cage as in an aviary and irns to speak. Its food should consist of two parts of canary to .e of hemp and one of oats, together with apple and green food. The Norfolk Island Parrakeet ( C . cooki) strongly resembles e Red-fronted but it is much larger and it has a stronger beak. It now almost extinct, having been exterminated by rats. They ipear to be gentle but are apt to feel the cold : they should not be owed much hemp or sunflower seed. The Yellow-fronted New Zealand Parrakeet (0. auriceps) even rarer than the above. It differs in not having red cheeks, it a w r ide yellow band on the top of its head while its forehead is d, and there is a red patch on the rump. It was freely imported former times and was scarcely less prolific than the Red-fronted ; was bred several times in France, especially by Delacour. Besides these species the following have been imported : C. saisseti om New Caledonia, C. unicolor from the Antipodean Islands, id C. erythronotus from the Society Islands. The first may be dis- tiguished from the Red-fronted by its larger size, and yellow cheeks id throat; the second is all green ; the third has a black forehead id the lores ; a spot on the ear-coverts and the rump are reddish *own ; its body is olive green freely marked with blue on the wings id tail. The two species belonging to the genus Nymphicus differ from the *yanoramphus by their pointed crests. They are pretty, interesting, id inoffensive. They have been bred in confinement but very seldom, they are usually most difficult to keep alive. Occasionally one ay come across an individual who lives many years without special re; but for one like this a dozen and more will die off most ixatiously. The Uvean Parrakeet ( N . uvceensis) from the Loyalty Islands grass green, yellowish underneath and on the rump ; it has a crest 'mposed of six curved dark green feathers, becoming paler towards e extremities ; the feathers on the forehead are dark green with d tips ; wings and tail partly blue ; the face, cheeks, and chin are irk green. I believe the sexes to be alike, unless there is some fference in the size of the head and beak.

Aviculture Those which I had did not live long : some which were in ni aviaries died of anaemia and softening of the bones ; while othei living in cages, succumbed to aspergillosis. It would seem that tl best method of keeping them in good health is by giving them ve nourishing and varied food ; hemp, canary, millet, oats, sunflowa monkey nuts, fruit, green food, and mealworms. This Parrakeet hi a peculiar but not disagreeable voice ; it is active and interest^ and becomes perfectly tame. The Horned Parrakeet (N. cornutus) from New Caledon is even larger and handsomer. Its chief difference lies in its head ar crest. This last is composed of two long narrow feathers which pob backwards and are black with red tips. The top of the head is re- black at the base of the feathers ; the nape and flanks are yellow face and cheeks black ; the remainder is grass green tinged with yello on the rump and with blue on the wings and tail. It is rarer than the Uvean and has not been imported for a lor while. It was bred several times in France by Cornily, who also reare the Uvean Parrakeeet and hybrids between the two ; but breedir them at all must have been due to a lucky chance combined wit uncommon skill. The Swift Parrakeet (Nanodes discolor), very widely distribute throughout South-East Australia and Tasmania, is an attracts and very distinct little species. It is the same size as the Gra: Parrakeets ; it has a yellowish beak and feet and golden yellow eve the forehead and throat are red, the latter surrounded by a yello line ; the crown of the head is bluish and all the rest brilliar green above, paler beneath, save for the wings and tail, which hav blue and red markings. This Parrakeet is interesting in many ways but hard to keep aliv in confinement and may die off without reason in spite of every can Although it feeds in the same fashion as the Lories, and is, like then active in climbing, it really has very little in common with that famil in its habits and character, but reminds one rather in some ways c the Barraband. The sexes are alike and very difficult to distinguish but the cocks are brighter and have a yellower iris. Swift Parrakeet are gentle and do not quarrel among themselves even when breeding

ieir diet should consist of bananas and sponge cake in equal parts, ished and mixed together ; soaked canary seed, fruit and all sorts green stuff ; a few mealworms may also be added. They bear cold rly well but should have some meat in the severest weather. A :m of enteritis, due neither to chill nor to irritants in the food, is eir most serious disease and they may contract it suddenly when in rfect condition. We do not know how to prevent nor cure is complaint. Formerly this species was bred in France in large antities especially by Kousse ; he kept several pairs together in tside aviaries provided with good shelters ; he fed them on seed, lit, and bread and milk. In their wild state they, like the Lories, id chiefly on nectar from the flowers of the Eucalyptus. The Budgerigar (Melopsittacus undulatus ) is too well known require description. It is a native of Australia, where it is migratory, are also many of the preceding species. The sexes are alike but e cere (the skin covering the base of the beak) is blue in the male- d cream or brown in breeding hens ; bluish white when the female is. eeding. The young have their foreheads streaked with black, lile those of the adults are pure yellow. The wild type is green with yellow head, the face marked with deep violet blue, and the wings, id tail partly blue ; the mantle, crown, and sides of the head are barred id streaked with dark grey. In confinement many different colour rieties have been bred, some very beautiful. The most striking e light blue, deep blue, mauve, grey, yellow, olive, and white. When idgerigars are kept in flocks they breed very freely. It may chance at a hen here and there may turn vicious and kill her neighbours, it this is quite exceptional. Odd hens, however, should be removed they disturb nests, but surplus cocks are seldom a nuisance. Some amateurs allow Budgerigars to breed all the year round, but is wiser to rest them during the cold months either by separation the sexes or simply by taking away the nest-boxes. Some strains e very hardy, but others having been kept and bred indoors for nerations have become tender and are as subject to chills as axbills. Budgerigars are not to be recommended as companions for small rds, and they destroy shrubs in an aviary. The Budgerigar is

Aviculture a delightful species at liberty and well worth the trouble it may gb in establishing it. It is necessary to procure several strong, healthy pairs whkj have been bred in an outside aviary and to keep them shut up f. several months on the spot where it is intended to release them. Tht can then be let out a few at a time, with food at hand and nest-box in the trees. It is wise to catch up young birds directly they cd feed themselves ; otherwise they stray. They should be fed at fir on soaked canary seed and kept in a sheltered aviary. In the midd of September all old cocks should be caught up and placed in aviarie When it is certain that no young remain in the nests the hens can at be caught. They are easily taken if they have been accustomd to be fed in trap cages which can be closed by pulling a string. It not safe to let Budgerigars winter at liberty on account of owl Budgerigars do no harm to the garden and never touch either but or fruit. The species is completely domesticated in Europe, an breeding it has become a considerable business, particularly in Franc where tens of thousands are raised every year. They are fed on canar and millet with all kinds of green stuff and a little soft insectivoroi food with bread and milk when they are nesting. Old wall morti is indespensable for them. In southern parts, Toulon in particula where they are chiefly bred, they are given Thuya boughs and lettuc leaves. Before leaving the Parrakeets we must mention those strang Australian birds distantly related to the Platycercinae which ai remarkable for their terrestial habits, and live on the ground, wher they run with great rapidity on their long legs. They fly rapidly bu never perch. The Ground Parrakeet (Pezojporus terrestris) is found in Sout. and West Australia and Tasmania. It is 12 inches long with a well developed tail, and it has a very short beak. Its plumage is gree: watered with black and tinged with yellow on the abdomen and tail its forehead is orange red. The sexes are alike. It is becoming mor and more rare and is hardly ever imported. It is active by day an< nests in tufts of grass and herbage. The Night Parrakeet (Geopsittacus occidentalis) may be knowi
algorithms.title: Walter Barnett--A Hybrid Cardinal
algorithms.bodyText: om the above by its short thick nails and shorter tail; it is also ightly larger and a greyer green without any red on the forehead. ; inhabits South and South-West Australia but is believed to be ttinct. It spent the day crouching in tufts of herbage, only coming nt under cover of darkness. It has been imported once or twice.
algorithms.sectionHeader: A HYBRID CARDINAL By Walter Barnett
algorithms.bodyText: In the spring of 1922 I bought a pair of Green Cardinals and turned lem out into the aviary in May. The cock bird, apparently quite ealthy, I found dead one morning about three weeks later. Here, may say that the aviary is built against a wall facing south-west, lb is open to all weathers, winter and summer, except that one end is lofed in with glass to keep the food dry in wet weather. Prior to he arrival of the Green Cardinals I had a Virginian Cardinal (male), ut it was not until the summer of 1925 that the Green Cardinal hen lowed signs of nesting. In that year, at the end of June she built nest of sticks and grass, rather an untidy structure, inside a wire asket hanging from the roof under the end that was covered in with lass. She laid four eggs, blue spotted with dark brown, and began to t. At the time, there was a spell of very hot weather, and she was i full sun directly under the glass, I put a bit of canvas shading over le glass to give her some protection. My attention, however, was ot appreciated, for she at once deserted her nest. I had no idea b that time who her mate was, or w 7 hether the eggs were fertile. On reaking one of them I discovered that they were. She was not many days before she got busy again, carrying up its of fresh grass to the old nest, and then laid three more eggs. This me, something took the eggs, and I have never to this day discovered ho was the culprit. I rather suspected a pair of Spreo Starlings wrongly as it proved later) for I had seen one of them take a Zebra inch's egg out of a nest-box. Nothing daunted, the Green Cardinal laid a third time. So I rught up the Spreos and caged them inside the aviary. However,

the eggs again disappeared, so the Spreos were once more set fn So each attempt at nesting that year ended in disaster. Last summer, however, she built again in the same basket, la four eggs and again they were taken. There was not even a trace broken shells. Soon after I saw her again carrying bits of gras so I took the basket away, in the hope that she would shift elsewher She then built a nest in a small fir-tree, laid three eggs, and this tin was not molested and hatched them in July. There was no dou] during incubation as to her mate, for whenever any mealworms we: thrown in, the Red Cardinal at once took them up to her and fed h while she was sitting. As soon as the young hatched he at once wei on to the nest when she came off to feed and both parents fed the your ones in turn. One young bird died in the nest, another I foun dead below on the ground. The third became fully fledged, almo; ready to leave the nest, when there was a violent thunderstorm. Th nest got drenched and next morning the last remaining young one ws dead. This was at the end of July. Early in August, she began building again in the basket which had replaced, so I moved it at once into a small wooden shelter insid the aviary, a much more secluded spot with a roof over her hea in case of storms. My hope that she might follow her partly-buil nest to its new locality was fulfilled. She finished the nest, laid tw eggs at some days interval, and duly hatched one. The other eg ; came to nothing. Both parents again fed the young one. Ther was the usual soft food available and I gave them a liberal suppl 1 of fresh ants' eggs and gentles, but was sparing with mealworms In due course the young one left the nest. The first morning I fount it out on the ground I had rather an anxious moment. Both the Spreo were standing over it and I was much afraid that they were going t< kill it. My fears, however, were quite unwarranted, for I sooi discovered that the Spreos were feeding it even more assiduousl) than its own parents. The Spreos, usually gluttons for mealworms flew down to the young bird, holding the mealworms in their beaks at the same time giving vent to a loud twittering song. As soon as the young one opened its mouth, the mealworms was popped down its throat. It continued to thrive, and until it could fly I caught it

The Marquess of Tavistock--The Perfect Gentleman 107 > at dusk and put it in the nest. It then stayed there, or on a anch near by under shelter for the night. In colour now it is rather a rich olive brown without any distinctive arking, except for the black round the base of the beak, which rather ' sembles the male parent. The crest is large and erect, but identical colour with the rest of its plumage. It is quite tame and very lick and sprightly in its movements. I imagine now that it is six onths old that it has attained its full plumage.

A TALE OF A BARNARD'S PARRAKEET By the Marquess of Tavistock I have, this winter, added one more to the list of the Barnard's irrakeets of my acquaintance who have possessed abnormal tempera- 'snts. There was one that despised matrimony and devoted himself the unpleasant hobby of biting human noses ; another whose devotion his mate always turned to furious resentment if she left his company t a few days, even against her will; a third who hated all Broadtails espective of sex and loved all other Parrakeets, likewise irrespective sex. The Perfect Gentleman came to me last summer, but at st I did not realize he was in any way unusual. For several years lave had two hen Barnards for whom I have vainly tried to obtain ites. Barnard after Barnard has been sent on approval, only to rn out to be another female ; if the new one did happen to be a ile it was some wretched little aviary-bred degenerate of no possible ! e and whenever I got on the track of a really good cock, someone else d always snapped him up before me. Meanwhile the ladies, deprived the wholesome influence and discipline of the opposite sex, became )re and more uppish and unfeminine in their demeanour, a circum- mce which I foresaw would not add to their charms in the eyes of s husbands I hoped to provide for them, for if there is one thing mck Broadtail cannot stand it is a minx. Last spring I at length 'ured a good imported cock and paired him to one of the hens, and
algorithms.sectionHeader: 108 The Marquess of Tavistock--The Perfect Gentleman
algorithms.bodyText: later in the year I got hold of a second cock, who is the Perfect Gent) man, as a mate for the green-breasted hen whose portrait is to appe in the Magazine at a later date. In buying the Perfect Gentlem; from a fellow member I heartlessly arranged to have him separat from the wife with whom he had lived happily for some time--a dir trick for which my conscience has reproached me since I have cor to realize the sterling merits of his character. Many cock Barnar on being parted from their lawful spouses and introduced to a stran female of unattractive habits would have murdered her without lc of time, but that was not the way of the Perfect Gentleman. Althou" he did not pretend to be greatly impressed with his new companio he evidently came to the conclusion that there was some excu for the poor thing and he lived with her on terms of kindly tolerant Early in the winter I made arrangements for giving both cock Barnar their liberty. The feeding and management of my Parrakeets liberty is complicated by the fact that one set have to be shut up eve night to protect them from Owls and consequently must know of i feeding places except those inside an aviary, while the other set, whi* is composed of birds too powerful to need protection, or too spite! to be confined together at night, have to be trained to feed in plac where the seed is not visible to those that have not been taught whe to look for it. Most of the Parrakeets that roost at liberty are f inside specially constructed boxes and the second cock Barnard w educated to the use of the box, but I trained the Perfect Gentlema who was the first to be released, to enter the shelter of a small avia up the garden, the top of the flight of which is always open. So( after being set free the Perfect Gentleman paid a civil visit to I former companion, but instead of being pleased, the ill-natured hus flew at him and tried to attack him through the wire. He was n" at all afraid of her, but his feelings were naturally hurt. From th day on he has never settled on the top of her aviary ; it is undignifit to engage in a brawl with a female ; if she is rude to you, it is be to avoid her. The hen has long ago repented and calls seductive to him, but although he often looks at her from a distance he will n* come within 30 yards of her home. When the time came for tl release of the second cock I was a little anxious lest there should 1

The Marquess of Tavistock--The Perfect Gentleman 100 bad fight between the two males, for all normal Broadtails love row when they are in perfect health and spirits. A few hours after e second bird's release I noticed a cock Barnard in the small aviary > the garden already referred to. He was looking inside the little "or of the shelter where the Perfect Gentleman's food was kept. i getting near I was surprised to see that it was not the Perfect ?ntleman but the second cock and still more surprised to discover e Perfect Gentleman himself inside the shelter, feeding amicably :thin a foot or two of the other. Instead, therefore, of flying at him e moment he set eyes on him as any ordinary cock Barnard would tve done on meeting a strange male on his ground, he had civilly inducted the newcomer round the garden and asked him in to lunch 1 l the afternoon the Perfect Gentleman showed his companion round i.e aviary field, called on the second cock's wife, refused to be embroiled the fight which that lady tried hard to precipitate, wished the couple >od day and flew off to his tea. Some time later, it is true, there as a temporary break in the amicable relations between the two >cks, but the Perfect Gentleman was in no way to blame. He had tnply flown into a tree near the second cock and the latter was rude lough to make an unprovoked attack upon him. In the melee which isued the Perfect Gentleman proved himself by no means lacking in mrage and came off victorious, but he bore no ill-will, for on subsequent eetings with the second cock he was as good-natured as ever, clearly iving decided to let bygones be bygones. It might be imagined that ie Perfect Gentleman's good humour was simply due to the fact tat he was not in breeding condition, but nothing could be further om the case. I have never seen a more active and virile bird. All iy long he was whistling and tail-waggling and examining holes hich might do for a nest. And yet never once have I seen him tack another Parrakeet. Barrabands, Ping necks, Kings may settle ose to him, but however excited he may be there is no attempt to 'ive them off. On Christmas Day a tame cock Hooded Parrakeet caped from his aviary and flew up the garden. When I went to look r him I found that the Perfect Gentleman had taken him under s care. He looked on while I coaxed the Hooded into a cage, followed > back to the bird-room, came close to the cage when I put it down at
algorithms.sectionHeader: 110 The Marquess of Tavistock--The Perfect Gentleman
algorithms.bodyText: the bird-room door, expressed the hope that the Hooded was not tir* by his excursion, wdshed him goodnight and flew away. Not the least striking feature of the Perfect Gentleman's condu is his delicacy in never forcing himself unduly upon any of his neig' hours. He can be sociable without ever being a bore. A predecess> referred to at the beginning of this article, aroused one's astonishmei by the large-heartedness he displayed to all distant connexion but his best friend could not have denied that he w T as ill-mannerc and eccentric. He may have meant well, but it was not really nit of him to pester the old Masked Parrakeet with offers of half-digeste food, when it was obvious that " Georgie " feared and disliked tl entire feathered race and only cared for the company of human beiig and rats ; nor, if he had had any tact, would he have forced his societ on a Barraband at the precise moment when the latter was wooin! the lady of his choice ; nor if he had had any sense of humour, woid he have finally laid his heart at the feet of an enormous and elder! Amazon Parrot more than three times his size. Another remarkable fact about the Perfect Gentleman is thsl he never uses bad language. Every other robust male Broadta| I have come across has only to hear or see a rival, to start a rapij 'clicking noise with his beak, low, malevolent, and most expressive The Perfect Gentleman, living, as he does, in charity with all birds is blameless in thought and consequently in speech. . . . The shoij winter day is closing in and the birds rouse themselves to that las period of activity which precedes bedtime. A Bingneck, tilting slightl j from side to side, crosses the aviary field in swift, direct flight, hi! appearance evoking a chorus of excited cries from his companion below. Kings pass backwards and forwards with restless grace. The tw hen Barnards break out into loud, sweet whistling in which the Perfecl Gentleman joins. There is a pause and very far away there come the whistle of a fourth Barnard. The chorus is renewed and a fe^ seconds later the second cock swings into a tree above the aviaries The Perfect Gentleman flies to the same tree and settles a few yard! from the newcomer. He bow r s to him three times and addresses Bin in gentle chuckling tones. " I hope, sir," you can hear him say " that you have spent an agreeable day ? Well, it is getting late
algorithms.title: Avicultural Notes
algorithms.bodyText: > I will wish you goodnight." He leaves the tree and goes dipping :ross the garden to his roost. A few moments later the second )ck has taken a rather different line to his own chosen sleeping place, he Kings, all together this time, pass overhead once more ; there is Crimson-wing with them, but he leaves them and makes his way ) a tall cypress wdiile they keep on to the evergreen oaks behind the ouse. The Roseate Cockatoo, ceasing at length from his misdirected 'forts to destroy his mate's aviary and murder his son, launches imself into the air, circles round once and then heads for a garden alf a mile away, his screams growing fainter and fainter in the distance. # his night's repose is as peaceful as the Perfect Gentleman's it is great deal more than he deserves !

Authentic records of the length of life attained by birds in captivity re always of interest. Here is one concerning a Red-crested Cardinal hich belonged to Mr. Melville, of Sutton Bridge, who writes : "I ought it twenty-five years ago next May at Rosario, River Plate, and died on the 20th February, 1927." Mrs. Prestwick says that she hears that a blue Lovebird w r as exhibited t a recent show 7 at the Hague, the owner being, apparently, a German, an any member supply further particulars ? A scientific test of the value of ultra-violet rays to chickens is being arried out by Mr. Will Hooley, F.Z.S., the well-known poultry judge, t his research farm in Kent, w T here he is rearing one brood under rdinary glass and another under the new 7 glass which admits the ltra-violet rays of the sun. He is also making experiments in feeding hickens on foods that have been exposed to ultra-violet rays. We shall look forward w r ith much interest to the results obtained y Mr. Hooley because w T e believe that the application of these rays

Avicultural Notes to young animals of all kinds may have a most beneficial effect, an we know of more than one aviculturist who has installed the systen either by means of vita-glass or special electric lamps, into thei aviaries. Bone-weakness is very prevalent in young animals that are reare artificially, especially during the winter months in our dull climate and there is little doubt that this is accounted for to a large exter by the absence of ultra-violet rays. The application of artificial sunlight by means of electric lamp made with special glass that admits the ultra-violet rays to tropica sun-loving birds, should prove very beneficial, and the new Bir House at the Zoological Gardens is to have such an installation. For nearly six months a white Cockatoo has been living wild witi a flock of Rooks in a park near Reading, so the Daily Mail informs us It was formerly the pet of a lady living at Fleet in Hampshire, bu being frightened by a dog, flew away, and is now as shy as the Rook with which it lives quite happily. The Editor of British Birds desires to make it known that his reader have placed rings on the legs of over 170,000 wild birds during the las seventeen years. Each ring is stamped Witherby, High Holborn London, and bears a distinctive number. Any person finding a birc bearing such a ring is asked to communicate at once details of the number and the date and place of the finding or capture of the birc to the address named, in order that its migration and other histon may be recorded. This system of ringing young birds has proved of immense value ir adding to our knowledge of the migration of birds. Two Kittiwakc Gulls ringed as nestlings, one in 1923 and the other in 1924, in the Fame Islands, have been reported from Newfoundland in 1924 and Labrador 1925 respectively.

Mr. Shore-Baily, in the interesting diary of his successes and failures, lentions the fact, which is only too true, that members are slow to ;cord their failures, whereas these are often as helpful to fellow lemhers as are records of success, as they often show where a fault has 9 en, and what should be avoided. Members are urged to write full ^counts of the many incidents that happened in their aviaries and which lay be of interest to other members, and not to wait until they think ley are entitled to a medal before putting pen to paper. In a recent consignment of birds from Mexico, received by Messrs, hapman, were three species which are apparently new to aviculture, amely the Crested Grey Bird ( Ptilogonys cinereus), a bird superficially ,jsembling the Clarino, but more closely allied to the Waxwings ; the hick-billed Cardinal ( Pyrrhuloxia sinuata) : and the Mexican Barred 'artridge ( Philortyx fasciatus) all very desirable species from the vicultural point of view.

It is proposed that both the Society's medals, namely, that for the rst case of breeding in Great Britain and that for the first case in lurope, be awarded to :-- Captain H. S. Stokes, for breeding the Nyasa Lovebird ( Agapornis liance (1926, page 169). Mr. Herbert Bright, for breeding Grayson's Dove ( Zenaidura raysoni ) (1926, p. 223). It is proposed to award a medal to the following members for the rst case of breeding in Great Britain :-- Captain Reginald Waud, for breeding the Golden-crowned Conure ^onurus aureus) (1926, p. 327). Dr. Wildeboer, for breeding the Guiana Parrotlet ( Psittacula \0x25A0uianenses) (1926, p. 244). If any member or reader should know of a previous instance, the Ion. Secretary would be glad of information without delay.

Sir, --The smaller Rails have always attracted me, and I am glal to have had the chance of acquiring two species rare to Aviculture. Limnopardalis rytirhynchus is given in the B.M. Handlist as hailir from Brazil and Peru, though my four specimens are said to have coir from Guatemala. Length, 9 inches ; olive green above, deep slat grey below ; bill very long, pale green, spotted with red and bln at the base. The Black Rail of Africa, of which Mr. Gurney wrote last montl is very attractive on account of its small size (7 inches) and neat shap< I have two pairs and a baby, from Messrs. Gamage's collectior Although not an authority on the keeping of Rails, I believe the are pretty hardy, wanting a soft floor covering such as peat-mosjj plenty of branches to climb amongst, both indoors and out, and a sma pond fringed with coarse grass and rushes to induce them to nest which apparently they do readily. A coarse and not too ric! insectivorous food with boiled rice and potato and a little raw mea seems to satisfy them. H. S. Stokes.

Sir, --Some time last July, Messrs. Chapman brought over a larg consignment of these birds. Amongst them were a number havin a good deal of black on the face and throat. Our Editor in the Augus issue of the Magazine suggested that these were wild-bred hybrids between the Nyasa and Black-cheeked Lovebirds. In order to tes this theory I procured two pairs of the darkest-faced birds I could find: These have nested several times but unfortunately no young have beer} reared, but strange to say they have now entirely lost the black oi| the face and could not be distinguished from birds of the normal colour! Does not this do aw T ay wuth the hybrid theory ? Wm. Shore-Baily. [These dark-faced birds are rather puzzling. I have seen several young aviary-bred Nyasa Lovebirds and some show no dark coloui
algorithms.figure: Correspondence
algorithms.bodyText: t the cheeks, while others are nearly as dark as a hybrid which \ Whitley bred and exhibited at the recent Crystal Palace Show. The fact would seem to be that the Black-cheeked and Nyasa \0x25A0vebird have comparatively recently sprung from a common ancestor d have barely arrived at the stage when they can be regarded as ;tinct species ; at any rate one still occasionally exhibits in its young ige traces of a character w r hich, in the adult stage, is only present the other. --Ed.]

Sir,' --Among the birds I have kept at liberty this winter is a young Je King Parrakeet in immature plumage. As his companions of } same species are adult and much taken up with matrimonial airs, he has associated a good deal wflth a Barraband, a playful ungster with tastes similar to his own. Lately he has started to itate perfectly the calls of the Barraband. Most of the larger rrakeets possess to a greater or lesser degree the faculty of mimicry, t it is interesting that the King should have acquired another - iguage while living at complete liberty wdth others of his own kind. Tavistock.

Sir, --With reference to Lord Tavistock's letter in the February mber of the Magazine, suggesting feeding delicate birds like Bee- pers throughout the winter on cluster flies. I have used these flies years for certain birds, with, I am sure, most beneficial results : 're is a quick and noticeable result in the condition of my Crimson- ;asted Shrikes, to give only one example, when they have them. Lord Tavistock says, the flies are very easily captured when they ier the house in the autumn, which in my case they do in swarms, 1 I easily keep them alive in the small wire meat safes, which one !8 everywhere abroad; the difficulty of giving them sufficient isture I get over by placing a small sponge in a saucer, which it st exactly fit, of water. In this way the flies cannot drown themselves 1 obtain all the moisture they need. G. H. Gurney.

algorithms.listItem: urth Series. --Vol. V.--No. 5 .--All rights reserved. MAY, 1927. OWLS * By Miss E. F. Chawner Few people keep Owls or take any interest in them, blit those who
algorithms.bodyText: find them so charming that they can only marvel at the indifference the rest. When it is realized that all Owls are beautiful, many quite rdy when once acclimatized, long-lived, and easily kept in health d perfect plumage, quickly become tame, and are often warmly ;ached to their keepers, their many merits should establish them tnly in the affections of bird lovers. As a rule their requirements are simple. My Owl's aviaries are merely oden structures of various sizes with wire-netting fronts. The small icies have their houses wired underneath as well, for fear of rats, stump or two and some perches of various sizes with the bark on are that is necessary inside with a barrel or box in the darkest corner, il the floors are thickly strewn with coarse gritty gravel. Owls need pty of room if they are to do themselves justice. An ideal position is |e facing south, under large deciduous trees. During summer the es provide the necessary shade, and when the leaves are off the birds ve the benefit of any sun which may be granted us, and are protected m north and easterly winds. If they have a dry abode and are safe m draughts (this is very important) they do not mind cold weather long as their food is not frozen. They should be given a bath, for

though certain species have no use for water in any form, most of then especially the Wood Owls and Pigmies, are great bathers. The staple food of all my Owls is rabbit, preferably wild ; they thru- on it and do not seem to tire of it ; but of course they do better if tliei food can be varied. Large species thoroughly enjoy a plump rat ncr and then ; birds, drowned kittens, and mice are appreciated by thei all, though I have found that they soon tire of mice if they are supplie in quantity, but as a titbit now and then they are eagerly taker Small Owls appear to be largely insectivorous. Pigmy and Scops Owl are mostly fond of cockchafers, though there are exceptions. My he White-faced Scops (Scops leucotis) will catch and eat as man cockchafers as are turned into her aviary, but the male bird will nc touch them. I have several times induced a sick bird to feed by givin it cockchafer larvae, hand-feeding and even cramming it until it wa strong enough to feed itself. Owls are not often on the sick list when they are properly house and fed, but care must be taken until they are acclimatized. Tropics or southern species are much easier to manage than Arctic or Norther kinds, the latter being very susceptible to cold and damp. The hens ai rather subject to egg-binding after they have been some years in cor finement. The best, if not the only remedy, is heat. All kinds nun have fur or feather in some shape. Owls pair for life, and are usuall very faithful and affectionate. They begin to take an interest in eac other as soon as the moult is over, and by early spring are generall ready to go to nest. Eagle Owls nest in a scrape made by the male bir on the ground ; Burrowing Owls either tunnel into the earth for then selves or take possession of and adapt some other creature's burrov Wood Owls like hollows in trees, as do also certain Scops and Pigm Owls. Some kinds like a tree from which the top has been blown of and nest on the stump. The male bird digs the scrape or burrow o carpenters at the chosen hollow, and when the hen is incubating o has young it is his business to cater for the family while she stays an guards her eggs or young. It is pretty to see the male return with hi prey and alight by the nest and give his mate what he has brought She feeds the young while he watches with the utmost pride and delight Incubation lasts four weeks, and the young are usually white or gre;

Jen first hatched ; some resemble their parents as soon as their I thers have grown, others have an intermediate plumage which often ers considerably from that of the adult, which they do not attain until j second moult. The larger kinds do not breed until they are three years nore old ; they lay two eggs in a clutch, and may have two to three tches in a season. Incubation starts as soon as the first egg is laid, l with some species the second clutch and even the third may be laid ore the first brood has left the nest, so that it may contain at one e fledgelings, newly hatched young, and fresh eggs. Pigmy and >ps Owls often lay three or more eggs in a clutch. In confinement Owls usually seem willing to go to nest, but the eggs often infertile ; in all probability one great cause of this is want of , ;rcise, for Owls are mostly rather sedentary birds, unless spurred by s necessity of hunting for food, which does not exist in an aviary, other cause may be inbreeding ; the pairs which come over are quently taken from the same nest, and unless a sufficient mber arrive at once to ensure a thorough shuffling, in all probability )ther and sister will be sold together and very few fertile eggs will ult from such a union. If they do hatch the young Owls must be b to themselves as much as possible ; the less they are looked at the ter. Interference generally results in the young being devoured their parents. When all goes well, the young remain in the nest until well feathered, lally about a month ; for the first week or ten days the mother broods jim continually and scarcely leaves the nest at all, unless to defend inn against some real or fancied enemy, for this she will do to the nost of her power, choosing death rather than desert her offspring, r While they have young to feed, the old birds live very sparingly, t make up for it during the autumn when they fatten themselves in preparation for cold weather. European Eagle Owl (Bubo maximus), found throughout the mntainous districts of Europe. Very large fine-looking birds, with lg ear-tufts, feathered legs, and beautifully variegated and rmiculated plumage in shades of brown, black, and tawny, with a lite patch under the chin. Their irides are orange. Their call is a , e, bell-like single hoot from the male, usually answered by his mate

with a double hoot pitched much higher. These Owls are very lonr lived if properly treated. They have beeu bred ; they are all the bette for a fast day once a week ; quite hardy and very fond of bathim; They nest in a scrape prepared by the male, the clutch consists of tw large round white eggs ; incubation lasts four weeks. The youn have no intermediate plumage. The Virginian Eagle Owl (B. virginianus and B. articus), fror South and North America, which are smaller and differ slightly togethe with B. ascalephus from North Africa, are generally imported, as ar also the following : B. bengalensis, from India ; B. capensis, fron South Africa ; B. cinerescens, from West and East Africa ; B. lacteus from South Africa ; B. blakistoni , from Japan. The Spotted Eagle Owl ( Bubo maculatus), from South Africa, i; the smallest Eagle Owl; a handsome bird, particularly the form wind is grey, thickly spotted all over with black. There is also a browr variety, in which the spots are not as plentiful nor so distinct looking The ear tufts are short and broad, beak strong and black, eyes bright buttercup yellow, legs covered with grey down, claws black. Quit( hardy, it is not very particular as to diet and not a very large feeder It nests in a scrape on the ground, and lays two eggs to the clutch Its note is a soft hoot, almost a coo. It is fond of bathing. Fraser's Eagle Owl (Bubo poensis), from West Africa. A very beautiful and distinct species, not often imported. In the intermediate stage has a white downy head and breast, the back fawn colour mixed with white, and black barred shoulders. Wing-coverts fawn. The flights and tail yellow-barred black. Adult plumage : Head, wings, tail, and back tawny yellow, barred with black, long ear-tufts of the same ; breast white, finely barred with black ; legs the same ; claws white ; eyes large and full, deep soft black, fringed with very long lashes. Length when full-grown about 17 to 20 inches. It is not very hardy, and requires a sheltered aviary with protection from cold in winter. Its diet should consist of rabbits, young rats, mice, etc. It is very fond of bathing. If kindly treated it becomes very tame, and fond of its owner, but is capable of strong and lasting dislikes, and is jealous of other birds. It likes to have its head scratched like a Parrot. The two white eggs are laid in a scrape on the ground. Among sand or dried

algorithms.bodyText: |ss a sitting bird would be practically invisible. The call is a rather ble hoot. The Scops ( Otus ) are miniature Eagle Owls, possessing longer wings. ;ey are charming little birds, with beautiful plumage shading into ^;ry tone of brown, grey, and black, and are easily kept and bred in ifinement. They are largely insectivorous. They are found all over * world, save in Oceania. The plumage of many species varies between lividuals. The Common Scops ( Otus scops), native of Europe, is too well known need description. It is enough to say that owing to its small size 1 docility it is a favourite cage bird. We have only space to imerate the various species of Scops which figure from time to time our aviaries : 0 . pennatus, from India ; 0. semitorques, from Japan ; bakkamoena, from India, and its varieties lettia, from China, and ipiji, from Indo-China and the Malay States ; 0 . asio, from North nerica. White-eared Aerican Scops (0. leucotis). These beautiful little *ds are not quite hardy and cannot stand damp cold, but thrive rfectly in an enclosed unheated aviary. They are about the size of a ng Thrush, have large faces, white cheeks, and grey beaks very thickly vered with long white hair, hiding the nostrils ; crown of the head ij speckled and vermiculated with black and a black outline round 3 face. The eyes are large, glowing copper. The breast is streaked 3.y on white, legs white, feet large, lead coloured, back and wings eaked and mottled grey and black. The general effect is singularly autiful and rich. They have the curious habit of bowing rapidly my times in succession while uttering a continuous husky chattering ind, this appears to denote pleasure, and is used to greet friends, 3 offer of food, or merely in answer to a word in passing. The breeding il is a soft grunting coo, and the anger note a savage growl. They end most of the day dozing on a high perch, and if disturbed open eir wonderful eyes to the fullest extent and lunge forward at the emy with open beaks, at the same time swearing like an angry cat* can easily be guessed that a squirrel or any other enemy coming ddenly upon them in a tree would get the fright of its life when con- )nted with such threatening gestures.

Probably they nest in a state of nature on a lofty tree whose t( has been blown off, but in my aviary they adopted an enamelled ir< pie-dish filled with sawdust, laid two eggs, one of which proved addle and reared a young bird. Incubation lasted a month, during which t male collected and carried food to his mate. When the young hatch the hen was very fierce, and flew straight for my face when I fed hi The nestling was covered with greyish white down, and remained the dish for four weeks, by which time it was well feathered. Its c. for food was a low hissing croak, and it did not bow like its parei until after it could feed itself and was quite independent. Its pluma was like its mother's ; the cheeks were grey instead of white, the ba darker and breast greyer. The ear-tufts did not show until it was qu well feathered everywhere else. These Scops never bathe nor apparently do they drink. I have nei seen them dust, but they are always snowy white and speckless. Li all of that genus they are enormous feeders, and cannot fast like otl Owls. They cannot digest rats or very old rabbit, are fond of bir< mice, which last they usually swallow whole, and field voles, also you kittens. They are not often imported. Cyprean Scops (0. cypreus). These lovely little birds are pecul to Cyprus, and are strictly protected. My pair were hand-reared a brought over by the late Major Horsburgh ; I have never heard of a others being imported. Their plumage is full and very soft, all shades soft grey, beautifully mingled until they look like a piece of lichem bark; eyes black. They are tiny creatures. My pair were very tame a accustomed to be hand fed ; they had very large appetites, w particularly fond of mealworms and cockchafer-grubs, and would gi down seven or eight full-grown ones at a meal--no small feat for si tiny birds. They also had mice, Sparrows, or chopped-up rabbit, 1 preferred the two former. They proved fairly hardy, and came saf through the winter in a sheltered aviary with a box to retire into in 1 weather. They were very silent, but occasionally uttered a low cr( ' when hungry. They bathed occasionally. The Wood Owls ( Asio ) are of medium size, have well-develo] facial disks, and long ear-tufts. The Long-eared Owl (Asio otus). This very handsome bird is

Lcommon in fir-woods in England. It is rather smaller than the iwnv Owl, and more elegantly shaped. Its face is round and namented, with two long erect ear-tufts. The eyes are orange. The ound colour of its plumage is brown, but it is beautifully streaked and ottled in the most protective style, so that when it sits motionless *essed close up against a fir-tree trunk with its eyes closed it is ,:ceedingly difficult to discern even if the observer is looking directly it. It nests in hollow trees ; there are usually two young in a brood, hunts chiefly by night, and is a friend to the farmer, since it destroys great many mice and rats. It is vociferous, and has a variety of notes, reams, mews, and other noises. It does well in confinement. The Short-eared Owl (A. accipilrinus) is another European )ecies, it frequents marshes and moors, and nests on the ground. It is ightly larger than the above, and carries short thick ear-tufts. The 'umage is rusty brown, mottled with dark brown. Eyes yellow. It idures confinement well. The Brazilian Long-eared Owl (Asio clamator) has only lately een imported. It is larger than the English kind, and very handsome, robably it has much the same habits in its natural state ; in con- nement it is fairly docile and lives well; is fond of bathing. Is drowsy y day, and usually feeds at dusk ; is fond of rats, mice, and birds, ut will eat rabbit. The back and long wings, which project beyond le tail, are yellowish brown mottled and vermiculated with pale black, he belly rather bright buff, also the legs and feathered feet; toes long nd slender, claws black. The breast is yellowish, with a large dark entre to each feather. When young the facial markings are very ,bribing ; the head is buff, bright chestnut, with a faint black spot ist over the eyes ; cheeks darker, but still bright chestnut; a broad 'hite stripe forms a St. Andrew's Cross between the eyes down to the lack beak ; chin white, with a few black spots ; the whole enclosed y a thin black line ; ear-tufts very long ; eyes black. In voice and abits it is very much like the English Long-eared Owl. Is quite hardy, nd thrives on the same food. The Brazilian Short-eared Owl (Asio stygius), from Brazil, is arely imported. It is an exceptionally beautiful bird of very elegant hape, the size is about the same as a Barn Owl. Its colour is golden-

brown, with a dark centre to each feather. Ear-tufts short and thic face very round, eyes black with a bright golden ring. Mine was a greed rather lazy bird, and was all the better for a weekly fast. It bath( occasionally, and was crepuscular in its habits. Its call was a shar rather melodious " wow ", several times repeated. It never becan really tame. A. grammicus, a closely allied species, has been brought over. The African Swamp Owl (Asio nisuella), from North Africa ar South Spain. Quite a number were imported by the late Mr. Hamh in 1921. They varied very much in character ; a female which I boug] has never become at all tame or tractable, but a young male was ; tame as any bird in my collection, and very playful. It is dark chocola brown, with dark brown eyes. Some have short ear-tufts, which usual lie flat but can be erected. The beak and claws are black. It is qui hardy and lives well on rabbit with an occasional bird or mouse. T1 note is a harsh loud squawk or bark, frequently repeated. It crepuscular. The Fishing Eagle Owls ( Ketupa ), with long ear-tufts, are to 1 found in Asia and the adjacent islands. They may be known by the long and very powerful, almost bare, legs. They live near watercours and feed on fish, but in captivity they will thrive on meat, and are lon : lived. From time to time K. ceylonensis has been imported. It is four from Palestine to Indo-China ; also K. ketupa indigenous to the Mala Peninsula and the Sondian Isles. The Scotopelia only differ from the above in not having ear-tuft They are natives of Africa. S. peli and S. oustaleti have been imported The birds of the genus Huhua differ from those of Bubo in haviu transverse stripes across their breasts. They are very handsome, ar four species have been imported. H. shelleyi from the Gold Coast H. nipalensis from the Himalayas ; H. orientalis from Malay ; an H. pcensis from West Africa. The Snowy Owl ( Nyctea nyctea ) is a magnificent Arctic Eag Owl without ear-tufts, having white plumage when full adult, an more or less streaked and spotted with ashy brown while immaturi It inhabits the Arctic regions and the Himalayas. It is sometimes m(;

The Spectacled Owl (Pulsatrix perspicillata), from South America, also known as the Downy Owl, and is a very distinct and handsome ecies. It is perhaps the most easily tamed of all Owls, being very id of having its head and neck scratched like a Parrot. This arming bird is larger than the Tawny Owl, has a black face with white spectacles " round the bright yellow eyes, and a white beak thickly nged with hair. The top of the head and back are brownish black, tl and wings brownish black faintly barred with grey ; breast, belly, d legs bright tan, claws black. It has a faint white half-circle round e front of the throat. Perfectly hardy and easily kept in health, ad of bathing. Nests in hollow trees. The call of the male in the eeding season is a kind of rattle, rather like a miniature machine- n, at other times a gruff sort of growl, and a gentle twitter when eeting its friends. Young birds have the top of the head white and a black mask over e face, the breast much paler, and the back and wings brownish intly barred. They should be fed like the foregoing. All too rarely sported. Anyone fortunate enough to own one of these delightful rds should house it where it can enjoy human society, as it soon opes when it is left to itself. The genera Ninox and Sceloglaux form a group of small Owls which e probably widely spread over Asia and Oceania. They do very well confinement, and some of them, especially the Australian species, <ve been imported from time to time. The Marbled Owl ( Ninox ocellata), from West Australia, is now ry rarely imported. It is a pretty little bird, about the same size as "e Little Owl, gentle and confiding in an aviary. The plumage is 11 and very soft, general colour dusky brown, breast lighter, and heaked with warm brown. The wing-coverts and the scapulars are * marbled '' with roun^l wdiite spots ; the eyes are greyish but sometimes 'aen the light catches the pupils they look as red as rubies. A dark -tch just behind the eyes adds very much to their beauty. They are nd of cockchafers and mealworms, and will pick up and eat large aootk-skinned caterpillars and those large brown spiders which live

among rubbish. They nest in hollows and lay three to four rather lar< white eggs. Their call is a double hoot, wdiich sounds very much lil a Cuckoo gone flat. They are great bathers, and should be fed like tlj Tawny Owls with the addition of insects when obtainable. My coo bird is 17 years old this summer. As far as I know, the other species hitherto imported are N. boobon and N. connivens, from Australia ; N. novai zeaJandice and Sceloglai albifacies from New Zealand. The Tawny Owl ( Strix aluco ) is a widely spread, very well-know bird commonly distributed throughout England and Europe. It round-headed, the plumage very full and soft. Its colouring is shades < brown and tawny, breast paler, all finely mottled and vermiculated on the wdngs a series of large, cream-coloured, or white spots. Ey< black, beak greyish or horn-coloured, legs feathered with grey dowj Call a loud ringing hoot several times repeated, and a sharp " kiwicl kiwick ". A fine, strongly flying bird, which hunts chiefly by nigh Hand-reared specimens become very tame, and can be allowed the liberty at night, returning to their aviary for the day. They nest i hollow trees or in barrel-shaped boxes, have from two to four your in a brood, and nest twice in the year. They are great bathers, an perfectly hardy. Their food in confinement should be fur or feather, bi they are not dainty. Sharpe's Wood Owl ( Strix nuchale), from West Africa. Anoth< very handsome species, a typical Wood Owl, round headed, with blac eyes and cinnamon coloured plumage. Its habits and requirements ai similar to the Tawny Owl. It is not often imported, but appears to 1 quite hardy and becomes very tame. It is a size larger than th Tawny Owl. S. woodfordi, an allied species from East Africa, has also bee imported, as have the following : S. uralensis, from Siberia and Russia

Besides these, the following have lived in confinement in Europe Gisella harrisi, from Colombia ; Nyclaia tengmalmi, Northern Europ and Asia ; N. acadica, N. America ; Surnia ulula, Europe; #

Acommon speciesontlieContinent, is introduced into England by the late Lord Lilford, and has become turalized. It is gradually spreading all over the country and has v^en rise to much controversy, many people considering it a dangerous st, others protesting that it destroys more vermin than game, and ould therefore be protected. It is a small bird, rather larger than a irush, grey, thickly speckled with white ; its eyes are round and iring, rather pale yellow, eyelids white. It is very active, bobbing up d down in a ludicrous manner when it sees anyone approaching. It mts by day and destroys a great many birds as well as mice and ;etles. It nests in holes and there may be three or four eggs to the atch. It has a variety of calls, ranging from chuckles to loud shrieks, terspersed with cat-like mewing. It has been bred in confinement, n allied species from India [A. hramah) has likewise been imported. Burrowing Owls (Speotyto cunicularia), South America, are : *casionally imported and make amusing pets. Their habits are well lown from many illustrations and articles. In America they share arrows with " Prairie Dogs " and (possibly) rattle-snakes, and bob a and down excitedly at the approach of a stranger. They are about le size of Athene noctua , but stand higher, being longer in the leg. heir heads and backs are speckled brown, the wings brown barred ith white, as is also the tail. Under parts and legs pure snowy white, j i spite of their burrowing habits. The young have brown heads without 1 ay markings. The eyes are bright yellow, beak pale. Their call is a arsh croak, but if disturbed or alarmed they spread their wings and i ireech loudly for several minutes on end. They also " swear ", which Hinds like a tap being suddenly turned on. They run very swiftly, [y pair constructed a burrow in their aviary but did not go to any j. feat depth, and the soil fell in several times until I put a drain-pipe j Lside the burrow. They worked hard at deepening and enlarging it, ad finally started nesting. To my regret the hen died egg-bound ith her third eg". The cock lived many years longer, but I was unable ) get another mate for him. They are quite hardy, and do well on ibbit and other fur and feather. None have recently been imported

to my knowledge. They have been bred in confinement. An allie species inhabiting California and Central America (S. hypogcea) has bee imported. The Sparrow Owls ( Glaucidium ) are tiny birds scarcely larger tha a Sparrow. The Passerine Owl (G . passerinum). Mountains of Europ. particularly Switzerland. They have no ear-tufts and are much moi diurnal and active than the somewhat lethargic Scops. They are grei bathers, very quick in all their movements, eaten up with curiosik and interested in all that goes on. They have rather long tails, whic they wag from side to side, while they bob up and down with excite chirps. Their eyes are light yellow, head and back dark brown thick] speckled with lighter spots and marks, wings brown with a reddis tinge on the flights, with paler bars, tail the same ; the feet are heavil feathered, claws black. The eyes are ringed with pale grey and the ey< brows and facial disk are white, as is the beak. Breast light grey, wit dark streaks. They need a good deal of exercise, and should be give a larger aviary than their diminutive size would indicate. They ai hardy in the South of England. They should have Sparrows and mice. Mexican Pigmy Owl (G . Jisheri), habitat Mexico. About tt same size as the last, and with much the same habits and colourin; but closer feathered. A bold, fierce little creature with bright yello eyes. On the back of the head, which is brown with small speckles, has a curious grey-brown crescent-shaped mark. The unpaired mai during the breeding season utters a metallic clinking cry, like the soun of a hammer on metal, nine or ten times repeated. It was very rarel imported, but last year several pairs came over. Mine went to nest i a wooden nest-box, and sat steadily for four weeks, but either the eg# were clear or went bad, as thev did not hatch and the birds did awa with them when they had sat their full time. Food and treatment shoul be the same as for the Sparrow Owls. Jardines' Pigmy Owl (G. jardinii), Venezuela and Colombi: This bird also much resembles the last named, but the colour of tb wings and tail is more rufous. It requires the same treatment and foot Mine went to nest in a small box and reared two young, a third vanishin when about two days' old. The nestlings are tiny creatures, covere

When fledged the young are ler copies of their parents, the white less pure, and the brown not warm in tint. Their call is a little trilling twitter. Both of mine ( ed to grow up. Besides the above, the following species have been imported : ' plialoenoides, from Trinidad, and G. perlatum, from South Africa. Photodilus badius . which inhabits the Himalayas, is a small brown d, which forms a link between the preceding groups and the Barn Ids. It has been brought over alive. The Barn Owls ( Tyto ) differ from all other birds of prey in their itomy. They chiefly inhabit barns, belfries, or caves in cliffs, and are *eedingly useful in destroying rats and mice. They are to be met with over the world. The Barn Owl {Tyto alba ) is a very beautiful bird, having yellowish ray plumage mingled with silvery grey, and lightly marked with all black spots. The under parts and breast are snowy white. The ial disk is well developed, the eyes are black and deep-set; the beak ;ite and partly covered with a thick fringe of hair, legs rather long and 3ck-kneed covered wdth white down, claws black. It is entirely iturnal and therefore not very interesting in an aviary. It is mailer, closer feathered bird than the Tawny. It nests in a barn or low tree, and it is not uncommon to find fresh eggs in the nest at the ine time as young birds. Barn Owls do not bathe and appear not drink often. They utter a loud screech and sometimes a hissing 1. They will eat rabbits, rats, and mice, etc., and are quite hardy. |ey have been bred in confinement. These are most useful birds to mers and countrymen, as they destroy enormous numbers of rats 1 mice, and are too nocturnal to take chickens or young birds, ich are all under cover by the time the Owls start hunting. Other species which have been imported are : T. pratincola , North lerica ; T. delicatula, Australia ; T. punctatissima, Galapagos inds ; T. capensis, South Africa, and T. arfaki , from New Guinea.
algorithms.sectionHeader: 130 W. Shore-Baily--Some Bare Mexican Birds SOME RARE MEXICAN BIRDS By W. Shore-Baily
algorithms.bodyText: Some time last November Mr. J. Bruce Chapman, to whom v aviculturists owe so much, for his enterprise in bringing over so man rare birds from all parts of the world, imported a fine consignment fro 1 the port of Vera Cruz in Mexico. Amongst these were about a dozcj of the little Lark Sparrow (Chondestes grammacus strigatus), which i secured. This little bird has the upper parts brownish grey, streakc with blackish and the under parts white, the head prettily striped wit grey, white, and chestnut. Its habitat is California and Westeij America, but it apparently finds its way also into Mexico, unle my birds should prove to be a sub-species resident there. Some of m specimens have the throat and breast washed wdth yellow. I notice when I bought them that some of them had a small spot of yellow on til throat, and thought that these would be the males, but on dissectic this has proved not to be the case. I have examined all the skins: the British Museum and none of them show any trace of yellow, an I cannot recollect ever having seen any with this marking in Californi where they were quite common. I am hoping to get them to brec I this year, and may then be able to find out something more about therj Another interesting bird was the Dickcissel (Spiza americana) < Black-throated Bunting. This is a pretty bird, and hardy. The upp parts are mixed grey, browm, and black ; chin and throat white, wil a black patch in centre ; breast bright yellow. I secured two or tlm specimens, but I am afraid all males, and these are now in full son This species was bred by Mr. Teschemaker a good many years agoj In this consignment were quite a lot of Thrushes, of which I bougli about a dozen. I found on getting them home that there were thro different species, but it took some time to separate them, as the were in such rough condition, some of them being almost denuded j| feathers through fighting. The most interesting was a Wood Thru* (Hylocichla meistelina). This little Thrush is very like our own bir- but is not much more than half the size. It is a native of the L.SA migrating to Mexico in the winter. I think that my bird must be hen, as it has made no attempt at singing yet. Another Thrush turne
