algorithms.bodyText: ts olivaceous brown, breast and abdomen greyish buff, throat ite, chin striped with black ; as the white on the throat extends ow the stripes, it gives the bird the appearance of carrying a white lar, which makes it look not unlike our Ring Ouzel. It is impossible sex the five birds that have survived, but I am hoping that I shall 1 a true pair amongst them. Early in January Mr. Chapman had another important con- tinent of Mexican birds, amongst them being, I think, several cies new to aviculture. The most interesting is the Rose-breasted 'dinal, a bird that I am inclined to think will be found to be a new *cies. These birds are about the same size as the Common Cardinal, jb are totally unlike them in colour. They differ in having the crest (f, a patch on the cheeks buff, a patch under the black throat yellow, I the abdomen pink. About eighty came over, besides a lot of the mmon Cardinals, including a good many hens, but as the latter had p been separated from each other, it was impossible to say to which the two species these belonged. It has been suggested by some lithologists that these birds are merely immature specimens of the mmon Cardinal, but I cannot believe this, as this latter bird has bred more than one occasion in this country and the young are said to be e the hen. It is my belief that the birds are adults, and this seems be borne out by the fact that a bird imported last year has not changed our. However, Mr. Chapman is taking steps to bring over some more ;h the females, and then we shall have a chance of breeding them 1 learning something more about them. In the meantime, they appear be lacking a scientific name. 1 Another interesting importation was it of the Thick-billed Cardinal, and I secured a true pair of these, eir scientific name is Pyrrhuloxia sinuata sinuata. They appear to very closely allied to the Cardinals. Their colour is dark grey, with ed crest and tail, under parts bufhsh pink or red, the hen not so ght in these parts. Their most curious feature is the beak, which is y short and thick, like that of the Bullfinch, hence one of the trivial f 1 A coloured illustration of this " spoit" of the Virginian Cardinal appeared his Magazine for December, 1924.--Ed.]

W. Shore-Baily--Some Bare Mexican Birds names--the Bullfinch Cardinal. This bird is found in Texas and Arizor as well as in Mexico, and its habits seem to be very similar to those the Red Cardinal. They appear to have a rather peculiar body scei similar to what one finds in the Petrels. I do not know whether this h been previously noted. I also secured half a dozen specimens of t Californian Scarlet Tanager, which differs considerably from t common Scarlet Tanager, more usually seen in this country. The co has the back, shoulders, wings, and tail more or less striated wij buffish yellow, head and throat crimson, under parts yellowh Female olive green, under parts yellow, two bands of dirty white acre! the wings. This bird is common on the wooded slopes of the Sierras I California, and presumably migrates to Mexico, unless it is resident the also. I do not think that it has yet been bred here in captivity. Anoth purchase was a pair of small Hangnests ( Icterus spurius), about the size our Brambling. These are mostly black and yellow, but are not yet 1 full colour, so am unable to describe them. They appear to be go*! aviary birds, as they partake freely of Thrush food, and do not seem J require much fruit, so should be easy to care for. My last acquisiti* was a pair of small black and yellow Siskins ( Chrysomitris tristri They are most charming little birds, black on top and bright yelk | underneath, with a white spectrum on the wing. I fear that they a rather delicate, but if they live shall hope to breed them. 1 I doij think that any of the birds mentioned in these notes have been br here, so I am looking forward to an interesting season in my aviari this year. Just as I had finished writing these notes I recollected one speci that I had not mentioned, and that a not unimportant one, the Mexico Barred Partridge ( Philortyx fasciatus). This is a small bird, about t size of the Scaly Quail ( Callipepla squamata ), and its habits appe similar, as it is fond of roosting in trees, like all the Crested Qua I don't know whether I have secured a true pair, as the sexes appe | to be alike. Time alone will show. P An excellent coloured plate of the American Siskin appeared in Vol. page 125 (June 1889).--Ed.

algorithms.bodyText: Now that the breeding season is once more upon us, some notes ;he management and breeding of Lovebirds may not be out of place. i genus Agapornis belongs to the sub-family Palseornithinae, and as as is known at present consists of ten members : (1) the Madagascar drey-headed (A. ctina) ; (2) the Abyssinian (A. taranta) ; (3) the l-faced (A. pullaria) ; (4) the Rosy-faced or Peach-faced (A. icollis ) ; (5) the Black-cheeked (A. nigrigenis ) ; (6) the Nyasa (A. mice) ; (7) Fischer's (A. fischeri) ; (8) the Masked (A. personata); Swinderen's (A. swindereniana) ; (10) the Black-collared zenkeri). he first six are all well known ; Fischeri and the Masked are jeedingly rare and swindereniana and zenkeri have not yet reached country alive. The genus is confined to the continent of Africa, and w adjacent islands. Once acclimatized, they are all very hardy, and be kept in unheated outdoor aviaries throughout the year with ty, provided they have good, dry, draught-proof shelters. They simple feeders, and no elaborate mixtures are needed ; most are shed with canary seed and white millet, with the addition of a little te sunflower and a few good oats, millet sprays, and seeding grasses very acceptable ; hemp should be avoided, except sparingly in 7 cold weather, as it appears to make them fat and sluggish. Fruit 11 kinds is despised by most, a few, however, will eat apple and pear linute quantities ; some will eat lettuce with apparent relish. When hble they should be kept in aviaries, as their chief charm lies in the they climb and scramble about, besides which their full beauty ily seen wdien in flight. In cages they are apt to mope at their loss berty and become dull and listless, sitting side by side and taking j little interest in life in general, only moving to visit the seed and er-pots. If, however, no other accommodation is available, and it is red to keep a pair of Lovebirds, possibly Red-faced are the most able, being the least active of the group ; Mr. W. T. Catleugh Hi a hen of this species in a cage for nearly ten years, and several for at six years, so it will be seen that pullaria can be successfully kept

algorithms.bodyText: The Madagascar or Grey-headed Lovebird is probably the best lown of the group, having been imported in enormous numbers for me years. No detailed description of this species is needed : it will tffice to say that the cock is distinguished from the hen in having the hole of the head, neck, and upper breast grey, and under wing-coverts ack, whereas the hen has the head and under wing-coverts green, he first importation was in 1860, and a pair was on view at the London lological Gardens in that year. They are quite unsuitable for cage life id when thus kept, as a rule, crouch in a corner and utter harsh olding notes whenever anyone approaches. In an aviary they remain *ry timid, and seldom get really tame. Madagascars are very spiteful ith weaker birds, especially when thinking of nesting, the hens more so lan the cocks. They associate well with Budgerigars and Passerine arrotlets, with only occasional sparring. They do best in an aviary y themselves, however, otherwise in mixed company, especially if ley are at all crowded, they are liable to play at nesting. In the wild ate they associate in large flocks, often as many as a hundred together, id sometimes do considerable damage to the rice crops. The nest is mstructed in a hole in a tree, being completely lined with pliant strips ' bark, carried under the upper tail-coverts ; this method of carrying laterial is usually adopted in captivity, but some carry pieces of bark, dinters of wood, fragments of millet sprays and strips of leaves in their saks. The hen alone usually cuts the bark, etc., and carries it to the est, the cock meanwhile keeping guard. A nest-box similar to the one lustrated is usually accepted by this species, although some shun boxes f any kind, and lay their eggs anywhere but in the proper place, irs. Charrington had a pair some years ago that burrowed under a tub, )ntaining a box-tree, in an aviary where they constructed a nest in the ( 3ual manner, on the ground ; just a slight hollow filled with cuttings : leaf. The first nest contained clear eggs; they nested again, lit with the same result. The eggs of Madagascars vary considerably i size, the average being 18'4 mm. by 13'8 mm., and the number from >ur to six or even more. Incubation seems to take nineteen to tw T enty ays, the hen alone doing this, the cock feeding her. The cocks can be icked out in nesting plumage, as their heads are a mixture of greyish
algorithms.page: 136 Joseph Appleby--Notes from a Lancashire Aviary
algorithms.bodyText: green and green. On leaving the nest the young cocks have darke beaks than the parent birds, the hood is apparent, but not very defined Fully adult plumage is donned at the first moult. The first to be success ful in breeding this species in Great Britain was F. W. Oates, who ha< four young reared in 1900. In this case the hard-worked hen wa deserted by the cock for a Passerine Parrotlet, but she managed to rea the brood alone nevertheless. Amongst others to be successful wit) this Lovebird may be mentioned the late Dr. Lovell Keays, the lat Mr. Wesley T. Page, Mr. W. Shore-Baily, Dr. P. Gosse, and Mrs. F. G Hedges. Aviary-bred birds are apt to be delicate, many suffering fron a form of asthma. The Marquis of Tavistock states that " Madagascar breed freely at liberty, but in a state of freedom are liable to becom paralysed in the legs ". The reason for this is not known, as aviary bird do not suffer in this way. Madagascars may be left out all year wit] perfect safety, provided they are not allowed to roost in the open a they are susceptible to lung trouble.

algorithms.bodyText: That tropical and semi-tropical birds can be accustomed to ou British climate is generally recognized. But as a rule there is sonn qualification attached to this statement, such as special accommodatioi or feeding, so perhaps an account of how some of the common anc less expensive seed eaters have been wintered on this bleak south-wes Lancashire coast, may be of interest to those readers of the Aviculturai Magazine, who like myself, do not profess to be experts, nor wealth enough to maintain large and elaborate aviaries. My bird census on 15th September, 1926, was 64 birds of 22 species All seed-eaters, such as Waxbills, Buntings, Finches, Canaries, Pekii Robins, Whydahs, Weavers, Siskins, etc., all reasonably priced bird that one might experiment with. My census to-day, 30th March, 1927, is 56 birds, 24 species (I bough 6 birds in January, 4 Lavender Finches and 2 Avadavats, thus increasing the kinds by 2). The losses are 19 all species, 9 from pneumonia, 4 fron
Joseph Ajjpleby--Notes from a Lancashire Aviary

Id age, and 6 from attacks by other birds, egg-binding or accident, *uring the six months I have bought 6 birds, the natural increase being , these are Silverbills and Zebra Finches, 3 and 2 respectively. The conditions under which my birds are kept were described in le October, 1924, Vol. II, No. 10, Avicultural Magazine, but I light state that with the exception of an oil lamp kept burning during pe months October to date in the shelter, the birds have had no other rotection against the damp and cold of this last winter. They are fed on a mixture of canary, hemp, white millet, Indian lillet, sunflower and teazle, together with soft food made of Spratts ad liver oil and softbill foods, to which is added maw seed. They get unlimited supplies of greenstuff, mostly garden weeds, etc., nd the floor of the flights are grassed. They can sleep inside or out as they choose, for though the shelter indow is lowered, it is never closed. Fire Finch, Siskin, Irey Singing Finch, Saffron Finch, Orange Weaver, and one pair Zebras have slept out all winter, and seem to prefer to do so, whatever he weather. The Javas, Whydahs, Nonpareil Buntings, and Cordon Ileus are more discriminating, and go indoors if the weather is stormy. Pekin Robins, Canaries, Combassous, Silverbills, Lavenders, Waxbills, nd Fire Finches prefer the warm bedroom. I don't know if my losses from pneumonia are due to the change of emperature from outside to inside, but I don't think this is entirely the ause, for the shelter is seldom more than 50* F. and in frosty weather } as fallen to 40*. I rather put them down to the fog and damp we get o much of here, along with cold damp winds. The losses from old age Ve are all liable to, for we can seldom tell the age of an adult bird jvhen bought. I generally look at the length of the upper mandible, nd the state - of the tarsus, but this method is not infallible. All hese four birds were in splendid plumage and condition. The murders and accidents were preventable. A Green Singing 'inch cock was responsible for three ; he wiped out the Siskin family, ather and two sons, and himself died of fright when I caught him fter the event. The other two were egg-binding, which I should I j iave seen to earlier. The moulting times are the critical ones so far * ps I can see, and if we can get our birds through without loss, we have

Correspondence our reward in perfect plumage and greater resistive power. For instant a cock Cordon Bleu which I have had three years is much mor brilliant in colour and thicker in the feathers than others I have ha only one year. The same applies to one of my Nonpareil cocks, he i much brighter now than when I first received him. I wonder if an one can tell me when a Nonpareil cock gets his adult plumage. I hav a bird, bought as a hen, now showing unmistakable male colour. Thi bird I have had two years, bought in July, 1925. The Pekin Robins are in excellent fettle, and are busy with domesti duties, as are some of the others. A cock Combassou gives the Whydahs a very anxious time ; he wi not allow them to feed at the same time as he and his wives, am though, of course, they are much heavier birds, he goes for them lik a terrier ; with this exception, since the Green Singing Finch cod deceased, the inhabitants of the aviary get on well together.

Sir, --Cannot the Avicultural Society do something to improve th conditions and management of Public Aviaries. At a few aviaries have visited in the north of England there was a deplorable lack o interest shown by those responsible for the stocking and managemen of these aviaries. A man is put in charge of an aviary who know nothing about birds and he has to take instructions from Towi Councillors who know less. At one place I saw Pheasants being kept in a glass house in whicl were Parrots and monkeys. A Silver Pheasant hen was laid on th floor and had lost the use of its legs. I asked the keeper why it wa allowed to live in that state, and he told me that he could not do any thing without instructions from the Borough Engineer. At a seaside place I visited they have some ideal aviaries wit! running water in. In one of the aviaries were a few Canaries and a Goldei Pheasant cock in a dilapidated state. In another was a Silver cock to( fat to walk with a pure-bred Amherst Pheasant hen, a rather scarce and valuable bird to be wasted.
algorithms.figure: Correspondence
algorithms.bodyText: w Even what is supposed to be a Lancashire Zoological Garden has no f cy Pheasants, the only one I saw being a Ring-neck, which seemed to [ n the last stages of consumption. In my opinion it is the duty of every member of this society to offer 5 ice and help to the councils who own public aviaries. In two cases my advice has been accepted and an improvement t taken place. There must be aviaries in other parts of England where advice is : ded. I think a list of all public aviaries should be published in the ) ?azine and reports sent in by members of the birds kept and their : ditions. It cannot be any help to aviculture to have birds shown . ier such wretched conditions. An official letter from this Magazine suggesting that some member ag near would be pleased to give advice, would do an immense t iunt of good. G. Beever.

algorithms.bodyText: Sir, --In the November issue of the Magazine, Mr. F. R. Ch asked whether the Prince Lucian Conure had been bred in captivil It has been many times in France, as Delacour has written in 1 article on Conures. I saw a brood of this species in Madame Lecallie aviaries, about 1918 and later. (See L'Oiseau , 1920, p. 31.) I mys possessed a pair of the young bred by Madame Lecallier ; they ha [ laid several times, but the young were never reared to maturity, lib because the parents were troubled by other large birds, which liv in their aviary (Glossy Starlings, Jays, etc.). Last winter I received, among other birds, a fine pair of Chalcomii senegalensis, now in fine condition, and a pair of Hedydipna platur but the cock died and I have only the hen left. I have just receiv from Senegambia some Masked Fire Finches, a young Zonogast j exterior , and an albino Fire Finch ; this bird is completely white, exctj on the tail, which is tinged with brown, and on the lores and che which are of a delicate pink colour. algorithms.bodyText: Sir, --The Council of the Royal Australasian Ornithologists' Uni is desirous of specially bringing under the notice of its members t new Checklist of the Birds of Australia, published last year. It represei the untiring efforts of a committee during a period of about 10 yea In addition to the scientific and vernacular names of the birds, it gi\ direct references to the work of Gould, Mathews, and others, states! range of each species, supplies lists of synonyms, and is furnish with a very complete index. It also contains a lengthy article by Mr. Wolstenholme on the derivations and pronunciations of the scienti names, which adds greatly to the value and interest of the List. Owing to the great amount of matter and the numerous referent the list contains and the high cost of printing, production of the List 1 involved an expenditure of more than #400, and therefore it coi not be made a part of, or supplement to the Emu. But this note is merely to record i death, while I have been abroad, of my Indian Adjutant under rat unusual circumstances. He withstood the cold of a Norfolk win remarkably W'ell, being out almost every day, walking about in a la j yard, which was also tenanted by a pair of Yulturine Guineafov Although perfectly friendly with one of the Guineafowls, the Adjutq had always looked with hatred on the other one, and at the le opportunity was quite ready to seize it, which on two occasions it c j though the Guineafowl managed to escape with not much more tl

However, while I was away a tragedy opened ! The Stork seized the hated Vulturine, and killed it, and en swallowed quantities of its feathers, so much so that they parently formed a kind of wad inside him, and he was not able to mst his own food of rats and fish, though continuing to feed as aedily as ever. My man tells me that for a week after he had killed r e Guineafowl, he kept on feeding, the undigested meat inside him lelling horribly, but eventually it killed him. algorithms.bodyText: Sir, --At last I have discovered a use for the aspidistra, that bane the middle-class parlour. I don't know whether the majority of aders know that all the large weavers of the genus Hyphantornis, \0x25A0 tagra, etc., only build their nests of long strips of palm leaves, etc., Inch they tear from the tree. They cut a small incision at the base the leaf, then holding a piece of the leaf above the cut firmly in their : ;aks they fly away, thus tearing a long narrow strip from the leaf, ith this they make their wonderful hanging nests. Dry grass, leaves, i c., are never used, being far too brittle, the green leaf being pliable I id yet very tough. In captivity the birds use hay, etc., but they never \ ;e this verv readily, neither do they build nests as perfect as when the wild state. One day I put several aspidistra plants into an aviary containing j me rare Weavers that I had had for a year or more, and, though the rds had been in a large outdoor aviary all the summer, they had

Correspondence made no attempt at nest-building, except to weave liay into the wii netting; but upon getting the plants they at once commenced to cut up the leaves and in a few days time had made perfect nests, and I an hoping that they will shortly breed.

algorithms.bodyText: By the Marquess of Tavistock The plate of a new race of Barnard's Parrakeet which Mr. G. Mathews has named after my wife, Barnardius crommelince, has been lone from a female bird imported by Mr. Frost some years ago and at present living in my collection. The locality where it was captured ippears unknown. Barnardius crommelince differs from the ordinary form in its wholly green breast. There is only a small patch of yellow on each side of he neck in place of the almost complete half-collar and the general hade of the plumage is a very pronounced blue- green. [The following note on this bird, by Mr. Gregory M. Mathews, appeared in the Bulletin of the British Ornithologists' Club of 4th November, 1925 (vol. xlvi, p. 21) :-- " While inspecting the aviaries of the Marquess of Tavistock, I was .struck by the appearance of a Barnardius somewhat like Barnardius mnardii Vigors and Horsfield, but noticeably without the yellow band >n the lower breast--which, in my opinion, is a new species. " It is as large as barnardii and richly coloured, with an abundance uf blue, the cheeks being only less blue than in whitei ; entire breast

Arrival of the Masked Lovebird blue-green ; the yellow collar only faintly indicated by a small yello patch on each side of the neck ; crown of the head pale green a dar Y-shaped mark of dull blue-green at the back of the head ; red front; band well developed. The bird is an adult female. "Locality : Australia (?). " I propose to call it Barnardius cro?n?nelince, sp. nov., in honour of Lady Tavistock."]

Mr. Chapman is to be congratulated on having at length succeede in importing several pairs of the very fine Masked Lovebird (Agaporm personata ) from Tanganyika Territory. It is perhaps the most strikin of the group, and, so far as I am aware, has never previously been offere for sale in this country, if indeed in Europe. The only specimen that have previously reached this country were three that Mr. Painte brought through London on his way to the United States in 192f as recorded in this journal for June of that year. This species, in which the sexes are alike in colour, has the fac blackish brown, a very broad collar on the nape and breast of yellow the upper breast reddish orange, the wings, back and under part green, and the upper tail-coverts ultramarine blue. The bill is brigh red and there is a conspicuous ring of whitish skin round the eye. Mr. Painter had no difficulty in breeding those he took to America and there is little doubt that this species will prove to be a good breede like the Black-cheeked and Nyasa Lovebirds. Mr. Chapman's Tanganyika consignment contained a few othe birds, two of which were new to Aviculture, namely the Blue-heade< Waxbill ( Urceginthus cyanocephalus) , which may be described as a Cordo] Bleu with a red bill and the blue extending over most of the head And the Buff-crowned Whydah ( Linura fischeri), a small and ver; dark-coloured Whydah with a distinct buffish crown. By Mrs. Prestwich (Continued from p. 136) Agapornis taranta The Abyssinian Lovebird has never been very popular with avi- turists, probably because it is considered quarrelsome and very inclined to reproduce its kind. Although it had been described My a hundred years previously, it was unknown in the living state England until the late Mr. H. D. Astley brought a pair from Italy July, 1909. This pair was given to him by a lady who apparently ught them quite common ; they were part of a small consignment ich reached Genoa in November, 1908. A few had been imported p Germany two years before, but had gone to the aviaries of an ktrian enthusiast. Mr. Astley's pair formed the subject of a plate he Avicultural Magazine, Third Series, Vol. I, No. 1. Abyssinians lained scarce until 1923, when they started to come over in fairly 'e numbers, and are now readily obtainable. The mortality in dy-imported birds is very heavy; they usually arrive in a very poor ;e, crowded in filthy cages, and it is little wonder that disease is ipant. In many cases they are entirely devoid of feathers on the d. I once had the misfortune to see the survivors of a very large ection : they were all in an exceptionally bad way and died in ens during the few days following their arrival in England from Britis and kindred troubles. In this case cocks and hens alike e absolutely bald, in addition they had developed cannibalistic lencies. It is common for the cocks to nibble and pluck the crimson hers from the foreheads of each other, but these had long passed 3 state, and when a bird fell from a perch through weakness, several Id immediately attack the unfortunate, and after putting it out ts misery, eat the major portion of its head. Fortunately birds orted direct by the English dealers do not arrive in such a shocking e, but only the birds from Continental dealers, who are not as icular as the majority of our importers. If newly-imported birds obtained they should be kept moderately warm and given soaked et and canary seed for a week or so, they can then be accustomed

Mrs. Prestivich--Lovebirds to the staple diet of canary seed, white millet, oats and white su flower, the last named they are especially fond of. Their water f the first few days should be slightly tepid. If the plumage is very soil they may be sprayed with lukewarm water after they have had tiij to settle down provided they are kept warm and given an opportune to dry thoroughly before dark. They should not be put out doc I until the beginning of May, unless the weather is exceptional. Thj will settle down very rapidly and are very hardy. A dry draught-prc shelter is absolutely essential, as A. taranta , in common with all ti other members of the family, cannot stand draughts or damp. T Abyssinian is the largest of the group, but is not very active and rati shy. They have rather pretty notes, sometimes resembling Peach-fac Lovebirds, and sometimes the cock has quite a twitter, after the fashi of the Bengalese. No difficulty is experienced in sexing this speci as the cock has a cap of the richest crimson, which is wholly abse in the hen. Nevertheless, breeding successes recorded in Engla are few, but several have been reported abroad. The late Mr. Asti stood a very good chance of being successful with his original pa as contrary to general experience they showed signs of desiring nest almost immediately after their arrival. Unfortunately the cc was unable to climb out of an exceptionally deep nest-box, which had been exploring ; he was not missed for several days, and it v then too late. The unmated hen laid eggs the following year. 1925 Mr. W. Lewis claimed to be the first to succeed in Great Brita The old birds took to a husk towards the end of June and laid f( eggs, which they duly hatched, but only reared two young, which w like the hen when Mr. Lewis disposed of them at three months c Incubation was thought to take sixteen days. Soon after Mr. Le' had made known his success, Mr. Alfred G. Groves, of Bath, clain priority. In response to a request by the Editor for particula Mr. Groves wrote as follows : " The Abyssinian Lovebird bred 1 year left the nest the second week in June. The parents came from late Mrs. Dalton Burgess' collection. Three eggs were laid, but oi one was fertile and the youngster remained in the nest for a k period " (A.31., Fourth Series, Yol. IV, p. 190). So it would seem tl the honour of being first goes to Mr. Groves. In both cases det;

The following extracts 3 for the benefit of new members who may not possess this number : Che hen appeared to be incubating at the end of January, 1925. i inspection on 17th February showed three almost round eggs, the 23rd two young had hatched, the third egg being fertile. Size eggs 23'18 mm. Incubation period about eighteen days. The n alone fed the young for about the first week. The young were nost feathered by 16th March, looked out of the box for the first he on the 19th, and the first left the nest on the 29th, the second, ir days later. Both resembled the female, except the red of the jak was paler ; both proved to be females. On 9th April the young gan to feed themselves, but were still fed by their parents; 27th April, ung independent, though still fed occasionally until 4th May. For !3 first few weeks the young birds were given soft food, containing ts' eggs and hard-boiled egg; on this food they thrived and later took eating seed, especially millet. A very interesting point observed was it these birds built no nest as other Lovebirds do, but the female lcked the feathers from her breast with which to form a nest founda- n." This was not the first occasion on which Abyssinians had been id on the Continent as Neunzig (p. 715) writes : " In 1906 some were ported by an Italian dealer and came into the possession of an .strian aviculturist. They bred, two young were hatched, which were ly coloured at ten months old. In another brood three young were xehed." Another account of the successful rearing of this species, t this time in America in the aviaries of Mrs. J. Bamfields, of Los geles, appeared in the Avicultural Magazine of August, 1926. n 1925, four eggs were laid, but only one youngster reared to maturity. 1926 four eggs laid, three hatched, two young reared. The eggs were 1 on a nest made of pieces of paper and canvas which they pulled the front protection of their cage. This pair is in an aviary with ne Softbills, and Mrs. Bamfields reports that they partake greedily the mealworms and gentles intended for the other birds, and believes it her success is partly due to this insect food." It will be noted that

Mrs. Prestwick -- Honey-Guide Death Lure both Herr Schiitze and Mrs. Bamfields provided insect food and bot have been successful, so it would seem that this species benefits 1 the provision of a good insectivorous mixture. In the wild state tl Abyssinian is said to make use of the nest of a species of Weaver, j the same way as the Peach-faced is said to use the nest of the Social) Weaver bird. As regards its life in the wild, Heuglin says {Ornithology Nord-Ost Africas, pp. 747-8) : " It usually lives in families of three l| eight individuals, most abundantly in the so-called Woma-Ded (7,000 ft. above sea-level), yet it descends to the lowest limi of the Abyssinian olive-tree and the Qolqual Euphorbia, and | Semien and Wogara we still met little parties at 9-10,000 f altitude. The isolated companies lead a tolerably independei life, but keep close together among themselves. They affect tl crowns of the higher trees, especially of Juniperus and the Chandeli Euphorbiae ; at the season of the ripening of the fruits of tl Cordias and Sycamores they also settle upon them. The call-no consists of a shrill, at times chattering, chirp, very like Agaporn pullaria. The males when in flight often utter a sharp pfiff. The fligl itself is usually high, straight and humming ; these birds also clin with great facility/' Heuglin thinks the pairing season must be midsummer. Abyssinans are given a very bad name as regards their quarrt someness, but they agree fairly well with other members of the genu Softbills they ignore, but it is not safe to associate them with smi Finches, etc., especially at breeding time. Two pairs of Abyssinia - should on no account be kept in the same aviary unless it is of vei exceptional size. [To be continued.)

The following extracts are taken from .Newton's Dictionary Birds and throw some light on the matter :-- " Honey-guide, a bird so called from its habit or supposed habit of inting out to man and to the ratel ( Mellivora capensis) the nests of es. . . . Yet Mr. Layard says ( B. S. Africa, p. 242) that the birds 11 not unfrequently lead anyone to a leopard or a snake, and will low a dog with vociferations, 1 so that at present judgment may rhaps be suspended on the matter, though its antics and noisy cry [questionably have in many cases the effect signified by its English me. If not its first discoverer, Sparrman, in 1777, was the first 10 described and figured this bird, which he met with in the Cape >lony, giving it the name of Cuculus indicator, its feet with the toes aced in pairs--two before and two behind--inducing the belief at it must be referred to that genus. Vieillot in 1816 elevated it to e rank of a genus, Indicator ; but it was still considered to belong to e Family Cucu idce (its asserted parasitical habits lending force to at belief) by all systematists except Blyth and Jerdon, until it was own by Mr. Blanford and Mr. Sclater that it was more allied to the ipitonidce (Barbet) and, in consequence, was then made the type of distinct Family, Indicatoridce. ... In the meanwhile other species had ;en discovered, some of them differing sufficiently to warrant mdevall's foundation of a second genus, Prodotiscus, of the group, he Honey-guides are small birds, the largest hardly exceeding a Lark size, and of plain plumage, with what appears to be a very Sparrow- ke bill. Captain Shelley in 1891 (Cat. B. Br. Mus., xix, pp. 1-12) ;cognized nine species and one sub-species of the genus Indicator, id two of Prodotiscus. Four of the former, including I. sparrmani, hich was the first made known, are found in South Africa, and one Prodotiscus. The rest inhabit other parts of the same continent, ccept I. archipelagicus, which belongs to Borneo and Malacca, and xanthonotus, which occurs on the Himalayas from the borders of fghanistan to Bhotan. The interrupted geographical distribution f this genus is an instructive fact."

algorithms.bodyText: A possible explanation of the antics of the Honey-guide is giv by a correspondent in the Daily Mail , who writes, " A honey-bird w lure a man to a tree where there is a snake because the snake is in t vicinity of its nest. My brother had an experience of this sort, honeybird led him to a tree and fluttered round the stem where! snake was coiled. My brother shot the snake, and the honey-bil cheerfully settled on its nest." Perhaps some member who has had personal experience with til genus would give his observations. A TAME HONEY-GUIDE

If it had not been for a shower of rain William and I would not hai met, which would have been William's loss. I will explain. Wanderil one day in the Bush, in search of new birds, I encountered a show] (they are called showers in that part of the world where 4 inch! of rain in an hour is no uncommon thing, but in England it woul have been called a torrential downpour). So not wishing to retra my steps 7 miles in a soaking condition and swim a swollen riv I sought shelter for the night at the homestead of a friend a few mill away. When the ever-welcome pot of tea was brought in by a dusll chef, a small feathered creature dropped on to the floor from somewhel out of the said gentleman's attire and protested forcibly as it hoppl across the floor. This was William. There was a general scrambj and I caught him first ; then the dusky " gentleman " protested--tl bird was the only titbit for the evening to augment the monotony of tl usual mealie pap--but as possession is nine points of the law as they sal I stuck to William and he spent the night under a wire meat covl and was regaled with a diet of flies mixed with golden syrup. Till was how William and I met. Now the reason that I stuck to William was--because he was a vel rare bird, far from common even in his native haunts. His other narj was the Yellow-throated Honey-guide, his proper name Indicaf\ major.

algorithms.bodyText: The Honey-guides, only three species of which I have studied heir native haunts, the Sparrman's Honey-guide in Mozambique, Scaly-throated in Gazaland, and the present species in Mashona- 1, are quiet and unobtrusive birds, living in the thickly-wooded ;h and seldom obtruding themselves upon one's notice unless there i; bees' nest in the vicinity ; then matters are reversed, and upon the lj it of a human being, either black or white, the bird gets into a great |e of excitement, flying round within a few yards and uttering its !i iously loud cry ; if it sees that one intends to follow, the bird will \ from tree to tree a few vards ahead of one until it eventually reaches nest. When it does actually reach the nest it utters an entirely . erent cry to the one which it has been uttering whilst it has been I ling one on. It is always the custom to leave a portion of the comb for the bird i payment for its services. The natives have a superstition that if jf does not leave anything for the bird, the next time they follow I, loney-guide it will lead them to a poisonous snake. It is a fact 1} t these birds do lead human beings to snakes as several of my friends \0x25A0i r e proved, but this is done no doubt with the object of getting someone <: kill the snake, for undoubtedly these birds possess a large share of elligence, as I proved by my pet.

To get back to William, the native who caught him said that ever a Honey-guide drinks water it gets intoxicated and he fou this bird " drunk " on the pathway leading to the native store. I thi: that this nigger must have belonged to the local branch of tj R.S.P.C.A., for instead of breaking the bird's wings and legs as tj natives always do whenever they find a bird (I have known nath to catch birds and treat them thus, leaving them all day in the boili i sun so that they would be fresh for the evening's meal, cruelty beij inherent to the African nigger), this fellow only cut its wing feathers oj William had an insatiable appetite. I am sure that he ate seven times his own weight in a week, even if the last grub was hangij out of his mouth, because there was no more room inside, he won call for more. We fed him on all manner of soft insects and honevcom! J [ This is a very easy matter in a country where insects abound and wi bees' nests are found everywhere. But hard insects and artific food he would not touch. There is a certain kind of hornet in the tropics which is a gre asset to the amateur bird keeper. It builds large mud nests on the wa of rooms, usually preferring the kitchen where it is extra warm. The nests consist of from one to thirty compartments, the hornet la! an each one and then stuffs it full of green caterpillars or lar spiders, which it renders in a state of suspended animation by 1 1 injection of some subtle preservative, and as the hornets are continual building these wonderful nests, there is provided a never-ending supp of food, and upon the contents of these nests William was regale If the egg in the hornet's nest had hatched and the insects were eat there was a huge juicy grub in their place which was relished even me than the insects. William would follow after one anywhere if he were hungry aij several times he was lost in a banana plantation, but upon bei called he soon disclosed his whereabouts by uttering his strange cii H e was frightfully inquisitive, prying into every dark nook ai corner, and if a newspaper was lying on the floor he would get unde neath it and come out at the other side. He liked to roost in sor dark corner on the floor, usually under a chest of drawers. His favouri perch was on my foot, and once comfortably settled there he wou

algorithms.bodyText: ike funny little contented noises as though he were speaking to nself in an undertone. I was hoping to bring him home to England, but as I had to make letour of over two thousand miles because of a railway bridge being shed away, I found this absolutely impracticable owing to the possibility of getting live food for a week's train journey, so I left n with a friend whom I knew would take care of him. Perhaps it is a good thing that he didn't come to this land of sunless grey skies d cold hearts, or like the writer he might have suffered from a rpetual heart-ache for that far away country of brilliant sunshine id eternally blue skies and--Freedom !
algorithms.subsectionHeader: By Sydney Porter Reichenow's Weaver (Othyphantes reichenowi)
algorithms.bodyText: A few of these beautiful Weavers were brought down from the tterior of Tanganyika Territory in Central Africa by my friend 'r. Schulz, and given to me in the spring of last year at Antwerp. I have never heard of their being imported before, and there is ery little likelihood of their ever having been brought to Europe efore, for they are rare even in the very remote part where the} )me from, and as notes on rarely imported birds are asked for I enture to send these very meagre ones. The Reichenow's Weaver is rather a large bird, and at first sight light be mistaken for a small Oriole, and this is accentuated by the ict that the beak is not at all Weaverlike, being thin, long, tapering nd glossy black. The birds were caught on a volcano where Mr. Schulz makes his drican home. In size they are rather larger than the Black-headed Veaver (Hyphantornis nigriceps), but more slender in build. They made delightful aviary birds, exceedingly active and cheerful n demeanour, also very tame and confiding, always ready to take aealworms from out of one's hand even though they were in a large utdoor aviary.

These Weavers are mainly insectivorous in a state of freedom, an eat very little seed. On board the ship they killed and partly ai several of the rare Black-thighed Weavers that were confined to th same cage ; they also plucked all the yellow feathers from out of th cock birds, and greedily devoured minced raw meat which was pi into the cage for other birds. In captivity they eat a great deal < soft food and many mealworms. In the aviary they spent most of their time searching the bushc and the ground for insects and weaving, but they never made a perfec nest. They moulted out into perfect specimens, but alas ! they wei killed at the end of the summer by the wretched cats chasing ther on the aviary at night. In colour the Reichenow's Weaver is bright golden yellow on th whole of the lower parts, somewhat greener on the flanks, the feathei having a remarkable satin-like texture in the living bird, the uppe parts jet black, the lower back and tail olive green, the wings marke with olive yellow ; the iris is white, which gives the bird a very crui expression, as indeed it deserves. There seems to be a seasonal chang in which the front half of the head changes to golden yellow. I hope to receive some more of these birds later this year. The Black-thighed Weaver (Pyromelana capensis xanthome laena) This very pretty little Weaver seems to have been seldom if eve imported, though it may have been confused with its very near all} the better-known Cape Black and Yellow Weaver (P. capensis), ; bird that it closely resembles and which it replaces north of the Limpop River in South Africa. When in breeding plumage the male is velvet black all over except the shoulders and lesser wing-coverts, which ar bright yellow, and a broad band on the lower back which is brillian golden yellow; the feathers are elongated and cover the wings ii repose ; there is also an irregular line of white in the centre of th abdomen ; the legs are black, also the upper mandible, the lower on is white. The hen is much smaller than the cock, and is the usua streaky brown with no trace of yellow. I bought my birds on th'
algorithms.author: Sydney Portei--Two Bare Weavers
algorithms.bodyText: land of Mozambique on the East African coast. I bought them with -enty other birds for the sum of 6s., including the cage ! These Weavers are very conspicuous objects in the landscape in e regions where they live owing to their brilliant coloration and *mparative tameness, though they cannot be called common. In , te breeding season each male takes possession of a certain area, either irt of a reed bed or one of the huge anthills wdiich are covered by dense tangle of tropical vegetation composed of thorn bush, reeds, iparagus fern, etc., but always in the vicinity of water. Here he reigns 5 a little king with his harem, chasing any other bird of the same or lied species from the immediate neighbourhood. When in full plumage the male has a very peculiar " slow motion " ight. He first puffs out his feathers until he resembles a black and olden ball and appears to be twice his real size, and then sails with a range jerky motion very slowly from bush to bush, and upon alighting ach time utters his harsh rasping song. He is usually so engrossed ith his performance that he takes very little notice of human beings. Although the males are so much in evidence the females are very eldom seen, for upon one's approach they slip away quietly into the ense undergrowth, the male meanwhile chasing first one and then the ther. These birds feed upon the seeds of weeds, grasses, etc., and also mall insects. The nest is like that of the Scarlet Weaver, a most beautifully |roven structure of fine texture, attached to several reed stems. The j ggs, five in number, are pale blue. Out of the breeding season, a few join flocks of other Weavers when hey can at once be distinguished from the others by the yellow lower j >ack and wing-coverts, this colour being retained all the year round. The majority of the birds, however, do not wander very far from their ! seeding haunts. These Weavers are quite charming birds in captivity, lively and ; dvacious, singing the whole day long their rather harsh and rasping [ 'Ong. They are wonderful nest builders, having constructed many perfect , lests exactly resembling those built in the wild state, and if I had only

F- Finn--Species and Sub-species left them long enough in my outdoor aviary doubtless they would ha\ nested, but I was compelled to take them indoors for the followin reason : morning after morning to my great chagrin I found th bodies of my beautiful Weavers stiff and cold on the ground, first od and then another, all apparently in perfect health and feather, an I only discovered the reason when three out of my twelve birds wer left: it was that arch-enemy of all bird keepers, cats. The brutes ha climbed over the aviary all the night, causing the birds in their fright t batter themselves against the wires. The more the birds fluttere* the more the cats chased them ; but this year I have a sure remedy- arsenic and kippers ! Indoors the birds still continued to build, and at the present momen the remaining hen and two cocks are still building perfect nests.

By F. Finn, B.A., F.Z.S. Aviculturists may be able to give us some light on this subject since by breeding from abnormal birds they often throw light on tin heredity or otherwise of variations. Their experiments have oftei shown that a sudden variation or " mutation " is either inherited completely or not at all; this is the case, for instance, with the black winged form of the Peacock when crossed with the common type, am the young bird bred at the Zoo from a Zebra Curassow (Crax globicera feminine mutation hecki) and a typical Globose Curassow cock was ar ordinary Globose Curassow hen, figured by our Editor with its femah! parent in the Avicultural Magazine years ago. Yet yellow Budgerigars appear to owe their present far too strong tinge of green and too pronounced markings to crossing with greens! and I can well remember when Silver Sebright Bantams, as described in Wright's Poultry Book a generation ago, had become straw-coloured) by crossing with the golds, though the first crossing of golds and silver^j reproduces the original colours truly, and true silvers have long age been re-bred and are now common. Moreover, I believe that I can see in some of the present light blue Buderigars a tinge of green, and this mutation can be better likened to
algorithms.title: F. Finn--Species and Sub-species
algorithms.bodyText: did form than can the yellow, for the light blue Budgerigar corre- >nds to the green very much as the Indian Grey Tit ( Parus major ereus ) does to our Great Tit ( Parus major), the yellow element in * plumage being eliminated in the Indian bird. Do we know, moreover, that such mutations as the new and eresting Dark Common Pheasants ( Phasianus colchicus, mutation curus Hachisuka), of which latter a nice pen are now exhibited at the d, will not ultimately produce intermediate forms if persistently \0x25A0d back to the typical birds ? # 0 If they did, we could envisage the production of sub-species as ows : First the type produces a mutation, which, if isolated or messing some advantage of constitution, character, or adaptation surroundings, becomes a constant local form. Then it breeds back, ough some extension of range, locally to the type, and intermediates se, all such intermediates being, as we know them to be in the case our common British Pheasants, in the case of which imported sub- ;cies have been crossed in, of hybrid nature. If this be ever recognized and proved as a fact, it will reduce sub- :cies to the level of full-species hybrids, and render it as unnecessary load our museums with series of sub-specific forms as it would be -v considered unnecessary to fill them with avicultural full-species- orids, albimistic varieties, etc. It may be argued that what I have been saying only concerns our-forms, which are not now--and rightly in my opinion--regarded full species ; but one gets the same intergradation where structure concerned, as between the common Reed-Bunting ( Emberiza oeniclus) and the large pale Bullfinch-billed Reed-Bunting of Central a, which Sharpe actually put into a distinct genus, Pyrrhulorhyncha. also separated the Flightless Moorhen of Tristan da Cunha as a ius ( Porphyriornis ) from the common Moorhen, though it chiefly uers in reduced wings and stronger and yellow-coloured feet. Here also we can find a parallel in domestic birds. If anyone goes one of our great poultry shows and looks at the Fawn Runner Ducks, ich are the truest representatives of the Penguin Ducks studied f Darwin, it will be seen that these birds differ from Mallard in much !..' same way as the Flightless Moorhen does from our bird. They

F. Finn--Species and Sub-species are shorter-winged and longer and stronger-legged, and although il so true to type as wild birds, they certainly have evolved incident differences in coloration. The Drake is like a Mallard with subdu colours, dark olive bill, olive-orange legs, deep bottle-green he; dull grey body, dull wing-bar, the white neck collar reduced absent, and the chocolate breast-patch paler and less well defin The Ducks are usually warm fawn, with a bronze wing-bar instead blue, black bills and pure olive feet, and the black markings of 1 plumage reduced to small longitudinal streaks even on the upper par Most interesting is the fact that the Drakes not unfrequent even when having only a small white collar or none, have white wi] coverts like Wigeon, and that such white wing-coverts occasiona appear in the Ducks. Altogether these birds, although a domestic race, look remarkal like a full wild species evolved by isolation where flight and swimm were both at a discount. Yet if they did exist as wild birds--as so fanciers actually imagine--and an invasion of Mallard took pi in their home, interbreeding would no doubt occur and sub-spec forms would arise. I do not mean to imply that the structural points of the Flight] Moorhen and Bullfinch-billed Reed-Bunting arose by sudden mutati any more than Mallard parents could suddenly produce Fawn Run j offspring complete in all points--though I have seen a Mallard Dij in Regent's Park with the Runner carriage ; the structural peculiarii) of such birds have no doubt arisen by the adding up of such sn variations as we know to occur by natural selection (the Runner Du no doubt, was not deliberately bred to the shape it shows, poul being usually compelled to forage for themselves in the East), coloration of such structurally different races often does not di much from that of the type, and has no doubt arisen incidentally being correlated with successful structural or constitutional variatic Yet when structurally different forms of recent common origin m< we can see that they interbreed just as colour-mutations do, as in case of the Kaleege Pheasants. In Assam, we have the Purple Kaleege (Gennceus horsjieldi) evider a melanistic male mutant from -the Lineated Kaleege of Burma

algorithms.bodyText: mtus) with its grizzled back and streaked breast. These species prick-crested and hen-tailed, but China has evolved the well-known *e, drooping-crested, long-tailed, white-backed Silver Pheasant nychihemerus) which certainly would not have arisen suddenly in its aplete form from the Lineated. Yet it interbreeds both with this and h the Purple where they meet--though about thirty species were *e made of the hybrids, of which some (of the Purple-Silver cross) are , even alike on the two sides of the body. To be developed as distinctly as it is, the Silver Pheasant must, ts infancy as a species, have been isolated from its fellows for a isiderable period ; while extension of range has apparently brought m together again, producing hybrid sub-species. If this view be correct, all sub-species are simply mongrels ; and l species are those forms which have been so long isolated as to have /eloped a dislike to mating with their relatives when by some cause y are brought into contact. This is evidently the case with the Iden and Amherst Pheasants (Chrysolophus pictus and C. amherslice) ich do not interbreed when wild, or even, though living in the same mtry, haunt the same localities, being indeed enemies; yet culture has shown us that they will produce completely fertile brid offspring. Indeed, a captive sub-species has been developed, most Amherst cocks nowadays show a touch of Gold blood, though s comes out, curiously enough, in an excess of red, not of yellow, the plumage, as well as in the breaking up of the black tail-bars. How, then, does one recognize a true or full species ? I think illace's definition--one that differs from another in more than one nt--is very near the truth, but not quite exact, for intermediate ms may exist between two of such, as we see in the case of the leege Pheasants. The decisive points must apparently be at least three, as we see the case of the Ruffed ( Chrysolophus) Pheasants, which differ in ! our, structure of ornamental plumage, feathering of face, and note, l have ceased to regard each other as kindred in the wild, though y will mate when man pairs them, and still produce, as I have said, |te fertile offspring.
G. H. Gurney--The Birds of Prey

By G. H. Gurney, F.Z.S. The diurnal Birds of Prey (Falconiformes) are divided into tv sub-orders, the Cathartse and the Accipitres. The former contains tl New World Vultures (Cathartidae) with its sub-family Polyborir (Carrion Hawks) ; the latter the Secretary Bird (Serpentaridse), tl Old World Vultures (Vulturidae), the Carrion Hawks, Hawks, Eagk Falcons and their allies (Falconidae) and the Ospreys (Pandionidse). Tl Accipitres alone consist of nearly four hundred different speck Although the Raptores are not nearly so often kept in aviaries as mai other species, still probably from their use in hawking, they were sor of the earliest birds to be kept in confinement. Possibly also their som what sombre colouring, and their general reluctance to breed, may al account for the fact, that but few aviculturists go in for them, or may be the difficulty of providing animal food for them, or aga their reputed fierceness and untameable natures may be the reason and yet they are an extremely interesting group, and if properly und< stood, are generally easy birds to feed and cater for. Many of the stand confinement extremely well, and live to a great age, whilst ma are perfectly hardy, and will become very tame, and as those who keep them will know, possess a charm and interest quite differe from any other class of birds. It is quite impossible in a short article of this description to descri all the various species which have been kept in confinement: I can or give a short account of those which are more commonly seen, with very brief description of their plumage. Owing to there being but small demand for them, no numbers of any one species are import* odd examples of all kinds of different sorts, many of them very scar arrive at the dealers, and may or may not be sold. In this article I propose to describe ( 1 ) suitable aviaries, ( 2 ) fo< (3) species which have been kept in captivity. Aviaries No Birds of Prey of any kind are suitable for cages, they must housed in aviaries. It is quite a mistake to suppose that they all hardy ; like all birds they will become acclimatized, and very ma
algorithms.reference: G. H. Gurney--The Birds of Prey
algorithms.bodyText: ill stand any amount of cold, but the smaller tropical and sub-tropical >ecies are often very delicate and must be treated accordingly. To 3gin with, the aviary must be (for all species) in a sheltered place, possible facing south ; it is nearly always useless to have an open ight, with an elaborate heated house, as very few Hawks will go into ich a shelter of their own accord. The aviary should be open only in ont, and boarded at the sides, back, and over the greater part of the )p ; for the more delicate species, the whole of the top may be boarded id a glass front, covered on the inside with wire netting, fixed to the ont of the aviary in the winter time. The size of the aviarv must spend a good deal on the bird it is to hold, but personally I am in ivour of large aviaries for the Birds of Prey : certainly for the bigger ultures and Eagles they can hardly be too large, though I must admit have seen large Hawks (Buzzards and Kites) kept in quite small places, ad looking the picture of health. The perches should be placed well apart and at some distance from le ground, so that the bird must use his wings to get from one to the ther. They should be of good strong wood, of different thickness, ad I find pieces of cork bark nailed round the perches in separate laces very much appreciated by the birds for standing on. A large beady block of wood, a couple of feet high, let firmly into the floor f the aviary is also much liked. It is a great mistake to vercrow T d an aviary with perches, but there should always be one at lie back, where the bird will get the most shelter. As regards the floor f the flight, it may be covered with sand, but I much prefer the natural arth : in some of my Hawk's aviaries half of the floor is of bricks, i diich are certainly easier to clean, and as these birds do not spend luch time on the ground, it does not appear in any way to affect heir feet. In an aviary of this description most species of Kaptores, with the xception of the Secretary Bird, and the smaller and more delicate ropical species, may be kept throughout the year. Food Jr The all-important question of food is often misunderstood in the hrds of Prey. All my Haw T ks, except the small delicate ones, are starved or one day in the w T eek, and they are never given more food than they

G. II. Gurney--The Birds of Prey can consume at a meal, all food left uneaten is removed. They are fed once a day only. The best food is small birds, rats, mice and rabbits and for the larger vultures horse flesh, fowls' heads may also be occasionally given. Whenever possible it is essential that fur and feathers should be left on ; as a substitute for natural feathers, tow cut up into small lengths and mixed with the meat may be used. This plan is, or was, carried out at the Giza Zoological Gardens, and appeared to answer very well, though I must say I have never tried it. Birds ol Prey are always lethargic in confinement and if they are to be kepi really well and in perfect condition, the different forms of food foi the various species cannot be too closely considered. It is ofter supposed that all a Haw T k requires is a large hunk of flesh throwr into its cage and left there until it is consumed. It is quite unnecessary as many people imagine, to feed Vultures on carrion ; they do perfectly well on fresh meat, but the bones should be given with the meat The very small Hawks, tropical and otherwise, some not much large: than Sparrows, are almost entirely fed on worms, beetles, moths, cock chafers, mealworms, and pieces of meat cut up very small; other: rather larger may be given small birds, mice, lizards, and small fish in fact many Hawks of all kinds delight in fish occasionally. The da] before I starve my birds I generally give them an extra feed, but no always. Of course, when a bird is moulting he will require rather i more liberal allowance of food, but by feeding as I have described the majority of Kaptores may be kept perfectly well and fit. As regards drinking and bathing, I have seen it stated that Hawk never drink in confinement. This is incorrect. A pair of small Black winged Kites ( Planus) I had were constantly drinking, and a Blacl Vulture also occasionally did so. They are certainly not great drinker as a whole, but should always have easy access to a large pan of fresl water, and the same applies to bathing. It is, as a rule, better to kee] the Birds of Prey in separate aviaries, even if they are the same specie (unless one is especially trying to breed them), one is often stronger tha: the other, and will take all the food : I think they do better also i apart. Vultures and possibly the Kites, which have rather differen habits, may, however, be allowed to live together. I will deal first with the New World Vultures.

algorithms.bodyText: G. H. Gurney--The Birds of Prey The Secretary Bird (Serpentarius Secretarius ) has been importer and kept in captivity from the very early days of aviculture. Th< first specimen to reach Europe alive was in 1770 and many of the early English menageries had specimens. The enclosure for a Secretary Bird can hardly be too large, and in such a place, they will take t great deal of exercise and keep themselves in good health ; the enclosurt should be surrounded by a wire fence at least 10 feet high, with i large dry shed facing south, the floor of which should be well coverec with peat moss litter. Kept under these conditions they are generally pretty hardy, and may be allowed out, except in the hardest weather They are tremendous feeders, and a diet of rabbits, given broken up but of course with the fur and bones, rats and small birds suits then well, if given perfectly fresh, while they are very fond of hens' eggs I shall never forget the excitement of three Secretary Birds at th< Buda Pesth Zoo, when five large live snakes were turned into thei enclosure. They were promptly killed, but not immediately devoured These birds have not yet been bred in captivity, but I believe a nes* was made at the London Zoological Gardens more than once ; anc there appears to be no reason w T hy they should not breed in a suitabh enclosure, under favourable conditions. Kolb's Vulture ( G . kolbi ) and Kuepell's Vulture ( G . ruepelli). >th these species have occasionally been kept in confinement. A pair Kolb's Vultures nested at the London Zoological Gardens in oc ember, 1912. After incubation lasting for fifty-four days, the young e was hatched, but was unfortunately devoured by its parents two ys later. They are found in West and South Africa. The Bengal Vulture ( Pseudogyps bengalensis) is another closely ied species, which has been kept at the London Zoological Gardens, d in one or two private collections. It often makes an extraordinary rking noise and becomes very tame. The lower part of the back adult specimens is white, remainder black. Other species which have been imported from time to time include e Pondicherry Vulture ( Otogyps calvus), the Eared Vulture ( 0 . ricularis), and the Occipital Vulture ( Lophogyps occipitalis). The Egyptian Vulture ( Neophron percnopterus). White, primaries ick, naked head, and neck bright yellow. This is one of the smallest the Vultures, and has often been kept in captivity. Though some- lat of a morose disposition, I knew one which would come to the bars its cage to be scratched and was perfectly tame. This species requires day shed for winter. The two examples I have kept appeared to d cold rather considerably, and I do not consider it as hardy in nfinement as most of the other Vultures. Hooded Brown Vulture ( N . monachus). Dark brown, tail black, ;ck covered with thick down of a pale brown colour. By the Editor The new arrivals at the Zoological Gardens include a very beauti pair of Mot-mots from Trinidad presented by Miss Byatt. The spec found on that island and Tobago, Momotus swainsoni, is somewl smaller than most of the mainland forms and more brilliantly colour and is recognized by its rich chestnut undersurface which extei to the throat. The Mot-mots are allied to the Bee-eaters and have very simi habits such as that of nesting in holes in banks, and capturing th prey on the wing, but the tail of the Mot-mot is unique. The t central features are considerably longer than the others and wt they are first grown they are normal feathers, but after a short ti the barbs for an inch or so disappear, leaving the bare shaft with a t or racquet at the end.

algorithms.bodyText: Sir, --I read with much interest the article by Mr. Appleby in May number, and thought perhaps a few observations on the sub! of mortality among the less expensive foreign seed-eaters might bj interest. My aviary is absolutely unheated and is situate in Surrey. Unfo nately the only choice of position was one facing north, and only open flight gets any sun. The shelter is in two parts, one altogej open in the front and the other screened off so that no cold v can penetrate. The roof of this latter part is lined with loose stj tucked under laths and that is the only protection from frost, roof itself is a high-pitched gable. In this I have Orange-chee and common Grey Waxbills, also Cordon Bleus, and the only de; for three years have been from accident, such as flying against a bra, or from old age. My Grey Waxbills were purchased in 1921, and tl: out of four are alive and in perfect condition. I also have kept Z( Finches, yellow and green Budgerigars, an odd Java Sparrow- other hanged itself in a forked twig, and some Cutthroat Fine;
algorithms.figure: Correspondence
algorithms.bodyText: \0x25A0st the hen Zebra Finch also through flying into a twig, and have :e removed the fatal branch which projected .across the opening n the inner shelter to the covered part of the flight. Since then re have been no more accidents. The water supply is a cement and pebble pool in the open flight l has to be freed from ice regularly in the coldest weather. The 1 supplies are in hoppers in the covered flight and consist of canary :1 and Indian millet only. Green foods such as flowering grass, :kweed and groundsel are freely given, but the latter is not much >reciated. All is scrupulously removed when withered. The covered ht is floored with about a foot of sand so that there is no damp. I this dryness I attribute the freedom from illness of my birds. There re some small bushes of wild plum, and a small sycamore in the open \0x25A0t of the flight, more for the purpose of harbouring insects than for /thing else, as I find the Waxbills and Cordon Bleus are very keen catching small flies. The wire roof of the open flight is pitched as high as possible so as get all the sun that is possible, owing to the north aspect. I find j Waxbills, etc., appreciate a cosy box with plenty of dry straw in it a winter roosting place in the inner shelter. I may say this inner her is not dark as there is an obscured window in it besides the ening from the covered shelter shed. I have come to the conclusion that when acclimatized the most 'ious dangers to this class of birds are damp and draughts. Cold by elf is not to be feared so long as the birds have plenty of room for *ht. These remarks are merely platitudes, but some beginner may perhaps- :k up some useful hint. W. W. Smith.
Sir,-- As a very interesting article is now running in the v t icultural Magazine, dealing with Lovebirds, I thought it an >portune moment to send you a description of a nest-box that I have signed.

In the nest that I have designed, which follows usual shape, perforated zinc bottom is used, to allow the damp air to percola from a zinc tray at the bottom. algorithms.bodyText: The Subscription to the Avicultural Society is #1 per annum, due on the 1st of January in each year, and is payable in advance. The entrance fee is 3 0/6 The Avicultural Magazine is sent free to members monthly. Members joining at any time during the year are entitled to the back numbers for the current year, on the payment of entrance fee and subscription.

This is one of the most beautiful of the genus to which it belongs, is confined to the island of Ceylon, where it is not uncommon in forest-covered hills. It is very seldom imported to Europe, which d be regretted. In its native country this Parrakeet is said to associate in moderately d flocks and to be noisy and restless, uttering a harsh "crake " the wing as it dashes up and down the forest-clad glens of the Ion mountains. It is said to be very partial to the wild fig. The coloured plate renders a description of this species unnecessary, bird figured is a male, the female being very similar in colouration, somewhat duller with the bill dusky black. D. S-S.

By G. H. Gurney (Concluded jrom p. 172) The Golden Eagle (Aquila clirysaetus). A description of this well- wn bird is hardly necessary. It is not so often kept in captivity flight be supposed. It has nested on two occasions at Lilford and, ough eggs were laid and incubation took place, both birds sitting rnately, there was no result.

G. II. Gurney--Birds of Prey Imperial Eagle {A. imperialis). Adult blackish-brown ab( tail ashy-grey, head and neck light fulvous. This very hands( species has been kept rather frequently in confinement. Three v kept at Northrepps, one of which had been there over thirty ye A hen laid several eggs in a scrape made on the floor of the avi; but would never sit. Their range extends through Southern Eur to China and India. Tawny Eagle (A. rapax). Above deep brown, primaries bis tail brown, entire under surface dark brown. Occasionally impori It is found all over Africa, extending occasionally into Southern Sp; The White-Shouldered Eagle (A. adalberti). Crown of h black, upper part of neck sandy-brown, upper parts black, entire ur surface blackish. A pair of these Eagles were kept at Northrepps many years. They were obtained from a nest in Spain by Lord Lilf in May, 1872. One of these Eagles was killed by an accident when ah twenty-three years old, the other died from natural causes in Decern' 1916, after forty-five years in captivity. Other species of Eagles ( Aquila ) which have been kept in conf ment are : the Spotted Eagle (A. clanga), habitat South Russia, Per and India ; the Wedge-tailed Eagle (A. audax), habitat Australia ; i the Vulturine Eagle (A. verreauxi), habitat South Africa. The White-tailed Sea-eagle (Haliaetus albicilla). Gener; brown, tail white, the fully adult plumage is not attained in this spe' until it is nearly six years old. Most of the Sea Eagles appear to do a in captivity and, though not often imported, specimens may gener; be seen, of one species or another, in Zoological Gardens, and occasion; in private collections. This species is generally distributed over Old World. The American form {II. leucocephalus ) and II. leucogas the closely allied Australian species, have also both been kept in confi ment. II. branickii , the Corean Sea Eagle, and H. leucoryphus, Fishing Eagle, have been represented at the London Zoological Gardt The Vociferous Sea-eagle {II. vocifer). Head and neck and eni breast pure white, tail white, remainder of lower parts rich chesti; primaries black. This very handsome species, although so comn all over East and Central Africa, does not appear to be often import though it has been kept at Lilford and in one or two other places.

Sub-family Buteonince The Rough-legged Buzzard ( Archibuteo lagopus). Light brown with rker markings, the tail has a white base with three or four dark |)wn cross bars. Specimens which have been trapped or caught may basionally be seen in captivity, and I have had two or three at one !ie or another. Like all the Buzzards, they vary very much inter se : jne birds become remarkably tame, while others appear never to le their natural wild habits. This well-known species frequently purs in Great Britain in the autumn, is common all over Northern crope, migrating south in the winter. The North American form, A. sancti-johannis , has been kept at the , ndon Zoological Gardens. The Common Buzzard (Buteo buteo), I suppose the commonest of the birds of prey in confinement and one of the easiest to cater for. \0x25BAthing comes amiss to them in the way of food and many live to a ?at age. The Jackal Buzzard (B. jackal). Black, tail chestnut red, sub- minal band black, chest rufous white, mottled with black. A very ndsome species, which is fairly frequently imported, it has been
algorithms.footnote: 3d at Keswick on two occasions, a full account appearing in the icultural Magazine.
algorithms.bodyText: I have never seen this species drink. It is perfectly hardy and pears to be long-lived in captivity. In a wild state this species feeds ely on snakes. It is found all over Central and Southern Africa. The African Buzzard (B. desertorum ) and the Augur Buzzard (B. jur), the latter a very handsome bird, are both brought over occa- jnally, and have been kept by several aviculturists, while the lowing species have been known in captivity. The Long-legged zzard (B. ferox), the Augural Buzzard (B. auguralis), the Lineated ( z zard (B. lineatus), the Red-tailed Buzzard (B. borealis ), the Penn- > vanian Buzzard (B. lalissimus), the White-tailed Buzzard (B. jicaiulatus), and the Red-backed Buzzard (B. erythronotus). The Shining Buzzard-Hawk ( Asturina nitida) and the Grey Buzzard-

G. H. Gurney--Birds of Prey Hawk (A. plagiata) have both been kept at the London Zoologi Gardens. Natterer's Hawk ( Rupornis natteri), very close to Asturina. A r; bird in captivity. It is found in Brazil. The Chilian Eagle ( Geranoaetus melanoleucus) . Black, wings grj under parts white barred with grey. This species was kept Northrepps. It preferred carrion to fresh food, occasionally it uttei| a shrill piercing note. It has also been kept at the London Zoologi j Gardens. The Dark-winged Buzzard ( Leucopternis scotoptera) and t Mantled Buzzard (L. palliata) have been imported. They inha| South America, and the Zoological Gardens has also had representati of the Ash-coloured Hawk ( Urubitinga anthracina) and the Band tailed Buzzard ( U . zonura) from Mexico and Chili. The Crowned Harpy (Harpy haliaetus coronatus). Chocolate brov wings grey, a long occipital crest, rump brown, tail black, under paj brown. Two Crowned Harpys were kept at Catton many years ago. It a powerful and savage bird, very much of a carrion feeder. It ran^ over the greater part of South America. The Black-necked Buzzard (Buteogallus nigricollis). Chestnut w; black markings, head grey, remainder of the body black. Anotl rare species from Brazil, solitary examples of which, however, ha once or twice been brought alive to England. The Brahminy Kite ( Haliastur Indus). Chestnut with darker wim head, neck and lower parts white, streaked with black. This Inclii bird is sometimes seen in captivity. Its flight is wonderfully easy a buoyant; one that was kept at Northrepps spent the greater part j its time on the ground in preference to a perch. This form has co paratively weak feet. Two other closely allied species of Haliasi have been imported, viz. II. intermedice, the Javan Brahminy Kil and H. sphenurus, the Whistling Kite. The Red Kite ( Milvus milvus). This noble bird still breeds, thanks i strict preservation, in Britain. Centuries ago it was common even! the streets of London, acting as a scavenger. Its broad wings ai deeply forked tail are always distinctive when it is seen in the air. captivity it adapts itself to a sedentary life, but is easily kept, a:
