The smallest M ileus and a common lian bird. Brown above, head and neck somewhat rufescent, ngs and primaries darker brown, tail brown, tipped with white d distinctly barred with black, under surface dull rufous brown, is species is rather frequently imported. I have known it to be sold the Egyptian Kite, but its much smaller size would serve to identify f It has often been kept at the London Zoological Gardens. The Black Kite ( M. migrans). Above dark brown, tail dark brown, lining to rufous at the tip, head and throat whitish, under surface ous brown. This species has been known to live twenty-two years captivity, and is frequently seen in collections of birds of prey. It found in Southern and Western Europe, accidental in England, the i ater part of Africa, and probably extends into Central Asia. The sely allied M. cegyptius is also imported. The Black-winged Kite ( Elanus ccendeus). Above ashy grey, ehead and sides of face white, wings grey and black, tail grey-white, ier surface pure white, iris brilliant carmine. This very beautiful 1 distinctive little Kite is an admirable bird for an aviary. I brought ee back alive from East Africa, and have never kept more attractive wks. They became absolutely tame, and as soon as they saw me uld run up to the side of their aviary, whistling loudly and fluttering *ir wings, in the hopes of getting a mealworm, of which they are very d. It has frequently been kept at the London Zoological Gardens, : I do not think it a very long-lived species in captivity. It is nd over the whole of Africa. The Sociable Marsh Hawk ( Rostrhamus sociabilis). Slate-grey all ?r, wings blackish, iris red. This very aberrant form has been sorted a very few times. It feeds entirely on shellfish, and its raordinary long slender bill with a large terminal hook is no doubt : y useful for extracting the molluscs from their shells. It ranges ough the northern parts of South America. As far as I know, only two species of Pernis have ever been kept in ifinement in England, viz. The Honey Buzzard ( P. apivorus) and the isted Honey Buzzard (P. ptilorhyncha) , and these did not live for

G. H. Gurney--Birds of Prey any length of time. These species would require plenty of gri bees, and wasps as food if they were to do well, but no doubt wo take small birds and rats as well. Mr. J. G. Millais kept a Ho Buzzard for some time on a diet of French plums and honey, the c things it would eat, while almost more extraordinary was a specir kept by Lord Lilford, which was fed on rice pudding. Sub-family Falconince--maxilla notched The Crested Black Kite ( Baza lophotes). Above glossy green black, varied with white and chestnut on the wings, a broad b; of white across the chest, below white banded with chestnut. ] Indian species has been kept at the London Zoological Gardens. The White-legged Falconet ( Microhierax melanoleucus). Ab bluish-black, under surface white. This tiny Eastern species, and next one, require artificial heat, at any rate in the winter ; they certainly delicate, but if they can be acclimatized they make most delightful birds in a small aviary. They feed entirely on wor beetles, moths, small lizards, and will eat small fish too. Both spe< have been seen at the London Zoological Gardens, and I once kep specimen of the Pigmy Falcon, but it did not live long. The Pigmy Falcon ( Poliohierax semitorquatus). Blue-grey abc forehead, cheeks, rump and under parts white ; habitat Central Afric The Kestrel ( Tinnunuculus alaudarius ). The Common Kes is too well known, both in captivity and in a wild state, for any desc] tion of it, or its habits, to be necessary. The most plentiful of Brit Hawks, its range extends as far east as China and as far south Mombassa in East Africa. The Lesser Kestrel ( T . cenchneis). Claws white, back of male spotted. Very similar in habits to the Common Kestrel, but particularly hardy in confinement. It is widespread over the Afrit Continent, and reaches the Pyrenees. Other species of Kesl ( T . gracilis), the Nankeen Kestrel ( T . cenchroides), the American Kes' ( T . sparverius ), and the South African Kestrel ( C . rupicola). The lat species I have kept for several years. They want a dry enclosed avi (unheated) for winter. All the Kestrels are long-lived in confineme The Ked-footed Falcon (Erythropus vespertinus) has been kept
algorithms.reference: G. II. Gurney--Birds of Prey
algorithms.bodyText: ford, but I do not think elsewhere. The male is blue-grey, tail nvnish, thighs chestnut; the female is barred with blackish above, id, nape and under parts rufous. Legs and feet red. The Hobby ( Falco subbuteo). Fairly often seen in confinement. The Red-thighed Hobby (F . femoralis) . I have had a pair of these nitiful little South American Hawks for over two years. They have iwn no signs of breeding. They have to be kept shut up in winter they are not hardy. I do not think this species has been previously pt in confinement. The Eleonora Falcon (F. eleonorce). Everywhere dark brown lining to black, tail brown. The late A. E. Jamrach imported ese Falcons as far back as 1860. One of these birds lived at >rthrepps till 1867, and there is a beautiful picture of it by Wolf, : 3 great animal painter, when it was in entire bright Hobby-like image. The very similar Ash-coloured Falcon (F . concolor) has been pt at the London Zoological Gardens. Other species which have en kept in confinement are the Rufous-throated Falcon (F . rufigularis) an Mexico and the Orange-thighed Falcon (F. fusco-ccerulescens ) also >m South America. The Merlin ( F . cEsalon ) is a lively and :eresting little species in captivity, constantly uttering its shrill te when excited or alarmed. There seems to be no reason why this \0x25A0d, which nearly always nests on the ground, should not breed in ptivity if suitable accommodation was provided for it. Young birds ten from the nest and brought up by hand make delightful pets, t they must be kept in an indoor aviary large enough for them to ie plenty of exercise in during the winter. I have never, however, md this species very long-lived. The Peregrine ( Falco peregrinus) * .is well-known bird has been kept at one time or another in most ivate collections of Raptores. Perhaps I have been unfortunate, t of the six or seven I have kept only one was what may be called satisfactory bird. Like so many of the British Hawks, unless reared >m the nest they are probably brought to one after having been nged or caught in a trap and therefore are slightly damaged, as fortunately the Peregrine is one of the most persecuted of the birds prey. I always feel a Peregrine is in a wrong place in an aviary, 'wever large a one. It is essentially a bird of the air, and anyone

G. H. Gurney--Birds of Prey who has seen it stooping at a Pigeon or a Teal, or dashing v tremendous courage and fierceness at an intruder molesting its n must realize that a wild Peregrine is a very different bird from cooped up in an aviary. It may be said to be one of the oldest b kept in confinement, as it has been used in Falconry from very ren times. The Lanner (F. feldeggi). Above ashy-brown mottled with fulv( whitish crown and lower surface mottled with brown. Many h been kept in confinement. The longest record that I have is six ye but it may have been kept for a longer period at the Zoological Gardi This Falcon is greatly used in Hawking by the Arabs. Other clos! allied species which from time to time are seen in captivity are Black-cheeked Falcon ( F. melanogenys) from Australia, the Beap Falcon ( F . biarmicus) from South Africa, the Barbary Falcon barbarus ) and the Juggur Falcon ( F.jugger ) from India. The Saker Falcon ( Hierofalco saJcer). Head pale rufous, up surface pale brown, all the feathers margined with rufous, tail j brown, under parts whitish. Has been kept at Lilford and more t once in the London Zoological Gardens. A young female in the Sociel collection some years ago was almost as dark as a Fcdco subniger ; had the mantle of a very similar hue. This bird had been brought fi Alexandria in Egypt. Two species of the Arctic Falcons are fairly often imported. T are the Greenland Falcon (H . candicans ) and the Iceland Fat (. H. islandus), but I can find no authentic record of the Gyr Fait (//. gyrfalco) ever having been kept in captivity ; though in 1 Lord Lilford obtained a Falcon which he considered to be this spec it was captured at sea off Cape Finisterre. Family Pandionidce , distinct character. Outer toe reversible, ti closely feathered. The Osprey ( Pandion haliaetus). Above dark brown, crest, h" and lower parts white. Has been kept at the Zoological Gard( but I have no other records of it, and it must be very seldom imported
Mrs. Pres tic ic h --Loveb i rds

(Continued from p. 150) Agapornis pullaria The Red-faced Lovebird of West Africa was described as long ago 1758, and has had a number of names bestowed upon it, such as Little Red-headed Parrakeet ", " Guiney Sparrow ", " Red-headed linea Parrakeet ", " Ethiopian Parrakeet " and Agapornis xanthops. is generally regarded as being the most difficult of the family to climatize, though when this is accomplished it is acknowledged to fairly hardy. Certainly when first imported the mortality is very gh. On arrival they look very well and seem pretty tame, but this induced partly by the crowded travelling conditions and partly by eir each having a clipped wing. Why this bird alone amongst the ivebirds should be clipped is a mystery. It is best to keep them caged d let them moult the stumps naturally ; but if an attempt is made to aw them great care should be exercised, as any sudden shock may ove very injurious to this highly sensitive bird. Only two or three lbs should be drawn at a time, the operation being repeated at the d of a week. They are frequently brought over from Africa on rice the husk, but, in the absence of this, ordinary rice will do just as well, ley take readily to white millet and canary, the former generally being eferred. Some will also eat a little sunflower and a few oats. Fruit ey do not seem to care for, except occasionally a little sweet apple, ttle trouble will be experienced with this species if it is kept caged til full-winged and is not put out of doors until May is well advanced, ley can then be left out the whole year. Red-faced are rather uninteresting aviary birds as they spend the 2 ater part of their time sitting in a group in the shelter, seemingly diking the glare of the sun. Occasionally, however, they have bursts energy, when they see how much damage they can do, stripping a tall tree in an incredibly short time. In flight they are a joy to behold, ssibly being the most beautiful of the family in this respect. They 3 quite easy to sex, the under wing-coverts being black in the male d green in the female ; the hen can also be distinguished by the

Mrs. Prcstivich--Lovebirds paler colour of her face, it being more of a yellow-orange than orang red, also the blue spot on the rump is paler than in the cock. Although this bird has been known to aviculturists for so long, ar has been exported to Europe in such numbers as to make it compar; lively scarce in its own country, no record exists of it having be( bred in captivity. Mr. G. C. Porter very nearly succeeded in 1901 he was unfortunately away at the time, so was unable to give mar particulars. They nested in a small box with half a cocoa-nut hus cemented inside. On his return he found two fine youngsters, fu feathered, lying dead on the ground. They were very fat and appeare to be as large, if not larger, than the old birds. He attributed h failure either to the mice which infested the aviary or the excessiv heat at the time. The young of this species are like the adult femal except that the forehead is yellow, with no orange tinge, and tl yellow-orange near the base of the bill and on the throat is paler. 1 1880 Mr. W. T. Catleugh put some into a large cage, and almos immediately a hen took possession of a cocoa-nut husk and began t. lay eggs. Some Budgerigars in the same cage, however, threw them ou Eggs were obtained both by Mrs. Anningson and Mr. R. Phillipps i 1902 and by Mr. Shore-Baily in 1915. There have been several instance of partial success in Germany, which show that the clutch is from thre to five eggs, which the hen alone incubates for about twenty-one days the young in down are scantily covered, white, with pure white fee and beak. Concerning their life in the wild, Mr. George Bates {The Ibv 1905, p. 89) writes :-- c# They resemble miniature Parrots in their tones and actions, a well as in their appearance. They go about in small flocks, makin little metallic squeaky cries, which yet have something in them recallin the screams of Parrots. They like open country, and especially th tall grass called # ukae ', from which they get their Bulu name c Kos-ukae ' ( # Kos ', meaning Parrot) ; hence they are more common inland, for grass is scarce within a hundred miles of the coast. At th back of my house at Efulen was a sort of wild fig-tree, and when it fruit was ripe a flock of these little birds often visited it. Among ther were apparently young birds, which would sit on a limb making a grea racket and fluttering their wings till the others brought them food. '

By E. Maud Knobel A great deal has been written from time to time on the larger icaws, but I wonder how many aviculturists know the fascination the smaller Macaws and what charming and delightful pets they a make. There are some six or seven different species of the smaller icaws, including the Spix, a very beautiful species, of delicate blue d grey in colour. All the others are green with bright patches of lour about them. They vary greatly in size, even those of the same ecies. Mine have the same food as the Amazon Parrots, i.e. equal rts of giant canary seed and white sunflower, mixed with a good rn mixture containing wheat, oats, dari and maize. When young they i :piire bread and milk, and even when adult I give it to them now and ain. Of course, water and fruit, chiefly apple, dry biscuit, toast, d pea-nuts. I must confess that for years I looked at these Macaws and found ev left me " cold ". The ones that one generally saw in dealers' ops did not seem to me to be very interesting. They never seemed ry tame or friendly, nor did they show very much intelligence, and was a long time before I was attracted by them. Then one day, ing into Chapman's, I saw a tame Severe, which came on to my ; nd and allowed me to do what I liked with it. He very soon made a nquest of me. The dark green of his plumage with the brilliant I arlet on the inside of the wings, the darker red on the under side of I e tail made him a most beautiful and attractive creature. I longed possess him, but hesitated on account of his voice. I had always iderstood Macaws could scream and were unendurable in a room.

E. Maud Knobel--The Smaller Macaivs I finally decided to go and consult the Zoo on this point. Their opin was that they did not think he would be more noisy than many of i Amazons, so I decided to risk it and returned post haste to Chapmai Alas ! how often one has missed things by hesitating. It is fatal in 1 bird world. If you see something and want it you must have it n and never pause to think. When I got back to Chapman's, and I h only been away half an hour, the Severe was sold and destined foi home in India. However, before he departed there he was put on depc at the Zoo, where I had an opportunity of visiting him several tim What happened there I do not know, for he was not on show to the pub] and was kept in the inner room, but somehow this affected his temp and one day when I put my hand up to take him out he bit me throu the finger. This was a surprise I did not expect, and after that I ne^ touched him again. The head keeper, who was not there when happened, could hardly believe it, and took him out to show me hi mistaken I was, whereupon he flew at him and bit him through t lip. I have often wondered whether in India he recovered his previc good temper. After that I began to " cool off " Macaws, and it w some time before I thought of possessing one. Then one morning as I was dressing I heard the voice of a Pari across the square. I thought to myself, " Well, someone else must ha set up a Parrot and put it in the window." Its cries were incessant, a after a time they seemed to come nearer, but even then it did not occ to me that it was an escaped bird. It was not until after breakfa when I was just starting to clean and feed my own birds, that the cf of the Parrot seemed suddenly to have come close at hand. I look out of the window and there on our balcony rail was an Illiger Mac? and a woman on the next balcony with an enormous broom. H( she hoped to catch it with a broom was a mystery. I immediate ran down to the balcony, and I heard the woman say, " Ah ! Now she catch it." I put a Blue-fronted Amazon that was in the room on the balcony hoping that that would attract it while I went for an emp cage. This I soon procured, and returned, having put plenty of fo< at the bottom of the cage. I need not have bothered much, for no sood did the little Illiger see the cage than he ran straight into it and was ve glad to find himself once more in safe quarters. By this time there w
algorithms.title: E. Maud Knobel--The Smaller Macaws
algorithms.bodyText: te a crowd below the balcony, and as I turned to go in two people ae round the corner each armed with a cage, and great was their ippointment when they saw that he had already been successfully ured. He turned out to be a clear little friendly bird, and soon de himself quite at home and had a good square meal. He was in e condition, but had a damaged foot. Of course, whenever one finds idling these days one has to give notice to the police, and this we y did, but I must say I did hope that no one would claim him. o days went by and nothing happened, and I was really beginning hink he was safely mine when one evening a policeman arrived with working man and his wife, who said they had lost a little Macaw,
algorithms.listItem: ent down and saw them, and when they described the injured foot new all my hopes were gone, and I sadly went up to fetch the bird, ver shall I forget the scene that followed, the joy of that woman and bird. She put it round her neck and kissed it over and over again, nother having found her long lost child could not have been more ghted than was this poor working woman. The man then explained 7 they had no children, and he had saved up and bought the bird n Chapman because she was so lonely while he was out at work. ;y lived in a tenement in Somerstown and the bird had never been , cage, but was allowed to wander about the room free. The woman . thrown up a window to speak to a child in the street, and the bird . taken fright at something and darted through the window and 'i gone in a moment. It apparently had been out three days before mght it, so no wonder it was glad at the sight of food, though I still 'vel that it so quickly went into a cage when it had not been used to . And what touched me more than anything was that the man
algorithms.bodyText: red to pay me for the care I had given it. However, I gave them some ice and told them if they wanted to keep it always loose about the m they had better cut one wing--that would make it quite safe, and I e them the old cage that it was in. They went away a very happy , and a big smiling policeman looking on. Well, that little bird quite decided me that when opportunity red I must have an Illiger. However, it turned out that a Severe was to be my first venture > the Macaw world. I was at Chapman's one day when a lot of

E. Maud Knobel--The Smaller Macatos Parrots arrived, and amongst them a most beautiful specimen of Severe or Brown-fronted Macaw. Why they should be called Se\ I cannot imagine. He seemed in perfect condition and talked a li I was told by the man who brought him over. But all he seemed to was " Buck up ". I carried him home in triumph, and for a few ho was very happy, but my happiness did not last, for my beautiful l seemed to be drooping and ill ; he would not eat. I went back Chapman and learned that the consignment had been beautifi brought over and well housed as far as Havre, but there they had 1 to tranship, and for the last part of the journey the birds had b put on the deck and many of them had caught a severe chill. By t time Bucky, as I called him, seemed very ill indeed ; he could nothing and seemed to be in pain and suffering from stoppage. I tr a good dose of salad oil, an hour after I tried castor oil and put 1 on a hot bottle and kept him in my lap near a fire. Then I tried a d of Glauber salts, which had the desired effect, and then he tried a lit warm bread and milk. After that I knew I had saved him, but it 1 been a " near go ", and had he been left in the shop or gone to some( who did not understand, his life in England would have been indi brief. He has just turned out one of the greatest successes one ] ever had. He literally adores me. Overjoyed when I come into i room and hysterically ecstatic if I go near his cage, and cries whe leave him. If he is out, which he often is, playing on my swing dog chain, he is only happy on it for a short time and then flies on my shoulder, letting himself slide down until he lies like a baby on back on my lap. That is his favourite place, and he will remain th for hours while I try and answer inquiries of the Society on what to with a Parrot who has plucked himself bare, or why we cannot sup] sample copies of the Magazine, etc. Bucky never knows a cl moment; he is the merriest bird of all my collection, always hi about something, either swinging in his swing, playing with a pi< of chain, or lying on his back at the bottom of his cage playing witl piece of wood and laughing to himself all the time. He talks quit< lot, but not real words, and he tries desperately hard to whistle. E do Macaws whistle ? I have an idea they cannot. Anyway, he if great success.

algorithms.bodyText: My next venture in this line was an Illiger. On looking through ot of packing cases filled with Amazon Parrots at Chapman's, I v that three of them each contained one Illiger Macaw. They were most miserable birds. One was almost bare of feathers and in a :y poor way. The next was a little better, but wild and inclined bite. The third was also a little misery, soiled all over by the )ppings of the bigger birds, and every time he tried to feed a Blue- nt gave him a savage peck and he retired to the back of the crate. 11 he had managed to exist during the long voyage over. I brought a home, and really when I looked at him I almost felt ashamed of n. He had no wing feathers and no tail whatever, and was a roughly miserable creature. In fact, during the week that followed ras several times asked if he was dead yet ? The first thing I did was to feed him up on good boiled maize, bread i milk, apple, and Parish's food in the water. Then I washed him warm water and put him by a fire to dry. At the end of a week he ?an to put on some flesh and fill out a bit, and his plumage began to k a little less like wire and to take on a more silky appearance, soon proved himself an amusing little beggar, and very soon took water like a duck. Now the Severe Macaw never bathes, and hates ng sprayed or anything to do with water. Not so the Illiger. He 1 get into quite a big basin and literally lie down in the water, first one side and then the other. He often gets so wet that I have to n on the gas-fire to dry him up a bit or else roll him in a towel. He f ]uite different in character to the Severe, though he loves playing out, and will run about the floor as quick as lightning, and likes ng on the floor, which the Severe does not. He gets into the waste ! per basket and will carefully take pieces of paper out and strew them 3 r my floor. I have sometimes come in and found my floor looking e a snowfield covered in white envelopes from members of the iiety. He has one horrid habit, and that is he likes to come and e you a nip in the back of your ankle. I think it is only play : still s a nip. Now he can say quite a lot of wrnrds, but mostly talks in a i d whisper. I have heard that whispering is one of the characteristics Macaws. Is this so ? He constantly asks " What are you doing ? " I is so fond of the word " doing " that he will repeat it half a dozen

E. Maud Knobel--The Smaller Macaws times before answering " I'm busy When I first had him he show no red on the lower breast and very little on the rump, and onh feather or so on the frontal. Now, of course, he is perfect, with plumage glossy like silk, far more so than the Severe. This I put do to the constant bathing. But his tail is his weak point. He seems| grow the feathers and then they break off or are malformed. I supp< why people do not keep Macaws more is their voice, for they ha voices and can use them. Taking them all round they are no wo than a Ring-neck or an Alexandrine, but they can be persistent, thou I have always found a remedy to stop it, either covering them over letting them out. But, like all the Parrot tribe, they generally lib good scream about sunset, when, in a wild state, I imagine they r returning to their roosting-places for the night. The two I have a far more gentle and reliable than most Amazons, and there is no dou about their devotion to one. I have several times had an opportuni of seeing very tame and charming Spix Macaws. Of the smallest all this tribe there is a delightful little specimen of the Noble Mac; now at the Zoo. It is very tame and talks a little in spite of a defecti beak. It is a beautiful little bird, not unlike a miniature Sevei though the head is very different, but the scarlet on the top of t shoulder and inside the wings gives it a very striking appearand Of the other smaller Macaws at the Zoo there is a nice Yellow Collare but he always seems rather a dull bird, perhaps it is because he is ratb high up and one cannot get at him to pet him. But the pair of Illige that live at the end of the house are really a fine pair of birds. 0 wishes they could be seen in an aviary where an attempt at breedii might be tried. They are most amusing in the way they play with ea< other, and the other day when I was watching them the cock wj feeding the hen. They are not tame, and will not allow one to tou< them. This is probably because they are sufficient unto each other. I have written these few remarks in the hope that others who mi have kept this group may be induced to give us their experience ar so help to widen our knowledge.
algorithms.table: ; The Tragopan's Display 193
algorithms.bodyText: The male of the Horned Tragopan (Tragopan satyra) has the head istly black, the neck and the whole of the under surface bright ange-carmine, the back and tail being brownish. Over the whole of e body plumage are distributed spots of white, with black edgings. ie skin of the throat is blue, more or less obscured by black hair-like itures. A peculiar wattle is situated on the throat, but this is so ntracted as to be invisible except on such rare occasions as during , e courtship display. The same may be said of a pair of wattles owing from the top of the head, which are completely hidden by e plumage except on rare occasions. The female of the Tragopan of an inconspicuous mottled brownish hue. During the breeding ason the cock Tragopan may frequently be seen to perform a lateral splay, walking round the hen with his tail and body plumage more less depressed laterally, a form of display that is common to many Peasants. But the full frontal display of this bird, which is seldom seen, one of the most remarkable exhibitions in Nature ; quite as extra- dinary a transformation as that of the display of either the Argus heasant or the Great Bustard. For the past twenty years and more I have known Tragopans captivity, but only on rare occasions have I seen the full display, id I will endeavour to describe what I saw on a recent occasion, id only regret that no description can adequately convey the thrill lat this wonderful spectacle gave me. The hen Tragopan was walking unconcernedly out into the open id I had not noticed the cock bird in the darkness of some under- *owth in the background, until suddenly out he came with a run, s body erect, with the white-spotted carmine feathers of the breast id flanks spread out like a skirt ; his black face surmounted by two 'ect horns of vivid verdeter blue, and from his throat a large bib of tense blue, barred with red. Thus he ran forward looking like a ttle Mephistopheles. Probably he saw that he was being watched, t he soon stopped, shook his head, and both horns and bib quickly mtracted and disappeared, and the Tragopan became once more normal bird.

Capt. Reginald Waud--Notes from my Aviaries These peculiar wattles on the head and throat are found in a the species of Tragopans, and no doubt the display is similar in though the colours and patterns differ in the various species.
algorithms.sectionHeader: D. Seth-Smit NOTES FROM MY AVIARIES By Captain Reginald Waud
algorithms.bodyText: The birds in one's aviaries at this season are so very interes| that I thought some members might like to hear of my doings. One aviary, inhabited by small Finches, so far is doing very \ One pair of Three-coloured Parrot-Finches have built the most attract nest. They took to a box nest made from a stump of a tree, hung on the wall, with quite a small hole for them to get in and \ They completely filled this with fine grass, twisting the grass round small entrance hole in the most wonderful way, making it inrposs for one to see in, so that I have no idea if there are even eggs ir but I feel pretty certain there are, as the hen is sitting tight. 1 I h in the course of a few days I may hear the voices of young birds. 1 second pair of Three-coloured Parrot-Finches laid seven eggs in a i on the wall, and then started to build. They covered all the el and eventually forsook the nest, and I felt they were pretty hope from the first. They then started a half moult, and now have recovej and are in fine condition, and I hope they will go to nest again be! the end of the season. I have two pairs of the ordinary Parrot Fincll both nesting, and the eggs should hatch in a few days. Diamond Doj also are sitting in this aviary. I find my pair very free breeders. In another aviary I have a pair of Shamahs ; the hen is sitting) five eggs. As soon as these hatch I intend opening the door of aviary into the garden and letting the cock out to find live food j the young. My Blue Birds in another aviary had a nest of five eggs, )| unfortunately a mouse got in and ate all the eggs. They went to n again about a fortnight after this calamity, and now the hen is sitt 1 Since the above was written three young Three-coloured Parrot Finches h left the nest, (12th June).

The Scarlet-chested or Splendid Parrakeet (Neophema splendida) Western and South Australia, the most beautiful of a beautiful gen has always been regarded as a great rarity, and for several years has b( thought to be extinct. Now a few examples have been noted in N South Wales, so that although extremely rare it appears to have very extensive range and may hold its own. A good coloured pis of this species appears in the Emu for April, 1927. Another of the nearly extinct Parrakeets of Australia and perhs an even more wonderful one than that first mentioned, has also be recently noted in New South Wales, namely the Paradise or Beauti Parrakeet (Pscphotus pulclierrimus). A writer in the Emu describ the appearance of a little party of five of these, driven out of th ordinary habitat by the drought which has recently been very sevs in the interior. It is much to be hoped that the Australian Ornithologists' Uni will use their influence to persuade the Government to take up serious the question of breeding some of these fast disappearing Parrakes in suitable aviaries in Australia. If put in charge of competent avici turists, there is no reason why some of these birds should not be saved

algorithms.bodyText: Mr. Heumann contributes some interesting Bird Notes to the current iber of the Emu, and from these we extract the followin" :-- The rarer species of Parrakeets could be bred most assuredly in ibers if aviculture were not looked upon as vandalism. Turquoise rots are supposed to be almost extinct. As a fact, when I lost my c bird of this species I had to pay #30 for another specimen. Out ieyoung which I reared, my friend, Mr. Harvey, jun., of Adelaide, * has a pair of them, again reared eight young this season in two >ds of two pairs each. Mrs. Mellor, of Adelaide, bred about a dozen icess Alexandra Parrots ; so also did Mr. Lienau. Out in the open e birds have not nearly the same chance, as Hawks especially ?e havoc amongst them. But catapults and pea-rifles and the atific and unscientific egg-collectors do their share in the speedy A \0x25A0rmination of anything that may be rare." Mr. James Charles Edwards, of 629 South Grand Avenue, Los eles, California, is probably the largest breeder of Budgerigars in United States. Commencing about fifteen years ago with one dred pairs, he has now 1,500 pairs. His aviaries are feet by 100 feet, divided into ten compartments, each housing breeding pairs. He is also breeding Blues, Whites, and alts. Besides the Budgerigar aviaries Mr. Edwards has others in which s breeding Bleeding-heart, Cuban and other species of Doves, iatiels, Redrumps, Lorikeets, Pennants, Blue-wing Grass Parrakeets, several species of Lovebirds, as well as many of the ornamental dies, and he greatly prizes some Tabuan Parrakeets given to him he Marquess of Tavistock for experimental purposes. Ae are very pleased to receive a copy of the first issue of The 7 erigar Bulletin, published by the Budgerigar Club. In it will ound much useful advice and many valuable tips for those who Id produce the various colour variations to which this most wonder- )f Parrakeets is subject.

Those who are rearing Budgerigars should remember that a wea youngster, providing he is not denude of flight-feathers, if caged { petted will become perfectly tame and make the most delightful bird pets. He will delight to sit on one's head, shoulder or hand, ; will actually repeat several words with very little training. The older members of the Society will recollect the instructive ,j often humorous writings that appeared in our Magazine a good m| years ago by the Rev. C. D. Farrar and will welcome the appeara| of a new book on his reminiscences as an aviculturist. It is fulj delightful humour and sound advice, and he does not mind record his failures as well as his successes. His accounts of interviews \j the dealers of the past will bring back vivid memories of some of i old friends of twenty years ago, such as Joseph Abrahams, of St. Georj Street, East, and Maschke, of Islington. He reminds us of the 1 temperature and lack of ventilation of the latter dealer's shop, w] those of us who visited it will recall. But both Abrahams and Masc sometimes had birds which we never see nowadays. From Abrah Mr. Farrar bought a pair of Poes, better known perhaps as Tuis, they are not Australian birds, as we are told, but New Zealand. Mr. Farrar's reminiscences go back to the time when Turquok could be obtained without much difficulty, and that is a long time He was fortunate enough to obtain two pairs, both of which b though one nest full of young birds died through the cock-bird fee* them on elder. He tells us that for some years he was not without species, but not knowing what was coming he sold them all, as n other people did. Now they are on the point of becoming extinct. Aviculturists will find much to interest and amuse then

algorithms.bodyText: Although this is a small book and produced-at an extremely low gure, it is one of the most interesting books we have read for a long time, vhy do birds sing ? Why migrate ? Why do some species require considerable area of territory for each breeding pair while others est in colonies ? Such questions may never have occurred to some f us, but they are of great importance, and are ably discussed by the uthor, who has for many years made a special study of these problems, 'he book, in short, is the view of an observer who has carefully studied he writings of the latest and best observers and put them thoroughly o the test. The territory theory, for instance, for which credit is due o Mr. Eliot Howard, applies to such birds as the Warblers, which lave a very restricted feeding area, but does not apply to those which ange far afield for their food. Gatke's theory of the speed and altitude >f flight during migration has been shown by recent observers to be it fault, the movement of birds at such time being much like that at )ther times, but in a straight line and towards a definite goal.

algorithms.bodyText: Sir,-- With reference to my notes on the American Siskin in the las number of the Magazine, I have looked at the illustration of Chrisomitril arisiis, mentioned in your footnote, and my birds certainly do no belong to this species. They much more closely resemble the Blacl Siskin, C. atrata, found in Bolivia and North Peru. They differ fron this bird by having much more yellow on the under parts, by the win* bar being white instead of yellow, and by the hen having the nape of th neck greenish-yellow instead of black. I shall take the first opportunity of examining the skins at the British Museum as they have been unabli to name it for me from my crude description. W. Shore-Baily.

Sir,-- Bowdler Sharpe, in British Birds (Allen's Naturalist's Library) j vol. ii, p. 85, says, " There can be no doubt that the Snowy Owl becomes whiter with age, and that the very old individuals lose their markings almost entirely, though it is a question whether the females ever become perfectly snow-white and lose their spots and bars." I should therefore like to record that the oldest specimen in the Zoo, which was received several years ago in the barred plumage, became at its fir si moult in the Gardens nearly if not quite as free from dark markings as it is at present. It will be interesting to see how its recently received! and well-barred companions moult out, and those who practise photo- graphy would be doing useful work in recording their progress. Frank Finn.
algorithms.figure: Correspondence
algorithms.bodyText: Sir, --If you think it of enough interest for the Avicultural agazine, I should like to report that I have two White Budgerigars lly reared and flying in my outdoor aviary. The parents are a Blue >ck and a Yellow hen, quite a different cross from the pair who bred hites last year in my aviaries, these were two Blue-bred Greens. There ere also in the nest two rather Olive Green and a Pale Yellow, and e hen is now incubating five more eggs. Alice Chatterton.

Sir, --Following on Mrs. Prestwich's very excellent article on the rvebirds, may I offer a few suggestions arising from my own experience liich may be of help to breeders ? My chief trouble, in common with hers, has been young dead in shell. I refer to the Nyasa and the lack-cheek. Mr. Denys Weston recently published an account of an ingenious ntrivance for retaining moisture in the nest. For it is probably a ct these species affect in nature damp situations. Anyhow, I have far shirked the operation of re-modelling my nesting boxes, and have 1 1 upon an alternative which appears to answer the purpose well ough. Upon the floor of the aviary I set a shallow pan of water and ranged therein a supply of the leaves of spinach-beet or kindred getable. The birds eat this greedily, but in addition they carry off e wet leaves and arrange them about their eggs. By this expedient i have hatched this spring a large percentage of the eggs of both j ecies, and the young show a much decreased mortality. The water the pan must be renewed daily, as spinach-beet soon fouls it. The j sting material most in favour is the bark of willow twigs, and I I d, too, that the sort of wood shavings used in parcels is acceptable. Be sure not to use aluminium rings on these birds. They work them |over the tibia, and swelling and gangrene rapidly set in. I have now three pairs of the Abyssinian Lovebird (A. taranta ) p*i sting. These birds were with me three years without attempting

Correspondence to nest. One pair have three young three weeks old. They used r nesting material of any sort. I could not see that the cock took ar. part in the incubation. My Masked Lovebirds (A. personata) have gone to nest within fh days of their arrival. They are constructing rather stout edifices * twigs, not bark, in the boxes. Being rather large birds, the nestir boxes should be of generous proportions. So far, this species hq refused to have anything to say to green food, which I shall neverthele.j continue to offer. M. Sir,-- I have just bought Dr. Ilopkinson's book, Records of Bin Bred in Captivity. I see that there is only one record of the Desei Bullfinch for the United Kingdom. I reared two nests of them last yea Two young birds each time. The first nest contained four young, bi when the first two left the nest I went to clean out the box and frightene out two others which were still in the fluff, dropping on to the flex from about six feet, one got killed and the other so hopelessly cripple its legs that after it had left the nest and could fly I destroyed it nvysei as it could not stand. Three young left the first nest ; one died later. Two left tl: second nest. In the autumn I caught them up and caged them, whe two of them suddenly died. Whether it was fright or not, or owirs to the others, as they were not very friendly towards each other, 1 d not know. I exchanged the two others with another member. In 1923 I had two nests of Hybrids, Indian Silverbill X Zebra Find Four young left the first nest; one died later. These three all san so I suppose they were cocks. The second nest only produced on young, as the three young of the first brood always roosted in the lies' It is rather a wonder that any were reared. algorithms.figure: THE BUDGERIGAR AND ITS COLOUR VARIETIES By D. Seth-Smitii From my earliest days I have known and loved the Budgerigar,
algorithms.bodyText: a child I remember some that were owned by an elder sister and ch I thought the most delightful birds in the world. There was lething about them that fascinated me then, and they fascinate still, and I shall always regard this species as the most wonderful all of the Parrakeets. There is only one species of Budgerigar, t no other species is closely related to it, or has one-half of its charming *its and ways. It has taken to a life in captivity as no other species Parrot has, and to such an extent has it been bred and reared in tivity that the world is independent of the original source of supply, if no more ever come out of Australia its numbers in Europe, Asia, America can be kept up and increased to almost any extent. As everybody knows, the Budgerigar, in its original dress, is of a utiful grass green, barred on the back, and with the forehead :ht Canary yellow. In this dress it occurs in its native habitat, jtralia, where it migrates from one locality to another in flocks, owing the ripening grass, upon the seeds of which it feeds. Yellow

206 D. Seth-Smith--The Budgerigar and its Colour Varieties birds have been noted in such flocks, so it is not to be wondered at tl a yellow race was produced in Europe many years ago. . Exact when these yellow birds were first produced I do not know, but 1 know that the yellow Budgerigars one saw ten or twenty years ;i were of a better and purer yellow than those one sees to-day. Yelll birds are not very popular just now, and this may account for 1 want of care that has occurred in their breeding. They have been! much crossed with greens that most of the birds one sees have mi; too much green in their colouring. What one wants to see is the 1 1 lutino Budgerigar with pink eyes and no trace of green whatev Such birds have been produced, but the ordinary type of yell Budgerigar has dark eyes and a green tinge on the rump. The t lutino would lack entirely the black pigment which, together wl yellow or orange pigment and peculiar feather structure, gives normal green coloration. If the black pigment be retained and the yellow eliminated, . obtain the beautiful blue variety which we have all become famil with. How the first of these mutants was produced we do not krnj but it was doubtless nothing more than a lucky sport which 1 fortunate breeder took great care to preserve and to breed from. T first blues seem to have appeared in Belgium in the early eighties, 1 it was not until the year 1910 that specimens were exhibited in t country. These were owned by a Belgian aviculturist who 1 established the variety in his aviaries. Others both in Great Brit and on the Continent obtained pairs, and the variety soon beca established. With the three colour varieties, green, yellow, and hi of a free-breeding species, there were great possibilities of produc other colours by judicious crossing, and the results of such experime are seen in the cobalt, which is perhaps the finest of all, the mai and the olive. Then there is the white variety which generally she a considerable trace of blue. At the Zoological Gardens a brood three of these appeared from blue parents, but it has also been obtain from crossing blue and yellow and mating their progeny. Exp< menting with the crossing of the different varieties of this Parrak; is a fascinating hobby, and probably much still remains to accomplished in the production of new tints.

D. Seth-Smith The Budgerigar and its Colour Varieties 207 One has heard of red Budgerigars, but few will be taken in by these *ious fakes. Mr. Chapman recently had some sent to him from lewhere in the East, and he was good enough to send me a pair see. They were very cleverly dyed an orange red and were of a king appearance, but a few new feathers were appearing here and *re and these were green ! Blue Budgerigars are expensive, and the cobalt variety is more tly than the other, but they can be produced by breeding from green ds that have been bred from one blue and one green parent. Such ds are known as " blue-bred " birds, and provided their parentage mown they may be expected to produce a percentage of pure blues, blue and a green bird mated together will produce only green spring, but these are the so-called blue-bred birds and are capable producing a percentage of blue birds. When mated together these blue-bred birds should produce 25 per it of pure blues, 50 per cent of greens that are blue-bred, like their rents, and 25 per cent pure greens that have no power to produce les. The trouble is that these pure greens cannot be distinguished m the blue-bred greens from the same parents, and here lies the lse of much disappointment. In breeding blues from blues, although only pure blues will be tained, the stock is likely to become weakly after a few generations, d so it is always advisable to obtain fresh blood by breeding a few le-breds, and mating these inter se. The blues bred from these w T ill absolutely pure blooded, and may be used for fresh blood amongst

With regard to cobalts, I have had no personal experience, but I derstand that blues mated to olive birds may produce birds which the next generation may produce this splendid variety. Perhaps I3se of our members who have experimented in breeding thes3 and \0x25A03 less striking though very interesting mauve variety will give us e benefit of their experience.
algorithms.address: 208 Sydney Porte)--Notes f rom Portuguese East Africa
algorithms.bodyText: I was hoping to have written a long and detailed article on the hi I; of some of the little-known parts of Portuguese East Africa, for : 11th September, 1925, two of us started from Mount Selinda on f< with a number of native carriers, intending to march into the interj of Portuguese East Africa, making the district where the Umvumaooi and the Sabi Rivers join our headquarters for a time. The same day that we started we crossed the frontier and spJ the night at Spungerbera, a small settlement where a Portugal Commandant lives; after that our way lay over the dense jungj covered Chimanimani Mountains, until 40 miles further on reached the great central plains, and in eleven days' time reached tj: Umvumaoodzi River, and there we intended pitching our camp t several weeks in a district which at the best of times is far fromhealtl|, But the hardships encountered en route, terrible tropical storri trouble with the carriers, illness, bad organization, terrific heat, a last, but not least, acute starvation, rendered me in anything but mood conducive to observing birds ; hence these meagre notes. The Umvumaoodzi is a very wide sand river (about 1 to [ miles wide in the rainy season), but at the beginning of the wet seas, is a chain of large deep pools resembling small lakes, covered for tl most part with huge water-lilies and fringed with tall and dense reec| This part of the country was particularly rich in bird life. We saw maj birds that I have already mentioned in my notes on Mount Selincj but the following were noted for the first time :-- The Hadada Ibis ( Hagedashia hagedash) In the early mornings, long before the dawn, we were awakened 1 a small flock of these beautiful but extremely noisy birds flying over o camp from their roosting-place to their feeding grounds down the rivet the noise they make is incredible. I should think the noise made by large flock would be perfectly deafening. The birds had one speci; roosting-tree, to which they came in small parties of three or four int evenings, and departed in the mornings to their respective feediij

Sydney Portci--Notes from Portuguese East Africa 209 iinds in the same small parties. The general colour of this bird is it grey, the wings being metallic bronze green, the tail purple. The Three-banded Plover ( AEgialitis tricollaris) These charming little birds are found in twos and threes in the ly mornings picking up their food on the sandy flats by the pools ; v have a peculiar habit of running a yard or two and then stopping l jerking their body up and down as though courtesying. They t over the sand or mud flats with incredible speed. Another little Plover, which I believe was the Caspian Plover gialitis asiatica), was common on the wet sand flats of the ivumaoodzi, where it kept in small flocks, running with great speed 1 every now and then probing into the sand with its bill. It was a y confiding little bird and would come within a few yards of one. The Saddle-billed Stork ( Ephippiorhynehus senegalensis) I came across these unique birds but once on the dry sandy bed :he river. They are easily distinguished from any of the other Storks the very peculiar black and crimson upturned bill, and when on the ig by the pure white under-wing feathers. These birds are far from union in East Africa, and only frequent the low-lying parts of the intry in the vicinity of marshes, swamps, and large rivers, where ;y seem to go about in pairs. They are shy and difficult to approach, ing up at the slightest sign of danger and making wide sweeping cles in the air, rising higher and higher until they are lost in the blue. The Black or Speckled Duck ( Anas sparsa ) I frequently came across small parties of these Duck on the pools the rivers, usually five or six together ; they are far from shy and II allow one to approach within easy distance of them. The Black ick does not seem to be very common in any part of South Africa, person who lived near Mount Selinda discovered a nest containing e eggs of this Duck, which she placed under a fowl; the whole five tched and the Ducklings were dark brownish black, marked with How. They were exceedingly tame, far more so than ordinary icklings, and would come into the kitchen every day to catch flies, ey grew up without mishap into delightful pets, but what eventually
algorithms.footnote: 3ame of them I don't know. I'm afraid that people in general in
algorithms.address: 210 Sydney Porte) Notes from Portuguese East Africa
algorithms.bodyText: Africa don't cherish any sentimental ideas about their pets if they of any utilitarian value. The Hooded Weaver Finch (Spermestes scutatus ) These pretty little birds, so well known in England as cage bill are very abundant in Portuguese East Africa. I first saw them in sn flocks on the ground, searching for seeds around the outbuildings! Spungerbera, a small but pretty frontier station. I also saw them mil times on our march into the interior, invariably around old Kal kraals and lands, feeding upon the minute seeds of various grasses J plants. They were exceedingly tame. The Fork-tailed Drongo ( Dicrurus afer) This was the commonest bird that we met with on our trip ; in sol parts there were hundreds of them and their loud notes could be he; the whole day through. One hears them before any other bird in morning and last thing at night when all the other birds are at roc These Drongos seem to take all their food in the air, taking up a p of vantage and making short flights at intervals to capture insel as they pass. I have very seldom seen one on the ground. Someth:: they have singing competitions ; two males will alight on a branch si: by side and sing with all their might, each one trying to drown notes of the other. The Three-streaked Bush Shrike (Teleplionus australis) I met with this rare Shrike several times, at least, I think it belong to this species. In colour it is ash grey, browner on the mantle, 4 wings chestnut, and the tail black, the throat white, a black stril from the base of the bill through the eye to the nape, the eyebro; light grey. Its habits seemed to resemble in most ways those of 4 Black-headed Shrike, to which bird it seems to be closely allied, h found this Shrike in the thick bush by the Periwiri River. The Melba Finch ( Pytelia melba) This charming little Waxbill was frequently seen around the Ka ' kraals and huts either singly or in pairs busily engaged in picking I minute seeds. It is a very confiding little bird and its habits resom * more or less those of the very familiar Blue-breasted Waxbill.
algorithms.author: Sydney Porter--Notes from Portuguese East Africa
algorithms.bodyText: The Carmine-throated Bee-eater ( Merops nubicus) Of all the African birds this is perhaps the most lovely--in colour lixture of delicate rose pink, of rich carmine, pale blue and green-- 5 a glory of the avian world. At the Periwiri River, which is a chain large, still, lily-covered pools in the dry season, we found these dous birds exceedingly numerous. Sometimes when sitting on the e branches of the trees by the river's edge their plumage would time a burnished copper hue in the brilliant sunlight. At various 3 rvals during the day they hawked for insects high in the air, after manner of the Swifts, the whole flock mounting higher and higher until y were lost to sight in the blue sky, then they would come down again 1 fly just over the water, dipping their bills into it and drinking as y flew. Their flight is nothing short of marvellous ; they can sail ng at an incredible speed, without a motion of their outstretched lgs, twist, turn, and stop dead still. Their method of bathing is eresting. They first of all congregate in small flocks on the bare es near the water, and from there two or three at a time will take a ;ht over the surface, suddenly dive down, and immerse their heads der the water, rapidly beating the water with their wings and churning up into a spray and completely soaking the plumage. Owing to the image being so wet the flight back to the tree is very laboured and avy. They then sit preening their resplendent plumage in the sun ; lanwhile, there is a steady flow of birds back and forwards from e water. The time taken by the birds in bathing is only a matter of few seconds. The voice of this Bee-eater is not in keeping with its amage, it is merely a rather loud harsh twittering. The birds seem to ve set times for bathing, resting, and catching their food. My com- mon told me that these birds nest in hundreds in holes in the sandy nks of the Zambesi. They are seldom found far away from water, ough I have sometimes seen them on the high dry veldt; but I believe ey were then only on their way to the north, where they go to breed. Arnot's Bush Chat ( Thamnolcca arnotti) We frequently saw this rare bird on the high dry veldt in Gazaland. striking mixture of black and white makes it a most conspicuous rd. The solitary specimens that we saw were always hopping about
algorithms.address: 212 Sydney Porter--Notes from Portuguese East Africa
algorithms.bodyText: the taller trees after the manner of a Thrush. Owing to the adve conditions we met with, I had little time for studying the habits this bird. The Black Tit (Parus niger) Occasionally we saw this very striking but very un-Tit-like b in the trees by our camps. Judging by its demeanour, it seems resemble the Shrikes more than the Tits. It is always a solitary bir I have never seen it in pairs. It is very active in the trees, passing fr< branch to branch the whole day and seldom resting. It does not r over the boughs after the manner of the true Tits. It utters most of t time a peculiar harsh note. The food consists of insects, especia spiders, which it finds in the trees. The Racquet-tailed Roller (Coracias spatulatus ) A pair of these beautiful birds were seen by our camp near t Umvumaoodzi, sitting on the top of a tree uttering their peculiar a: very distinctive note. They feed principally upon grasshoppers. The Yellow-billed Kite (Milvus cegyptius) We found this bird fairly common and single examples would st; around our camp on the look out for scraps; sometimes if they saw small piece of meat they would swoop down and seize it with th( talons within a yard of one. The flight is extremely buoyant and ligl and the tail during flight pivots from side to side. Sometimes this bi will sweep over the low bushes in search of small birds and mammals Sparrman s Honey Guide ( Indicator sparrmani) In some parts, especially in the well-wooded districts, we found tl bird plentiful; it at once attracts attention by its loud, harsh, chatterii cry. When it wishes to attract the attention of a human to a bee nest it is confiding enough, but at other times it is very shy ai extremely difficult to approach. The Wood Hoopoe (Irrisor viridis ) We found the nest belonging to this species in a tree in the midd of a rest camp about 50 miles from Spungerbera. We discovered tl nest owing to the female bird flying round and round uttering its lou
algorithms.author: Sydney Portci--Notes from Portuguese East Africa
algorithms.bodyText: attering cry. The natives we found had stuffed up the hole with tss. I have no idea why this was done, because-when a native finds lest with eggs in he usually keeps a watchful eye on it with a view to dug the young as soon as they are large enough to eat. We found 3 eggs, five in number, a beautiful pale greenish blue, very much e those of the European Starling, at the bottom of a hollow branch, out 5 feet away from the opening ; there was no nest, the eggs were $t lying on the damp rotten wood, and were very much stained in risequence. Moselikatze's Roller (Coracias caudatus) Not far from the nest of the Wood Hoopoe we found a nest of this )ller placed in the upright hollow branch of a large tree about 20 feet )in the ground, the hole was so small that we would have thought was almost impossible for the birds to enter. The Swallow-tailed Bee-eater (Dicrocercus hirundineus ) We frequently saw these beautiful birds on the way down to the tnvumaoodzi River, usually singly, perched on the topmost branch some dead tree, and from there making short flights into the air capture winged insects as they passed. They have a very stinctive call. Tiie Brown-headed Parrot (Poeocephalus fuscicapillus) In some districts that we passed through this Parrot was exceedingly mndant, in one especially which was covered by grey lichen woods ey were breeding in the hollow trees. Like most of the East African irrots, these birds associate in pairs and are usually very shy, but hen camping by the Umvumaoodzi River we found them com- . iratively tame and quite easy to approach. They came there in large imbers to feed upon the nectar of the huge red flower of the # ' German ^usage" tree. During the time they were feeding they remained irly quiet, but at other times, especially when flying, they gave vent * ear-piercing shrieks. This charming Parrot is light brown on the >per parts, including the upper breast, darker on the head, and the ipe is tinged with green ; the mantle wings and tail dark grass-green, te lower back rump, upper and under tail-coverts brilliant grass- 'een, the under parts are bluish pea green, the under wing is brilliant
algorithms.address: 214 Sydney Porto Notes from Portuguese East Africa
algorithms.bodyText: ^ an d is very conspicuous in flight. This Parrot seen I seldom to have been imported into England, which seems a great pit' for it is plentiful in its native haunts and would, no doubt, make delightful pet. Peter's Fin-foot (Podica petersi) I first saw this strange Cormorant-like bird on a secluded lib covered pool of the Periweri River ; it was swimming with the bod submerged, the back being on a level with the surface of the wate It didn't seem in the least perturbed at seeing me, and later when I w; sitting on the trunk of a large fallen tree which lay half across the po- it came and settled on a branch within a few feet of me ; it was in drenched condition, and at once proceeded with a lengthy toilet, whic lasted over a quarter of an hour. After that it went into the water agaii and proceeded to fish by diving and staying under the water ; som times it was submerged for more than a minute at a time. It mu; have travelled at a great speed under the water, judging by where went under and where it came up again. If the fish it caught was large one, it would bring it to the surface to swallow, but if the catc was a small one it would be swallowed under water. After about fh minutes of this the bird would come and settle near to me and a*;ai proceed with a lengthy toilet. I have never seen such a fearless bird it seemed, in fact, to approve of my company ; evidently I was the fir white man it had seen. The Jacana (Phyllopezus africanus) On the same pool on which I saw the Peter's Fin-foot I saw a pa of Jacanas and spent several pleasant hours watching them. Their hu# feet are specially adapted for walking on the large water-lily leaver when the leaves are en masse thev do not sink under the bird if it */ stationary for any length of time, but single leaves gradually sin If the leaves are too far apart for the bird to comfortably walk on will swim. The whole time that the birds are walking over the aquat vegetation they are busily engaged in picking up minute aquatic insec upon which they feed. The Jacana is an extremely graceful bird i build and also in its movements.

algorithms.equation: PELICANS AND THEIR ALLIES i By J. Delacour
algorithms.bodyText: These birds have completely webbed feet ; the great toe being joined v a membrane to the rest. They are mostly sea birds, and only a few : them frequent fresh water. They are large perching birds and feed I fish. Certain species are often met with in Zoological Gardens, where ley live well if given their proper diet of fish and meat, but few of lem are desirable to amateurs, for they are not beautiful, are large *eders, and very dirty. The Pelicans ( Pelecanus ) are well known, they are all large birds aving white or pale grey plumage. They are characterized by long eaks, provided with an enormous expanding pouch below. There are )ughly speaking about ten species, all about the size of a Swan ; II swim and fly with great ease. They do well in captivity, feeding on sh. Pelicans have a duller colouring when in eclipse, and the females ilfer slightly from the males. They are sometimes dangerous to feebler irds. The species are as follows :-- Pelecanus onocrotalus, inhabits Europe, Africa, and West Asia ; irge ; w r hite, with a pink flush and black flights. P. roseus , which frequents the same regions and spreads to the I xtreme east. Smaller, and with a shorter beak. P. crispus, distributed over the same ground except Africa. Black nd white, with a crest on its head. P. philippensis, from India, Indo-China, and the Philippines, flack, white, and vinous brown ; smaller.

J. Dclacoui--Pelicans and their Allies P. rufescens , from North-East Africa, resembles the preceding P. fuscus, Gulf of Mexico. Pale yellow head, brown neck, gre} with black streaks above ; vinous brown underneath ; small. I californicus , from the Pacific Coast, is much the same. P. thagus, native of Peru and Chile, one of the guano-making bird, is brown with white stripes ; head and sides of the neck yellow, uppt part of the neck black. P. erythrorhynchus, from the interior, North, and Central Americ is white with black flights and in the breeding season it is adorned wit a horny plate on the middle of the upper mandible. P. conspicillatus , Australian, is white, with black on the mailt] and wings. The Tropic Birds (Phaethontidce) are very beautiful sea birds, wit| white plumage more or less flushed with pink, and sometimes also wit black markings, and with very long pointed tails. Their bills are shoj and conical, and their feet very tiny. There are about half-a-doze species, all frequenting tropical seas. They cannot endure confinemen The same applies to the Frigate Birds (Fregatkke), large sea birc with very long narrow wings and forked tails, which one often se< floating above tropical coasts. They are black, but the male has naked red pouch under his bill, which he can inflate at pleasure. T our birds have white heads and necks. They have been successfully kej for a time in some zoological gardens, especially in New York. Gannets (Sulidoe) are large birds, with pointed tails and laq bills bare at the base. The Common Gannet ( Sula hasana), well known on our coasts, all white save for its black flights ; there are many other species, most, white, or brown with more or less white, which cannot be enumerate here. Gannets do fairly well in confinement, but have little to recor.j mend them to amateurs. They are generally to be seen in zoologic gardens. Darters or Snake Birds ( Anhinga ) are curious birds, whi( frequent river-courses and lakes in hot countries. They remind 01 of Cormorants and have much the same appearance. They are thic bodied, with fairly long tails, very long and slender necks, terminatii in a scarcely larger head, itself prolonged by a long, pointed, narro

algorithms.bodyText: Their strange appearance has earned them the name of " Snake

Darters often perch ; they swim and dive with amazing facility, 1 are very amusing to watch ; they also become very tame. I brought ne back with me from Orinoco, and one occasionally sees them in (logical gardens. The Ruddy Darter ( Anhinga rufa), from Africa and Asia Minor black on the top of its head and back of its neck, the throat and nt of the neck ruddy, with a white stripe from the eye to the shoulder, . rest of its plumage is black, streaked above with white. The female 3 the top of her head, middle neck, and back ruddy. The Asiatic Darter (A. melanogaster) is known by its brown id and neck, with white spots, and by its fawn-coloured mantle. The Australian Darter (A. nova-hollandice), also found in ! w Zealand and New Guinea, is black with a white band at the sides the neck, a chestnut spot at the base of the neck and in front, and ite-streaked mantle. The female is brown above and white beneath. The American Darter (A. anhinga ) is black, with brown and ite mantle. The head and neck of the female are light brown. ! Cormorants are well known birds ; our two species Phalacrocorax bo and P. graculus are black with green lights ; the last named is aller and crested. After the breeding season they assume a dull, deep )wn plumage. There are many species of Cormorants, all much alike, ing sometimes by thousands on rocky coasts all over the world. Some ! vq black and white plumage. They nil live well in confinement, and 1 ne are always on view in zoological gardens ; but they aie not birds \0x25A0 the amateur ; so we need not dwell longer on them. They live on l. The Chinese and Japanese tame Cormorants and train them to ; i for them.
The Marquess of Tavistock -- -Swans

By the Marquess of Tavistock Swans, together with Geese and Ducks, make up the Anserii'orr Order, which is known by having webbed feet, but the big toe fre and flattened bills provided with lamella) or plates. Swans compose small, very special group of Palmipedes ; one species may be looke upon as aberrant and intermediate with other kinds. They are larg birds of quarrelsome disposition, but given sufficient space an water they are both beautiful and imposing. Swans are a great ornament to a piece of water, but unless they ca be accommodated with a really large territory and plenty of watei enough to enable each pair to isolate themselves, it is better to giv each pair a separate pond or tank, which, however, may also b inhabited by aquatic birds of other species. They feed on grass, aquati plants and grain, and must be enabled to obtain all the vegetable foo which they need to keep them in good health. Generally speaking, Swan do not mind cold. Although pairs of the same species or of differen species fight savagely for the purpose of keeping to themselves a stretc of water which would really be large enough for a dozen of them, the do not as a rule interfere with other swimming birds, except the large? kinds, and those in particular which are coloured like themselves which last is a habit common to all birds. The sexes are alike, but the female is smaller than her mate. The are monogamous and pair for life, and should one perish the widowe bird often pines away and dies of grief. A male which has lost its mat often attacks a fresh one, but may, after a time, get used to and accep her. Swans are migratory birds, as are most Palmipedes. The Mute Swan (Cygnus olor) is the White Swan, commonly me with everywhere. It is perhaps the most handsome, but also the mos vicious of all its race. A breeding male not only tries to kill every othc Swan he comes across, but attacks all other kinds of web-footed birch The young in their first plumage are grey, which is the case with most c the genus ; they turn white after their second summer. The so-calle '\0x25A0 Polish Swan ( C . immutahilis) is nothing more than an albin variety of the domestic bird. Adults have grey feet and paler bill?

algorithms.bodyText: d the young in down are white. The so-called Mute Swan is not illy without a voice ; it utters a kind of- grunt. It is quite mesticated here, but is wild in Northern Europe and Asia. The Trumpeter Swan ( C . buccinator) is the largest Swan ; it has [come very rare in its own country, western North America. Its beak perfectly black and its plumage white. It is easily domesticated, e cock bird is very spiteful towards its own species, even in winter, t does not attack Ducks. It has a very powerful voice, like the sound a trumpet. I The American Swan ( C . columbianus ) is smaller than the preceding, d has a small yellowish white spot at the sides of its beak, near the strils ; it has the same kind of cry as Bewick's Swan. This species
algorithms.listItem: .is never yet been bred in confinement, though a cross has been ' tained between it and the wild Swan. It is a native of North-East * nenca.
algorithms.bodyText: The Wild or Wiiooper Swan (C. cygnus) is found in Northern I irope and Asia. It has a musical cry like the sound of a shrill trumpet, is distinguished by the large yellow spot at the sides of the beak, has bred in confinement, but more often the eggs are unfertile ; I ien this happens, the male bird should be changed for another. This ecies is very migratory, and once it takes to flight it quickly ' sappears. Bewick's Swan ( C . bewicki) resembles the above-mentioned but decidedly smaller, besides having the yellow spots much diminished, i >t extending beyond the nostrils. It has been bred occasionally. It i as quarrelsome as the other species. The Black-necked Swan ( C . melanocoryphus) is a South iinerican species with striking plumage. Its body is white, head and *ck black with white eyebrows ; bill bluish grey and a large red (jittle. It does very well in confinement, but should have a shelter in inter lest its feet get frozen. The cygnets have a pretty habit of imbing on to the backs of their parents by means of their bills and king refuge under their wing-feathers, leaving their heads outside, tiey are somewhat delicate, need fine weather, and plenty of water- eed. The female is the smaller, but has a wattle. The Black Swan ( Chenopsis atrata ) is greyish black, with the wing-

It breeds very freel in captivity, and is very pugnacious, but not very powerful, and Canadian Goose can stand up to it. The female is smaller and has shorter neck than her mate. It raises its wings like the Mute S'wai when flying it makes a peculiar but musical noise. It is a native Australia. It will not stay if full-winged. The Coscoroba Swan (Coscoroha coscoroba) is probably only a hu. Dendrocygna , which it resembles in shape, but its size and colour ha' caused it to be provisionally placed among the Swans. It is white wi black-tipped wings and red bill. Its feet are thick and pink. It is # inhabitant of South America. Unfortunately this handsome species tender, needing very pure water, plenty of natural food and shelt in winter. Its eggs should be hatched under a hen and the youi reared on duckweed and fresh grass. Should the Swan wish to s she may be given Ducks' eggs, but she is so excitable that si seldom rears them. In this species the sexes are alike, but the female the smaller. It has a curious, rather low voice, and when annoye slightly ruffles up its wings.
algorithms.sectionHeader: THE BREEDING OF THE SPOTTED FRANCOLIN (FRANCOLINUS SEPHAENA SPILOGASTER )
algorithms.bodyText: In January, 1926, I got from Chapman a pair of Francolins froi Abyssinia. These were turned straight into a large aviary, with only a open shed for shelter, in which enclosure they have been ever sinc< This has jiroved them to be hardy birds, which one would rather expec to be the case, as I believe they come from the highland districts ( North-East Africa, where the temperature at times must be very low They proved to be quiet and inoffensive birds with the other occupant of the aviary, mostly Waders, and were well able to look after their selves, ignoring the sham attacks of the breeding Buffs. On 1st Ma I found the hen sitting on five eggs. These were cream-coloured, with few small pink spots. The eggs were shaped like those of the San< Grouse, being equally rounded at each end ; the shells were extra
