I inarily thick. On the 24th two young were hatched, these were like e Partridges, but rather larger. Both birds looked after them by day, the hen took sole charge by night, the cock retiring to roost in a \0x25A0 ow over the pond. The little ones grew slowly, but were soon able ly. At the time of writing they are about the size of Quails, and are 'y strong on the wing. Size about the same as the Red-legged tridge. Colour above brown, each feather more or less pencilled h a darker shade; underside bullish ; throat spotted with stnut; a conspicuous white eyebrow stripe ; feathers on head 'tile. Both sexes are alike, but the male has spurs.
algorithms.table: V By Mrs. Prestwick (Continued from p. 187 ) Agapornis roseicollis The Peach-faced or Rosy-faced Lovebird was first described in
algorithms.bodyText: j'3, and was thought to be a variety of A. pullaria . It, however, Aived recognition as a separate species in 1817, under the name tlacus roseicollis, and its present title was bestowed on it in 1852. j j Zoological Gardens received their first specimen in 1862, probably j year of the first importation. Roseicollis has been imported piently since, but in small numbers, and is at present rather scarce, y few having arrived since 1914. The Peach-faced is fairly popular with aviculturists, as it nests te readily, but unfortunately it has two drawbacks which lose it ny friends, namely its high-pitched, oft-repeated shriek and its , tefulness towards other birds. Two pairs of Peach-faced should on ; account be kept together, and it is not advisable to trust them with iller and weaker birds. The sexes are somewhat similar, but the hen * ers from the cock in the slightly paler red colouring of the frontal j ch, which is usually more restricted, also the rosy colour extends jTher towards the breast in the male than in the female. This member he family has been bred on many occasions. Dr. Brehm was success- in Germany as long ago as 1882. The first recorded success in Great tain was that of Mr. J. Cronkshaw, who reared two young in 1895 ;

Mrs . Prestwick--Lovebirds Mr. Cocksedge bred eight in 1899. More recent successes are those the late Dr. Lovell-Keays, Dr. Amsler, Mr. T. Hebb, Mr. H. E. Brigl Mr. E. J. Boosey, and the Marquess of Tavistock. They take readily nest-boxes or hollow logs, which they proceed to cram with strips bark, hay, grass, etc., carried in the usual manner under the feathers the lower back or upper tail-coverts. The number of eggs varies frc five to seven, which the hen alone incubates, being fed by the ecu Three broods are frequently produced, and even more, Dr. Russ stai that when not prevented, six and even seven broods have been produc in succession. After three nests their activities should be discourag for a time. Incubation appears to take nineteen to twenty da 1 and the eggs, which are rather pointed, measure approximate 23-5 mm. x 17-5 mm. The young have no red colour on the forehea which is yellowish ; the rose colour of the cheeks and throat very pa Insectivorous food can be provided with advantage when young a being fed, and some parents partake of this quite freely, suggesti that in the wild state insect food forms part of their diet. Little information is available as to the habits of this species the wild state, but Andersson in his Birds of Damaraland , writes follows : " This species is always observed in small flocks, and seldc far away from water, to which it resorts at least once a day, and consequently not a bad guide to a thirsty traveller ; though, if he inexperienced it would hardly avail him much, as it frequently happe that the drinking places resorted to by this and other water-loving bii are but of small compass and strangely situated. " This species is very swift of flight, and the little flocks in which is observed seem to flash upon the sight as they change their feedir grounds or pass to and from their drinking-place ; their flight, liowev is only for a comparatively short distance at a time. They utter raj and shrill notes when on the wing, or when suddenly disturbed j alarmed. Their food consists of large berries and berry-like seeds, j Andersson then proceeds to make a statement which has caus much controversy :-- " This bird does not make any nest of its own, but takes possessi of those belonging to other birds, especially the Social Weaver B. (Philceterus socius ) and the White-browed Weaver Bird ( Ploceipass

tali). I cannot say whether it forcibly e'ects the rightful owners of ie nests or merely occupies such as have been-abandoned, but in case of the first-named species, I have seen the Parrots and Weaver Is incubating in about equal numbers under the shelter of the same idly roof." Mr. Seth-Smith probably provides the true solution in his standard k, ParraJceets. On page 147, he writes :--
algorithms.listItem: " Although we cannot doubt Andersson's statement that the huge f -s of the Social and White-browed Weaver Birds are often used by ' pornis roseicollis as nesting places, his contention that this species ds no nest of its own cannot be accepted by those who have known bird under more or less natural conditions in large aviaries in this ntry and on the Continent. ' " There is little doubt that the enormous umbrella-shaped nests of
algorithms.bodyText: Weaver Birds, which are described as consisting of 4 whole cartloads rass ', are used merely as receptacles for the nests of the Lovebirds, sibly in districts where large trees, containing suitable holes and vices for nests, are scarce." Some aviculturists have managed to p Peach-faced in large cages and have even induced them to breed, unless the cages are of very exceptional size, sooner or later they elop into " feather-pluckers ". The Marquess of Tavistock has d this species at liberty, but found that it did not stay well. A very interesting variety of the Peach-faced was received at the > in 1921 ; the rosy tint of the cheeks had spread over nearly the Me of the body, so that the bird was rosy-pink over the greater part ts plumage. The ever-popular and accommodating Budgerigar has been used cessfully on several occasions to hatch the deserted eggs of Roseicollis . Russ had young reared in this way, and M. P. Paillard, of "deaux, met with similar success. Incidentally, Mr. J. W . Marsden, lue Budgerigar pioneer, once had a Black-cheeked Lovebird fledgling cessfully reared by Budgerigars. In conclusion, the only talking /ebird I ever heard of was a Peach-faced, hand-reared by . Amsler. This bird, whenever he had misbehaved himself by giving
algorithms.figure: |extra hard nip, would say " Naughty Joey ! " quite distinctly. (To be continued.) L *
algorithms.sectionHeader: Avicultural Notes AVICULTURAL NOTES By The Editor
algorithms.bodyText: So far as foreign birds are concerned, the breeding season of 1 seems to have been a very bad one. The early part was abnornu dry with cold winds, a condition that is most unfavourable. Ci eggs, or no eggs at all, or young birds dead in the shell were repoi from most aviaries. And when the damp weather came there rain to excess with very little sunshine and a low temperature. Mr. Walter Goodfellow has just returned home with a collect of choice birds, amongst which may be mentioned 3 Twelve-wi Birds of Paradise, 2 Red Birds of Paradise, 1 Lesser Bird, 2 Wilso 1 Magnificent, mostly adult males in full plumage ; 1 Great B1 Cockatoo, 2 Pesquet's Parrots, male and female ; 1 Goffin's Cockal 7 Varied Lorikeets, 8 Black-capped Fruit Doves, 5 Treron vernc an Owl (Huhua orientalis). Most of these birds are in beautiful plum and bear testimony to the great care that has been bestowed u them during the voyage. The Ibis for July contains two papers of interest to aviculturi! Both are from the pen of Mr. F. E. Blaauw, who describes the succes breeding at Gooilust, Holland, of the Blue-winged Goose of Abyssi (Cyanocheyi cyanopterus) and the Bare-eyed Cockatoo ( Cacc gynopis) during 1926. Of the first of these little was known u Mr. Blaauw obtained seven examples in 1923. He finds that t! are very nocturnal in their habits, nest-building, courting, and mat all taking place during the night. Five eggs, of an elongated shj and cream-coloured, were laid, and four goslings were hatched b domestic hen after thirty days' incubation, all being rea successfully. The Bare-eyed Cockatoos which bred were very old birds wl had previously lived in the Zoological Gardens of Hanover, probably never before had an opportunity of nesting. A single was laid in a log nest. Only the female incubated, and a chick hate after three weeks, but did not leave the nest until 9 weeks' < when it was the image of its parents.
algorithms.title: Avicultural Notes
algorithms.footnote: About thirty Members of the Society met at the Zoological Gardens 8th July, and took tea together, afterwards- visiting the Small 1 House and other places of interest to aviculturists. It was very
algorithms.bodyText: isant to meet members who one has only known by correspondence, [ to discuss the many problems that confront aviculturists. Most unately the weather was ideal. In a few months' time the large collection of birds in the Small d House at the Zoological Gardens will be transferred to their !v quarters in the old Reptile House, which is being converted into up-to-date Bird House. There will be some twenty large wall es suitable for Toucans or Birds of Paradise, three very large tral aviaries, and some thirty or more small cages, while on the th and west sides of the house will be a number of outdoor aviaries, e house will be well lighted by electricity, both ordinary and " sun- it " lamps being employed during dull weather, while palm-trees 1 hanging baskets of ferns will add to the beauty of the house, ich will provide far better accommodation for the birds than they oy at present. u \0x25A0 ------ Amongst the new arrivals at the Zoological Gardens are two imples of the fine Derbyan Parrakeet ( Palceornis derbyana) from ina, one of which has been presented to the Society by Mr. Eustace, ! other acquired by purchase. It is long since an example of this [*e species, a coloured plate of which we published in June, 1926, U been represented in the collection. Both are males, one in perfect image, the other showing signs of melanism on the head. Mr. Allen Silver has recently constructed a very useful series of aries which he believes to be mouse- and rat-proof as well as escape- i )of, the birds being fed from outside window-doors without the 1 3essity of the owner entering. Before completion, however, some ey and Green Singing-finches did escape, but they did not go away, i d when shown a cage with a millet-spray inside entered at once. 1 \ Silver believes that in a cat-proof garden the Grey Singing-fmch >uld stay and make a very tame and delightful pet. They are so

Correspondence tame, however, that they are liable to be trodden upon. The gr drawback to this kind of aviculture is that the birds are apt to taken by cats or owls, both the Tawny and Little Owl being v destructive.

Sir,--I am sending you a line to say that one young Bar (Abyssinian) left the nest yesterday, and in spite of flying straight i some hot water as hot as I could bear my hands in, with which I a washing some pans, seems none the worse to-day, and the pare are still feeding it assiduously. I regret to say the other I foi dead on its back below the nest to-day--between the seed-box and wall; I suppose it came out of the nest this morning, got in there, i could not get on to its legs ; it is bad luck. I examined the nesting bb --no nest, no eggs, or remains of any, and very clean. Yet I never ,* the old birds bring out excrement, but they must have done so. Tlj fed the young for choice on mealworms, but used a great number gentles and possibly a certain amount of currants and soft f< mixture, also any other insects they could get, including dead hi bottles, which we gave them. I only hope they may nest again : I should like to see the eggs. Am I the first to have bred them ? Plej j use any of above you think fit for the Magazine. I regret to say h; had rotten luck with Nyasas ; had four young birds in nest--th flew this week ; about a day after I found one on floor with hr bashed in, another dead next day plump as a Partridge and no sigrl mishap, and the fourth is neither in the nest nor elsewhere to be seei so one out of four remains ! John S. Reevej 25th June, 1927. [To breed any species of Barbet in captivity is a great achievem and there is little doubt that Captain Reeve is the first to succ< with Trachyphonus margaritatus. Writing on 15th July he says t the young bird is feeding itself, and it may therefore be conside as fully reared. --Ed.]

algorithms.bodyText: Sir, --With reference to my recent notes on newly imported Mexican Is, I have now had the opportunity of examining the skins in the
algorithms.listItem: ish Museum and I find that the Siskin I described is Astragillinus 7 rai and the Tanager Pyranga bitentata, or Swainson's Tanager. W. Shore-Baily. MACAWS AND A HAWK-HEADED PARROT ! Sir, --I was much interested in Miss Knobel's article on the Smaller
algorithms.bodyText: jaws. I have never kept any of the varieties described, but I have t a number of the larger ones : these seem to vary in disposition ost as much as the Grey Parrot, although I think on the whole these less really bad screamers ; the best-tempered one I have had was feed and Yellow, with whom one could do almost anything. This ; closely rivalled by a Blue and Yellow, who quite made up for asional playful nips by being quite a good, if somewhat monotonous ;er. It is very fond of saying in a most sorrowful tone " Poor La ", and then looking round for approval. One curious habit ave noticed with all Parrots, but more especially with Macaws, lie way they open and close the iris with great rapidity, especially [ m excited. I have only had one Macaw that I really could do nothing with : t was a Blue and Yellow, but I rather fancy it was caught as an bird. Macaws make charming pets in many ways, but they are her noisy and appallingly destructive. By far the tamest Parrot I have ever had is a Hawkhead ; when I t had her, she was extremely nervous, but with a little coaxing became very tame. A favourite game is to play dead, and she 1 lie on her back on one's hand and go perfectly limp and will allow self to be passed from hand to hand. She behaves very much as ^ cribed in Green's Parrots in Captivity, except that she has never *wn any sign of talking or even trying to talk. All day she keeps a sort of " Chuck " noise, but when excited it becomes much higher |ched and very rapid ; occasionally she whistles odd notes, but has \0x25A0er tried to make a tune. She is most acrobatic and very quick, ;

with none of the laborious caution of the Grey Parrot, preferring rath to jump than climb. At night she sleeps in a box attached to the do of her cage. She always retires at about 7 p.m., even when it is lig in the evenings. She does well on a good plain Parrot mixture with a little apj or toast crust occasionally. Apparently the crest is only thrown up after preening the feathc or when defending itself ; she will terrify my Grey Parrot if it interfer by throwing up her crest and giving short, sharp hisses. R. M. Evans.!

It reads " Beautiful Wood Hawk (Dryotriorcl spectabilis) from Lagos. Scalp, back, wings, tail, dark brown wi broad transverse darker bars on wing quills. Beak black. Fa around eyes and throat, pale brown, with dark moustache at each si* and a narrower dark median streak on throat. Breast and abdomi pale brown, with dark broad transverse bars. Legs yellow. We marked dark brown erectile crest. Utters long loud cry." It was a largish bird, rather Buzzard-like in body appearan excluding crest, and was in the Eastern Aviary of the Zoologic Gardens about the year 1906. By J. Delacour From the time of its discovery in 1895 up to 1915, when three more lecimens were found in Siam, this fine bird had only been known xmgh the three original specimens sent to the Paris Museum by ther Renauld, from Central Annam. It is one of the rarest birds ! skin collections. Since I have undertaken the ornithological exploration of French lo-China, in connexion with my friend M. P. Yabouille, Civil Officer 1 presently Travelling Commissioner in Annam, we have procured lumber of Ground Cuckoos, several of which are now alive in our aries at Hue (Annam) and four in our President s aviaries at xwarren. I Of the latter I brought one home in 1926, the first to reach Europe v r e. It was sent by me to Clcres with another one in April of that ir - Both birds travelled quite well, and arrived safely, although ,lr plumage was rather damaged ; unfortunately, one got its leg 'ken and had to be killed, as it had lost it whole, being otherwise i de healthy. The sound specimen was soon put into an outdoor

J. Delacour -- Renauld's Ground Cuckoo aviary, where it slept in the open from June to October, keepin; perfect health in spite of our very cold Normandy nights; To surprise, it never molested the other birds which inhabited the s* flight; Eheinardt's, Argus, young Sonnerets, Jungle Fowl, diffej Pigeons and Doves, and even Waxbills, which Coucals, their r relatives, would have most certainly eaten in similar circumstan It moulted in July and since has been in perfect feather. It bew very tame during the sea voyage, and now takes food from o: fingers. Last spring I brought three more. Ground Cuckoos are quite easy to cater for ; at liberty, they f on all kinds of worms, grubs, insects, and small vertebrates ; in captb they eat cut-up meat, earthworms, mealworms, and insectivor mixture, even bread and boiled maize. The present plate, drawn from life, is worth any lengthened desc tion, and I shall only add to it that Renauld's Ground Cuckoos avert a total length of 28 inches, about the size of an ordinary pheasamj From our investigations, it appears that this species inha|: the whole of French Indo-China and the south and east of Siam, j may not be as rare as it is generally thought, as it is a very shy b Very little is known on the bird's habits at liberty ; they live in thickest jungle, where undergrowth, entangled vine, and boultj make it most impenetrable. Only once did we see one flying low ac| the path, at the Col de Nuages, in Central Annam, one of their favoul haunts. Chicks remain unknown so far, though eggs have been j in Mr. Ezra's aviaries. This Cuckoo's ordinary voice is a low grji but it also utters sometimes a whistling call, resembling thatl: the Argus Pheasant or the Brown Owl. It is rather difficult at first to keep several Ground Cuckoos in same aviary, as they are rather quarrelsome at the beginning; \0x25A0! it can be done, and we have kept six in two aviaries, four in and two in another one. It would be most desirable to breed these rare birds in captivi as there is little chance, owing to their retiring habits, of ever fine! their nests at liberty.
algorithms.title: A. Ezra--The Nesting of Benauld's Ground Cuckoo
algorithms.sectionHeader: THE NESTING OF RENAULD'S GROUND CUCKOO By Alfred Ezra
algorithms.bodyText: This very rare bird has been a source of great interest to me. The igle specimen brought over last year has done very well, in spite the long wet winter. Again this year, M. Delacour very kindly night me three more of these rare birds. All the four birds were put o a large aviary. As they all look alike I thought I could sex them time, by watching them, and their behaviour to one another. As
algorithms.listItem: * as I can make out, I have two pairs, but of this I am not quite sure,
algorithms.bodyText: though not very friendly, they are not really spiteful with one another. iey fly about a good deal and perch sometimes, but most of the ae they are on the ground. They eat a good deal of meat and earth- rms and are very fond of mice, and sometimes will swallow as many four one after another. They are delightful aviary birds, and quite rdy and easy to keep in an aviary, where they will not molest the .allest bird. On 3rd July the boy, while feeding the birds in the iary, found an egg under a small tree in a nest consisting of a few igs and leaves. This egg disappeared about an hour after it was seen d most probably it was eaten up by some of the other occupants the aviary. I don't quite know who the culprit was, but as the ary is occupied by Babblers, Boilers, Bails, and Starlings, I am not prised that the egg disappeared. The same evening I caught up all ' above birds, leaving the four Cuckoos by themselves, with only a few rmless birds. On the 4th another egg was laid. This egg I removed once from the nest, and sent to Lord Bothschild, as I believe it is ' } first known egg of this bird. I noticed that all four birds were \0x25A0rying twigs and leaves to the same nest. On the 6th of July I pnd another egg in the nest. This egg the birds were allowed to ubate, and I am certain that three out of the four birds sat. They ubated steadily for ten days, when this egg also disappeared, and st probably was eaten by the birds themselves. The egg looks very ch like that of a Bantam, but is rather rounder, white in colour h a rough shell. If they winter safely, I hope to be more successful
next year in breeding this beautiful and interesting bird. I do know whether all the three eggs were laid by one bird or rnore a whether more than three eggs had been laid.
algorithms.listItem: ( Continued from p. 223) By Mrs. A. A. Prestwich
algorithms.bodyText: The Black-cheeked Lovebird was discovered by Dr. A. H. | Kirkman, on the Muguazi Biver, in September, 1904. The first sir collection, consisting of five birds, arrived in England, via Germai in April, 1908. Three of the five went to the late Mr. Reginj Phillipps, and the remaining pair to the late Mr. H. D. Astley ; 1 latter pair formed the subject of an excellent coloured plate in ij Avicultural Magazine, October, 1908. Further small collects subsequently arrived, and Black-cheeks proved excellent amc birds and free-breeders. During the years of the war the species almost died out in Engla:| and pairs were practically unobtainable. Last year, howe\ ; . Mr. Chapman received several very large consignments, and Bla cheeks would seem to be well-established once more. Some lit difficulty is experienced in obtaining true pairs, as the sexes are so v alike. Mr. Phillipps, after exhaustive observation, came to the cl elusion that the only way to sex them with any degree of certaii was by noting the colour of the iris, which differs in the two sex! that of the male being pale yellow-brown, and of the female da yellow-brown. This difference probably proves correct in ma instances, but cannot be relied on as an infallible guide, as the j will vary in colour in any particular bird according to its state of heal; age, light, and various other causes. When a number are seen togetlf pairs can be picked out with certainty by observing the shape of tb heads and beaks, which are noticeably broader across the top in 1 males. The female would also appear to be slightly smaller a
algorithms.table: Mrs . Prestwich--Love birds
algorithms.bodyText: Jer in colouring, the forehead and front of crown is darker and ler; the orbital ring narrower ; the beak less suffused at base h white ; while the front edge of the wing is slightly yellow in the le and green in the female. Black-cheeks nest very readily, and I have before me the names of ne twenty successful breeders. Mr. Phillipps was the first, a pair his original three birds went to nest about two months after their ival, laid four eggs, all of which hatched and the young reared. . Phillipps has written in a most interesting manner on A. nigrigenis, i members should refer to his various accounts in the Avicultural ,gazine as follows i--New Series, Yol. VI (1908), pp. 206-10, 318-29 ; 1. VII (1909), pp. 31-6, 148-56. The nesting arrangements are similar to those of A. roseicollis, ;ept that the nesting material is usually carried in the beak, the Ik of the work being done by the female. The eggs vary considerably shape, but are usually rather elongated and pear-shaped and proximately measures 22'3 mm. by 16'9 mm. The usual clutch is ir, but the females seem to be in the habit, after disposing of the ;t clutch, to lay immediately an additional three in the same nest, e female alone incubates for seventeen to eighteen days, the male t seeming to feed her until after the young are hatched. The lowing description of the young is taken from one of Mr. Phillipps' iicles (Avicultural Magazine, 1909, pp. 33-4) :-- " It was on 23rd July that I first saw a young bird in the nest. ie could only see a portion of the inside, but a nestling a few days 1 was visible. On the 26th I saw two nearly naked little things latting side by side, like a couple of young pigeons. On the 29th, \0x25A0 *. Seth-Smith inspected the nest, and reported four young of different 3S, all right. On 4th August I just noticed a touch of colour, one irdy youngster having a pale yellow-red beak. On the 12th, the . >wns of the nestlings had all the appearance of being fully feathered. l 13th August the two elder, after playing possum for a moment, >od boldly up, raising their heads towards the opening. Along 1 fir backs and down their necks there were the usual tracks of feathers t they were far from being fully covered ; their tails, less than an ( )h being visible, showed the subterminal band of black quite well

marked, especially in the eldest, where the markings were of a deep black and much more clearly defined. The forehead showed the colo of the adult, or seemed to ; and the salmon-red patch on the chest w conspicuous. The nostrils were quite covered and hidden; I cou not manage to get a glint of light on to an eye--in the shade of the lo the irides seemed to be quite black. " The first young bird to leave the nest appeared on 22nd Augus but, for a few days at any rate, he returned to the nest after a sho outing. No. 2, I think a female, appeared on the 25th. The gre< of the general plumage of these two birds was at first very dull, b rapidly became brighter, and the flanks yellower ; the breast-pat( at first was very bright; the brown of the forehead extended farth back in " A " than in " B ", and then there came some green or greenis The black on the sides of the chin seemed to be as deep as in the parent but only a little colouring extended upwards behind the eyes. T1 head of " B " seemed to be broader than that of " A ", and, althom the younger, " she " seemed to be the larger bird. But all tl differences of shading quickly assumed a dull level--the young and tl old became very much alike. Even the yellow in the red of the bea]! of the fledglings seems to have gone. No. 3 had joined the group ( the 27th, as usual in the quiet of the early morning ; and the fourth ai last came out on the following day, carefully tended by one of i parents. I think the latter must have been " hurried " out of tl log, for it was less forward than the others, and was fed by the ma for some days after the others were feeding themselves. They quick took to nibbling at green food, but on and from the 30th the three we feeding on dry seed, etc., with their father." I am afraid the foregoing is rather long, but it seemed of sufficiei interest to stand reprinting. Black-cheeks are exceptionally shy when breeding and on no accoU] should the nest be interfered with in any way. The young in the ne appear to be practically mute, neither calling for food nor audib responding to its arrival. Among the more successful with this species may be mention* the late Mr. H. W. Mathias, the late Dr. Lovell Keays, Capt. G. 1 Rattigan, Mr. J. Sumner Marriner, Mr. Id. Willford, and Mr. W. Shor

ly, the last-named having been extraordinarily fortunate in the nber bred. The Marquess of Tavistock has tried this species at liberty and nd that although it readily nested it almost invariably migrated August or September after breeding. Black-cheeks agree well together and with other members of the ; aily ; non-nesting pairs, however, seem inclined to interfere with |! young of nesting pairs.
algorithms.sectionHeader: THE REARING BY HAND OF YOUNG ROCK PEPLARS
algorithms.bodyText: By The Viscountess Grey of Fallodon A basket is required 14 inches long, 6 or 7 wide, and 6 inches deep, >sed with a lid, with a stick that runs through the wicker staples, should be of a light wicker-work, so as to be airy. Have two squares mackintosh for the bottom of the basket, and keep one dozen flannel uares for loose lining. Lift the young birds out of the nest in the iary from time to time, to see their stage of growth, and take the one c the two) you intend to rear while still in down, with the feathers in .ills, the colour just showing, while the bird is at the age when it is idy to gape for food, and can raise itself on its feet. Two are easier rear than one ; for they keep each other warm. Place one rubber square in, and lay one of the flannel squares into e basket loosely \ have more of the flannel under the birds than er them ; there should only be one light flap-over of the flannel cover them, and as they get older they will not need even this. It is sential they should be in a warm hole with air round them, rather an folded closely. They must be able to potter about, inside the mnel-lined basket and not be swaddled tight. Between the wall of the basket and the flannel, keep a fresh bit of 'own bread in a wisp of tissue paper, so that it keeps clean, and that )U may always have it handy. Bite a little up into small bits, and .oisten it well in your mouth, and when it is in a soft, porridgy con-

dition, it is ready to give to the birds. Lift the one you want to f e < and hold it carefully in both hands, place its bill between your lij It if does not take at once, touch its bill with your lips lightly. Ne\ close your lips over its nostrils. Place its bill to your lips sidewa 1 If they both take well, you can rear them ; if only one does so, p the other back in the nest, and try another bird, who may take fo better. Brown bread, mouth-moistened--almost fluid--is enough at firs but as they get older you must mix it with little mouthsful of bitt- and peeled apple--or chewed lettuces--or the pulp of grapes, or banan and a hard-boiled egg occasionally. Even from the first, small drinks of warm water are good, i tlle y g e f older this is essential. You will know when they want feedii by their calling for it. Never force them to feed, but persuade then once they get the habit they will let you know when they need i For the first four or five days feed them every three hours or so. I toe mine about with me in its basket, while it was still in down--and whi in the house it is wise to take the basket from room to room with on so that one can hear them when they need feeding. Change the flannel squares repeatedly ; it is important to keep the clean ; be sure the clean squares you put in are quite dry. When the feet got clotted at all, I stood them for a minute or so in a soap dn of warm water. Do not line the basket with hay, as this fosters disease of the lungs. Let them have exercise as they get older ; climbing about yoi lap and up to your shoulders. Be very careful not to let them drop out of your hands, nor let tl basket drop , a fall kills a bird from shock. I think this is wh fledglings picked up in spring, having fallen from the nest, so seldoi live. I tied a label on to the handle of my basket with a big notice- with care live bird. This protects them from tidying housemaid and being casually shifted or jarred in ignorance. When almos fully plumed four meals a day suffice--but leave a millet spray in th basket. Let the basket stand somewhere near your bed, so that yo can hear them when they wake, and feed them. I found that min slept till seven a.m., or later. When feeding them, always give a littl

a time ; and take time over it. Feeding three, I found, took twenty nutes. At a month old they should have millet in the spray put in their sket with them, so that they can nibble the seed when they like. They should often be lifted out of the basket and allowed to potter out ; they like to stretch their wings, which they repeatedly do, engthening the muscles in preparation for flight, by winnowing e air. The advantage of bringing up by hand in this manner is that you ve birds so absolutely and entirely tame that you are able to know mi from a new angle. You see their ways, their movements, their itty loves and jealousies, their playfulness, and their exquisite luty, at close range. And all their feelings they expend on you, ing to meet you as you enter the aviary, and not only tame to you, t regarding all humans as their friends. In fact, it is a question birds thus reared will mate. They appear to become disoriented -m their own kind. This is true of the bird I reared last year ; but 1 may be because I reared one, by itself. It will be interesting to see if this will be the case equally of the ree I have reared this year. They have now grown to full size, and ) in no whit different from the three I left to the parent birds, except the matter of tameness. The parent birds were given me two years ago by Lord Tavistock ; ey bred the first year I had them, hatching three out of four eggs ; t the only one that lived was the one I took to bring up by hand, the next attempt in their breeding I had the great advantage of
algorithms.listItem: >rd Tavistock's expert advice ; the male bird being one of his liberty - * lined birds, that can be released in the morning, returning to an ! nexe of the breeding aviary through a wire funnel ; a system that s been, I believe, described by Lord Tavistock in the pages of this |igazine.
algorithms.bodyText: The female, he tells me, is an older bird than her mate, and bears idence of some years of previous life in a cage. She is certainly 1 mer than he, and whistles a snatch of one of the more jaunty tunes the songs of Chevalier, but only in moments of stress or anxiety. ie sidles along the perch, if one looks at her young, whistling this tune

in hurried anguish, which gives a funny effect of conflict, just as might say " a merry Christmas " in a flood of tears. But her at soon dissipates, and on the whole she trusts me, as indeed she m; for I would never take the whole clutch from her ; and, judging her decrease in vitalitynow, she has found rearing three birds sufficiei exhausting. The success we have had this year in hatching these six yo Rock Peplars, the full clutch of eggs, I attribute entirely to ha\ had the great advantage of Lord Tavistock's advice in the matte the right kind of nest-box, as well as in other nesting details, recommended a tall construction in appearance like a grandfath clock, filled up to within a foot and a half from the hole with dry w pith--the light, porous stuff you find inside a hollow tree that is inva by decay. The hen nested in April, the eggs hatched on the 18tl May. I took the three young I intended to rear by hand out of the i on the 5th of June, and freed them into another larger aviary on 7th of July, flying well and able to feed themselves. Of the three I left to the parent birds to rear, one already i free, with its father returning through the funnel, to feed ; and I s bring the other two on to do the same. The extreme beauty of tl birds in flight cannot be described. I have not a wide experiei but among the species of the Parrot tribe that I do know, I give Rock Peplars the palm, for they are without the two great disabili of their race---they are not noisy, and their beaks are too soft to be i to hurt. They have also a further quality of grace--one by no me of small account in the communal life of an aviary--they are ge and peaceful birds, and do not molest their neighbours.
algorithms.sectionHeader: PARRAKEET NESTING SITES : SUITABLI AND UNSUITABLE
algorithms.bodyText: By the Marquess of Tavistock The past few seasons have taught me some severe but interes lessons about the extreme importance of securing the right kin( nest for the successful rearing of Parrakeets : especially remark;

|been the evidence of the overwhelming superiority of the perpen- llar hollow tree trunk with a natural bottom or with no bottom at n the cavity being filled up to the required height with earth and uld taken from the interior of a decaying tree. Hollow tree trunks terribly heavy and cumbersome to move and often difficult to i ain, but the results more than justify their use in districts where : climate is none too favourable to aviculture. When first I started birds in the new movable aviaries I provided artificial nest-boxes ' h wooden bottoms covered with a layer of dry, decayed wood and lg up in the flight. Those for Kings and Crimson-wings were nearly t. deep and the bottom rested on the ground. In these boxes the t season I bred two or three lots of very healthy Ringnecks, a few dthy Barrabands, and one healthy Rock Peplar. Kings and Crimson- lgs, however, were a dismal failure, the young either dying of 3umonia at an early age or becoming hopelessly rickety about the le they began to feather. One young Crimson-wing was bred in a rnral tree trunk with an artificial wooden bottom. When she left i nest she was so rickety that she was quite unable to fly and could ,rcely crawl and remained in this condition for several weeks ; but ange to say she slowly improved and in the end became quite i decent bird with good use of her limbs : indeed, I believe she entually laid eggs. This proves that it was her early environment d not inherited weakness of constitution that was the cause of her bleness. The two following seasons yielded less satisfactory results I th the birds using the artificial boxes. In only one out of four j rraband nests were all the young reared. One hen, though a good d attentive mother, lost all her brood from pneumonia at about

wever, in natural tree trunks with natural bottoms or hollows half ed with mould, reared vigorous young with no sign of weakness. Next year, in the hope of preventing losses from pneumonia, I put ! tificial boxes in the aviary shelters which were very warm and dry. my-colours, Blue-winged Grass-Parrakeets and Yellow-rumps reared althy young under these conditions, but in the main the experiment

was a failure. All the young Ringnecks, Barrabands and Rock Pepl died of pneumonia quicker than they had done in the flights, and yoi Browns, Crimson-wings and Ringnecks were crippled with rick* although they had nearly a foot of earth at the bottom of their ne; separating them from the wooden floor. As on the former occasi however, the Crimson-wings made surprising progress when they w taken out of the aviary shelter. This season I substituted Vita glass for ordinary glass in all shelters, and removed the trays at the bottom when the birds w breeding, admitting far more air and moisture. These alterati- were, in the main, useless so long as natural perpendicular tree trui were not employed. Two pairs of Ringnecks had artificial boxes the shelters. One lot of young died when a few days old ; the oth died of rickets soon after leaving the nest, though they were nice strc birds at the start. Another pair had a natural log hung horizonta in the shelter. The hen--a good mother--lost both her broods wl a few days old. Yellow-rumps were given a bottomless, mould-fill perpendicular box in the shelter for their first nest, and in it rea five strong young. For their second nest they had a horizontal natu log in the shelter and the young died when a few days old. But h similar log, similarly placed, Rosellas reared a healthy brood. A R j rump Parrakeet paired to a Hooded had an artificial box in the shel with the trays left in. Her two young hybrids lived to fend for the selves, but were weak on the wing and are now dead. The Rock Peplar had a bottomless, mould-filled perpendicii box in the shelter, and lost her young of pneumonia when ab< ten days old. Another hen who laid on the ground in the open Aid reared a strong brood. Crimson-wings lost their first brood in a rather small, draugh bottomless natural log in the open flight, but reared a second bro well in a good tree trunk in the flight. Malabars reared a strong brood in the shelter in a natural perp< dicular tree trunk with a natural bottom. Barrabands reared a stro brood in a bottomless, mould-filled perpendicular box in the flight. The results go to prove that the natural perpendicular tree trU with natural bottom or mould gives good results either in flight

ter, preferably in the former, for hardy species not subject to egg- ling. The artificial box with no bottom but partly filled with mould y give good results with the hardier species but in the shelter it is lse for Rock Peplars. The horizontal natural log is, in the shelter, little better than the ficial box and will only do for very hardy birds and for species (oddly ugh in most other ways delicate), which, like Many-colours and ss Parrakeets, are resistant to the normal ill-effect of the combina- ' i. of artificial box and shelter. Pneumonia is not encouraged by the st and mouldy character of the interior of a natural tree trunk, 1 it is not in the least discouraged by the use of disinfectants, nor the extreme dryness of the nest and its immediate surroundings, kets seem primarily due to artificial wooden floors, even when these covered with a thick layer of earth, and it makes no difference ether the nest stands out in the fresh air and sunshine or whether .sina dark place with a closer atmosphere : diet makes no difference ier. Experiences with Crimson-wings are especially telling. Hen . 1 in 1921 reared in the flight a rickety young one in a natural 3 trunk with an artificial wooden bottom. In 1922 and 1923 she red healthy young in the flight in a perpendicular tree trunk with atural bottom. In 1924 she lost hybrid young by a Princess of les' Parrakeet in an artificial box in the flight. In 1925 she reared lthy hybrids in the natural tree trunk which had been the scene of previous successes. Hen No. 2 in 1926 had rickety young in a : in the shelter and, after a failure in a rather poor log, reared lthy young in a perpendicular mould-filled tree trunk in the flight 1927. Sich These birds are generally called Pyrrhulauda or Eremopteryx otis, but the author of Birds Bred in Captivity says that they are |ost certainly the southern species, smithi, and mine are probably same. In the early part of 1925 a fair number were imported, all I could find in London were cocks ; however, by writing. Various dealers, I obtained a cock and two hens by 8th May. The # consorted with one hen, but drove the other one away ; this bird ! wed a few black feathers on the lower part of the breast which other bird had not got. There was no further change when I let , birds out into the flight of my new aviary at Worthing at the end of : f, 1926. These birds do not care for the grass and spend most of |ir time on two gravelly patches just inside the two doors leading 1 n the passage into the flight ; in very dry weather they sometimes on to a strip of bare earth at one end. Under these circumstances

II. L. Sick--The White-cheeked Finch-lark I have not found them very interesting. About the middle of J last year I suddenly noticed that I had two full plumaged- cocks 1 conclude that they take two years to reach maturity. If this 1 comes from the south of the Equator it may have been hatched ah November, 1924, which would make it about eighteen months. When watching my birds on 9th June last I saw a harmless-look Turnix strolling over the grass : as it came close to the stem of a sn cupressus tree the pair of Finch-larks suddenly flew up and attacl it, one bird perching on its back and pecking at its head ; this co only mean a nest. On examination I found the cock bird squatt on the ground just where the grass meets the soil close to the stem the tree. A yard in one direction the Turnix had a nest ; in the k grass close by a hen Harlequin Quail was incubating seven eggs. J to hatch in about a week. There was no chance of a ground b rearing any young with a lot of Quail chicks scrambling over evervthi so a risk had to be taken. I formed a fence with wire-netting ab( 2 feet away all round the nest ; of course, the birds flew away duri the process, but a few minutes afterwards the hen was back a^a The nest was only a slight hollow, rather thickly lined with hay, a contained only one egg, coloured very much like the dark bro variety of that of a Skylark, much smaller, rather longer, and Li pointed in shape. Both birds incubated till 21st June. I fancied tl: my going into the aviary to feed the Quail chicks had disturbed the but there was no signs of a chick in the egg when blown. On 23 June they were incubating one egg again, in the same nest. On 7 July they had deserted it: there was no chick in that either. Tb have not nested since. Only laying one egg seems rather curious, b a single bird was reared in 1917 by Mr. Shore-Baily, and Avicultue. Magazine, August, 1924, pp. 183-4 : " Witherby found a nest abo Khartoum. . . It contained one egg. Perhaps insects to feed theyoin with are scarce in their habitat, and one at a time is all they ct manage. algorithms.sectionHeader: STEAMER DUCKS AND SHEATHBILLS AT THE ZOOLOGICAL GARDENS
algorithms.bodyText: Through the kindness of Dr. Stanley Kemp and Mr. A. G. Bennett, jjthe " Discovery " expedition the Zoological Society has received r examples of the Steamer Duck (Tachyeres cinereus) and five of the : low-billed Sheathbill (Chionis alba) from the Falkland and South tland Islands. The Steamer Duck is a large, heavily built bird with a dark brownish k d and the body more or less spotted with grey, the bill of the drake nge yellow and that of the duck greenish yellow, the feet also ng yellow. The under surface is white in both sexes. There would t>ear to be two distinct types of this Duck, the one greyish in colour, 'act in very old birds the head as well as the body becoming light y, the other type being mostly reddish in colour and smaller, reover, the larger grey or greyish birds have short wings and are titless, whereas the smaller redder birds have longer wings and capable of flight. The larger type is met with in the Straits of Magellan and the open , whereas the smaller birds frequent more the inland lakes of Southern ith America. These two types or races of Steamer Duck have long n a puzzle to ornithologists, for it is known that the one is not the mg of the other as has been suggested, and, moreover, it has been perved that the two sometimes interbreed. : Steamer Ducks are so named on account of their habit of swimming h great rapidity with the aid of both wings and feet, a mode of *gression that has been likened to steaming They spend a good i 1 of their time sitting on the rocks, and have their nests beneath the er of some bush or rock.

Correspondence The bill of the Steamer Duck is very powerful and capable crushing shells such as mussels ; shell-fish, in fact, forming a- const able part of its food. On four occasions only has the species b exhibited at the Zoological Gardens, the last being forty years ago The Sheathbills ( Chionis ), of which there are two if not three spec superficially resemble large white pigeons, though in reality they related on the one hand to the Plovers and on the other to the Gi But they are very distinct from all other existing species of bi Their bills are powerful and carry a peculiar sheath, the use of wl has never been satisfactorily determined, and the feet are not wehl C. alba inhabits the Falkland Islands and South Georgia, where it some three or four species of Penguins as its companions, and the c of which form the chief food of its young. It is an omnivorous fee* a scavenger to which little comes amiss from Crustacea and sea-bi: eggs to the excreta of Seals and Penguins. Sheathbills have been imported previously on rare occasic but not for a number of years.
algorithms.sectionHeader: D. Seth-Smite CORRESPONDENCE THE SMALLER MACAWS
algorithms.bodyText: Sir, --In Miss Knobel's very interesting article on the sma Macaws, she asks for experiences. I had a Severe who could whistle and say " Come hon " : he ha water, except to drink. He was pinioned when I got him, and summer-time he spent most of his time at liberty in the garden. I rained he made for the nearest shelter. One day a heavy shower cai and I could not find him anywhere : after a time I heard his usual c " Come hon " ; he had climbed over the fence into the waterf* enclosure, and was sitting with a Duck under a nest-box. He was good terms with the fox terriers, so I had no fear of cats and vermin I have had two Spix Macaws. One, I think, was an adult-cau; bird and was never tame ; the other was very tame, but seldom nu a sound.
algorithms.figure: Correspondence
algorithms.bodyText: A. pair of Illiger's Macaws I got from Mr. A. Zache were very dy, but were all in all to each other, and cared little for me and ild not be handled. I have had at one time or another all the large \ > a ws, except the Glaucous. I cannot remember ever hearing of them whistle. I have a Scarlet (Yellow Saddle-back) Macaw who whispers to you ; t s a good talker and sings songs composed by himself. John W. Marsden.

Sir _Mr. Sydney Porter is to be envied his acquaintance with such a rming bird as " William ", the Yellow-throated Honey-guide : at tj same time he is to be commiserated with, in that he was unable bring him back to England. Concerning the parasitic nesting of Indicator , Lydekker writes ild Life of the World, vol. iii, pp. 150, 151) :-- " According to a recent account, the widely distributed African low-throated Honey-guide ( Indicator major) in most cases makes of the nesting-hole of Spreo bicolor, a bird which, like the Honey- des themselves, lays white eggs. The Honey-guide's eggs are, ! vever, less elongated than those of its hosts, among which are certain cies of Swallows, as well as other birds laying white eggs. Whether Honey-guides lay more than one egg in the Spreo s nest is not ntioned, but it is stated that these birds whenever possible break 1 1 eggs of their hosts with their beaks, thus ensuring that their own 5 or eggs shall alone hatch. The most remarkable point connected :h this egg-breaking business is that the Spreos or other hosts should itinue to sit. Their parasitic habits being apparently well known, s Honey-guides are in most cases fiercely attacked by the owners of ; nests visited, and in some cases the resistance prevents the intruders m breaking the original eggs. In such instances the young Honey- des probably eject their fellow-nestlings, and it is noteworthy that 1 ) beaks of the former are furnished with powerful hooks, which appear in the adult. This, it is conjectured, is a provision to assist im in ejecting the other occupants of the nest. It has also been

Correspondence noticed that a young Honey-guide taken from the nest of a Diamc Sparrow (Petronia petronella) was very large for its age ; here ag; exhibiting a Cuckoo-like feature. The mention of a single nestli in this instance suggests that the Honey-guides lay only one eijg a nest. As Indicator is common to Africa, Malaya, and the Himakr it would be interesting to ascertain if the parasitic habits of the Afric species are shared by their Asiatic cousins ; but as the Himalay bird is believed to lack the ' honey-guiding ' habit of the Sou African species, it may also differ in the matter of egg-laying." Perhaps Mr. Porter, if he has had the opportunity of studyi the nesting habits of the Indicatoridse, would be so good as to commf on the above, and make known his own observations. D. G-. Prestwich.

While I cann say that I have never lost a Peach-face by straying, I got very fs results vith them when free in the garden. Many young were reare and the old birds did not appear to be migratory in the autumn. Tavistock.

Sir, W ith the acquisition of two new specimens by the Zoologic. Society the number of this rare Parrakeet in captivity in this counti v ould appear to be raised to four. A male bird came into my possessic a few months ago, and has since done well. He was in perfect coi dition on arrival, although he had evidently been closely confined f( a very long time as he had the cage-cramped habits of a bird whic has forgotten how to use its wings or even climb. For several da^ after he had been turned into an aviary it was necessary to hold hi seed and water up to him on the perch, as he would have starved befor he ventured to descend the wire to the food dishes. He is perfect!;

algorithms.bodyText: * e, and very amiable in disposition, having the little courtly r merisms characteristic of male Palceornis Parrakeets that have i 1 treated as pets. On the approach of a friend he keeps bowing and king the perch with his beak, moves his lower mandible very dly, and makes a little sound between a puff and a hiss. When ted by the presence of visitors he utters very loud, harsh, and lent calls which would render him intolerable inside a building, ging from appearances, the nature of its habitat and the fact that i a glorified edition of the Moustache Parrakeet, the Derbyan is ) rnbly an excessively hardy bird which it would be difficult to kill ;pt by violence. Mine is fed on the usual seed mixture, together l monkey nuts and apple, of which latter he is very fond. Like t Parrakeets he greatly enjoys a rain bath. Tavistock. THE BREEDING OF THE BIB FINCH AT LIBERTY 3ir, --Last May I obtained two or three pairs of this soberly-coloured not unattractive little bird, and after training them to enter an ry shelter through a little door a few inches in diameter, gave them r liberty. They stayed and did well, and after some weeks my aviary ndant reported that they had bred. On my return home in August, ost the first small birds I saw in the garden were two young Bib i ikes on the feeding tray, very well grown, and only differing from r parents in the lack of bib. 1 have yet to winter them, but I do not anticipate great difficulty his, and it would appear that the Bib Finch can be added to the i of small, common birds whose presence at controlled liberty can aade to add beauty and interest to a well-planted garden. In spite ; s diminutive size and quiet coloration the Bib Finch is by no means nspicuous at liberty, as it is tame and not at all retiring in its i its. Tavistock.

Sir, --Some time ago I bought lead wire for fastening labels on rc and, unthinkingly, used this for fastening drinkers on cages. I use the cages for isolating birds for a few weeks after receiving tl from dealers. All went well with ordinary hard bills, but latterly I have ta up Lovebirds and Parrakeets. About a month ago I got a pair of Masked Lovebirds from Chapin and put them in one of these cages, and found, on the second morn they had eaten the wire through and spilt their water. I fastened the drinker up again with stronger steel wire, and thou no more about it. On going to feed them the following day I found cock completely paralysed in the legs, and so he still remains a three weeks, although in other respects quite fit. The same thing happened to a pair of Budgerigars before I foi out my mistake ; one Budgerigar died after severe contortions. Perhaps you may think it worth while publishing this as a warr to fellow aviculturists, who may, like me, find soft wire very e to use. I have a young Black-cheeked Lovebird on its own, hate 16th June, and should like to know if this is the first breeding suc( in Ireland. A. E. Blythe Jackson

Sir, --Just a line to say that I have had a hatch of the Mas] Lovebird (Agapornis jpersonata). Doubtless other enthusiasts < report a success as early, if not earlier. The hen began to sit on 8th Ji and was still on three eggs when I left home on 4th August, on return to-day, 17th August, I found two young ones. Incubation in have lasted at least twenty-five days. Two other nests, which were started about the same date, app to contain addled eggs. These young are covered with the oran coloured down characteristic of the Lovebirds. It remains to be si how long they remain in the nest, provided all goes well. M. T. Allen

You refer to percentage lue young ; several of us tried this theory many years ago, with ns and yellows, but the 25 per cent and 50 per cent did not turn and I have tried it with blue and green since, without success. )n the other hand, one member, Mr. Danys Weston, has proved it ij -ork out with blues and greens. Now he used blues that had been [ from blues for several generations, whereas I used blues bred ii l blue-bred greens. [ like a dark blue (not cobalt) better than a sky blue, and as I do show, nor breed for the market, I seldom pair two blues together. . think this proves that unless the blues are bred from blues and the n blood bred out, they are not potent enough to prove this theory. I have known young of other colours produced in an aviary nly blue birds ; these would be the best of blue birds, of course ; n producing a new colour, you would give consideration to the ur of breeding stock, as well as pedigree. I think the olive was I luced by selection, so now we really have four shades of colours for sing green, yellow, blue, and olive. .t is a long time since I had any Pennants, or saw T any young ones, ! as far as I can remember, the nest feather is nearly all olive green, enerations ago the Pennant must have been an olive-green bird, we have olive Budgerigars and the mauve has a pink shade showing he blue, so we are sure to get pink or red Budgerigars in time. ! ve already heard of two cases of birds that show a few pink feathers. John W. Marsden.
Memorial to the Late Mr. H. D. Astley
algorithms.sectionHeader: MEMORIAL TO THE LATE MR. HUBEI DELAVAL ASTLEY
algorithms.bodyText: Mr. Allen Silver writes :-- " In peaceful Herefordshire, where no sound but the notes of b and the rustle of leaves in a hay-scented breeze broke the stillnes a beautiful afternoon, stands the small church of St. George, siti in the parish of Brinsop. " A little before 3 o'clock on the afternoon of 30th July, a could be heard calling to those who were gathering together in men of our much esteemed and friendly late member. The almost mediaeval atmosphere of this little church with sounds of ancient pipe organ and viols was most impressive, and Right Reverend Dr. Trollope, in dedicating a window to the Hubert Delaval Astley, alluded in his address to the great inte] that was taken and the love that was shown by him for all thi beautiful. One has only to look through a series of volumes of our Magas to know how true this was, and to many of us who knew him person; his memory will be long cherished like the sunshine and breezes < beautiful summer afternoon."

algorithms.sectionHeader: THE BREEDING OF THE CROWNED WOOD PARTRIDGE
algorithms.bodyText: By Herbert Whitley, E.Z.S. Our worthy Editor informs me that there is to be a plate of the wned Wood Partridge (Rollulus roulroul ) in the Magazine, and t as I have been fortunate enough to breed this beautiful species, ; my duty to record my experiences with it. To those unacquainted h the adult birds, the excellent plate accompanying these notes gives <h a life-like representation that further description is unnecessary. The Roul-roul is the sole member of its genus which is characterized the presence in both sexes of long hair-like bristles springing from middle of the forehead. All the Wood Partridges, and there are two er genera, have the claw of the first toe rudimentary. The home of the Roul-roul is in ''South Tenasserim, Malay linsula, Sumatra, Java, and Borneo " (B.M. Catalogue), and I under- id that it is upon the well-wooded hillsides at an elevation of from X) to 4,000 feet, that it is usually to be found in " coveys " of from to a dozen.
algorithms.author: Herbert Whitley
algorithms.bodyText: To the late Sir William Ingram belongs the credit of being the fii to hatch the Koul-roul in captivity, and twenty years ago he was far successful in that he reared a chick so hatched to the age three weeks in one of his aviaries at Monte Carlo. A drawing of the chi and an interesting account of the nesting habits of the bird appear Avicultural Magazine, New Series, Vol. VI, p. 38. I purchased my first pair of Roul-roul from Chapman in the la summer of 1924. These were shortly afterwards turned out into fairly large aviary thickly planted with shrubs and in which there w a good deal of undercover. The cock bird never seemed to thrive, and about six weeks aft< wards he was found dead under one of the bushes. The hen, on the oth hand, appeared to improve and later came through a good moult. S passed the winter in this aviary to which was attached a lofty shelb without artificial heat. She frequently roosted in the open, and exce in very severe weather the door of the shelter was never shut, whi! the large window near the top of the shelter was continuously op night and day. I must here interpolate the remark that I do not recommend tl spartan treatment for Roul-rouls, as this last winter during a prolong spell of wet I found that the damp earth " balled " on their feet, ai that both parents and chicks seemed happier and naturally mo active when brought to a somewhat drier atmosphere where their fe soon recovered from the chaps which were starting to form on the und( side of their toes. As a mate for the hen I purchased, in December, 1925, a cock bi from Mr. Hebb, of Luton. The weather being bad and the time of t year unfavourable, I kept this bird for some time shut in a roomy ca# but eleven days after his arrival he had the misfortune to break a leg this was on the 29th of the month. Having set the bone to the best my ability, with a bandage soaked in white of egg, I kept him in the da until 3rd January, 1926, when preferring to risk the weather rather th; he should disturb the setting of his limb, I turned him out in the b aviary with the hen. I have mentioned these details in order to she that, whilst these birds probably prefer rather more warmth than i average English winter brings, they are certainly not delicate.
The Breeding of the Crowned Wood Partridge

On 3rd May the aviary attendant's notice was drawn to the cock i standing under a laurel and near him a small mound of sticks 1 dried leaves towards the centre of the bush. This mound was shaped " a tunnel, with a small entrance hole in the front ; upon closer ervation the green body feathers of the hen bird were visible hin. Later in the evening the aperture was completely sealed and the k had gone to roost in the laurel above. Some few days afterwards the hen was seen to be feeding, and a it to the mound disclosed the fact that she was therein incubating ee white eggs, almost round, with the shell having almost the same ture and substance as the egg of the Guinea Fowl. The size of the ; is given by the late Mr. Astley as diameter L25 in., axis 1*55 in. The hen proved a very close sitter, and this was the only occasion on which she was found away from her nest. Every night she was lied up inside and presumably she did this herself from within, but s possible that the cock lent a hand as he was invariably on guard, rein my experience differs from that of Sir William Ingram, who md that his male bird kept " as far as possible from his partner's ode ". After three weeks the hen was gently driven from her nest, and the *s were found to be unfertile and removed. About this time I considered it advisable to take off the bandage ich still adhered to the male bird's leg, and on 17th July the hen ul-roul was reported missing. After a prolonged search--and I uld here emphasize the marvellous way in which the domed nest nds with the surrounding foliage--her whereabouts was discovered the other side of the aviary, at the foot of an old disused feeding dter, and seventeen days later the mother made her appearance with ir tiny chocolate-coloured chicks. One of these was noticed to be aker than its fellows, and was found dead later in the day. About reek after this one of the remaining three chicks disappeared and was ver found, the other tw T o reaching maturity and proving to be one of :h sex. Sir William Ingram gives the period of incubation as eighteen days, d w r ith me the hen might have been sitting a day or tw T o before she v r as )orted absent.
algorithms.sectionHeader: 256 The Breeding of the Crowned Wood Partridge
algorithms.bodyText: Apart from the Boul-roul's ordinary food (grain, insectivorous foo bread, and milk, and cut-up fruit) there was supplied finely chopp. egg and bread crumbs, chopped green food, and mealworms or gentk Both the old birds took a hand in feeding the young, but the hen alo; brooded them and this she was never seen to do except under the cov of the nest. It might be of interest here to remark that, as far as my knowled; goes, green as a colour is unknown amongst the gallinaceous birds, sa 1 in the female of this species, and in the males of the Blood Partridges \0x25A0

Did the hen Roul-roul acquire her comparatively bright pluma< (i.e. for the brooding sex amongst game birds) because she builds domed nest for herself or does she build a domed nest because she hi put on somewhat gaudy attire ? Perhaps those interested in " protects coloration " will give their opinion. Doubtless she is " protective] coloured " whilst moving about amongst the changing lights in heav woodland, but presumably her vivid green tint would be conspicuoi when at rest. At a fortnight old the chicks were able to fly into the low busk and roost with their parents. In their first plumage the young hire had the body chocolate brown with speckled wings and a small cream fawn spot on each tail feather. As the moult took place the sex< became discernible, and in three months or so they were almo: indistinguishable from the old birds, except in size. The white ban across the top of the head of the adult male bird took some time-i manifesting itself in the chick of the sterner sex. In the early months of this year, when I brought the family undt cover for the reason stated above, the young male was if anything finer bird than his father. Presumably four eggs would be the norm; clutch for these birds.
Capt * H. S. Stokes--The Arrival of Fischer's Lovebirds 257
algorithms.sectionHeader: THE ARRIVAL OF FISCHER'S LOVEBIRDS (AGAPORNIS FISCHERI)
algorithms.bodyText: By Capt. H. S. Stokes For the third time in eighteen months a new species of Lovebird s come to us, through the enterprise in each case of Mr. Chapman, is species hails from Tanganyika, and was recently depicted in our in the Magazine. But we find on comparison with the living d that it is not green on the back of the head as painted, but the ne bright orange colour as on the face and neck. It has a blue rump, d is the same size as the Nyasa Lovebird, and not so highly coloured, in our opinion so attractive. Probably it will breed equally freely, d in this connexion it may be useful to mention the experiences this year. During the spell of dry, cold winds in April and May all Lovebird gs, Nyasa and Black-cheeked, proved unfertile. They were thought need a cool, damp atmosphere more like their rain-soaked native unts. Mr. Denys Weston devised a nest-box with a false bottom, below lich is a drawer packed with sphagnum moss which can be moistened necessary. One of these boxes was given to one pair of Nyasas and an ordinary idgerigar box to another pair. Large baths filled with long grass d groundsel were placed in each aviary and damp moss also thrown the floor. The result from both boxes was just the same, each ir having reared a clutch of five young from as many eggs. The bath ould be big enough to oblige the birds to get into it among the damp j rbage, which is bitten off and taken into the boxes, and doubtless pplies the necessary moisture. The Black-cheeks reared one young ly out of four eggs, and this one unfortunately died after leaving e nest. Lovebirds are rather a problem in the winter : they do not do very 11 in cages ; if their aviary is quite cold they need sleeping boxes, which case they insist on perpetually breeding, and if a paraffin lamp ; used, as in my case, to exclude frosts and provide a little comfort, 3 atmosphere probably becomes too dry.
algorithms.category: 258 Marquess of Tavistock--The Perfect Lorikeet in Captivity
algorithms.sectionHeader: NOTES ON THE PERFECT LORIKEET IN CAPTIVITY
algorithms.bodyText: By the Marquess of Tavistock Last winter, while visiting Mr. Lewis' fine collection, I wasinteres: to see three specimens of this lovely little bird, Psitteuteles eute recently imported, and practically new to aviculture. Although 11 given up keeping Lorikeets some years before, as Mr. Lewis did i want them himself, I was tempted to buy them. Unfortunately bef I was able to take charge of them one of the cocks died. The p I took home myself, not caring to leave such delicate treasures to 1 tender mercies of the railway company. They arrived in good condit but further ill-luck was in store. I told my aviary attendant to g them Lorikeets' food. He misunderstood me and gave them Hang Parrots' food--mashed banana and sponge cake--which they woi not touch. The result was that next morning I found them in a v< shaky condition and before the proper diet could be obtained i cock collapsed quickly and died. The hen soon revived on Dr. Allinso Food prepared as for infants and sweetened--the only diet on wh 1 have been able to persuade all Lorikeets to thrive and keep free fr fits. On this, with the addition of a few sweet grapes, she has In ever since. After a considerable period of quarantine in the hospital the Lorik was moved to the warm bird-room and thence, late in May, to a la outdoor aviary with a heated shelter, of which latter she has irn full use. When in the cage she was quite tame and almost inclined be friendly, but after a summer in the aviary she has become Vi wild. In her movements and behaviour she resembles the Trichogloss Lorikeets, as also in her sharp cries, though being no larger thai Tui these naturally have little power. Her general plumage is bri^ glossy green, somewhat paler on the breast. On each cheek there i curious patch of yellow feathers interspersed with blackish ones ii manner to give the former a streaky appearance. In the centre of i upper part of the rump is a small patch of brilliant, deep blue. 1 pointed tail feathers are first green, then red, and at the tip yelk The beak is red and the feet and legs, unlike those of any other livi
