rot I have seen with the exception of the Queen of Bavaria Conure, ; reddish pink, like a Barbary Dove's. The gorgeous little cock was te differently coloured, having dark blue cheek patches instead of i iow and black ones. It is a thousand pities that an unlucky accident robbed me of the chance of breeding this interesting species.
algorithms.sectionHeader: THE BREEDING OF HYBRID CRIMSON- INGED X SULA ISLAND KING PARRAKEETS
algorithms.bodyText: By the Marquess of Tavistock This article might also be entitled "Per ardua ad astra' , for although ave had my Sula Island hen nearly nine years and she has laid once I sometimes twice most seasons and sat diligently, she has been a
algorithms.listItem: *y difficult bird to mate with success. Her first partner was a d Shining Parrakeet, but her eggs with him were never fertile, *haps because he was twice her size which is considerably less than ; -X of a Common King. When the Red Shining died I attempted to pair * to an Alexandra Parrakeet, but he never took to her and she was aid of him, which was odd, as she was by far the more powerful
algorithms.bodyText: d of the two. I next tried her with Australian Kings, but she bullied "life out of them although she was nearly a third smaller than they. >elieve they took her for a cock by reason of her plumage, and the ;ult to her Sex was more than she could endure ! Parrakeets aie ; t to be straUgely stupid in such matters and by no means so unerringly ided by instinct as one wmuld expect. Adult Cock Barrabands will ^lay to cocks in first plumage with the greatest energy and are viously quite deluded into the belief that they are hens. Finally, noticing that the Sula Island seemed attracted by the cock imson-wings I had at liberty, I decided to offer her a Crimson-wing I a mate. She obviously admired the fine male I introduced into her iary, although she was a little afraid of him, and had he possessed ! 5 disposition of a gentleman all might have gone well from the j ginning. Unfortunately, however, a Crimson-wing has no manners ; all and considers it a necessary preliminary to married life to impress i hen with his fine, masculine qualities by pursuing her with curses

Marquess of Tavistock --* up and down the aviary, biting her whenever he is able to catch 1 A female Crimson-wing understands this method of courtship { apparently quite enjoys it, but hens of other species do not. W the cock flies at them with his beak open, calling them unmentiona names, and endeavours to pull a mouthful of feathers out of their ba( they conclude that he dislikes them, and the more persistently declares his passion with strange oaths, the more hurriedly they before him. This happened in the case of the Sula Island. W the breeding season arrived her companion, I am sure, really qi liked her. He got very thrilled over her visits to the nest-box and e displayed to her at times, but he could not bring himself to for the formality of the preliminary thrashing, even when she was n anxious to be on intimate terms with him, and she on her part co not screw up her courage to the point of allowing him to bite ) So the end of it was that the eggs were unfertile. During the winter, however, the Sula Island made herself mat of her turbulent partner, and I had great hopes that the change in tl relationship might spell better fortune during the following spri Once, indeed, it seemed as though an accident would restore the fori position : in moving her we allowed a hen Crimson-wing to esc and she flew to the aviary occupied by the cock Crimson-wing ; the Sula Island King. The cock was thrown into transports of exc ment at the unexpected appearance of a lady of his own race, anc once fell upon the Sula Island and quickly put her to flight, captured the disturbing visitor as quickly as possible, and w T hen presence no longer excited him to deeds of valour I was relieved to 1 that the cock Crimson-wing once more accepted the domination of King, to which he had become accustomed. However, no bei fortune was in store, for the Sula Island King's eggs were ag clear. Worse still, as soon as she started to sit the Crimson-wing m himself master and when the eggs were removed began to harry hen so unceasingly that in disgust I separated them and allowed 1 to set up house with the female of his own kind already alluded this he did without a moment's hesitation or regret for his late c< panion. So relieved, indeed, was he to be rid of the Sula Island t he scarcely addressed a single cuss-word to his new bride and for

The Breeding of Hybrid Parrakeets 261 few weeks showed her more affection than I have ever seen in a |j ason-wing before or since ; I fear I must, however, add that he proved unable to keep it up indefinitely, although he is still with her is rearing a family at the moment. About a fortnight after the 1 ason-wing had been removed, the now solitary Sula Island laid two e eggs, one of which, to our intense astonishment, proved fertile hatched ! The triumph was, however, short lived, as the chick l when only a few days old, owing, as I now know, to the unsuitable ire of the nest, an artificial box in the aviary shelter being, in this *e, a perfect death-trap for any young King or Crimson-wing, spite of the belated and unexpected measure of success attained 1 the cock Crimson-wing, I felt it useless, now that he had settled -n with a mate of his own species, to try further experiments with and the King. I therefore obtained a new Crimson-wing, choosing - wo-year-old bird not quite in full colour, in order that the Sula I nd might be able to discipline him and teach him manners before had developed the hooligan disposition of his race and sex. All it well during the autumn and winter, the Sula Island keeping the i nson-wing well in his place. Early in March they became friendly
algorithms.listItem: . paired and although she had no nest the King insisted on laying * eggs on the sand on a zinc tray in the shelter immediately under the ling dish. This was not at all what I wanted as I planned to give
algorithms.bodyText: a natural tree trunk in the flight as soon as the weather became mild. aviary attendant put the eggs on a concave wooden nest bottom 1 the Sula Island proceeded to incubate them with great steadiness, y flying off for a few moments when the little door above her head i opened to replenish the food dish. I was, however, far from isfied about the probable fate of the chick which might hatch from one fertile egg. Young Aprosmictus Parrakeets develop cramp l rickets on an artificial wooden floor as surely as Ducklings, so 1'ecided to try the Sula Island's patience by yet another interference h her domestic arrangements. With great skill and by dint of rculean labours, the gardener and two assistants cut a gigantic f about 4 ft. square and 18 in. thick. I turned the Sula Island gently |her eggs and shut her out of the shelter. Then we removed the oden block, established the turf, bottom upwards, in its place, and

Marquess of Tavistock -- put the eggs in a hollow on the top. As soon as I pulled up the slit the hen, who had been quietly eating monkey nuts most of the till we had been banging about in her home, went back to her eggs and ml nest, I was going to say " like a lamb but as lambs are not not* for steadiness during incubation, " like a broody Dorking hen " mig be a better simile. That is the best of Parrakeets : they will start any reasonable and often quite a lot of most unreasonable interferen with their nests without deserting. They are wise birds, and, wi rare exceptions, devoted parents, very different from those addle-pat. Finches and Softbills that desert, at the most trivial disturbance, ev. their helpless young. Unfortunately all our trouble was once more vam. The Sula Island sat over her full time, but the chick was dei in the shell. I forgot to mention that soon after she had begun sittii the Crimson-wing developed bad manners, made himself master ar bullied her so incessantly whenever she came off to feed that I removcj him to another aviary. With the failure of the first batch of egJ there was nothing for it but to return him in the hope that solituc had improved his temper. If anything, however, it had made hii worse . directly he got over the fright of his transfer he was after tl Sula Island for all he was worth, driving her up and down the aviai with open beak and torrents of his choicest Billingsgate ; I could ha\ wrung his neck ! In desperation I resolved to apply to him the fin; discipline reserved for hopelessly savage cocks. I told the aviar attendant to catch him and cut his wing, not enough to stop him froi altogether, but sufficiently to restrict his capers pretty severeh He was exceedingly annoyed at the indignity to which he had bee subjected, and for some days sulked inside the aviary shelter, swearin at the Sula Island when she approached him. However, it turned on eventually that the punishment had done him a world of good. In few weeks time he was quite a reformed character and on excellen terms with his companion whom I had provided with a piece of ; natural tree trunk for her next attempt. It was not an ideal nest having no bottom and being little more than 2 ft. 6 in. high, but it wa the best I could get hold of. I placed it in a sheltered corner of th aviary flight and put plenty of mould and decayed wood in the interior The Sula Island laid three eggs which hatched a few days before I lefi
The Breeding of Hybrid Parrakeets

ie in May. Shortly before I lost a brood of young Crimson-wings very similar but rather more draughty log and my hopes of the rid nest were at a very low ebb and were not raised by what little uld see of the young ones when I got the chance of a peep with the of an electric torch. Young Parrakeets when in good health usually /e ry upright and very close together with their funny little " arms " ad each others' necks and their heads wobbling over each others' alders. But as far as I could see only one young hybrid was moving, that feebly, and the biggest lay very still and appeared to be dead, ent away with a heavy heart, daily expecting to hear that X, the spirit who appears to take a special delight in frustrating the hopes viculturalists, had done in one or all of my greatest treasures of the son--the hybrids, a Lutino Ringneck and a nest of Malabars. nade no mistake with the Lutino and duly destroyed the lovely len bird I had toiled for twelve years to produce, a few days after eft the nest, but for some reason the bad news of the hybrids never ae. The result was that when I got back in August I found sitting the perches three as sturdy and handsome young birds as one could h to see. They are not unlike rather slender young Common Kings,
algorithms.listItem: * ; all their colours are much more brilliant ; indeed, I have never
algorithms.bodyText: n any Parrakeets in first plumage with such rich tints, and if they } to be three years old they should be gorgeous birds, indeed. Their Ms, necks, wings, mantles, and breasts are green, the tint on the ast being slightly paler. The upper part of the rump is brilliant blue 1 the belly is very rich, dark crimson, streaks of the same colours ming upwards towards the breast and mingling with the green icaudal feathers. The cock has a few red feathers on the crown, e tail feathers are green above and black below with pinkish-yellow s. The beaks of the young birds are of a pinkish colour, becoming lower towards the tip of both mandibles. Eyes large and very "k. The Sula Island, encouraged by her success, went to nest a rd time and now (September 13th) has another young one about f grown. The newly-hatched young were covered with long white vn. It seems a great pity that the wonderful Aprosmictine larrakeets, i sexes of which are coloured alike, should remain practically unknown

algorithms.sectionHeader: THE BREEDING OF THE LEPURANA ! BUSTARD-QUAIL (TURNIX LEPURANA) \
algorithms.bodyText: By H. L. Sich Of the very few of the twenty-odd species of Turnix which I hii been able to pick up nearly all have been hens. As far as observation has gone they all appear to have simii habits, which have been described before. I have never had mil than three eggs in a clutch and sometimes only two, with paired bii as well as odd hens, although I have heard of four chicks having bel hatched and reared. It is impossible to say how many clutches are L j. by one hen in a season in nature. My two species, both paired, til year have laid one five clutches, the other four, and the latter is boomil; again now. Lepurana is, according to Ogilvie-Grant, a sub-species of sylvatl j. differing only in being smaller, and having a more southern range ! Africa. But his description of the latter does not quite describe t pattern of my lepurana. I can see no difference in the two sexes except size, and that t| breast of the hen is a little brighter yellow. The Upper parts a mottled and streaked with two shades of brown. The throat, breast, ail under parts are yellowish buff, a streak down the middle of thehea(| the sides of the neck and sides of the breast are very nearly white ground colour but each feather has a black centre, giving a sea! appearance. The bill, which is rather long, is lead coloured, the to! and tarsus yellowish white. The black of the eye is surrounded 1] pale yellow, which gives the birds a very scared look. Having got two tanli hens last year and failing to find a cock ana vhere I offered another bird in exchange for a Turnix which I sawij the Small Bird-house at the Zoological Gardens, and thought that !

H. L. Sick--Breeding of the Lepurana Bustard-Quail 265 been told that it was a cock. My offer was kindly accepted. Not r after the bird was in my aviary it started booming, then I knew r as a hen. Only then did I inquire its name and found it was <rana. I could see from the first that it was too different from my to be a cock tanki, but it was better than nothing. [n the autumn some more lepurana were advertised. The first lot ck I bought were all dead in two days. I was just in time to save cock of the second lot. A hen Chinese Painted Quail had taken a ike to them, being, I suppose, too much like herself in colour, hunted them round the shelter in which all the birds were shut n for the winter. Having caught up the remaining cock and the old hen for safety ie had not been attacked, being there before the Quail had arrived-- ut them in a small run 7 by 4 feet in the shelter of the other sion. By 11th April she had laid three eggs behind a board. These amoved besides three more laid by 23rd April as there was no live 1 for the chicks, even if the cock had hatched them, and there was j /here to put the hen if I had removed her. On 30th April they were out into the flight. On 4th June I discovered that what appeared )e a handful of hay tumbled out of a privet bush was the dome of 3 st: being placed in short grass it was more elaborate than usual, ,, looked much like a large nest of the Quail Finch. It contained \0x25A0 eggs, a third being laid about midday and the cock began to lbate soon after. The eggs are about 11 lines by 9 lines of a white and heavily mottled with dark olive brown and much smaller bches of pale brown and lavender grey. By 7.30 a.m., 18th June, all three eggs w r ere hatched. Going in eed some Quail chicks, the cock ran off the nest and the chicks tried ollow. I collected them and put them back. When I went again ).30 the nest was empty and the egg-shells which were there before 11. gone ; the nest was never used again. Did the cock eat them to er up all traces ? I never expected these eggs to hatch. The cock ! 5 always off the nest when I came in the morning, and came off ularly at about 6 p.m. for what seemed in my anxiety to be about f an hour. Besides that about every quarter of an hour all day long would leave the eggs for five or ten minutes to feed or have a dust

266 11. L. Sick--Breeding of the Lepurana Bustard-Quail bath. I could see the nest a good way off from the outside of the avia so his coming off was not due to fear of me. He sat more closely last few days, which raised my hopes. What summer weather we h; had this year was over by the middle of June. The three chicks w still alive on the 19th, after a soaking wet and stormy night, but the 22nd after a similar night there were only two left. I caught the cock and these two and placed them in a small run in the pass about 6 by 3 feet and had no more trouble, feeding them on 1 ants' eggs and gentles. I had to cover half the run over with rool felt to keep them moderately dry ; that and the drenching weat made observation rather difficult. I noticed that even when qi young when the sun shone the chicks would sit together apart fr the cock. At first they were dusky white with two darker stripes do the back and the whole of the eye appeared black. At six days the wing quills were visible. At about ten days old they began pick up food off the ground. By 3rd July at fifteen days old the be was covered with feathers and a little tail was showing ; the head t still covered with down. On the 5th I first noticed that the irishadbeco pale. On the 17th they were about two-thirds the size of the c< and coloured much the same but very much whiter looking and with any yellow on the under parts. I put them in a run by themseh inside, where they have been ever since. They are now, 1st Septeml the size of the cock and coloured like him except the breast wb only shows a tinge of yellow. As they are both the same size tl are probably both the same sex and I expect cocks. Thehenhas.l twice since, once in a small run where the cock refused to sit, and the aviary where he hatched out on 16th August, but I could not fi even the cock bird and in a week he appeared alone, so the wet a scarcity of food, which I could only scatter broadcast, which the ot birds ate, killed them. My other species, nigricollis, hatched out t from two eggs early in May, but on an isolated wet day and onlyliv a few hours. They have nested since but the eggs did not hatch. 1 young chicks were a few shades darker than lepurana but just t same pattern and size.
G. II. Gurney--Some Bird Notes from Tenerife 267

By G. H. Gurney, F.Z.S. h To the Naturalist, whether he be ornithologist, botanist, orentomo- st, no group of islands present a more fascinating and interesting for his particular hobby than the Canary Island Archipelago, various species peculiar to the islands, or in several cases to one icular island, offer problems of surpassing interest, and added to magnificent climate which one nearly always enjoys there renders ay on any one of the islands one of peculiar enjoyment. I spent greater part of February and March this year at Puerto Orotava he coast of Tenerife, and no better centre could be found from which vork the birds which are found on that island. Puerto Orotava is ated on the west coast of Tenerife, the largest island of the group, is reached by a drive through splendid scenery of 30 miles from ta Cruz, the principal town and port of the island. The island of erife roughly covers an area of over 900 square miles, and is 50 miles r by 32 miles broad. A long Unbroken range of mountains running ghly from Esperanza to Guia, forms, as it were, the backbone of island, and culminates in the well-known peak, the Pico de Teide, ch reaches a height of 12,180 feet. The sides of this long ridge of intains are deeply cut by barrancos (ravines) which run down on ier side, some of them of very large size. The entire surface of the nd is composed of basaltic rocks, lava, cinders, and scorrise, though i ;he fertile Laguna plateau there is a fine rich mould. Owing to the intains there is a considerable amount of moisture which renders, i island far less arid than some others of the group ; indeed, many of barrancos are most luxuriant with brilliant almost tropical vegeta- t, and it is only in the extreme south of the island where typical ican desert conditions exist that sandy, stony tracts of desert ntry are to be found, and it is on these desert-like plains that some i he most interesting insular birds are to be found. The extremely picturesque town of Orotava is situated 1,500 feet ve the sea, overshadowed by the snow-capped Peak of Tenerife ; Puerto, where I stayed, is 3 miles lower down, at sea-level. The ntry all round is now largely devoted to the cultivation of the 1 iana, and a great deal of what was formerly good country for birds

268 G. II. Gurney--Some Bird Notes from Tenerife has gone for ever. The banana plantations extend for miles all ro Orotava, and stretch up to some 2,000 feet, where one gets into region of the chestnut and laurel forests. There has been in the past considerable differences of opinion amoi scientists as to the origin of the Canarian Archipelago, and vari theories have been put forward : (1) that they are merely of volcr origin ; (2) that they were originally joined to the mainland of Afri
algorithms.listItem: (3) that they are the remaining peaks of the submerged fabled contin of Atlantis ; but it is now, I think, generally agreed that they w formed by volcanic action in the late Tertiary period. The Archipel is made up of some twelve islands, forming an eastern group an western group. The eastern islands are mainly composed of a
algorithms.bodyText: stony deserts and extinct volcanoes, with a very scanty vegetatit the two large islands of the western group, viz., Gran Canaria # Tenerife, are also purely of volcanic origin, but on them water is fai abundant, and consequently vegetation is much more luxurio The whole of the island of Tenerife can be divided up into very disti zones of vegetation, which bear a marked influence on the distribut of the birds. These zones may be differentiated as follows :-- (1) The Maritime Zone , which extends from sea-level to 1,000 fe and includes the desert-like plains. This zone is characterized bj semi-desert flora, where such arid-loving species as Opuntia and t wonderful Tree Euphorbias flourish, and is the habitat of such interest birds as the Courser and the Trumpeter Bullfinch. (2) The Monte Verde or Zone of Cultivation, including the rema of the chestnut and laurel forests, between 1,000 and 3,000 feet. Th the vegetation, whether indigenous or introduced, is of the utm luxuriance : vines, oranges, loquats, and bananas all thrive, and w flowers of every description clothe the sides of the barrancos, while t gardens of the villas and houses are more like outdoor conservator than anything else, with an extreme wealth of magnificent plants a shrubs ; the brilliant yellow and scarlet Bignonia venusta, red a purple Bougainvilleas climb in profusion over roofs and balconi flaunting crimson Hibiscus grow side by side with Daturas with th enormous white trilmpet-like flowers, while the beautiful blue Thi bergia grandiflora climbs over the dracaenas and palms, all making a picture of surpassing loveliness. Special birds peculiar to this zo
algorithms.listItem: G. H. Gurney--Some Bird Notes from Tenerife 269 } the Superb Redbreast, Spectacled Warbler, and till the destruction the laurel forests, the wonderful Pigeon, Columba bollei. (3) The Pine Forest Zone , 3,000-4,000 feet, and the habitat of one the most remarkable of Tenerife birds, the Teydean Blue Chaffinch, out which more will be said later on. (4) The Cumbres , or high mountain zone, extending from 4,000 to *00 feet; vegetation here is very poor, though the characteristic nt Escobon ( Cytisus prolifer) grows freely. Large tracts of the more by parts of the island (Zone 1) are given over to the Prickly Pear of 1 o species, viz. Optuntia coccinellifera and O. dillenii, the former,
algorithms.bodyText: ich in the past was largely cultivated, is the food-plant of the *hineal bug, which previously was bred by the inhabitants for the ;e of the well-known dye ; this industry was killed, however, in s Canary Islands by the discovery of aniline dyes in 1878. However, ! ir as told that recently an effort has been made to restart the cochineal lustry in Gran Canaria, principally because it is an industry which M.uires very little heavy labour, and in consequence suits the tempera - nt of the indolent Canarian peasants. The larger Birds of Prey are very common in Tenerife : Buzzards and d Kites may be seen at any time, and are remarkably tame, though y do not haunt the vicinity of the towns in the way they did twenty irs ago. The Egyptian Vulture is also an abundant species, but keeps the more mountainous parts of the island. It is a fine sight to see ee or four of these large Vultures wheeling over one's head, the black I white plumage of the adults standing out finely against the brilliant r e sky. Occasionally I saw them being mobbed by Buzzards, which their turn were mobbed by Ravens. The little Canarian Kestrel nnunculus tinnunculus canariensis) , which is a resident sub-species, 3 extraordinarily abundant and breeding in the barrancos ; they re absurdly tame, and would sit on a small tree, or on the top of a II by the roadside, and hardly bother to fly away as one passed, hink they feed almost entirely on the Lizards which swarm every - ere. A few years ago the Osprey was a comparatively common bird, ! 1 lived in the cliffs quite close to Orotava ; I was disappointed not 3ee it at all. (To be continued .)

algorithms.sectionHeader: THE UNSUCCESSFUL NESTING OF THE SENEGAL TOURACOU (TURACUS PERSA)
algorithms.bodyText: By Capt. H. S. Stokes Two years ago I related in these pages how a single Senegal Touraci had surprised us by laying a clutch of eggs. There followed the difficult search for a cock, rather like lookii for a needle in a haystack, for Senegal Touracous are very few and f between. However, through the kindness of friends we succeed in getting a beauty, and the two birds were duly put together. T hen went for him like a tigress, and they had to be separated. Tb were kept in separate aviaries, but within sight of each other throu; the winter, and on Whit-Monday, 1926, were put together, both in fresh aviary. They at once began to feed and kiss and make charmi crooning noises, and soon started a nest in some ivy outdoors, abo 5 ft. from the ground. A clutch of two eggs was laid and the bir ! sat steadily in June but the eggs proved to be clear. We had been warned by the previous experience of Mr. Delaco of the exuberance of the cock, who would certainly kill the first bro< of young, but we did not remove him as he regularly took his turn the eggs by day, after the manner of pigeons, and being also rath lame with rheumatism was not addicted to wife-beating. A secoi clutch of eggs was laid on the same nest in August, 1926, and one e hatched about 9th September. On this date I went abroad, as I have learnt to do when any specia precious birds are breeding. Letters from my aviary girl report the good progress of the baby, Upon whom she lavished endless ca and thought and trouble, and on my return on 10th October I w shown the young with great and justifiable pride. It was not yet o' of the nest, about half grown, and about the size of a pigeon, a covered with black down. It w T as about six o'clock in the eveni and just getting dark, wffien pleased to be home and elated at the bii into the world of another Senegal Touracou, I stood outside the avia and talked to the mother, who is attached to me and will feed fre my hand. She came to the wires for a grape, and the cock joined h and both became very excited and began to crow. Alas, it was the dea
. H. S. Stokes--Unsuccessful Nesting of Senegal Touracou

11 of the poor little one : in their excitement they left it that night ts fate, and in the morning it was dead. I learnt my lesson, and ^ed never more to pet them. This spring about April the hen showed signs of wishing to lay, we made every effort to induce her to do so indoors. Boxes and kets were put up, and heather and dead damson branches strewn mt, but she would have none of them. Back she went to the old t, and though the nest of last year had been demolished and we l put fresh heather up for her, it was all pulled out and the nest uilt entirely of branches broken off a small tree in the aviary by h birds. One egg only was laid, and after two days it disappeared. One more 5 then laid after a fortnight, and I caught the cock red-handed ing it. Another egg was laid in July--observe that the clutch was ariably only of one egg this year as against the normal two in 1926-- 1 this time both birds sat splendidly. The hen would come off ry morning about nine for breakfast and a bath, the cock taking place till six in the evening. We were very careful to keep them et and to make no fuss of them. Indeed, I again removed myself m the temptation of meddling by going to London. About the twenty-first day of incubation--I think the full period j :wenty-four days--we began an extra feed of banana and bread l milk. On my return home I was horrified to find both birds flying )ut and my bird girl almost in tears. Fragments of egg, evidently a ir one, had been found beneath the nest on the very day they *uld have hatched. For the second year, therefore, we are cheated of success and robbed the great joy of rearing so beautiful and delightful a bird, so rare too L English aviaries. No praise is too high for the Senegal TouracoU. It is steady and i isible and most beautiful in its dress of green and purple, with carmine 11 in the wing. The sexes are by no means easy to distinguish apart, t the cock is slimmer and longer than the hen, his green crest tipped j :h purple, and a broader streak of white below the eye than she ssesses. These birds lay very large and almost round eggs, and on more than

Avicultural Notes one occasion the hen was so ill with the effort that she could scare reach the nest to lay. However, she allowed herself to be placed on and would feed from the hand on banana rolled in olive oil. She woi also let my bird girl take the egg from beneath her to examine it. 1 have now stopped breeding operations for this year as the nights ; getting cold. Next year if both birds are still with us we shall consi< removing the cock directly the eggs are laid, but I am by no met certain how this will answer in the case of birds of which both se> share the task of incubation. Mr. Delacour was successful in breeding the species in Frai before his aviaries were destroyed in the war, but it has not been bi in England, no doubt owing to the great difficulty of obtaining pairs.

By the Editor Mr. Webb returned home from Costa Rica on 21st August, witl number of Humming Birds, which he had collected for Mr. Sped Lewis. Mr. Lewis most generously presented seventeen of these to t Zoological Society, and as they required special lighting and heati arrangements, special cages were arranged for them in the Insect Hou There are at least five different species, namely Phaethornis longirostr Cam'ptjlo'pterus hemileucurus, Thalurania colombica, Amazilia dubasi, a Elvira chionura. Humming Birds will live for a time upon syrup only, but a certa quantity of insect food would seem to be necessary for most spec at any rate. There is a very small white fly which is extremely numero on the underside of the leaves of some marrow plants in my garde It is a regular blight, and appears to be responsible for a very po crop of vegetable marrows. But the Humming Birds love these tii insects which they capture on the wing in a very dexterous manner. A pair of very beautiful Conures arrived in a recent collection ma" by Mr. Chapman's representative in Central Brazil, and were purchas* by the Zoological Society. They belong to the species known s Pyrrhura rhodogaster of Sclater--the Crimson-breasted Conure, whi(
algorithms.title: Avicultural Notes
algorithms.bodyText: represented in the Natural History Museum by Mr. Sclater's type- 'cimen only. It is slightly larger than the White-eared Conure, and many respects resembles that species, but its chief distinguishing ture is its bright crimson lower breast and abdomen. Mr. Frost has returned to England after an absence of three years, i has brought with him a very fine collection, including several birds v to aviculture. The Raja Lory (Chalcopsittacus insignis) somewhat embles the Black Lory, but is clothed in delicate shades of purple, mze, and red. Rosenberg's Lorikeet ( Trichoglossus rosenbergi) is 3 of the most beautiful of its genus. The Javan Kingfisher ( Halcyon miventris), the New Guinea Kingfisher ( Sauromarptis gaudichaudi), d the very interesting Malayan Falconet ( Microhierax fringillarius ) appear to be the first of their kinds to be imported. The collection includes thirty-three Birds of Paradise, belonging six species, no less than nine Great Black Cockatoos ( Microglossus ), I r enty Lories of various species, twenty-four Fairy Blue Birds, seven le-tailed Pittas, forty Crowned Pigeons of three species, two Casso- ries, twelve Egrets, and so on ; a really remarkable collection, ese are temporarily housed at the Zoological Gardens, and those o wish for rarities should communicate with Mr. Frost, c/o the

The question is often asked as to what is the best method of catching 'ds from an aviary. For my own part I dislike nets in any shape or m, though they are necessary in certain cases. A catching cage of ne form is much to be preferred. The birds are fed into this, and a or is operated with a string. A combined feeding tray and cage can i devised so that it is always available for catching any bird when it > dts the food-tray. This would be a rather large cage with a large or at either end, which would be left open normally, but when a bird ! s wanted, one door would be shut and the other worked with a string.
algorithms.footnote: 1 ts must be used for some kinds of large birds, and these should be of 1 ge size, the shape of a butterfly net with a strong cane or wooden op and a light deep string net of half inch or one inch mesh netting.
algorithms.bodyText: Those who are interested in the breeding of Canary mules a hybrids between the various species of British Finches, will be glad possess the new edition of Mr. Houlton's book edited by Mr. C. A. Hon both author and editor being experts in hybrid breeding. While the breeding of Canary mules does not quite come within 1 scope of our journal, we may well consider the production of hybr between two British species, such as the author deals with. Some these are extremely beautiful, as well as interesting, and the list those that have been produced is quite a formidable one, the mi remarkable being perhaps that between the Chaffinch and Brand) finch. Many have claimed to have crossed the Canary with the Chaffin or with the Yellow-hammer, but no bona fide specimen of either these has been produced.
algorithms.sectionHeader: CORRESPONDENCE THE NESTING OF THE ORANGE WEAVER
algorithms.bodyText: Sir, --About the middle of July my Orange Weaver had complet a nest suspended to the outside twigs of a holly bush. I thought worth photographing. As the entrance faced the interior I was goi to remove a bundle of hay, of which the nest was entirely made, fr( the middle of the bush, when the hen flew out. On 18th August I & the hen hunting round for insects, so I wrote for some mealworn In the meantime I beat the garden bushes for insects which were ve few and mostly plant bugs. One young bird left the nest on 23rd Augu It was well feathered, but had no tail, and seemed quite bare under t throat, otherwise it was a paler edition of the hen and showed a slig yellowish streak above the eye. Now, 1st September, it is darker than it was and has a tail; it still being fed by the hen. What the hen found to feed the nestli on in the earlier stages among a host of other birds puzzles me. Nc the cock has entirely picked the nest to pieces, which felt quite cle; inside when the bird had flown. H. L. Sich.

Sir,-- Observations on the food of a species when wild are sometimes ; value to aviculturists because, as remarked by E. Gr. B. Meade- /aldo, F.Z.S., of Kent, " The sciences of ornithology and aviculture 'e intimately connected. Each has much to learn from the other tvic. Mag. Yol. 1921, p. 34, beginning of article). Therefore may be of use to some member to state that on 5th August a bird was roughtto me (which had been accidentally shot in mistake for a common lecies) and which I recognized as a Crossbill, evidently a this year s ird, breast with dark streaks ; and on going round to the land where le bird was seen I found four Crossbills feeding on the leading-shoots f fruit-trees, plum and apple (while the peculiar voices of two others, resumably parents, were heard quite close). Up to that morning I thought the food of Crossbills consisted only f vegetarian matter such as seeds of various fir-trees, mountain ash, lder, hawthorn, etc., but these four birds were obviously clearing off i nd eating greenfly from the leaves of the fruit-trees, and during the ime the owner of the land, Mr. Percy Dennis, and myself watched them, |Dr about half an hour they systematically " worked over " the top 1 hoots of young trees, holding the head sideways, almost flat, against he leaf in doing so, and using beaks to pull themselves Up the boughs. Vith mandibles not meeting at the tips I should have thought that ating aphides would have been very difficult for Crossbills, but these

Correspondence four evidently accomplished the feat quite easily judging from the w they climbed Parrot-like all up one twig after another ! There \ no sign of them interfering with the fruit, plums or apples. All w very tame, one reddish on breast apparently a young male* a presumably hatched in North Kent; and Mr. Dennis informed on 15th August that the birds were still feeding chiefly along 1 tops of trees as stated above. Aviculturalists may find such food useful for any young bii hatched out in future years. Frederick D. Welch [There has been a large immigration of Crossbills to these islar during the past summer, and they have been recorded from ma parts. We noted a number feeding upon thistle seed in South Devc shire, but their usual food is the seeds of various firs-- Ed.]

I note with interest in the August number of our Magazi the article on the Rosy-faced or Peach-faced Lovebird, and as l experience at present with this species is almost wholly at variar with what is there recorded, I appear to be in possession of exceptional pair. They are housed in a cage of which the insi measurements are 22 in. high, 18 in. wide, and 10 in. deep. I had idea of them going to nest in a space so limited. They were provid with a husk in which to sleep, and after a time I noticed the hen got little rough in plumage. I blamed the husk and had it remove One morning, on attending to their wants, I noticed the cock won not move from the bottom of the cage. His gaze was transfixed < something in which he appeared to take great interest. On clos examination I discovered that the object of his infatuation was an e# I took the hint, returned the husk, and with the aid of a teaspo< deposited the egg therein. Along with that egg disappeared the co bird. For weeks he was rarely seen. I got anxious as to whether was being fed, and thought also that perhaps he was v T asting tir and strength on one egg. Suspense prompted action. After soe difficulty he was induced to leave the husk, which was found to conta
algorithms.figure: I n eggs and a chick which appeared to be newly hatched crawling Correspondence
algorithms.bodyText: them. Of this clutch six hatched ; one did not, and the other disappeared. Of the six that hatched three appeared not to have i fed at all ; the other three are now in perfect health and plumage, i jr than their parents, and fortunately able to do for themselves, parents have again gone to nest, and would not tolerate the presence leir offsprings. First the cock showed his resentment, and a few 3 later the hen stopped feeding them and also became aggressive, ley were separated. Che colour of the foreheads of the young reminds one of the head hen Blossom-head, or a sort of dove grey : the throat and breast paler shades of those of the adult, but the beautiful blue of the p is quite as deep, and the tail when spread shows all the beautiful kings of the mature specimen. The striking difference is the ur of the upper mandible : the upper two-thirds appearing to the to be black, but closely examined would, I think, be found to be ery dark brown. This is gradually disappearing from the point ! ards the cere. The eggs are white, large for the size of the bird, and round rather i pointed. One of the drawbacks mentioned in the article to A. roseicollis \ 3 not apply to my parent birds. They never screech, or give vent ;ar-piercing sounds, but their progeny take turns at drowning each |'sr down. I thought this contrast to their parents would prove a j 3ing phase, and due to the exuberance of youth. As they have not w T ith me had an opportunity of displaying temper ards their own or other species, I cannot express an opinion as to ir disposition in this respect. But to each other as a pair they are
algorithms.footnote: 1 'ebirds indeed. i The necessity of removing the young at the succeeding periods of 1 ification of parent birds apply to so many different species as to : nerate A. roseicollis from being on that account considered spiteful.

Incubation, unfortunately, commences when the first egg deposited, consequently " hatching out " may extend over a w and prove calamitous to the younger members of the brood. The cock, and the cock bird alone, incubates, and will not al the hen to enter the nest when he comes off to drink. Time ; again, under this circumstance, I have seen the hen move up towa the nest. He w r ould emit a short, sharp command, which judging fi her action in response clearly meant " stop " and stop she always ( During incubation the hen carries the food to her mate in the n After the young are hatched she feeds him on the perch, and when young leave the nest both parents feed the young. Their food consisted of canary, w T hite and Indian millet, and a li sunflower. Nuts and all fruits they ignore. Hay tops I have alres mentioned. When the weather is propitious their cage is taken into the gard This procedure appears not to disturb in the least the serenity of cock bird, who sits tight through it all, while the hen is making most of the fresh air. Beyond the size of the cage, I presume there is nothing remarka in this case, but it proves that however limited the accommodat: offered, A. roseicollis will increase and multiply. The cock is now, 29th August, sitting on four eggs. Alf. S. Nicholson, [We should be glad of the opinion of others who have bred Agapor , roseicollis as to the alleged incubation by the cock bird, and woi suggest to Mr. Nicholson that he may possibly be mistaken in supposi the sitting bird to be the cock. If he is correct then he has madf very interesting discovery. --Ed.]

algorithms.bodyText: Sir,-- If a cross between a cock African Grey Singing Finch and hen Canary is unique, or even sufficiently unusual to be of interest record in the Avicultural Magazine, I may state that I found B

algorithms.bodyText: art little birds of that parentage in my aviary lately. Larger than ; father, smaller than the mother, and markings something like len sparrow. Unfortunately one was killed by a stoat the next y, the other lives and thrives. E. A. H. Hartley.
algorithms.sectionHeader: CBRID BLACK-HEADED (BRAZILIAN) SISKIN <$ AND CANARY p.
algorithms.bodyText: Sir, --In the autumn of 1925 I obtained from a local dealer, who s unaware of their identity, two cock Black-headed Siskins hrysomitris icterica). They were not in the best of condition, but soon improved in health d appearance after being turned into a large flight cage and given
algorithms.listItem: ly plain canary and teasel seed, which latter had been previously iked for ten minutes in boiling water. This was given to the birds a damp state, not hot of course. It was amazing to note the improve- 3 nt it effected, and they soon began to sing. As a matter of fact, ! is species is quite a fine songster, and in my opinion is superior |:her to the Goldfinch or Brown Linnet, or as far as I know any other
algorithms.bodyText: tall Finch. In the following spring they became more vocal and used sing incessantly, one against the other, with lowered wings, showing f the beautiful golden yellow of the wing feathers. I tried in vain to secure hens of their own race for that season (1926), id both ultimately spent a bachelor existence in an aviary with other nches. It seems there are very few hens imported. Those avicul- i rists who have this species have only cocks. I saw two fine birds Mr. Ezra's in May. This year I introduced a hen yellow Canary to one of the cocks, i June she went to nest and laid one egg, which was clear. Then e laid three more and two young were hatched on 17th July. Fourteen ! tys later the elder left the nest. The general colouring was yellowish own with darker markings on the back, and lighter under parts-- pical young bird colouring--resembling a young Brown Linnet but rather a yellower tint. The second was similarly coloured but had : ore yellow in the wings and tail, '' variegated I believe is the Canary 'eeders term.

Correspondence I should be interested to hear if this hybrid has been bred befo 1 know the Hooded Siskin has been crossed with the Canary anc believe the Sikkim Siskin too. The hen Canary is sitting on four me eggs and the young are now independent of their parents. B. Hamilton Scott.

Sir, I think perhaps the following incident might possibly interesting to aviculturists with regard to the hardiness of the beautif Masked Lovebird (A. per sonata ). I recently bought a pair of the fascinating Lovebirds from Miss Chapman, of Birmingham. I did n think they were sufficiently acclimatized to put outside altogethf as the weather just then was anything but good ! However, I wante to put them in an outdoor aviary as soon as possible for breedii purposes, hoping to get them to go to nest before too late this yea I decided, therefore, in order to accustom them to our changeab climate to put them out in the garden for a little each day, just as th( were, in the wire cage in which I bought them. After a few days, as tl weather seemed suitable, I decided to harden them off a little mo: by leaving them out until after dinner. This particular evening aboi 8.30 p.m. I went out to fetch my birds in, when to my horror an ope door and an empty cage greeted me ! They had somehow manage to open the door with their beaks ! A pair of Black-cheeked Lovebirc of mine did this in the early spring but fortunately in that case escape into a room. This door, however, seemed too secure for it to be possibl heeling utterly helpless and scarcely daring to breathe even, I calle to them. As they already seemed to know me a little, I hoped by thi means to keep them in the garden for the moment! The smaller on answered at once from a tree just over the cage. He was perching o a coconut husk, which I had hung up for wild birds to nest in, and wa apparently studying the accommodation therein ! However, th next minute the larger one called from the very top of a fir-tree clos by, and the smaller one flew to it immediately, while I stood wit! bated breath waiting for their next move. Needless to say they had . perfectly glorious time flying from tree to tree, and to my joy alway within sight! One bird flew once to the very tip of a poplar-tree quit

; lUndred yards away from the cage, and I never thought to see it ck again. However, he returned, and so on, until too dark to watch y more. Eventually they both went to roost in the fir-tree close to eir cage--which I had not moved, of course--and there I had to leave em for the night. I think, of the three, I spent the most miserable e ! We have a great many owls here, and I felt sure they would ver survive for this reason, even if they managed to stand the cold d dampness of the night air. The next morning I was awake at 30 a.m. ! From then onwards I watched from a window overlooking e garden for any sign of my Lovebirds. I did not see or hear either them until about 7.30, although the wild birds had been awake for long time. My birds did not believe in rising too early apparently ! iddenly the smaller one flew down from the fir-tree on to the top their cage, and struggled unsuccessfully for several minutes to pull millet spray through the bars. At last giving up the struggle he tually went inside the cage, and so was soon captured. The other le followed suit soon afterwards, much to my joy. Neither of them 1 ire any the worse for their adventure in spite of a very thick mist the early morning and a very cold night. This, I think, proves at the Masked Lovebird is not at any rate delicate, also that they ow a certain amount of intelligence, and would, I believe, become very me. They fly very swiftly, and are a truly beautiful sight to watch, it, even so, I hope never to see mine at large again ! All the same, does make one feel rather sad, of course, to see them shut up, after
algorithms.footnote: : ie has seen them at liberty ! This incident happened about a fortnight j so ago, when the evenings were lighter. I venture to send it to you case you might consider it to be of any interest. Irene M. Marriott.
algorithms.bodyText: Sir,-- Your suggestion that Budgerigar breeders, particularly those Cobalts and Mauves, should give some of their experiences, prompts e to send a few notes. To the experimental breeder it is not always the striking varieties aich prove to be the most valuable in colour breeding. The Olive, for :ample, is not to some a very attractive colour, yet there is no doubt

Correspondence that it has so far proved to be the most useful. In the same w the Mauve, which is probably, as yoil say in your article, " less striking than the Cobalt (although many prefer it to all others), may prove a] to be of immense value. As yet this colour is hardly a true " mauve It should contain more pink in its composition. Improvement, howev* is being made all the time, and already birds bred this season frc crosses with the Mauves which Mr. Roland Green painted for o coloured plate are better in this respect. It is the ambition of mai breeders to go still further in this direction and produce a pure Pic This I believe to be quite possible, but it will be some time before it attained, although many secretive and admittedly speculative cross are being tried ! One variety that I hope soon to establish is the Silver-Grey. Sor crosses produce a beautiful French grey colour, but only those wi grey face-spots are likely to moult out true Greys, those having dark spots moulting into light Mauves. Apart from their attractiveness, two most valuable varieties won be the Cinnamon and the Brown or Bronze. From experiments alreac being made these are apparently well on the way. Their value I colour crossing would, of course, be inestimable. H. Tod-Boyd.

Sir,-- I should like to supplement my article on Parrakeet nestir sites by a further short note. I find that moisture is apt to be anoth factor essential to the healthy development of the young. If the ne gets too dry, even though it consists of a natural tree trunk filled wil mould and set up in the open flight, rickets are still liable to appea It is therefore desirable to place the tree trunk under the open si where the rain will fall on it and not to attempt to give it the protectic of any kind of overhead shelter. Tavistock.

algorithms.bodyText: Sir, --Few members of the Parrot family are of much accoUi as nest builders ; least of all the Cockatoos. I was under the impressio that all Cockatoos laid their eggs on the bare wood or mould at t!
algorithms.figure: Correspondence
algorithms.bodyText: ;om of their tree hollow, with at most an accidental bed of chips led by their biting off the entrance and sides of the cavity. I was *efore surprised when this year my breeding pair of Roseates cut ers of wood from the perches, carried them into their barrel, and by iting them round the bottom made quite a presentable attempt at 3St. Tavistock.
algorithms.sectionHeader: UNG PARRAKEETS RE-ENTERING THE NEST TO SLEEP
algorithms.bodyText: Sir, --It is unusual for young Parrakeets, as distinct from Lorikeets, iUres, etc., to re-enter the nest once they have flown. It is somewhat ious therefore that this year a young Barraband and also a young labar Parrakeet did so for some days. The Barraband was a single 1 , but the Malabar is one of three. None of the Barraband's brothers l sisters of former years have ever gone back to their nest after leaving nor have the other two members of the Malabar brood attempted follow the example of the third. It appears to be only another Gance of the remarkable amount of variation in individual conduct iervable among the more intelligent birds. Tavistock. HONEY-GUIDES Sir, --In regard to Mrs. Prestwich's letter respecting the nesting jits of the Honey-guides, I must confess that from personal experience j :now nothing whatever. The nesting habits of all parasitical birds ; very difficult indeed to study, the Honey-guides especially, because ise birds inhabit the " bush " district of Africa and roam about in 'as comprising hundreds of square miles of thick bushland, they ^ also very hard to find, being shy and retiring birds unless engaged the pursuit of bees' nests, when they elicit the aid of human beings, id again they only lay their eggs in the nest of birds which breed deep cavities in trees such as Wood Hoopoes, Glossy Starlings, etc. I could never glean any facts from the Europeans out there, for their athy towards bird-life is appalling. Very few people in Africa know 1 e correct name of any single bird ; true they know the difference tween a Parrot and an Eagle, or between those useful for the pot

and the remainder which prove Useful as living targets for shoot practice. I might mention in passing that the skin of the Honey-guide: 'extremely thick and tough and resembles leather, which is no doi a protection against the stings of bees and wasps. These birds a co-operate with the Ratel, a honey-eating Badger which lives in Afri The Honey-guides have an extremely gentle expression which no doubt caused by the beautifully coloured brown eyes and the p fectly shaped head. In weight they are heavier than any other b I know in proportion to their size. There is a very fine plate of two species of Honey-guides

algorithms.bodyText: Sir, Reading through the back volumes of the Avicultur Magazine I noticed the following :*-- " On going to press we have received from Mr. George Carrick cutting from the Glasgow Evening News of 27th April relating to t sale of Bostock's Menagerie. The most extraordinary bidding took pla when The Australian Gin-Gin bird, a small bird of the Parrot kin* was put up. The bidding commenced at 10 guineas, and the bird w knocked down for 260 guineas. This bird was said to whistle ma] tunes. Can any member enlighten us as to the proper name of ti k Gin-Gin ' bird ? " (Avicultural Magazine, 1909, p. 214). Apparently no member could, as the query remained unanswere Can any reader solve the problem now ? The only name I can trace with any semblance to " Gin-Gin " an obsolete name used by Latham for the Cingalese Alexandrii Parrakeet ( Palceornis eupatria), namely, Gingi Parrot. Whatever the bird, it fetched an exorbitant price.

algorithms.bodyText: rth Series. --Vol. V.--No. 11 .--All rights reserved. NOVEMBER, 1927 SOME BIRD NOTES FROM TENERIFE By G. H. Gurney, F.Z.S. (Concluded from p. 269) lavens, Corvus corax canariensis, nearly always in pairs, were much vidence ; for a few days two haunted a large Ficus-tree in the hotel len, occasionally I saw them on the beach, searching amongst the |ris thrown up by the tide ; and not at all disturbing the Kentish 1 ^ers, another very common bird, which were engaged in the same suit. In the gardens and thickly grown barrancos, many interesting - is occurred, nearly all species or sub-species peculiar to the islands. instance, Cabrera's Blackbird (Turdus merula cabrerce), which rmed, cocks seeming to be a great deal more plentiful than the very j i-coloured hens ; Canaries ( Serinus canarius ) singing everywhere and I iding by 1st March, Chiffchaffs in swarms, Dusky Blackcaps ( Sylvia oapilla obscura) and the Tenerife Blue Titmouse. With regard to the I, |er species, there are no less than four perfectly distinct races of |e Titmouse living in the Archipelago. On Gran Canaria and Tenerife us cceruleus teneriffce is the form : the islands of Hierro and Palm

286 G . H. Gurney--Some Bird Notes from Tenerife each have their own sub-species, P. c. ombriosa and P. c. palmem while on the two large islands of the Eastern Group P. c. degene found, and it is extraordinarily interesting to note that these ra show special colouring in their plumage according to the conditi in which they live. For instance, P. c. palmensis, which lives i; verdant mountainous island, is much more richly coloured than pale forms, P. c. degener inhabiting the dry arid islands of Lanzar and Fuerteventura. All these forms are races of the European B Titmouse (P. e. cceruleus). Another common bird, though a v interesting one, which was generally to be seen in the' barrancos ^ the Spectacled Warbler ( Sylvia conspicillata bella). The cocks are beai ful in their breeding plumage, but they were very shy, and would quic dive into the thick foliage if they thought they were being observ On 19th March a pair were watched carrying food in their bea but owing to the extremely precipitous nature of the ground it t impossible to search for any nest; when frightened this bird Utter very peculiar chattering cry. On more open ground Berthelot's Pip occurred frequently all round Orotava ; they were also breeding a were very confiding and tame. Here, too, the Rufescent Short-tc Lark was found, often in company with the Pipits. One of 1 commonest birds at Orotava was the Hoopoe : they were to be s( everywhere, and two pairs were feeding young in the Martial Barranco just outside the hotel. In the Laurel Forest Zone at ab( 2,000 feet, one finds quite a different lot of birds, amongst the m< interesting the Superb Redbreast ( Erithacus rubecula superbus) v common, splendid large dark brown birds, with brilliant ruby-coloui breasts; while flocks of Brehm's Pale Swift ( Micropus murir brehmorum) flew screaming up the barrancos. Another species, viz. t small Black Swift ( Micropus u. unicolor), was also seen, but as a ruletl seemed to be commoner nearer the coast. A long expedition was made on 19th March to a reputed locali for the Teydean Blue Chaffinch in the Pine Forest Zone above a villa called La Sorriba. After an hour's drive in a motor, which was enliven by the great quantities of Neophrons, Kites, and Buzzards which wt continually in view, we found mules waiting for us at La Sorril Leaving the road, we began to climb upwards on a very steep mounta

m G. H. Gurney--Some Bird Notes from Tenerife 287 ack, with splendid scenery all round. After an hour's arduous climb ie became aware that the character of the country was changing, id single pine-trees began to appear, and very soon we had reached e forest itself. After the very gloomy accounts we had heard of the sstruction of the pines by local woodcutters, we were agreeably rprised to find that here, at any rate, were many miles of quite ispoilt forest, indeed the " Pinar " stretched as far as the eye could e in all directions. We were not lucky enough to see the " Azule ", e local name for the Blue Chaffinch, which has probably of recent >ars become very much rarer in Tenerife than it was in 1893 when r. Meade-Waldo wrote " it appears to hold its own in all the pine rests of Tenerife " ; indeed, he was able to bring a pair home, which ed in his aviaries, and Mr. Ezra had a specimen, I believe, a few years ter. All the natives know of the existence of the " Azule ", and have 1 entirely inflated idea of its value, and although I offered a good *ice if a pair of live ones were obtained for me, I never received any. ae natives are rather fond of keeping birds alive in cages, and one ten sees the fine local form of Koenig's Partridge looking remarkably ell in a tiny cage in which it can hardly turn round ! In some of the itios in the Spanish houses were small aviaries containing Canaries hey prefer the domestic breed to the much more interesting local ild Canary), Goldfinches and, in several instances Blackcaps, the tter in each case looking the picture of health and in the finest ndition. In the Botanical Gardens at Orotava was a large outdoor |'iary containing, amongst a number of common foreign Finches, m good Black-breasted Sandgrouse (Bier odes orientalis), two or three 'ecimens of the Least Goldfinch (Carduelis c. parva), some Madeiran ock Sparrows, a single Thanner's Bunting (Emberiza calandra inneri ), and a remarkably tame Red-billed Chough, which followed the rdener about everywhere. On 25th March an expedition was made the Charco of Maspalomas in the extreme south of Gran Canaria, id a most interesting day was spent in this very remarkable locality, saving Las Palmas in the early morning by motor-car, the road for e first 10 miles or so was fairly good, but after passing a place called dde, it very soon degenerated into the merest track, and at times 1 ased to exist altogether. Large birds of prey were almost continually

288 G. H. Gurney--Some Bird Notes from Tenerife in sight, and flocks of Berthelot's Pipits and many Short-toed Lai would fly up from the side of the road as we passed ; soon after passi Telde one gets into practically desert country, arid stony plains, a miles of bare sandy ground, which have a certain fascination of th own, added to by the wonderful desert flora one passes. The groi of huge Candelabra Euphorbia ( Euphorbia canariensis) which i peculiar to the islands, followed by another most striking speci E. balsamifera, which here grows over 6 ft. high, the miniature Dragc tree ( Kleinia neriifolia ) growing out of the sand, and as a contn the bright green pendulous foliage of Plocama pendula, all make a fascinating picture, which was accentuated by the interest of the bii we saw, species peculiar to this district; the fine Koenig's Shri (Lanius excubitor koenigii) becoming quite common, and looking ve conspicuous as they sat on the topmost shoot of an Opunta, watch us intently as we passed. I have no doubt they were breeding, b we had not time to stop and look for their nests, as I was anxio to get to the Charco itself, another 30 miles further on. This reas also prevented me searching for the Eastern Canarian Thick-kn (CEdicnemus o. insularum), which is found not uncommonly on th( plains, and the Trumpeter Bullfinch had to be missed too, though expected to find the species at the Charco. A collision between o motor and a bullock-cart also caused a long delay, the terrific argumei between the drivers of each vehicle as to who was in the wrong neai came to knives being drawn in true Canarian fashion, and so it w almost one o'clock before we eventually got to our destination and we able to start searching for the Coursers which we had come so far to s< The Cream-coloured Courser is found here on little shing beaches between the sandhills which stretch along the shore. T sun pouring down from a torrid sky made the ground extremely h( shade there was none, and vegetation seemed to have entirely d appeared: in fact almost the only life of any sort to be seen w represented by four large Vultures sitting motionless on the shoj who allowed us to approach very close before flapping slowly o We soon saw a pair of Coursers running on the shingle in front of i They were not particularly shy, and would often stop and turn the heads right round to have a look at us. When running they a

Maurice Amslei--Breeding of the Grey Francolin 289 tremely inconspicuous, but as soon as they fly the black on the under le of the wings shows them up plainly. N In the foregoing notes I have only mentioned a very few of the 3 re interesting species we saw at Orotava ; a little later in the year )lden Orioles arrive, also Bee-eaters and Rollers, and many rare igrants turn up. A sub-species of the Houbara Bustard (Chlamydotis idulata fuertaventura) is resident on the island of Fuerteventura, it found nowhere else. The extremely rare Black Oyster-catcher fcematopus meadewaldoi) is also found there ; the Black-breasted ndgrouse (Pterocles orientalis) is another species peculiar to Fuerte-
algorithms.listItem: ntura. Many rare species of Petrel and Shearwater breed on the cky coasts of some of the islands ; while a very local Chat (Saxicola cotice muriclce) has so far only been found in the islets of Montana ara and Allegranza. Indeed, so attractive is the bird life on these .narian Islands that I can imagine no pleasanter spot for an ornitho- gist to pass a winter in exists.
algorithms.sectionHeader: BREEDING OF THE GREY FRANCOLIN (FRANCO LINUS PONDICHERIANUS )
algorithms.bodyText: By Maurice Amsler, M.B., B.S., F.Z.S. It was in May of this year that a pair of these birds came into y possession, through the kindness of one of oUr new members, r. Geoffrey Davies, I.C.S., who had just returned on leave from dia. These birds had reared four young before they left their native untry, and had started laying again towards the end of their journey England. Both birds were most delightful pets, far tamer than any Barndoor )wl--they had, I believe, been captured when quite young, and ire therefore thoroughly domesticated and much attached to their |lall home, which was one of the familiar double-domed Indian bamboo |ges with a compartment for each bird--it was in these restricted larters that the first brood was reared in India--but the birds being i tame, it was possible to open the doors and let them out to forage r food, have their dust-bath, etc., and it was only necessary to *proach them with the cage, when they would step inside with '.emplary obedience.

Maurice Amsler--Breeding of the Greg Francolin When the Partridges came to me on 19th May, the hen had laid fou eggs of a creamy white colour, milch the size of that of our ow Partridge. On arrival I placed their cage with the doors opened in a sma covered run about 4 feet square. This enclosure was in the shelte of one of my aviaries, and it was possible to let the birds out int the aviary or confine them to the run, at pleasure. I constructed a nest of turf and hay in one corner and placed th four eggs therein. By 26th May nine eggs had been laid, and the hen began to sit in earnest on the 27th. I reckoned that they should hatclj about 20th June, but on several occasions I found one or more ego thrown out of the nest. Sometimes they seemed almost cold to th" touch, but I always replaced them as soon as discovered. On 19th June to my dismay I found that the hen had given uj sitting. The eggs which looked fertile were stone cold. It was the worl of a few moments to take the eggs indoors and place them in hot water After a very few minutes of this treatment some of them began tcj "wabble " and show signs of life, and not long after several of thi chicks could be heard " cheeping " inside the eggs. Having no broody hen at the moment and no incubator, the eggf were placed in a box on the top of my hot water cistern for the night-- the temperature here was only 100*--and I had grave fears that al the chicks would be dead by the next day when I was able to place; them in an incubator belonging to a man of my acquaintance. Within a few hours six of the nine eggs hatched, and the chicks at first looked quite normal, though perhaps a little less active than do most Game- birds wh^n they first leave the egg. I gave them ants' eggs, green fly, and Armitage's No. 1 chick food, but on the evening of the third day three had died, and although the remaining three were put in a brooder and carefully fed I lost the last one on 1st July at the age of ten days. On the same date the old hen began to lay again. She chose a corner of the run immediately behind her bamboo cage, laying the eggs on the hard concrete. In this place I again made a nest for her, and she repeated her previous clutch of nine eggs. Incubation began on 10th July, and the eggs hatched on the 31st. All the eggs were fertile, but one chick died in the shell.

Maurice Amsler--Breeding of the Grey Francolin 291 During the last three days of the incubation I noticed that both 'ds sat side by side and brooded the eggs, this certainly did not ppen on the first occasion. The cock continued his care and attention the chicks after they had hatched ; in fact I think he was, if ything, the better parent. This second hatch proved to be much more vigorous than the st, no doubt because the chicks got the correct amount of warmth d protection from their parents, and also because they were shown iat to eat and what to leave. Their diet consisted at first almost tirely of live ants' eggs. No water was given for thirty-six hours, after lich I gave them a few weeds pulled up in the garden, which were vered with rain drops. It was most interesting to note how quickly ey realized that this was meant for a drink. First the drops of water ;re swallowed, and next the tips of the small blades of grass were lied off and swallowed. On 3rd August I removed the whole family a small movable run which I had prepared. This was placed on the vn and moved a yard or so each day. At night parents and chicks ;re driven into a closed box attached to the run, where they were fe from cold, rain, and rats. Within a very few days I had to move e run on to a piece of rough grass at the bottom of my garden as e parents dug large holes 6 inches or more deep in their search for >rms and insects. When it was raining, or on those rare occasions when the sun shone tly, each parent would take charge of four chicks and protect them )m the weather. The cock, hitherto very friendly and docile, made no nes in trying to spur anyone who dared put his hand into the run. As the young grew the diet was increased and varied a good deal, its' eggs were always welcome and cleaned up at once, but as they ;re also required for other birds, I found that gentles were equally ceptable. A small amount of insectile mixture was eaten dry, also imbled sponge cake and Indian millet. At ten days the chicks would vour any amount of earth worms--even quite large ones, if broken '\0x25A0:o pieces an inch long, were eagerly fought for and gulped down, eel quite certain that fresh grass must form a very large part of the J 3 t of these birds, both young and old ; for each day when the run was
algorithms.footnote: 3ved the previous day's site looked as if it had been recently mown.
algorithms.subsectionHeader: 292 Maurice Amsler--Breeding of the Grey Francolin
algorithms.bodyText: All seemed to be going well, for the youngsters grew apace, and \ their feathers well developed at two weeks, when I had to cut wing in case of their escaping. I then noticed that one of the chi whom I had suspected of some slight deformity, had four legs inst of two, the two supernumerary legs were ligatured and snipped and the young bird at once began to eat and seemed none the wo! At three weeks the young birds were the size of Chinese Pain Quail; they had lost the longitudinal striations, which I believ; common to Game chicks, and could fly strongly notwithstanding i trimming of one wing. About this time I began to think they did not look quite so ti in feather as they should, and a few days later one died, and sev"!i others looked ill. I came to the conclusion that they were suffei from absence of sunshine and the effects of the constant rain. Soli 30th August I replaced the seven chicks and their parents in tlj. original aviary, but did not confine them to the little run when chicks were hatched. The result of this was that the birds spent n of their time in the soaking grass of the outer flight, and I lost twoin^ young Partridges. Having learned my lesson, and being left with only five chicks, family were once more placed in the closed run, and all has gone P since then. To-day, 21st September, at about eight weeks, the young Partriai are about half-grown. They are much like the hen in colouration, ;j I should say are perfectly independent, but the moment the partj hear me or my man walking in the aviary they begin to peck lou ; at the walls of their run, which means that they want some gen or worms, and when these are forthcoming not one do they ton all are left for the young and growing family. I think there are three males and two females among the yon birds; of this it will be easy to make certain in a month or two, as 1 males have well-developed spurs when adult. This species, like the more familiar " Black Partridge ", is m i prized in India for fighting purposes, and I believe that good fight! males realize quite high prices.
