algorithms.sectionHeader: GEESE By The Marquess of Tavistock and F. E. Blaauw
algorithms.bodyText: The term " Goose " is applied to several orders of web-footed birds, , speaking generally, large birds with varying characteristics recalling pse of certain Ducks, and as a matter of fact there are many birds own as Geese or Ducks which by rights belong to the same sub- nilies, and in many cases these so-called " Geese " and " Ducks " :erbreed freely (e.g. Egyptian Geese and Sheldrakes). As a rule Geese ve thicker feet and not such flat bills as have Swans and Ducks, and ey are not so aquatic. Some indeed do not like to go into water. Their ,^d mostly consists of grass, which, with the addition of grain, is their ual diet in confinement. Most kinds of Geese are hardy and long-lived, number of pairs of different kinds can be kept together in a park or her enclosure where there is water, and as a rule they will agree well gether. The Cereopsis, the Chloephaga , the Sandwich Island Geese, e Spurwings and Egyptian Geese are, however, very quarrelsome spring and must be isolated in pairs in large enclosures well furn- hed with grass and water. Geese are monogamous, and pair for life ; .ey make admirable parents and usually find no difficulty in rearing ieir young. They do not breed until they are three years old at the uliest, and if they are older than this it is all to the good. The true Geese, genus Anser, are migratory birds which nest in the retie or temperate zones and go South for the winter. They are hardy it not prolific in confinement, and must be pinioned to make them ay. The males are rather quarrelsome in spring, but are not seriously
algorithms.listItem: * id tempered and do not harry weaker birds. As soon as the young are
algorithms.bodyText: itched disputes cease and the families often unite in a flock. The ;xes are alike, except that the female is the smaller. The Grey-lag Goose ( Anser anser) is the ancestor of the domestic oose, the grey variety being like it, grey plumaged with pink feet and ill. It is more inclined to breed and is less migratory than the other r ild species. The Bean Goose (A. fabalis) is much smaller and darker, with n orange bill, black at the base and on the nail; its feet are orange.

Marquess of Tavistock and F. E. Blaauiv--Geese The Short-billed Goose {A. brachyrhynchus) resembles the li named, but is smaller, has a shorter bill and rosy feet. The White-Fronted Goose (A. albifrons ) is smaller and mr elegant in shape. It may be recognized by its white forehead a the very dark deep brown spots on its breast. The Dwarf Goose (A. erythropus) is the preceding in miniatu with slightly darker plumage ; it is the prettiest bird of the whe genus. The Bar-headed Goose (A. indicus ) nests in Thibet and winte in India ; it may be known from all its relatives by its pretty pea grey plumage picked out with darker grey and white, and by the tv black stripes across the nape of the neck and the yellow bill and fee It is often imported but is usually susceptible to cold and not vei prolific ; it has, however, bred freely at Kew Gardens. If it is n< pinioned it is apt to wander away, but it has not been found to do J at Kew. The Emperor Goose ( Anser canagica) from North-east Asia an North-west America is very rare and has only been bred in captivit of late years. It is very handsome, bluish-grey, every feather edge black and white. The sides of the neck and crown of the head ar yellowish white, the feet are yellow, and the beak rosy grey. It i easily bred in confinement and is very gentle. It requires good pasture maize best not be given, being too fattening and likely to bring oi apoplexy. The sexes are alike in plumage but not in size. This specie cannot stand heat and requires fresh running w r ater. The Chinese Goose {Anser cygnoides ) from North Asia is representec m many farmyards by a domesticated variety from which it iff distinguished only by its more slender figure. The wild species is prac | tically unknown in confinement. The male is the larger and has alscf a large knob above its bill. The Snow Geese are like the preceding but have rose-coloured bills and feet. They are white or sometimes of a light bluish-grey colour. They are inhabitants of North America and Eastern Asia and are accidental visitors to Europe. The W hite Snow Goose (A. hyperboreus ) is pure white with black flights , young birds are greyish-brown above. It begins to breed at

Marquess of Tavistock and F. E. Blaauw--Geese 295 years old, but does not go to nest readily and takes a 'time to make up its mind. Unpinioned birds will usually stay, arger species (A. nivalis ) has been imported, a native of tern North America. The Blue Snow Goose (A. coerulescens) is etimes considered to be a mere variety of the white ; and h the two interbreed their young may be either blue or white, the blues will be whiter underneath. This Goose is grey-blue with i grey markings, and with partly white wings, head, neck and omen. It is met with in North America, east of the Rocky mtains. Ross' Goose (A. rossi) is much smaller and more elegant; it is all ,te except for the black flights. It breeds freely in captivity, s quite one of the prettiest Geese and is a native of North-west erica. The Geese of the genus Branta are like the preceding species in position, but are more marine ; they have smaller bills, and ?er, thinner necks. The sexes can only be distinguished by their size. The Bernicle Goose (Branta leucopsis) is one of the prettiest opean species, having its plumage heavily marked with black, white grey. It thrives and breeds freely in confinement. If the young left unpinioned they stay fairly well where they were born. The Brent Goose (B. bernicla) is exclusively marine. It lives well onfinement where it can have grass, but soon dies if fed on grain le. To our knowledge it has not yet been bred in confinement, s smaller, darker, and duller coloured than the preceding species. The Red-breasted Goose (B. rujicollis ) from Siberia has unusual 'kings. It is the handsomest of the genus. Black, with the sides ;he neck and the breast bright rust coloured edged with white ; as also white about the head and under the body and wings. It is y scarce ; does well in confinement, and has been bred at Woburn. The Canada Goose (B. canadensis) is the largest of the wild se ; it is a fine striking bird, in colour brown mixed with fawn, and h a black head and neck. A white streak from one cheek to the er passes under its bill. It is a native of North America, breeds freely onfinement, and need not be pinioned. Its voice is one of its charms, l as it calls principally while flying, it is preferable if only on this

296 Marquess of Tavistock and F. E. Blaauw-- Geese account to leave it full winged. The male bird becomes quarrelsc m the nesting season and may injure other Geese or even small Swa but it does not attack Ducks. Once the young are hatched the gan abandons his warlike demeanour and with his family seeks the comp* of his kind, thereby refuting the theory of certain naturalists t the fierceness of breeding male birds is a provision of nature to ens sufficient space wherein to find food for the young. Hutchin's Goose (B . hutchinsi ) inhabits the same neo-Arctic regi. and resembles the preceding but is only half as large. It is rar met with in confinement. Another occasionally imported species wh resembles the first but is even smaller is B. minima from West* America. They do well in confinement but, unlike their larger relativ are shy breeders. The Sandwich Island Goose (Nesochen sandvicensis) is alm< extinct in a wild state. It is a very fine bird and has very pleasi habits. Its colouring is brown variegated with grey and its ne feathers are barred with light fawn ; its head, a stripe behind the ne< beak and feet are black. This species bred freely in the Bond Zoological Gardens many years ago and has been kept by Herr F. Blaauw at Gooilust for the last thirty years. It is easily bred, b in spite of this is not easy to manage, one reason being that the eg are laid very early in the year, the end of February or the beginni of March, that is long before fine weather can be looked for. Cons quently they often fail to hatch or the young die from cold nights ai changes of temperature. Another reason is the spitefulness of t males , sometimes a gander has lived peacefully for years with i mate, and then suddenly will attack and kill her, and one has c always the luck to intervene in time. Some males are so ill-temper* that they cannot ever safely be left with a female and always ne< watching. The young are easily reared and thrive best when they a left to their parents. They are susceptible to cold, particularly if comes suddenly after a long period of warmth, and it is wise to brii them into shelter at night during early summer. The South American Geese belonging to the genus Chloephaga for a very distinct group. They are very handsome birds both in shaj and colour. They are more terrestrial than aquatic, are lon#
algorithms.footnote: * Marquess of Tavistock and F. E. Blaauw--Geese
algorithms.bodyText: ed and walk well ; they have very small bills. The genus ains six species ; in three of these the sexes are alike, and three they differ, but both are pretty. Those in which sexes are unlike are the Magellan Goose (Chloephaga magellanica ) i Patagonia and the Falkland Isles, which is kept throughout ope, where it breeds freely and does well. The sexes are altogether ke each other, the male being white, striped on the sides with k, with a grey back. His wings are grey with black and white its and a large reddish-brown speculum, his tail is black as are also jill and feet. The female is russet where the male is white, her wings like his but her feet are yellow. The male whistles, but the female a loud call resembling the word " purr-roor ". The sex of young Is can easily be distinguished as soon as they get their feathers, ough at that time the males have grey heads instead of white ones. In the breeding season these Geese are very vicious towards their ipanions, particularly if these happen to be Sheldrakes. They be allowed full power of flight. The nearly related species s inornata) is frequently imported, in this the male has the breast as as the sides barred. The females are identical. They are natives /hili and the Argentine. The Ruddy-headed Goose (G. rubidiceps) is much smaller. The ! is are alike and resemble the hen Magellan, only with redder ds and greyer bodies and more delicate markings. Their voices sr like those of the foregoing species. This is a far rarer and more cate species than those already mentioned. It requires very pure er with fresh grass. It is peculiar to the Falkland Isles. The Ashy-headed Goose (C . poliocephala) is another pretty little I'cies and is very rare. Needs similar treatment to the preceding and like it breeds freely. Both sexes have ashy-grey heads, : logany backs and breasts, white abdomens, and black and white [ped sides ; bills and tails the same colour as the Ruddy-headed ; ; lge yellow feet spotted with black. It is found in Patagonia, th Chili and the Chiloe Isles. The Kelp Goose (G. hybrida) is a peculiar bird. The male is pure te with black and yellow spotted bill and yellow feet. The female ark brown above and has white stripes on head, neck, breast and

Marquess of Tavistock and F. E. Blaauw--Geese sides ; her abdomen, rump and tail are white ; she sports a wl and green speculum ; has a flesh-coloured bill and yellow feet. T handsome species is met with in the Straits of Magellan, Tierra Fuego, and the Falkland Islands. Unlike its fellows, the Kelp Go does badly in confinement, which is accounted for by its habits its own country. There, where the species is fairly plentiful it is alwi found among rocks by the seashore. It does not go inland to f ( like other geese, but lives exclusively on a kind of algse called " lutsch by the natives, and doubtless also on small marine creatures. We 01 brought a Gander back, but in spite of every care he only lived fo few months at Gooilust; although he fed freely on all Sorts of thii they did him no good ; he " went light " and finally died. We brou< with us a bag of dried lutsche " bought at Santiago, where it is s< for human food, but it became exhausted, and could not be obtain in Europe. Apart from this individual we only know of two other importation one in 1868 to the London Zoo, and one more recently to Berlin : I neither bird lived for any length of time. Both male and female are ve handsome, and it would be interesting to make another attempt acclimatizing them. The Andean Goose (0. melanoptera) is rare in confinement b has been bred in the London Zoological Gardens. It chiefly inhab mountainous parts of south-west South America. The sexes are all but the male is much the larger. It is a big white bird and its greeni black wings have a purplish speculum; its tail is black, 'i shoulders light brown with darker spots, beak and feet are red. This species does not mind the cold, but is subject to vario diseases. It is easily tamed, but the Ganders are apt to turn spitefi pursuing their keepers, and puffing themselves out with curioi whistling noises. They appear to dislike the water. The Blue-winged Goose ( Cyanochen cyanopterus ) from North-ea Africa has only twice been imported, but there are now sever at Gooilust. It is ashy brown with pale grey spots, black flights ar grey-blue wing coverts ; bill and feet are black. It seems to 1 nocturnal in habit, only moving about like a true Goose after dusj It keeps motionless during the day, and if obliged to move it does #

Marquess of Tavistock and F. E. Blaauw -- Geese 299 i very curious attitude, its head lying on its back and the chest anced: It has been bred by Herr Blaauw. Gander and Goose are :e in their plumage, but she is the smaller and has a different call. The Maned Goose ( Chenonetta jubata) from Australia has ch the appearance and size of a Carolina Duck. It is one of our ttiest species, the male bird's plumage is silvery grey and black h deep chestnut head and back ; the feathers at the back of the neck long and form a kind of mane. The female is light brown with grey ks. Both sexes have very distinctive plumage and the effect is ghtful. This species is pleasing both in character and habits ; it is y hardy and needs pure water and fresh grass. It breeds very gularly and doubtless it would be desirable to give it a nest eptacle like that used by Mandarins and Carolinas, a small kennel ;ed above the ground and reached by a sloping plank. It bred cessfully thus in the London Zoological Gardens. The Cereopsis Goose ( Cereopsis novce-hollandice ) is a large and larkable Australian Goose ; its colouring, which is the same for h sexes, is pale ashy grey, having blackish spots on the wings, the , e greenish yellow, the legs are deep rose colour and the feet black. It is a terrestrial bird and often travels far from water. It is very : ;ressive during the nesting season, its victims being chiefly terrestrial Is ; even Cranes find them dangerous. It is a very hardy species, ,; often breeds in the depth of winter when it is necessary to shelter nestlings. The female has a deeper voice than her mate, and the es can easily be distinguished owing to this peculiarity. The i eopsis must be pinioned to make it stay ; young birds disappear h extraordinary rapidity unless pinioned. We shall now consider those birds which, though popularly known " Geese ", scientifically speaking are really intermediary between Geese and Ducks. The Spur-winged Goose ( Plectropterus gambensis) and its related ; cies make up a little African genus of which some examples are sorted from time to time. They are large birds with very large pink 11, metallic black and white plumage, strong beaks with a purplish knob. They are unfortunately ugly and clumsily built, very teful, and very susceptible to cold. The sexes are alike.

300 Marquess of Tavistock and F. E. Blaauw -- Geese The Pied or Semi-palmated Goose (Anseranas semipalmata ) frc Australia slightly resembles the above-named bird but anatomica it is altogether different. Its colouring is dull black and pure whi but its shape is far more pleasing. Its bill and slightly palmated fe are orange yellow. It is a hardy and harmless species. The sexes a alike. It has not yet bred in captivity though eggs have been lai If allowed the use of its wings it perches freely. It has a peculiar odoi The Egyptian Goose (Alopochen cegyptiacus), a native of Africa ai Palestine, really belongs to the Sheldrake group, with which it inte breeds readily and produces fertile hybrids. It is hardy and proli, but very quarrelsome. If kept in a small enclosure it will kill all t: birds it can master, but on a lake it only attacks Geese and Shelduc and leaves small Ducks in peace. Young unpinioned birds usual stay well unless their parents drive them off. The sexes are alike plumage, which is greyish fawn prettily relieved with chestnut ai golden red. The wings are white, reddish brown and tawny with blac primaries. Feet and bill are pink. The Gander hisses and the Goo makes a loud cackling. The Orinoco Goose (Alopochen jubatas) is found on the banks < the great tropical American streams, particularly the Orinoco and i tributaries. It is very rare in confinement. Its head, neck and brea are greyish white, the mantle is russet and brown, back, wings and ta metallic black, the under parts a mixture of russet, white and black beak red and black ; feet pinkish orange. The female may be distil guished by her smaller size, and resounding cry, while the male whistk like the male Magellan Goose. The species has been kept several time in the London Zoo and has been represented at Gooilust since I88( but it is only rarely imported and fresh blood is seldom availabk The Orinoco Gander is very aggressive, but usually his temper i directed against human beings and not against his mate. This species is not hardy in Europe, and must be taken into a heate shelter as soon as the weather turns frosty. Even in autumn it shout be driven in as soon as the nights become chilly, and shut up in a she< well furnished with dry straw. The Geese usually start laying late in th season, which is a good thing as there is more hope of warm weather They lay at least eight to ten eggs every year, but very few are fertile
The Breeding of the Malabar Parrakeet

hat one may consider oneself very lucky if four or five hatch out. *se Geese often fall ill if they are allowed to sit, accordingly it is dent to take the eggs away after a few days' incubation and put m under a small kind of hen. The young grow very quickly, and are not usually difficult to rear hey are given plenty of ants' eggs and kept warm. They must be ,t in a warm place as soon as the weather begins to turn cold. The Orinoco Goose is a splendid bird, but requires great care to p it healthy in our climate. It is closely related to the Egyptian jse with which it interbreeds very readily.
algorithms.sectionHeader: THE BREEDING OF THE MALABAR ARRAKEET (PALAfORNIS PERISTERODES)
algorithms.bodyText: By The Marquess of Tavistock This pretty Palceornis is an Uncommon bird in confinement; only r have come into my possession since I began aviculture, and I T e seen but two more in other collections. The first specimen I r owned--a cock given me by Canon Dutton--I tried to mate with Len Moustache Parrakeet {P. fasciata) living at liberty. The two J : ds greeted one another in the most friendly way, but Unhappily Malabar had not learned the language of his alien bride and did ; connect her with her cries when she was out of his sight. The ^sequence was that he lost touch with her the evening following his ?ase, straved, and was never heard of again. Several years later present breeding pair reached me. They were in immature plumage, 1 as the beaks of both were black with a little red I concluded that ad a couple of young cocks. It was, therefore, an agreeable surprise tne when the beak of one gradually became wholly red, and that of ! other entirely blackish, showing that I had a true pair. For a I isiderable time the hen Malabar did not appear very strong, and *wed poor quality of feather. Feather weakness seems not uncommon ; the species, as a breeding hen at the Zoological Gardens ultimately
algorithms.footnote: 1 a very weak and ragged growth of feathers from close confinement 1 lack of fruit, and, though she improved a little after coming into
algorithms.bodyText: my possession, I was never able to make a good bird of her to end of her days. For two years the Malabars showed no sign of nesting. In ) third they inspected a nest-box but got no further. In the foil the hen laid and got egg-bound--a very common occurrence w this species, which likes to breed in February if it can. The three e< were given to foster parents, but proved infertile, as the cock, some reason, would not pair properly with the hen, though in mi ways he was very attentive to her and extremely interested in the ne Later in the spring the hen Malabar again laid, this time withe accident, as the weather was then warm, but once more the eggs wt clear. I began to fear that my cock was useless as a breeder, and it w an agreeable surprise when, the following year, one of the three ep proved fertile and hatched. All went well for about ten days, and th one morning I opened the aviary shelter to find the nest-b fallen to the ground and the young bird inside cold and dea The nest was fastened to the side of the aviary shelter i means of a very large nail passing through a brass eyelet ho Naturally I supposed that the nail or the fastening had g loose, but strange to say the latter was perfectly intact and secUi while the big nail, with an Upward cant, w r as as firm in the wood of t shelter as when it was first driven in ! I can only conclude that n enemy X, annoyed at the prospect of a young Malabar being sUcces fully reared, had, in the dead of night, detached the heavy box fro fche nail and hurled it to the ground ! This year I determined that whatever games X might play, he shou not be able to repeat his little joke of 1926, so I provided the Malaba with a perpendicular natural tree trunk in the shelter, about five fe^ high and hollow for half its depth. For some reason the birds wei slow in settling down. April passed and May was well advanced, an I began to have serious fears that they would drop into moult witlioi laying at all. The cock was anxious enough to set up house and wa constantly rushing into the shelter with loud screeches and trying t entice his mate to enter the hole. Finally, as on a previous occasio " ^ len s ^ e ^ iac ^ been unduly slow in taking up her domestic duties, he los
The Breeding of the Malabar Parrakect

patience and went for her tooth and nail. His display of temper 3 all the more amusing as on ordinary occasions he invariably gave y to her ; indeed in their behaviour to one another the pair always linded me of human married couples living in that bygone period en husbands and wives addressed one another as " Mr." and " Mrs." d treated each other with a kind of distant courtesy. The Malabars re really quite fond of one another, but the hen always liked to se as being rather severe and managing, and as a rule her mate moured her out of politeness. During the winter and early spring >nths they would display to each other from a distance, bowing wly with the neck extended, " chin " depressed, tail slightly sed, and iris contracting. Occasionally during the display the I would bring Up food from her crop, but she never fed her mate r allowed him to approach her closely. Only when she was nesting earnest would she let him feed her. In the ordinary way the cock peared to be an almost henpecked husband, but it was only on ferance that she drove him about, as on the rare occasions when she dly annoyed him he put her in her place in no Uncertain fashion, ter the tiff above mentioned the hen went to the nest in a chastened me of mind, her movements being accelerated by her angry spouse, the entrance hole she turned on him and although a moment before had been making her fly for her life, he got out of her way at once, ' it is etiquette for cocks to give way to their wives at the nest. So lg as she was doing her duty he was still prepared to show her the j artesy due to a lady, but at the same time there were limits to the lulgence she had a right to expect, and in future she would remember lat those limits were ! One of the strangest, most interesting and 3 st amusing things I have observed with breeding Parrakeets is e anger and distress the cocks often display when their partners II not settle down in an eligible residence that has been provided for em. This annoyance is not due to thwarted sexual instinct, as it is ; splayed just as much when the hen is willing to pair ; neither is it ational, for it is hardly ever shown when there is no nest within ich and the birds are in breeding condition. After the lesson she had received the hen Malabar began to settle >wn to business and had laid before the end of May. I was still anxious,

The Breeding of the Malabar Parrakeet however, as she sat Unsteadily, coming oh the nest at the slights alarm, while a dropped feather or two hinted at the arrival of t moult already overdue. However, she did not desert. In due course; four eggs hatched and early in August the young ones left the nest intervals of some days. In colour they are not Unlike the old bir and more closely resemble the adult male than any other nestli: Palceornis I have seen. The areas of the plumage, which are grey the adult, are heavily washed with green in the nestling, giving a mo Uniform green tint to the whole body. The black ring of the adr is quite clearly indicated by a dark line widening under the low mandible. To my surprise, the beaks of all are not black but red, tv having a small dusky patch below each nostril. Presumably, therefore, tl dark beaks of certain female Palceornis are not a primitive characterist but a recent development, and it is the brighter red beak of the ma| which is the primitive feature. The red-beaked female Javan Parrake! would appear to be a more primitive type than the dark-beaked femaj of the almost identical Moustache Parrakeet. Does anyone know tlj colour of the beak of a hen Moustache Parrakeet when she first leav"l the nest ? On the day on which the last young Malabar emerged I was di turbed, when passing the aviary, to hear flutterings and screeche which told all too plainly that a row was in progress in the sheltei Had the parents, now that success was almost in sight, grown tired ( their offspring and decided to murder the lot ? On opening the do( of the shelter the cock popped out, and I found the hen and the younges baby both looking upset and dishevelled and clinging to the wire. Whaj had happened, and what was to be done for the best ? Both adult I were moulting, so there was no question of a second nest. Had th parents quarrelled about the education of their family or had the he attacked her youngest child and been very properly punished by th father ? Belying on the fact that the male Parrakeets are Usual); j more patient and devoted to their newly fledged young than th mothers, I removed the hen Malabar to another aviary and hope< for the best. Luckily all went well, and the cock proved a model parent) In the care of his children he was amusingly methodical. Each on was fed at a different time to the others ; he seldom fed all at once!

algorithms.bodyText: tave watched him after dozing in the flight, suddenly say to himself, Tommy's mealtime ! " and he would go quickly off in search of mmy. Jane and Susan might meet him first and loudly demand ention ; Tommy might be out of sight and quite quiet, but if it s Tommy's mealtime, Tommy and Tommy only would be hunted b and fed. What a contrast to those birds which always feed the ;t and most clamorous youngster and sometimes starve the smaller d weaker members of their brood ! When hungry, young Malabars er a quavering cry--a series of squeaking chirps--Uttered in a lower d softer key than most young Parrakeets employ. The voices of the ilts are, however, most UnmelodioUs--a succession of short, harsh
algorithms.construct: eeches, or, when displaying or investigating nesting-places, a more donged screech in a somewhat deeper tone. Jerdon says of the labar : " Its cry is mellow, subdued and agreeable." Either Jerdon s deaf or he never heard P. peristerodes ! U I ___ _ _ __ THE AVIARIES AT WINSOR By Mrs. A. A. Prestwich
algorithms.bodyText: The main aviaries consist of a range of twelve, facing south. Each iary has a shelter 6 feet wide, 4 feet deep, 6 feet high front, and feet high back. A large window of Muranese glass is fitted in the nt of each. The floors are cement. Attached to each house is a flight feet long, 6 feet wide, and 6 feet high, half-inch wire netting being ?d. Shrubs, etc., were originally planted, but as the majority of the labitants are Parrakeets, they were quickly denuded of leaves, and w only the skeletons remain. The inmates and their doings this year are as follows :-- No. 1.---A pair of Abyssinian Lovebirds, went to nest in May, and d four eggs which they did not hatch ; they are now incubating I . jam. No. 2.--A large flock of Green Budgerigars have had a long : ^cession of nests and have done fairly well, but quite a number of ! *s have not been hatched. ( No. 3.--Some odd Parrakeets, including a Cockatiel, an All-green rrakeet, and a Lineolated Parrakeet.

Avicultural Notes No. 4.--Red-crested Cardinals and a Purple-eared Glossy Starlii No. 5.--A colony of Nyasa Lovebirds, have been very success! quite a large proportion of the eggs laid were hatched and the you reared. No. 6.--Madagascar Lovebirds, have only played at nesting ; laid everywhere but in the right place. No. 7.--A pair of Red-speckled ConUres ( C. euops), have now be out of doors four years. They have nested four times during the 1; eighteen months, laying four or five eggs on each occasion ; in ea case they have eaten the eggs after sitting for ten days to a fortnig They are a true pair, but possibly the eggs are infertile. No. 8.--Black-cheeked Lovebirds, have reared several youngste No. 9.'--A cock Madagascar Lovebird mated to a hen Red-fat Lovebird, very friendly but do not seem interested in nest-boxes. No. 10.--A cock Madagascar mated to a hen Black-cheeked Lot bird, five eggs were laid but proved infertile. A Madagascar suppli as a mate earlier in the year was scalped by the Black-cheek. No. 11.--Masked Lovebirds, no attempt at nesting yet, but da are still young. No. 12.--A pair of Turquoise-rumped Parrotlets (Psittacula eye opygia) from Western Mexico, wintered out successfully, but as far I can tell have never ventured inside a nest-box. Another aviary with a shelter 12 feet wide and 6 feet deep, and wi a flight 42 feet long and 36 feet wide, is in course of erection ; tl will be tenanted by a mixed series of Lovebirds next spring. T 1 smaller aviaries are reserved for the use of two African Grey Pam and a Blue-fronted Amazon, and for any British birds that come hand. A delightful pair of finger-tame Abyssinian Lovebirds complet our family of aves at present.

The second number of the Budgerigar Bulletin, the official org; of the Budgerigar Club, contains some very valuable informati* regarding the breeding of the various colour-varieties of this Parrake* The laws of heredity brought to light by Mendelhave been showntoapp
algorithms.title: Avicultural Notes
algorithms.bodyText: the Budgerigar as to other animals and plants, and an able article Consul-General Cremer shows how these laws can be relied upon plicitly, and if a breeder understands them and knows the pedigree his stock he can calculate with accuracy as to what colour and what ventage he may confidently hope to produce. The chief difficulty when breeding from blue-bred greens or green it-blues, as General Cremer calls them, is that a percentage of the )geny are pure greens which cannot be distinguished from blue-bred sens from the same nest. These can be tested by crossing them with les. If pure greens they will produce only greens, albeit these will blue-bred, but if themselves blue-bred (or* split-blue) they will )duce some 50 per cent of blue offspring.
Another collector from the East has arrived in the person of
algorithms.listItem: ft '. Mayer, who has landed a choice collection of birds, mostly from !W Guinea. Amongst these the following are worthy of special bntion : A Blue-collared Parrakeet ( Geoffroyus cyanicollis) , a very autiful species, though apparently delicate ; a Pleasing Lorikeet ; ypocharmosyna placens), no larger than a Budgerigar, Black-winged, ack-capped, Blue-streaked, and Purple-capped Lories ; Red Birds Paradise, Black-capped Fruit Pigeons, and Victoria Crowned Pigeons, t to mention a large number of Three-coloured Parrot Finches.
algorithms.bodyText: The Emu for July, 1927, is a particularly interesting number, ntaining as it does accounts of some of the most beautiful and rare the Grass Parrakeets, and their present status in their native habitat. \ E. Ashby writes on the Orange-breastedand Blue-winged Parrakeets eophema chrysogaster and N. chrysostoma ) as observed by him. 1 \ W. W. Giblin and Mr. A. W. Swindells supply notes on the nesting bits of the Blue-wing in Tasmania, while Miss Florence M. Irby i -ites on the Scarlet-chested or Splendid Parrakeet (N . splendida) and e Paradise Parrakeet (Psephotus pulcherrimus), both of which exquisite S ecies she has been fortunate enough to observe in their wild state, i l excellent photograph is published of a male Paradise Parrakeet ! its nesting hole in a termites' mound, and Miss Irby supplies the

Correspondence information that this species also nests in holes in banks of ere after the manner of Kingfishers, an observation that has not previou been published. Still another rare Parrakeet is the subject of anarti by Lord Clive in this issue, namely the Ground or " Button-gras Parrakeet (Pezoporus wallicus), which is still comparatively coma in South-West Tasmania, though gradually disappearing in front advancing settlement and settlers' cats. A rare bird that has just been acquired by the Zoological Soci< and has not been represented in the collection for nearly forty yean the Horned Screamer (Palamedea cornuta), from the Amazon vail It is as large as a Turkey, black above with white underparts a mottled black and white breast, and on the head it carries a tl horn. It has very large feet and feeds chiefly upon grass and otl vegetable matter. It is extremely tame and delights in being peth

Sir, --I have recently received a Tanygnathus Parrakeet (Tam nathas luconensis) which is perhaps new to aviculture, although, strac to say, it figures in Levaillant's quaint old book on Parrots. In sizel resembles Mueller's Parrakeet and in general plumage the GreJ billed Parrakeet, but it differs from the latter in having a wide b of turquoise blue across the head and hardly any blue on the run: There is a well-marked strip of brownish bronze feathers in each wii and some of the smaller wing feathers near the back and mantle a broadly marked with blue. Taken as a whole, the bird's colouring distinctly beautiful, although, like all Tanygnathi, it lacks grace form. Unlike a captive Greatbill, which is Usually sluggish and moros the Lucon Parrakeet is active and friendly. He talks in a somewh husky and indistinct voice, and displays to a human friend in t' usual manner of the genus by throwing up the head and elongating tl neck. Occasionally he Utters a series of short screeches like a Palaeori

. Takeet or Comlre, which have no counterpart in the Greatbill's i ertoire. I hope eventually to allow the bird full liberty, and it will i interesting to see whether in a state of freedom he indulges in any- lg resembling the extraordinary " song " of his larger relative. Tavistock.

Sir, --With reference to the correspondence in the October numb of the Avicultural Magazine on breeding A. roseicollis, I succeed* in rearing four young from one nest last season (1926). From w observations I would say that the hen solely incubated the egg although the cock went in and out of the coco-nut husk, presumab to feed the hen, but rarely stayed more than a few minutes. Withii a week of the young hatching, the hen died from inflammation, an the cock succeeded in rearing the young himself. One young got its wing caught in a joint in the husk and unforti nately died before I found anything wrong ; one I gave away, lea vie father and two young. Unfortunately I omitted to separate, and i February this year one was killed by the parent, leaving one whic I am sure is a hen, although they have not shown signs of nesting. Contrary to general practice, these birds made no nest other tha; scooping out the husk.

algorithms.construct: Hh Series. --Vol. V.--No. 12 .--All rights reserved. DECEMBER, 1927. THE YELLOW-BREASTED CISSA (<CISSA H. HTPOLEUCA) By J. Delacour
algorithms.bodyText: This fine bird, figured from nature in the accompanying plate, was discovered in Cochin-China as far back as 1846, but it was not until 5 that the collection then made and deposited in the Fornis Museum sorted out and that Griglioli and Salvadori named it; as the type firnen was entirely faded blue and white, they called the bird oleuca, " white-bellied,'' an entirely wrong expression which we better change in English into " yellow-breasted ". The fresh bird, pature, is pale Naples yellow underneath, bright grass green above, h a broad black band over the eye, black subterminal spots on the 1 and chestnut markings on the wings. In captive specimens of all Cissas kept in indoor cages with Tfficient fresh animal food, all the yellow in the plumage fades to >te, and the green becomes pale blue, wfith greyish olive markings die wings. In that state, however, the present bird looks different, * still quite handsome. The same thing happens to skins if they are , carefully protected from all light. It seems that daylight destroys yellow pigment, which has to be constantly replaced through stances derived from live or fresh food, such as insects, small

J. Delacour--The Yellow-breasted Cissa vertebrates and berries, and also that fresh air and sun is indispensai Flesh, the proper food, is essential, and is well shown by the'fact t we found wdld Cissas which had faded to blue and white more or ] completely on the Kontoum Plateau in South Annam, a dry and bu district which had been suffering from severe drought and fire many months and where live food was very scarce. The Yellow-breasted Cissa is a rare bird in skin collections, and u I obtained it only three others, So far as I am aware, have been obtaii since its discovery. It inhabits the thick jungle and forest of Cochin-Ch and South Annam, moving about in small flocks and mixing w Drongos,Babblers, Woodpeckers,etc. They are very noisy, shy, and v difficult to secure. For the past few years some had been kept by Dr. M. Cogna then the Governor of Cochin-China, in the Saigon Zoo, and last spi Dr. Cognacq brought to Cleres three fine birds, which I sent to Mr. E before leaving again for the Far East. As they had been over a yea captivity they were blue and white, but in perfect condition. T; did very well in a very large outdoor aviary, with a heated she! which contained other birds of similar strength, such as Starlii Although they mastered them, they never molested them. Their sh and hues, as well as their pretty and amusing attitudes, made them, v conspicuous and charming. Male and female are similar, and their t< length averages 13 inches. These CiSsas are fed on insectivor mixture, cut-up meat, fruit, and plenty of mice, mealworms, ; insects, which they are extremely fond of and which helps to ret their yellow and green dress. The last time I saw them they w moulting and the yellow and green feathers showed distinctly am< the old faded white and blue ones. They are very strong birds, f rather noisy. They had been carrying sticks about all the sumn but never attempted to make a proper nest. The three above mentioned Yellow-breasted Cissas are the first i only ones ever imported alive into Europe, or, in fact, to leave tl native country. Mr. Alfred Ezra adds the following notes :-- Mr. Delacour has already given a description of this beautiful hi
algorithms.title: J. Delacour--The Yellow-breasted Cissa
algorithms.bodyText: [ need say no more about its appearance. The three birds he gave me 3 year have done splendidly in a large aviary, and I consider them y hardy birds. They have been fed principally on insectile mixture, h some meat and fruit, and mice when obtainable. Last October \0x25A0as delighted to see that the birds had moulted out in their natural ours, and instead of being pale blue and white were grass green and ion yellow. This colour they retained right through this summer, y getting much paler by the end of August, when they started to ult again. From the few feathers they have grown so far it looks if they will be green and yellow again. The coloured plate gives a >d impression of the bird, both in its natural colours and in the e and white state. The whole of last winter the three birds were ot in an aviary together. Last April, in order to give them a chance lesting, I tried to sex them, and to take the odd bird out of the aviary, all the three birds looked alike, this was no easy matter. After tching them carefully for some days, I discovered that two of them med rather friendly, so I caught up the third and put him in another ary. I also emptied out the aviary of all the other birds, and the r of Cissas had the whole aviary to themselves. The next day I nd the pair fighting viciously, and thinking that I had made a ?take and put two cocks in together, I decided to separate them, put off doing this till the evening. To my surprise in the evening ound them building in a basket I put up for them inside the iltered aviary. They worked very hard at it, and the nest was soon shed. The outside was rather rough, but the inside was nicely lined :h dry grass and feathers. On the 16th April I found one of the birds iting the nest, and on the following day there was one egg in the nest, the 18th I found the hen bird on the floor of the aviary, egg-bound 1 very ill. After treatment in a warm room, she recovered, but did visit the nest. As it was the first known egg of this bird, I removed nd sent it to Lord Rothschild for his collection. Again, on the 28th, mnd the CiSsa on the nest, and on looking into it I found her sitting two eggs. Only the hen bird incubated, but the cock sat on the side the nest, and attacked any of us if we entered the aviary. He was te fearless, and flew at our heads with open beak, making an awful se all the time. The hen bird sat till the 24th of May, when I took

Lady Grey--Bock Peplars at Liberty the eggs away and, on examination, found them both clear. r Cissa was seen on the nest again on the 2nd June, and on the next < I found one egg in the nest. On the 4th I again picked up the hen e bound, but she recovered after treatment. On the 5th she was on nest again, sitting on two eggs. I found two broken eggs on the fk so it looks as if these birds lay at least four eggs in a clutch. On 16th they deserted the nest and again I found the two eggs cb They again went to nest, and I found the hen sitting on two eggs 2nd July. These two eggs were also clear. After all her efforts I foi the hen bird in heavy moult and in very poor condition on my ret from abroad. I fed her up, but she suddenly died on the 20th Septeml The size of the egg is more or less the size of that of a Blackbird, wh it resembles closely. A dull white with minute olive-brown sp> specially heavily spotted at the larger end. Needless to say, it wa great disappointment to me not to have succeeded in breeding i lovely and interesting bird. I have put the two remaining Cissas toget in the same aviary, so far without quarrelling, but I am afraid they both cocks.

By Lady Grey of Fallodon Perhaps our members may be interested to hear of the young R Peplars, an account of the rearing by hand of which was publishec the September issue. All three prospered, and were strong on the wing, delightfully ta and intelligent. One, when fully grown, succumbed to pneumoi but the other two continued to thrive. They live in one partitioi the aviary here at Fallodon, 22 by 25 feet in size, which they si with a pair of Kentucky Cardinals, a Rock Thrush, three Ama Parrots, and one Grey African Parrot. Every morning the Pep are set at liberty, and they remain out till 2 or 3 o'clock in the af noon. These hand-reared birds fly to us readily for food and c< panionslnp, and are easily taken in to their safe quarters when we w to put them back in security from the Brown Owls. They go at o to the feeding trays, and eat with the zest their hours of flight h

E. Hopkinson--Birds at the Primley Zoo, 1927 917 ?n them. When first they are released their exuberance in flight xhilarating to watch : a marvel of speed, power, and grace. They ep past and over, it is difficult to keep them in sight. They go |eading through the green spaces of the trees, keeping in touch with h other by their call-note, and when lost to sight this little yelping e is audible quite far away over the Park, and then again denly far to the left over the kitchen garden and drive, such is their ftness. It puts one greatly out of conceit with cages, and I feel more vinced.than ever that people might trust their birds with greater >rty than is customary because the territory instinct is so strong ; ! course, always pre-supposing the point of contact with food and lk is once established and the cage or aviary, as the case may be, amiliar to the birds and easily accessible. Our Amazon Parrots have their freedom in this way, and are remely intelligent about it. When the Rock Peplars alight on us 3 r one of their circling flights, they look hastily to right and left, ir eyes appearing not to focus on near objects at all ; but a raisin % monkey-nut soon catches their attention, and they feed from our ; or hands till, like a flash, they are off again. They eat hawthorn- ries and lime twigs and buds, and the daisies on the lawn and ding grasses; and such is their love of water that when quite wet with a they take an even more exuberant bath than usual.

By The Rev. R. B. Abel I procured my pair of Blue Tanagers ( Tcmcigici ccoici ) from [r. Chapman in January, 1926. After a month or so, wdien their lumage was in condition, I let them into my outdoor a\iarj , where hey have been ever since. I note this to show the hardiness of the irds. All last winter they roosted in their usual corner in the open helter. On 16th March this year I noticed them building in a box |rith half-open front in the shelter. Soon after they ceased owing to "ad weather, but resumed operations on 6th April. They then went 1 head and built a complete nest of dried grass, wood sha\ mgs (used foi tacking) a few r feathers, and a little cow r -hair. So the nest remained for
algorithms.listItem: * everal weeks carefully guarded by the pair but egg-less. About the
algorithms.bodyText: B. B. Abel Breeding the Blue Tanager beginning of June they forsook it and began building in the next bo; This time I thought it advisable to give a little assistance, and put rush cup-nest in the box. They apparently appreciated the attentioi completed their nest, and adorned the entrance with a substanti; tuft of wood-shavings. By loth June 1 felt certain the hen was layinj On 16th June I took a peep ; there was one egg. I dared not stay t measure it, but it appeared to be f in. long, not very pointed at ei.tht end, dull white, marked pretty evenly with purplish-brown spots an splotches. Whether my visit was the cause or no, that was the onl egg laid. I dared not look again for some time, but I judge the perio of incubation to have been about fourteen days. At any rate, b 28th June the parents were clearly feeding young. About ten day later I took another peep, and saw the young bird covered in blackis down. It left the nest on 19th July, and received its first lessons i flying, to the amusement of the other inmates of the aviary. L appearance it was duller and, of course, much smaller than the parents They fed it assiduously for some weeks on mealworms, banana, lettuce soft-bill mixture, and, when I could get them, fresh ants' eggs. It i now a strong lusty youngster, well able to take care of itself, but stil following the parents more or less and roosting near them in the ol< corner. The wing feathers are now growing brighter with something o the glorious blue sheen of the old birds. two further facts I should like to mention. My Blue Tanager M eie the shyest birds in an aviary which contains some forty birds o various kinds. In this company they successfully nested. Further I made friends with them over the process. When thev were feeding tin young bird they came to my call for a mealworm, and still come. Tin other thing is this. Ihey were assisted in the feeding business byai odd cock Crowned Tanager, who dodged up to the nest with rations v henever the parents backs were turned. Often he was caught by then in the middle of his unsolicited attentions and ruthlessly driven fron the scene. May I mention also that my Brown-shouldered Meadow Starlings have had two nests, and in the second instance reared a vouno'stei J o till it was half-fledged.
algorithms.figure: u Si E. Maud Knobel--A Short Account of the Owls at Wargrave 325 A SHORT ACCOUNT OF THE OWLS AT WARGRAVE By E. Maud Knobel
algorithms.bodyText: Having spent a most delightful week-end with Miss Chawner Thatched Holme, Wargrave, and seen Mr. Spedan Lewis's wonderful Election of Owls, of which Miss Chawner is curator, I think perhaps note in the Magazine will be of interest to some of our readers, he aviaries are built on three sides of a quadrangle, the quadrangle 3 ing large enough to contain a full-sized tennis court, and a fairly rge greenhouse for Alpine plants. There is room in the house for the lore delicate species. I do not suppose in any other part of the world such a unique and splendid collection of Owls--there were at the time c my visit 113 individuals, comprising thirty-three different species, here seemed every kind of Owl, certainly " more than dreamt of in ly philosophy", but, then, I do not know much about Owls. There 'ere great big fellows and tiny little pigmies that would go into the aim of one's hand, and they came from every clime--from the tropics ) the Arctic zone. I have always been under the impression that Owls ould only see in the dark and therefore only came out at night; that uring the day they either lived in a hole in a tree or in the eaves or Afters of a barn, where they slept quietly until it was dark enough for tiem to venture out. Great, therefore, was my surprise to see these )wls not only enjoying daylight, but sitting in the full glare of the sun, j iany of them enjoying a real sun bath with wings outspread and ring down on the warm stump of a tree to get the full benefit of the rarmth, also being able to see and take an interest in all that went on round them. Another surprise to me was to find them such tremendous *athers, splashing about in huge pans of water and getting thoroughly i ret through. Out of such a collection it is only possible to mention one or two. The biggest was the Eagle Owl, erroneously, I think, called " the ! iurk ", for a tamer bird it would be hard to find. He followed
algorithms.figure: r 7 vliss Chawner about like a dog, and it was quite difficult to get out of i iis aviary without his coming also. His plumage was tawny and black, ]
algorithms.bodyText: 82G E. Maud Knobel -- A Short Account of the Owls at Wargrave white under the chin, and he had long ears and huge feet and talo well feathered up to the toes. His eyes were of that wonderful de> orange that belongs to some of the Owl tribe. Unfortunately he had badly dropped wing, but in spite of this handicap was learning to i from perch to perch. The most beautiful to my mind, and also one of the rarest in tl collection was the little Hawk Owl from circum-polar regions. A real exquisite little creature, with a coat of light and dark grey both spott< and barred, the barring being specially noticeable across the breas It was about the size of a Pigeon, and more like a Hawk than an It is really a day bird, and has pale yellow eyes. Another charmii Arctic Owl and also a rarity was Tengmalm's, very similar in colourii to the Hawk Owl, but considerably smaller. There were two of thes but unfortunately they would not agree together, probably on accoui of sex. Perhaps the tamest in the collection was a White-eared Scop which just loved to be petted and made a fuss of--a very unusual thii in birds of this group. But what fascinated me most were the Ur Owls from the Mark of Finland. There were six of these, all young bin of the year. Two were very tame, one specially so, coming 1 Miss Chawner and playing with her gloved hand like a kitten. Th rejoiced in the name of " Black-eyed Susan ". The other was a mo: daring bird and, having taken Miss Chawner's hat off her head ar carried it up to a rafter, had earned for himself the name of " Terrib James '. They were delightful birds, and I was immensely pleased whe they eventually came on to my hand and allowed me to play with thee Their colouring is composed of shades of dark grey with dark brow bars, and their faces are like a baby's with a granny's hood round they have most beautiful dark blue-brown eyes, and the feathers ( the face are so fine that they are more like hairs than feathers. It is quite impossible to describe in a short space all I saw. I ca only hope that perhaps some day other members of the Society ma see and enjoy for themselves what is a most unique collection.
algorithms.figure: Maurice Amslei--On Colour Breeding in Budgerigars 827 3 N colour breeding in budgerigars By Maurice Amsler, M.B., B.S., F.Z.S.
algorithms.bodyText: Our Editor has published one or two notes on the abnormal coloured udgerigars, in which there has been such a boom during the past year
algorithms.listItem: * more. Though not posing as an authority, I have had a certain
algorithms.bodyText: easure of success in breeding for colour during the past few years. I am not at all certain that this is really a subject which should be* ritten on or discussed in a magazine such as the Avicultural, which purely scientific and not a publication for fanciers ". I started Budgerigars with Blue-bred Greens some years ago, and filter breeding from these for a couple of years with no more encouraging \0x25A0suits than young Greens, I parted with the whole lot ; some eight or Line birds going to Mrs. Chatterton. I fancy these were all hens ; from lese hens, paired to Blue-bred Green cocks, which she purchased, I |elieve, from Mr. Marsden, she has, as most people know, bred Whites,, lues, Yellows, and, of course, Greens. I then started with two pairs of Blues, and from these birds, with very occasional fresh Blue bird for new blood, I have during the past mr or five years bred some hundreds of Blues. I think it may safely be said that with Torquoise-blues--Bluest ! iways breed Blues--the exception to the rule must be extremely rare* tid can be taken as negligible--the same does not apply to Cobalts,, liich I suppose must be considered a less fixed type. I have at the I foment a Green cock both of whose parents were Cobalts. Last month bred a Green bird from a Torquoise-blue hen and a Cobalt cock. The ime nest contained two Blues and three Cobalts, as I have already t :ated a Green chick is a very rare occurrence when both parents are* f the ordinary or turquoise-blue colour. The following notes are not of outstanding interest, but go to prove (, lat although it is worth while working on definite lines, results cannot e guaranteed, and that there is no rule-of-thumb in colour-breeding., laving one small heated aviary in the end of my greenhouse, I ecided to start breeding early last January. Even with heat there is distinct risk of egg-binding if one starts too early, so I put up four *lue-bred Green hens and paired them with four Blue cocks. I got
algorithms.figure: 1 f i
algorithms.address: 328 Maurice Amslei--On Colour Breeding in Budgerigars
algorithms.bodyText: two nests from each pair, some thirty young birds, before the coc! were transferred in May to their rightful Blue hens. Among all the young there was not a single Blue--but I did get two Yellows, whi< I greatly prized, and rightly so, as will be seen later. Having one or two extra Blue cocks, I allowed one of the adu Green hens to continue breeding later in an outdoor aviary. In tl second nest she produced three Blues and one Green, and at the presei moment she has five young, of which two are certainly Blues. Th goes to prove that it is not wise to turn down " a pair of birds if they < not produce what is expected and wanted on the first occasion. J July I paired one of the young Yellows (a hen then five months ok to a Blue cock. I hoped to get a white, but the result was two Blm and a Green. I then gave her another Blue cock, and she has now two Whites an a Blue, which is exactly what I expected and wanted. I think that it unwise to introduce the ordinary Lutino or Yellow Budgerigar ini one's strain--but if a Yellow is produced from Blue or Blue-bre parents, it should be carefully preserved and bred from. I have bred from several of this year's early-bred birds, and ha\ got some good youngsters from these young parents, but I must als admit that some of the offspring have shown signs of " French moult in varying degrees--whereas I have not had a single case among son: hundred birds bred from adults this year. A few more statements of facts may also be of interest, if they onl give rise to opposition or discussion. There is little doubt, I think, the even given the requisite abnormally bred or abnormally coloure parents, it is more difficult to obtain young from these than it is froi common Greens. As proof thereof, when I was breeding from the Gree hens in my heated aviary in January, I also put in a Blue hen paire to a Cobalt cock, the former died with her second egg. A Green Blue bred hen paired to a very fine White cock gave me clear eggs, as di also a Cobalt hen paired to the Green cock previously referred to, wh was the offspring of two Cobalt parents. Some of these birds retrieve their reputation later in the season ; the Cobalt cock has fathered thre nests and, paired to a Blue hen, has produced eight Cobalts, ten Blue* and one Green.

algorithms.bodyText: One of the Green hens .which produced two nests of Greens January to March has since then given me 50 per cent of Blues i red to the same Blue cock. A young White hen, which came to me xchange for the White cock previously mentioned, laid a clutch of mte eggs from which she reared two Blues, one of which was :herless--her mate was a Blue ; she is now sitting on her last clutch our for this season, of which the eggs are quite normal in size. ; November 10. These four eggs were put under a common green |[ who hatched and brought off four vigorous young blues, n the absence of a white cock I should, I think, have done better i I paired this white hen to a blue -bred yellow cock. >ince writing the above I have had quite a number of ill-feathered : .ngsters in the third nests from my adult pairs and I am writing a notes on this so-called French moult which the Editor has kindly sented to publish.

By Dr. E. Hopkinson, C.M.G., D.S.O. Dakar, the chief port of Senegal, is the headquarters of the export iein the small ornamental Finches commonly called Senegalis )se include the Waxbills, Firefinches, Cordon-bleus, and Lavender ches, and besides these a good many larger seed-eating birds are ) caught and exported--Weavers, Whydahs, Combassous, Singing ches, etc. These, or selections of these (according to season), form usual contents of the catchers' cages, though odd rarer birds may asionally be found there, but not very often, for these comparatively 1 3 ones are those which are not found as a rule in flocks and therefore : to be caught wholesale, and the African, preferring quantity to Tity, wants a good return for every pull of his net. Such rarer birds ude Aurora Finches, Spotted and Vinaceous Firefinches, and i gpie Mannikins, the last once very common, but now, for some son, only infrequently seen either wild or in the cages. Nowadays, , one may towards the end of the rains see cages full of the Yellow avers ( Hyphantornis , etc.), mostly cocks in colour. A bird-catching party consists of two or three men, each with a

E. Hopkinson -- Bird-catching in Senegal cage and two or three nets like our clap-nets, but very much sma (about 8 by 2 feet), and used singly. The cage is an ordin packing-case, about 3 by 2 by 2 feet, with a wire netting frc a sliding door in the top, and a wooden water-trough which slides from the front along one side of the cage and runs its whole dej Perches parallel with the front, a great number--often forty, in li occupying the upper three-quarters of the cage, and many, theref< one above another--complete the equipment ; they are fixed in h< drilled in the ends of the cage, and are cut longer than the cage facilitate their withdrawal when it is wished to catch up the bii There is no drawboard, and therefore no means of cleaning the c while inhabited, but this does not matter much in the dry climat( Senegal (i.e. in the dry season), and the big door in the top allow good scraping every time the stock is sold which, if things go w should be about once a month. The whole lot with the nets, a se grinding mill and perhaps a cooking pot, forms a cumbersome but too heavy head-load. In recent years great changes have, of course, occurred everywh and in everything--bird-catching even has been affected, and hi as in many other things and places, the change has not been for better. I am speaking of the Gambia, where for more than twenty-five ye I have lived (with yearly, or nearly yearly, leaves home), and wh I have Seen the catching of, and often also caught and brought ho] these birds. The Gambia Colony and its Protectorate is the Ri Gambia and a narrow strip on each bank, running for about 300 m right into Senegal and providing easy means of transport into interior, for ocean-going steamers go up for nearly 200 miles and local ## cutters " and launches as far as our eastern boundary. Gam and the adjacent French territory to the north used to be the favom hunting ground, owing to its nearness to markets, but nowada Gambia is less frequented and the catchers work along the new Frei railway which runs much further east than does our Gambia. Twenty years ago and earlier the catchers came from some sort clan of their own, and the " profession " was obviously a closed oj they were generally Senegal Fulas, of low caste apparently, for tl
algorithms.title: E. Hopkinson -- Bird-catching in Senegal
algorithms.bodyText: ere certainly looked down on by everyone else, but they could catch rds, and, what is more important, could keep them alive and in good *ndition after catching. A party would start operations from home and, moving about ^ery three or four days, travel slowly along till their cages were 11 (400 birds was the object), and they had reached the place where ley could sell their catch. This was either Bathurst, one of our up-river ading places, where they sold direct to certain captains of steamers hich came there to load ground-nuts, or at one of the French nut- lying centres along the Dakar railway line, then only reaching about )0 miles from the coast. New hands I suppose had to find good places jf n"r catching, but all the catchers I knew had learnt this from previous sits ; they set the nets and began catching the first day, simply atting them down early in the morning, baiting with a little seed and lenty of millet-husks from the pounding-places, leaving them ^touched till the afternoon and then getting a catch. Sometimes they ould set at a drinking place, but this was mainly for Weavers, and at le end of the season proper or when they wanted Pigeons, etc. They id not consider the results good enough to justify the spoiling of the ets by the water, and therefore dry sites were the rule, clearings in the dl grass either in or near the millet-fields or on the dry swamps, range-cheek and Zebra Waxbills being the commonest bag in the last, hree pulls a day was the rule, four exceptionally, as during the hot lid-day hours there is nothing doing in the bird-catching line. One |oes not wonder therefore that they like as many birds as possible 3r pull and take but little interest in birds which can only be caught one-one ". Soft-bill birds (except for an occasional individual who ent for Glossy Starlings) they never troubled about, and any mis- ! aided bird except a seed-eater who got into the nets went into the pot, /en the over-bold Hawks, which so often spoil (experto crede) a ood chance. As they travelled along the catchers lived in the small villages of leir friends and fellow-tribesmen along their road, and avoided the |igger places, where they got plenty of abuse but little chance of food >r themselves or their birds. Among their friends they were able to eg the seed for the birds and their own meals, or barter for it any

algorithms.bodyText: Doves or Sand-grouse they had caught, and every self-respecti catcher had one old net which he set at a water hole simply' for tl purpose. They fed their birds on millet ground-up in an ordina coffee-mill with the addition of " findo ", a small grass-like cere whenever they could get it. Our millet in its ordinary state is too ha for Waxbills and the like, though Weavers, etc., husk it easily, but ev these do better if given it ground. This grinding was done twice a da at daybreak and again after mid-day before the men started on t evening round of the nets. The water troughs were filled at the sai time. The birds, therefore, had plenty of quiet time in which to fee the essential thing with fresh-caught birds. In spite of the primiti cages and the constant travelling, the birds did well in capable hane and I learnt a lot of useful tips about the business from these peop My experience is that with proper food and average care the mortali is very low, ridiculously low compared with what used to be the ca with English birds ; two per cent I should think was about t average mortality while in the catcher's cages, say for about a mont What was the rate among fresh-caught Goldfinches at home ? Fifty Such was the ease under favourable circumstances, and I have oft got lots of birds all the way to England with the same success, my bt effort being with three dead out of 400 odd from day of catching Africa to arrival in England two months (at least) later. That is n likely to be repeated, but I have often got other smaller lots home wi almost as good results, and, of course, there have been times win things have not gone well and the death rate been really too high, b then, thanks to 'flu, etc., we at times suffer from that sort of thi] ourselves. Why this is so I have never been able to discover. All n birds have always come in July, at the best season, and to a appearances everything, weather, shipment, length of journey, et< has been the same in every case, good or bad. Our old catchers' bin did just as well, if they got into the hands of exporters who al understood them. Nowadays all is altered. Up to about the war things were ; described, but now, owing, I suppose, to the greater demand for bin and their decrease in the more accessible districts, things have be< speeded up, have " advanced " (Progress with a big P), and Ford cai

E. Ilopkinson \0x25A0-- Bird-catching in Senegal lways and other results of Progress and advancing civilization have 3 ned up wider circles of possible catching and*much shortened the ie between catching and export, so that the birds, as some one *ently put it, get to Europe " before they have time to die This L y be so or not, but they are now hustled along so quickly and have breaking-in to cage-life before shipment, that I should have pected the dying rate would exceed the journey speed. In any case, ere is no doubt that these birds do not as a rule arrive in the condition ey used to. The bird-catchers themselves have changed, and I believe also the rd-buyers at the ports. Of the first, instead of the " select " few of the i days, who caught only in the dry season, January to May, and I .ent the rains at their proper job, that is on their farms, we now may id any scallywag who is out of work, or thinks he has found a soft b, trying his hand and at all seasons. A dozen or so will get to work id set their nets anywhere where they see birds, even close to the >wns where Firefinches, formerly sacrosanct as guests of the town, 3 rdon-bleus, and Combassous can easily be caught. In about a week ieir cages are full ; they are then bundled on to a lorry and hustled > the selling place with all speed. None of the old leisurely progress , [ying plenty of time for the captives to feed and get accustomed to l ige-life; haste and quick delivery instead. Most of the present-day } itchers, too, know nothing about the birds and their care, and for their j )od simply throw in millet uncrushed and expect that to do for all-- jo do well enough at any rate to keep the birds alive till they can be i ot rid of to the big buyer. It does not do, and hence more deaths, besides, catching now goes on at all seasons, for now that big liners j rom South America put into Dakar, the dealers there have found that i hey can sell at big prices cages of bright-coloured birds to the Passengers, and one sees there cages of Weavers (. Pyromelana , Quelea, |nd Hyphantornis), Whydahs (Pintail and Paradise), Cordons, and |firefinches, all in full colour, from about August to November. These, 1 if course, are caught during the rains, the period of full colour, and at ; he best are unlikely to live, for at that time they live so largely on insect rood and soft unripe seeds. The change to hard seed, especially i mcrushed as supplied to the purchasers, is impossible, and m addition

most arrive in our cold weather, so that total loss of a whole cage-fi is almost the rule. Bird-catching in West Africa is foolish after Ma unless you have a foolish buyer on your doorstep, and even then wicked. During the dry season, January to May, I can see no more han in it than in catching at home, or as a matter of fact than in shootin hunting, etc., or even eating butchers' meat. The names used by the catchers are of some interest, for most a] sort of slang words, more or less French, more or less Joloff or Fuh Most of them are of long-standing usage, for bird-catching has bee going on here since the end of the eighteenth century, at any rate Kumbasu, for instance, is as old as Vieillot's time, his " I Combassou " being Hypochera chalyheata. algorithms.reference: By Maurice Amsler, M.B., B.S., F.Z.S. On the occasion of my last visit to our late and much lamentec President, Mr. Hubert Astley, we were talking about his pair of Hermi' Thrushes (Hylocichla guttata), which I believe he obtained through th< New York Zoo. He then said that if the cock did not shortly begin tc sing he would let me have them to try my hand at breeding them.
algorithms.title: Maurice Amsler--Breeding the Hermit Thrush
algorithms.bodyText: To the great sorrow of every aviculturist, Mr. Astley died within a nth, and through the generosity of Mrs. Astley*the birds came into . possession in May, 1925. The hen was not in perfect plumage on ival, but improved after being in an outdoor aviary for a few weeks, e cock, though in good condition, never uttered a note ; a few straws ;re carried during the summer, but no serious attempt at nesting is made. S' Not knowing how hardy these birds might be, I caged them up in e autumn, and a few weeks later the cock, who had for some time hibited a queer quivering movement in one leg, died in convulsions. My chagrin at this was very great, both because of the bird s origin id also because I did not think it likely that I could ever replace him. Much to my surprise and delight, I received a letter from Chapman j March, 1926, offering me another cock of this species. I, of course, )0 k the bird, which proved, indeed, to be a male. The sexes are Osolutely identical and, as they fight like Gamecocks, whether they be airs or like sexes, during three-quarters of the year, I was only able ) determine the sex of this last bird when he began to sing a few weeks iter. I discovered subsequently that this cock came from Captain Stokes, nd that it was through him that Chapman knew I was wanting a nale of this species. The two birds were turned out in April, 1926, and were inclined to piarrel, but not seriously. Towards the end of the month the cock I >egan to sing, and continued this throughout the summer months, i [n May the hen carried a few fibres, but did not build properly, and the , wo birds may be said to have led entirely detached existences. There 1 ,vas none of the devotion seen in true Thrushes during the breeding I reason, when the cock collects and gives every dainty he can find to i :he hen. Thus, another breeding season passed with nothing achieved beyond U great deal of singing of a somewhat monotonous quality. The following autumn and winter were spent in the same aviary, ( which has a good shelter but no heat. f In the early spring of this year there was some bickering between the two birds, which by degrees became so serious that I had to put

the cock into an adjoining aviary whence he could see his wife b could not molest her. During the middle of March I replaced him with the hen, and a sta of armed neutrality was established and maintained. The male beg; his little song in April, and this was continued from dawn till dai throughout May, June, and July, until the hen began to sit, when 1 became completely silent. On 13th July my man informed me that the hen Hermit Thrus had built and laid one egg. I did not look into the nest, which ws placed high up m a small open box about 4 inches square, but I was nc at all happy to see her carrying fine grass and coconut fibre after sh had begun to lay. This was something abnormal and irregular, an boded ill for the future. On the following day I looked into the nest an found a very neat structure, cup-shaped, and lined with very fin grasses and fibres. It contained one small egg, which I just glanced a and did not touch. For a couple of days building went on, and then tb hen spent most of the day on the nest. I took the opportunity of he being off to look into the nest again. I found one beautiful elongate! ' Starling-blue " unspotted egg, and the other which I had previoush seen. The latter I removed and examined. The hen's behaviour wa: then explained. She had taken possession of and relined the nest of a Siberian Bullfinch, which had built and laid one egg without iot knowledge. Another egg was laid on the following day, and this completed the clutch. During the time of laying and the early part of incubation was the only time when an onlooker would have suspected any association between the male and female. The former was usually dancing attendance on his spouse, and was frequently seen to give her gentle but friendly pecks, quite unlike his behaviour in the early part of the year. Incubation began in earnest on 17th July, and lasted until the 29th. During these twelve days the hen was only seen off the nest for a few minutes on two or three occasions, and as far as I know was never relieved or fed by the male. There was nothing distinctive about the two squabs during their early days. The first two days they were constantly brooded by the

; a, after which both parents took their share in the duties of ding. During the first few days ants' eggs only were used, and meal- .rms entirely disregarded, I suppose, on account of their size. At the e of six days, mealworms, a few small earthworms, and quantities of 11-scoured gentles were used, and all seemed to be going well from lat one could see from below, but on 7th August I found one of the icks in a fairly " high " state of decomposition, on the ground, 6 feet nn the nest. It was well feathered and looked much like a miniature ng Thrush of about ten days of age. My chances of rearing this Species, already slender, were now halved, d I have to thank the male parent for any success which I may have record, for from this day onwards the hen seemed to lose all interest her family, and the whole duty of feeding devolved on the male, lose time was fully occupied in collecting live food for the remaining ick and chasing the hen away from the much coveted contents of the j r e-bait pan. On 11th August the young Hermit Thrush had left the nest. He was st thirteen days old, but looked as if he would have been the 1 tter for another two or three days in the nest. I Compared with his parents, he was very dark in colour ; the back, ngs, tail, and head were a dark lead-grey instead of the bright tmamon-brown of the adult. The upper breast was a similar colour. iis, the crown of the head, and mantle were flecked with numerous ! ots of light buff. The lower breast and abdomen were a dirty white, th no markings of any kind. The weather about this time was so atrocious that I expected each t iy to find him drowned, but although he persisted in staying m the itside flight, notwithstanding the fact that I often drove him into the elter, he seemed to have the sense to find spots on the ground where he i as more or less sheltered from the rain, and there he was constantly ! ssed over and cared for by his father, who, like most parent birds, |ways Seemed to know the exact whereabouts of his offspring, though frequently hunted around and could not find him. It is interesting * note that the male began his little song again on the very day the lick left the nest.
