Gocldarcl--Breeding the Blue-rumped Parrotlet On 16th August the young bird could pick up food and could j quite strongly, though he still spent most of his time Squatting und bushes or other plants. A day or two later I found the young bird in extremis, and on pickii him up discovered that he had attempted to swallow a dead bloom the day lily {Hemerocallis ). This flower was about 4 inches long and tl thickness of a lead pencil, and he had very nearly gorged the whol I was able to extract it, and a few moments later he seemed none tl worse. On 13th September the youngster was as large as his parents ai almost indistinguishable from them, but his general colour was st a little darker than either of the adults and he still showed the bn spots on the crown of his head and the upper mantle. I believe and hope that it is the first occasion on which this speci has been bred in captivity, for I feel sure that had they not unfortunate had to change hands, Mr. Astley, who was a past-master at breeding tl genus Turdidne, would have succeeded sooner or later in doing wh< has taken me two years to achieve.

By Mrs. G. K. Goddard About eighteen months ago I purchased from Mr. Hedges a pa of Blue-rumped Parrotlets, Psittacula cyanopygia. These I turned ini a large outdoor flight, with some Nyasa and Black-cheeked Lovebird In the centre of the flight I have a small house in which I put their foe and water, but the nest-boxes hung around the sides and at the ends < the flight, the only protection being some felt on the outside of the wi: to keep the rain off. For months the boxes were only used by tl Nyasas and Black-cheeks, the pair of Blue-rumps roosting in the hous One day, about the middle of August this year, I missed the little he: so watched closely for several days, when suddenly I saw her emeq from one of the boxes. On looking inside I found three eggs. The ne: was made with a few pieces of dry grasses and old millet sprays, and i the centre were many green feathers, plucked from her breast. 0

( Recently so much has been written by members on the Nyasa , ivebird that it is almost impossible to throw fresh light on the habits this interesting species. The excitement caused by the first arrivals, e rapidity with which they settled down and commenced breeding >erations, and the subsequent " first " success of Captain Stokes, j e all still fresh in the memories of lovers of the Agapornes. Mr. Seth-Smith gives a very complete account of this species in ie Avicultural Magazine, 1926, pp. 53-4. Agapornis fischeri i Little seems to have been recorded concerning this rather sombre floured Lovebird, figured somewhat indifferently in the Avicultural Magazine, July, 1926. Until last month only one living example had ever reached England, ad that only stayed a few days before continuing its journey to i merica. Now, thanks to the enterprise of our member, Mr. Chapman, i iveral consignments have arrived. It is to be hoped that those lembers who obtain specimens will not fail to make known their bservations. Pres tide h--L ovebirds Concerning this species, Dr. Emin Pasha, C.M.Z.S., who w; assassinated in the Upper Congo in the autumn of 1892, writes " Agapornis ftscheri is a noticeable bird of this country (Ussongc One seldom traverses the woods here without a pair or a small pari of three or four individuals being met with, which utter delicate scream not so piercing as those of Agapornis pullaria, as they fly high up wil a whirring noise, and in a straight course. These Parrots also frequei the ground a good deal. In the crops of shot birds I have found hi grass seeds, which must have been picked Up from the ground, { there was no upstanding grass anywhere about." ( J.F.O. , 189 pp. 338-9.) Agapornis personata The Masked or Yellow-breasted Lovebird is undoubtedly one < the most beautiful members of a very attractive genus. First discovere by Dr. Fischer at Kibaya in Masailand and described by Dr. Reichenor in J.F.O. , 1887, p. 55. Until recently extremely rare, only thre specimens having reached England, en route to America, in 1925 ; it now quite plentiful and is proving an excellent aviary bird. It remair to be seen how it will stand the winter outdoors, but there is no reaso to suppose it will prove less hardy than A. nigrigenis. The sexes would appear identical in plumage; the shape of the heac however, is a sure guide in sexing. They are quite friendly dispose to one another in an aviary, but some Seem very quarrelsome in confined space. Mr. K. \ . Painter, of Cleveland, Ohio, was successful in breedin from the three birds already mentioned. According to our Editor 1 Parrakeets , p. 281, Mr. Painter writes that his three birds were pu in a large flying cage of which the inside part was about 14 fee square and 10 feet high, with an outside flight of about the same size He had no idea of any young ones coming until they suddenly appearei irom the breeding boxes; '' full grown and almost in mature plumage their plumage is so like that of their parents that they are hardh distinguishable excepting that the colours are a little fainter." Con cerning the birds of East Africa, Mr. Loveridge ( P.Z.S. , 1922, p. 854 writes : " Parties of this handsome little Lovebird ( Agaporni personatus ) flew about with great rapidity, screaming noisily ; the}

>i -e first met with at Kongwa. They were nesting in the holes of a ibab-tree, whose apertures they had apparently closed with a i ence of thorns. Two eggs were found at the foot of the tree, side side, and measured f X J in. How they came to be there I cannot *, for they contained embryos nearly ready for hatching." Oscar iimann ( J.F.O ., 1899, pp. 63-4) writes : " I observed this brown- ,ded dwarf Parrot in flocks from ten to twenty strong in the sacred ii ,cia groves of North Ugogo, also in Usandawes, Irangi, and at the : them point of the Manjava Lakes. Its area of distribution appears be very limited."

The return of the Bittern to Norfolk is one of the most satisfactory ults of the efforts that have been made in recent years to protect our 1 -e birds. Some few years ago the Bittern was no more than a casual itor to this country on its migration. Many years before this it had id regularly in Norfolk, and elsewhere where conditions were suitable, t persecution from collectors and so-called sportsmen had driven it ay, and it Seemed unlikely that it would ever again return as a : ceding species. But now it has come back, thanks to the protection it has been afforded it, and for several years past its " boom " has sn heard throughout the Broads district, and it has nested freely and ired its young unmolested. ! And it is the ardent desire of all bird-lovers that the case of the I ttern may not be a solitary instance of a species returning to its 'mer haunts, and, with an increased love of birds and an abhorrence the insane desire to kill every rare arrival, other former breeding ecieS such as the Avocet, the Ruff, the Black Tern, and the Spoonbill ty realize that here they will find a sanctuary and be our honoured

If they are to be se in their breeding haunts now, one must follow Mr. Bentley Beetha who has spent many days amongst them in their haunts in Holla and Spain, and who, in a most fascinating volume describes a illustrates their life history. The author writes in a vivid and charming style, and all his chaptt are delightful, but perhaps the most interesting of all is that devoted an account of the Spanish Marismas, vast areas of low-lying grou at or near the estuaries of rivers that at times are swamped, except f tiny scraps of land raising their surfaces above the water, which the sun increases in power, and the water evaporates, grow larger a form ideal breeding places for many birds such as the Whiskered Tei the Egret, the Avocet, the Stilt, and the Pratincole. Amongst all of these, Mr. Bentley Beetham has wandered ai waded, and his observations, so well described in his book, will gi great pleasure to all who read it.

The Island of Bute in the Firth of Clyde is about 16 miles length, with an average breadth of 4 miles. It is of a very irregul shape, two-thirds being arable land and the remainder mostly und heather. There are two large lochs, and the ground rises in parts over 600 feet, and parts are well wooded. With such a variety of country a varied and numerous avifauna w to be expected, and Mr. McWilliam is able to give accounts of no le than 168 species as occurring on the island. The Lapwing is coram< at all Seasons, and is extremely conspicuous in the fields and on tl moors in spring. The Curlew is also extremely common. The Skyla and the Song Thrush and the Waterhen are easily found. The Gann is to be seen diving almost every day between April and Septembe Gulls old and young are present almost everywhere at all seasoE " In fact," writes the author, " from the diversity of the country, the are few places of the same size where a naturalist would be certain 1 finding so many of the finer British birds as on Bute."

algorithms.bodyText: Sir, --The following note may be of interest and help to anyone who the happy possessor of a pair of Blue Robins, but who has failed induce them to nest. Last winter a pair of these truly delightful birds arrived here ; d were most carefully tended ; in fact, they were perhaps pampered, afraid was I of losing one or other before the breeding season. At [ 3 end of March the birds were placed in a nice aviary with only a ,v Parrot Finches and some Chinese Quail as companions. During the whole of April and May every insect was pounced on ' the male and given to the female, who seemed to have a never- ; ding appetite for such dainties ; at the same time never a straw was j] rried, though I had provided some four or five most attractive boxes all types in the shelter of the aviary. I began to feel despondent, 3re especially So on 28th May, when I visited Mr. Ezra and found at his birds were rearing their second brood. I looked around for a use ; his birds were certainly not so fine a pair as mine--the aviary i smaller, and there was less choice of nest-boxes; in fact, the one e birds had used was hung in the open on a post--" A silly place for k e birds to choose,thought I. On the following day, as my birds were still doing nothing, I took a idgerigar nesting-box and hung it on a nail which happened to be j eking out of one of the posts forming the outer flight of the aviary, 1 me 6 feet from the ground. What was my amazement to see both rds instantly dive into the box through the entrance hole. The time is 1.15 p.m., at 2 o'clock I looked in the box and found an almost mpleted nest. By 9th June the hen had laid her clutch of four eggs, 3m which she reared three young. Contrary to Captain Waud, I find i ese birds very easy to satisfy. Mine must have consumed several j nts of gentles when rearing their young. The season was now too far advanced to expect a second nest, but im still wondering whether any attempt at nesting would ever have >en made had I not put that nest box outside. Maurice Amsler.

algorithms.bodyText: Sir, --My Sula Island King, mated to a Crimson-win; hatched two young ones with her third nest; one died when a few da\ old, I think because the first brood worried her and prevented hq from feeding properly, she being too good a mother to send thei about their business. The second left the nest on 4th October, and is fine bird, rather differently coloured from the three older ones, re covering more than half the breast, while there is a tinge of the sam colour on the throat. About ten days before the young bird fie 1 the indefatigable King laid a fourth time in the same log, feeding he offspring and sitting on the eggs at the same time. In the former tas she was helped by the Crimson-wing, although the latter has been Ion in moult. Tavistock.

Sir,-- A young Crimson-wing I bred this last summer recent! gave an almost uncanny display of intelligence and adaptability; When he could feed himself, I moved him from his mother's aviary t that occupied at night by the liberty birds, it being my intention t- train him to fly at liberty. The liberty bird aviary is one of a row o about twenty exactly similar aviaries, and is a hundred yards from th Crimson-wung's habitation. The only means of exit in the morning i through a small door about a foot square, low down in the front of th' flight, an opening not usually discovered by birds until they hav been in the aviary many days or even weeks. In the afternoon ai inward-pointing funnel of wire-netting is put in the little door to trap for the night, the birds which enter to feed. Only one Parrakeet, ai adult cock Crimson-wing, has ever learned to find his way out througl the end of the iirward-pointing funnel, and it took him many month: to do so, and he was never able to negotiate a funnel as long as tkos<! at present in use. The young bird did not seem disturbed by his change of quarters and was not observed to be making any effort to find a way out, bui that Same afternoon, with the funnels in, he made his escape ancj joined his father on the top of the aviary where he was born. Next

algorithms.bodyText: ruing I found him feeding inside the box used for birds at liberty, ich are not shut up at night. It has a dark interior, and the food is visible from the entrance, and only birds trained by gradual stages *r use it. Of course, in this case he had his father's example to ow, but even so he learned the use of the thing in an uncommonly "rt time. As he had soon found his parents, and an outside supply of d, I concluded that he would enter the other aviary no more, but hin a couple of hours he had left the old birds and was back inside and has never offered to leave it since !

algorithms.bodyText: The bird was a Bauer's Parrakeet (Barnardius zonarius), not a rticularly fine specimen, but was a wonderful whistler, whistling one two tunes in a very sweet mellow tone, in fact, it was the sweetest istler of any bird I have ever heard. The bird was sold to the late Mr. Frank BoStock, a brother of . E. H. Bostock, and many thought at the time that the sale of this d might be an advertising stunt, but of course there could be no proof this. I am afraid the name " Gin Gin '' was a coined one. And. Wilson.

Sm,--Being somewhat short of room, I recently turned a Fischer's vebird that had been ill into a large aviary containing Siskins and ntings. Within a very few days and before its evil disposition had m observed it had succeeded in killing one of each. This may act a warning to anyone who may be disposed to try this new Lovebird mixed company. I believe Black-cheeks and Nyasas have the mtation of being fairly amiable. Tavistock.
algorithms.sectionHeader: Correspondence GREEN INDIAN CORN AS FOOD FOR BIRDS
algorithms.bodyText: Sir, --It may interest some readers to hear that I have found i green cobs of Indian corn (maize) a very useful food in my avh this Summer, Budgerigars, Parrakeets, and Finches all seem very ft of it and prefer it to lettuce, seeding grass, or unripe millet sprays. The best time to use this corn is just before the grain is fr developed, but no longer milky It is of course necessary to strip off the outer leaves and the si tassel, So that the birds can get at the grain easily. The silky tassel when dried is an excellent material for nest linin This note is chiefly intended for overseas members, but I th maize could be grown quite well in the south of England if the se< were Started early in the year under glass and planted out after * danger of frost was passed. Sweet corn, such as is grown for table use, is even more read eaten than the common yellow variety. PI. C. Eustace. Shanghai.

Sir, --Having just received the Magazine for September, and ri Lord Tavistock's letter regarding the Cock Derbyan in his aviar I am sending you this note in case it may be of general interest. The Derbyan Parrakeet reaches Shanghai under normal conditi from Chungking in Szechuan Province, West China, and from the ti it is caught is fastened by a chain around one leg to its perch ; whi in transit this perch is usually a bamboo Supported on a framewo and several birds are attached to the same perch ; it is never cag In Shanghai the birds are sold on iron frames about fourteen inc long, but as this perch has two moulded brass caps attached, one either end, the bird's movements are restricted to about ten inc of perch, and if they are sold to the Chinese they remain fastened this manner for life. The Chinese feed this bird on paddy rice, sometimes adding a lit
algorithms.figure: Correspondence
algorithms.bodyText: ip seed, and whilst agreeing with Lord Tavistock that the bird would hardy under the conditions in which birds are kept at home, yet it lid appear that they soon die in Chinese hands. It has been quite impossible to obtain this species in Shanghai he lower Yangtze River ports this year, as no birds came down from ;chuan last year owing to the civil war on the upper river, and as dealers were unable to produce birds when quite large sums were ired one must assume that those brought down the preceding year re dead. Having twice met with no success in obtaining birds direct from *chuan I hope the third attempt will meet with results and that in er issues of the Magazine we may read of " The Breeding of the rbyan Pararkeet " and that members will be able to see a pair of ;se birds in the London Zoological Society's Gardens before next .*ing. H. C. Eustace. jiianghai.

Sir, -- I read Mr. Nicholson's letter on the breeding habits of the >sy- or Peach-faced Lovebird ( Agapornis roseicollis ) with great fcerest. In my experience of the breeding of this bird the eggs are always rnbated by the hen bird alone, the cock entering the nest solely for e purpose of feeding the hen. L. Christie-Miller. Sir, --With regard to Mr. Nicholson's letter in the October issue, sing that you invite the experiences of other members who have bred 'japornis roseicollis. I have bred a good many of these birds, and have vays found that the hen undertakes most of the business of incuba- )n. It is true that the cock spends a fair amount of his time in the :st with the hen, but that would appear to be the case with most the genus Agapornis . In the case of the Rosy-faces I have bred the ck seems to spend even more time in the nest when once the young
algorithms.figure: Correspondence
algorithms.bodyText: are hatched, though the overcrowding with say five young and the tv parents in one nest must be appalling. I have a late brood of half-fledged young in the nest at the tir of writing (24th October), and it is seldom that either of the pareD leave the nest-box. Incidentally I have found the best nesting material for them to branches of lime, from which they readily strip the bark. I wou suggest that it is just possible that Mr. Nicholson mistook the sexes his birds, as I recently possessed an abnormal pair of which the hen w not only the larger, which is not usual, but much the more bright coloured bird of the two.
algorithms.author: Edward J. Boosey.I
algorithms.bodyText: Sir, --I am now able to record the successful breeding of the Mask Lovebird (Agapornis personata). A single youngster, the only surviy of four, flew from the nest on 29th October. The bird was as large the parents, and was readily distinguishable by the greyish tint of t yellow collar and the less intense black of the head. The nest was continually added to, so that the young were gradual elevated in the box until almost pressed against the roof. In this t practice of the Masked Lovebird conformed to that of the Black-che and the Nyasa. The young bird did not remain in the nest above a month. M. V. Allen. [Lord Tavistock has also been successful in breeding Agaporn per sonata, but his article is unavoidably held over until next montj In reply to our inquiry as to the date of leaving the nest, he writes, * 4th November, " My Masked Lovebirds must have left the nest aboi a fortnight ago."--E d.]

algorithms.bodyText: PRINTERS, HERTFORD.

NOTICE .--Members are particularly requested to inform the Hon. Secretary of any error in the spelling of their names, addresses, or descriptions, so that it may be corrected. The date following the Member's name is the date of his election. " Orig. Mem." signifies that the Member joined the Society on its formation in October, 1894. The asterisk denotes that the Member pays the subscription through a bank. Members are requested to adopt this method of payment if convenient.

algorithms.bodyText: Hales of the Avicultural Society

Rules of the Avicultural Society As amended, December, 1024 1---The name of the Society shall be The Avicultural Society, and its object shall be the study of Foreign and British Birds in freedom and in captivity. Poults, Pigeons, and Canaries shall be outside the scope of the Society. The year of the Society, with that of each volume of the Society's Magazine, which shall be known as The Avicultural Magazine, shall commence with the month of January and end on the 31st of December following.
algorithms.listItem: 2. --The Avicultural Society shall consist of Ordinary and Honorary Members, and the latter shall be restricted in number to six, and be elected by the Council. 3. The Officers of the Society shall be elected, annually if necessary, by members of the Council in the manner hereinafter provided, and shall consist of a President, one or more Vice-Presidents, a Secretary, an Editor, a Treasurer, an Auditor, a Scrutineer, and a Council of eighteen members. The Secretary, Editor, and Treasurer shall be ex officio Members of the Council. 4. --New Members shall be proposed in writing, and the name and address of
algorithms.bodyText: every person thus proposed, with the name of the Member proposing him, shall be published in the next issue of the Magazine. Unless the candidate shall, within two weeks after the publication of his name in the Magazine, be objected to by at least two Members, he shall be deemed to be duly elected. If five members shall lodge with the Secretary objections to any candidate he shall not be elected, but the signatures to the signed objections must be verified by the Scrutineer. If two or more Members (but less than five) shall object to any candidate, the Secretary shall announce in the next number of the Magazine that such objections have been lodged (but shall not disclose the names of the objectors), and shall request the Members to vote upon the question of the election of such candidate. Members shall record their votes in sealed letters addressed to the Scrutineer, and a candidate shall not be elected unless two-thirds of the votes recorded be in his favour ; nor shall a candidate be elected if five or more votes be recorded against his election. 5. --Each Member shall pay an annual subscription of #1, to be due and payable in advance on the 1st of January in each year. New Members shall pay, in addition, an entrance fee of 10s. Gd. ; and, on payment of their entrance fee and subscription, they shall be entitled to receive all the numbers of the Society's Magazine for the current year.
algorithms.footnote: Bides of the Avicultural Society 6. --Members intending to resign their membership at the end of the current year of the Society are expected to give notice to the Secretary before the 1st of December, so that their names may not be included in the " List of Members ", which shall be published annually in the January number of the Magazine. 7. --The Magazine of the Society shall be issued on or about the first day of
algorithms.bodyText: every month, and forwarded, post free, to all the Members who shall have paid their subscriptions for the year ; but no Magazine shall be sent or delivered to any Member until the annual subscription shall have reached the hands of the Business l Secretary or the Publishers. Members whose subscriptions shall not have been | paid as above by the first day in November in any year shall cease to be Members ; of the Society, and shall not be re-admitted until a fresh entrance fee, as well as | the annual subscription, shall have been paid. 8. --The Secretary, Editor, and Treasurer shall be elected for a term of five years, and, should a vacancy occur, it may be temporarily filled up by the j Executive Committee (see Rule 10). At the expiration of the term of five years in i every case it shall be competent for the Council to nominate the same officer, or : another Member, for a further time of five years, unless a second candidate be ! proposed by not less than twenty-five Members of at least two years' standing, as set forth below. In the November number of the Magazine preceding the retirement from j office of the Secretary, Editor, or Treasurer, the Council shall publish the names ! of those members whom they have nominated to fill the vacancies thus created ; j and these members shall be deemed duly elected unless another candidate or i candidates be proposed by not less than fifteen Members of at least two years' [ standing. Such proposal, duly seconded and containing the written consent of the nominee to serve, if elected, in the capacity for which he is proposed, must reach I the Secretary on or before the 15th of November. The Council shall also publish yearly in the November number of the [ Magazine the names of those members nominated by them for the posts of Auditor and Scrutineer respectively.
algorithms.sectionHeader: 9. --The Members of the Council shall retire by rotation, two at the end of '
algorithms.bodyText: each year of the Society (unless a vacancy or vacancies shall occur otherwise) and | two other Members of the Society shall be recommended by the Council to take | the place of those retiring. The names of the two Members recommended shall j be printed in the November number of The Avicultural Magazine. Should the i Council's selection be objected to by fifteen or more Members, these shall have i power to put forward two other candidates, whose names, together with the j signatures of no less than fifteen Members proposing them, must reach the Hon. Secretary by the 15th of November. The names of the four candidates will then be printed on a voting paper and sent to each Member with the December number of the Magazine, and the result of the voting published in the January

Bides of the Avicultural Society issue. Should no alternative candidates be put forward, in the manner and by the date above specified, the two candidates recommended by the Council shall be deemed to have been duly elected. In the event of an equality of votes the President shall have a casting vote. If any Member of the Council does not attend a meeting for two years in succession the Council shall have power to elect another member in his place. Immediately after the election of the Council that body shall proceed to elect three from its Members (ex officio Members not being eligible). These three, together with the Secretary, Treasurer, and Editor, shall form a Committee known as the Executive Committee. Members of the Council shall be asked every year (whether there has been an election of that body or not) if they wish to stand for the Executive, and in any year w r hen the number of candidates exceeds three there shall be an election of the Executive. The duties of the Executive Committee shall be as follows :--
algorithms.listItem: (i) To sanction all payments to be made on behalf of the Society. (ii) In the event of the resignation of any of the officers during the Society's year, to fill temporarily the vacancy until the end of the year. In the case of the office being one which is held for more than one year (e.g. Secretary, Editor, or { Treasurer) the appointment shall be confirmed by the Council at its next meeting. (iii) To act for the Council in the decision of any other matter that may arise in connexion with the business of the Society.
algorithms.bodyText: The decision of any matter by the Executive to be settled by a simple majority (five to form a quorum). In the event of a tie on any question, such question shall be forthwith submitted by letter to the Council for their decision. The Executive shall not have power

office. It shall not be lawdul for the Treasurer to pay any account unless such account be duly initialled by the Executive. It shall be lawful for the Secretary or Editor to pledge the Society's credit f for a sum not exceeding #15. Should a Member wish any matter to be brought before the Council direct such matter should be sent to the Secretary with a letter stating that it is to be brought before the Council at their next meeting, otherwise communications will in the first place be brought before the Executive. A decision of a majority of the Council, or a majority of the Executive endorsed by the Council, shall be final and conclusive in all matters. 11.--The Editor shall have an absolute discretion as to what matter shall be published in the Magazine (subject to the control of the Executive Committee). l The Secretary and Editor shall respectively refer all matters of doubt and difficulty to the Executive Committee.
algorithms.listItem: 12. --The Council (but not a committee of the Council) shall have power to alter and add to the Rules, from time to time, in any manner they may think fit. Rive to form a quorum at any meeting of the Council. 13. --The Council shall have power to expel any Member from the Society at any time without assigning any reason. 14 . --Neither the office of Scrutineer nor that of Auditor shall be held for two consecutive years by the same person. 15. --The Scrutineer shall not reveal to any person how any Member shall have voted.
algorithms.bodyText: The Medal may be awarded at the discretion of the Committee to any Member who shall succeed in breeding, in the United Kingdom, any species of bird which shall not be known to have been previously bred in captivity in Great Britain or Ireland. Any Member wishing to obtain the Medal must send a detailed account for publication in the Magazine within about eight weeks from the date of hatching of the young, and furnish such evidence of the facts as the Executive Committee may require. The Medal will be awarded only in cases where the young shall live to be old enough to feed themselves, and to be wholly independent of their parents. The account of the breeding must be reasonably full so as to afford instruction to our Members, and must appear in the Avicultural Magazine before it is published or notified elsewhere. It should describe the plumage of the young, and be of value as a permanent record of the nesting and general habits of the species. These points will have great weight when the question of awarding the Medal is under consideration. In every case the decision of the Committee shall be final. The Medal will be forwarded to each Member as soon after it shall have been awarded as possible. The Medal is struck in bronze (but the Committee reserve the right to issue it in silver in very special cases) and measures 2b inches in diameter. It bears on the obverse a representation of two birds with a nest containing eggs, and the words " The Avicultural Society--founded 1894 ". On the reverse is the following inscription : " Awarded to [name of recipient ] for rearing the young of [name of species'], a species not previously bred in captivity in the United Kingdom." The Council may grant a special medal to any member who shall succeed in breeding any species of bird that has not previously been bred in captivity in Europe.
